item.title: Course Outline
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Play the audio below and you'll hear the course outline lecture:
[audio m4a="http://digitalcultureslab.ca/hybrid1102/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/1102-course_outline_lecture.m4a"][/audio]
English 1102.001 (Hybrid Delivery) - Reading Literature and Culture – Douglas College - New Westminster Campus In-Class Meetings: NWS2680 / Wednesdays - 8:30 - 10:20pm Dr. David N. Wright / Email Address Office Hours: W: 10:30-11:30 / Office: NWS: 3625 Phone: 5818 (I rarely check this. Email me instead) In this course, we will examine artistic (primarily literary) representations of digital culture. We'll look at texts that represent coders, hackers, and computers, analyzing how those texts reflect or interpret our digital world. In particular, we'll account for representations that suggest interpretations of digital culture that reflect themes such as fear, the apocalyptic, runaway patriarchy, and unbridled optimism. In short, the course will offer an opportunity to see how artistic production represents the structures of our digital lives. As we work to understand representations of digital culture, we'll pay attention to how digital culture reflects social attitudes, cultural practices, and political movements. The aim is to understand how the devices of literary interpretation--character, setting, theme, narrative--can help us dissect the underlying currents of an emerging digital environment. The course will be delivered in a hybrid format, meeting once a week and the remainder of the work conducted through on-line resources and this website. The weekly classroom meetings will be conducted as if they were taking place in a lab setting. The classroom is a place for collaboration, implementation, experimentation, execution, and interrogation. It is imperative that you come to class ready to work, having the assigned homework completed and the readings done ahead of time. I will often send announcements through BlackBoard notifying you of new posts, comment threads, and generally reminding you that the course exists. If you do not use BlackBoard, it is your responsibility to keep up-to-date with what’s happening on the website and come to class having done all the required work. If you are not using the Google Chrome browser on your home computer / laptop, please download it for this course. Chrome is a web browser that plays nice with things. You do not need to get / have a google account to download Chrome and you do not need to install it as your “default” browser. You just need it on the machine so I don’t have to remake all the videos. You are welcome to attempt to complete the course on a mobile device. However, there will be occasions when you will need access to the power of a desktop and I make no promises about the mobile compatibility of all the lab exercises. Make sure you can successfully devote 2-3 hours a week to being online with high-speed internet access, either on a desktop, laptop, tablet, or phone. Please take note of the features and requirements of this course. To complete the requirements for this course, you will need access to a computer with internet on a regular basis. The day that we are not in class should not be considered a day off, but should instead be spent reading, researching, and writing. I will expect that when we meet, you will have a great deal to add to our discussions of the texts. If you are not a self-motivated student, you may want to consider whether a hybrid class is the right choice for you because this type of course can sometimes be difficult for those who aren’t prepared to take on the responsibility for learning the material on their own time. You will be expected to do a good deal of learning on your own. I will guide you, but often, you will be required to find your own way and report your findings. Required Texts (in order to appearance):
  • All the course readings and other texts that appear on this website
  • Sloan, Robin. Mr. Penumbra's 24-Hour Bookstore ISBN: 978-1443415798
  • Ullman, Ellen. The Bug: A Novel ISBN: 978-1250002495
  • Coupland, Douglas. JPod ISBN: 978-0679314257
  • Cline, Ernest. Ready Player One: A Novel ISBN: 978-0307887443
  • Beukes, Lauren. Moxyland ISBN: 978-0857663818
** A note about the class readings: This course makes extensive use of secondary information that is freely available on the Internet. Links to required readings and other materials will be posted to this website. Please make every effort to do the readings for the class before the class meetings and bring a copy, or a way of reading the novels and/or texts due for the class meetings (paper, tablet, phone, etc.). You will need access to the readings while you are in class. YOU MUST PURCHASE THE TEXTS ABOVE; these novels require a hard copy--paper, digital or otherwise. You can purchase all the books for this course at the Douglas College Bookstore or, using the ISBN numbers above, through another source, like Amazon. If you order a book for the course, please be aware that delivery timelines may not mesh with the course timelines. Make sure you have the book in time for the classes. Assignment Weights and Due Dates (Subject to Change):
  • 10% Multiple Choice Quizzes (Due Bi-Weekly, one on each class module)
  • 20% Lab Modules and Online Short-Essay Responses (Due Weekly)
  • 15% Mid-Term Essay / Unessay - Due Feb. 6, 2015
  • 15% Mid-Term Exam - Due Feb. 18, 2015
  • 20% Final Essay - April 8th (with comment) / April 15th (without comment)
  • 20% Final Exam - Distributed April 8th, Due April 13th, 2015, no later than 1pm -- LLPA Fieldbase
Course Policies:
  1. Emailed assignments are preferred. Emailed assignments should be submitted in a compatible format (I.e.: .doc/.pdf) on the day of the deadline to the Email address above. Please include your name in the filename (essay1_davidnwright.doc). I will acknowledge the receipt of your essay by Email within 24 hours. If you submit your essay via an Email address other than the one assigned by Douglas College upon your enrollment, please be advised that you may be subject to the terms and conditions of the United States Patriot Act.
  2. You are responsible for reading ALL the readings listed in the course schedule and available through the class website.
  3. Though not assessed, in-class attendance is required to complete aspects of this course.
  4. Late work will be accepted for 7 days after the due date. No late work will receive any written comments. Extensions beyond 7 days or extended absences should be accounted for in person and will require proper substantiating documentation (i.e.: a doctor's note).
  5. Essays and other class assignments cannot be rewritten under any circumstances. Proper MLA citation formatting is required for all essays and essays must be formatted according to MLA citation style. Correct citation, according to the rules of the MLA style guide, is mandatory for all essays. Failure to cite correctly will result in a marked essay with no marginal notes.
  6. Missed exams can be re-scheduled in person with the appropriate supporting documentation (I.e. Doctor’s note). Exams cannot be rescheduled for personal reasons, such as travel. Exams cannot be re-written.
  7. You are encouraged to participate fully in the classroom through the use of mobile devices, tablets, laptops, and otherwise. However, please make sure that all audible alerts from these devices are turned off.
  8. Though not explicitly stated above, draft writing is a required element for this course. Please be sure to make yourself aware of editing session dates and any penalties associated with missing them.
  9. Students who do not submit both essays and complete both exams (70% of the course work) will receive a final grade of UN (unofficial withdrawal) for the course, which will later become an F.
  10. Plagiarism--using the ideas or words of another--a published source, website, chat-room, forum thread, internet portal, social networking site, tutor, or friend--in your writing without proper acknowledgement--is a serious offence that will result in a minimum penalty of an F/0% for the assignment and may result in a note being placed in the student’s file, which could be grounds for expulsion. I will show no pity toward plagiarized papers. Ignorance is not an excuse.
  11. All Douglas College policies apply in this course; in particular, I draw your attention to the Academic Dishonesty policy and the User Conduct policy.
_____ Explanations: Essays: The course will require two take-home formal essays. In order to pass—a grade of P—the course, students must submit both essays. Topics for the essays will be distributed well in advance of the due date. Please submit your essays by Email attachment in a compatible .doc file (i.e.: pdf / rtf) format on the due date with your name in the file name (i.e.: essay1_wright.doc). Take-home essays should be typed, double-spaced, in Times New Roman 12pt font, with minimum 1 inch margins and be formatted in MLA style with a title, proper in-text citation and a work(s) cited page. For those of you unfamiliar with the requirements of an English course, please remember that good writing is imperative for a positive assessment. Essays should include a relevant thesis statement supported by exposition that is clear and logical. Errors in sentence structure, argumentative logic and grammar, spelling, etc., will affect your grade negatively. Take the time to proof-read your work for typos, formal problems and logic. Keep an extra copy of all essays (except those written in exam booklets). It is your responsibility to provide a copy of your essay—or other work—should it go missing. Exams: Exams will require a good knowledge of the texts discussed in class and a contextual knowledge of those not directly addressed in the classroom. Questions will be a mix of short answer and essay questions that ask the student to demonstrate an acquired and applied knowledge of the texts and concepts covered in class. In every instance, the emphasis is on the student’s ability to explain clearly and accurately, with a degree of originality, the major concepts of the course. Other Assignments: Explanations and expectations for the other assignments in the course will be included on the assignment sheet. Suffice to say, all the writing, comprehension, and critical thinking skills required for essays and exams will be needed to be successful in these other assignments. Ethics Statement: This course prioritizes the formal requirements of “academic writing” usually understood as proper citation, the logical development of persuasive claims, and a somewhat formal voice. You have an ethical responsibility to write at a level that reflects the absolute best of your abilities in the English language. Remember, your completed essay is a reflection of your effort. Your essays will be graded for the application of course content in the service of making a claim, grammar, vocabulary, argumentation, rhetorical style, organization, and for their attention to the rules of proper academic essay format. All of these components figure equally into your final grade. Peer Evaluators / Tutors: While having others respond to your work outside of class can be helpful, if someone else does more than point out errors and problems and discuss corrections in a general way (if a friend, family member, or an individual solicited on-line rewrites your sentences, adds words that are not your own, or provides you with a thesis or structure for your essay) you are not learning to improve your work. Having others write all or part of your essay or assignments is plagiarism and academic dishonesty. If you are working with a tutor on your essays, you should inform me of that fact and be prepared to submit, if requested, all notes and drafts of your home essays so that I can see what kind of help you have received. Failure to do so will result in an F/0% on the assignment in question. Statement of Responsibilities: My responsibilities for this course are to introduce a wide range of essay examples and academic writing styles, and to offer strategies for generating, organizing, and writing academic essays. If there is ever something you do not understand, please do not hesitate to raise questions during class. As well, feel free to come and see me during office hours or Email me if you want clarifications, suggestions, or general guidance. However, be prepared with something to talk about, or some general ideas about your problem(s). I will not develop, write, proofread, etc., your paper for you. I encourage you to take advantage of my office hours or Email with questions should you have any problems, but I will not teach the course directly to individuals who do not participate fully in the class. If you cannot make the scheduled office hours, feel free to inquire about making an appointment. Explanation of Grading Procedures: If you receive a grade you are unhappy with, or do not understand, you should make every effort to come and see me promptly. Do not let grades fester or take on undue gravity. I am more than willing to explain where you went wrong and give you plenty of pointers for improvement. If you do not attend to issues with your writing, you cannot expect to improve. I am never grading your work with an eye for cruelty. I am grading your work in order to show you where you stand amongst students who take—or have taken—an English literature course at Douglas College. As much as possible, try to manage your expectations where grades are concerned. The point of the course is to improve your writing. If your writing did not need improvement, or assessment in a college context, you would not be here. This course is difficult because it demands a level of writing that reflects college and university contexts, not the aptitude of your personal expression or comprehension. In this class, I am grading your writing and how you present the content of your essay. Course Learning Outcomes: Upon completion of any first-year English literature course, the successful student should be able to:
  • read receptively and reflectively, with sensitivity to the subtleties of language;
  • recognize and understand literary devices;
  • practice writing as a process involving pre-writing, drafting, revising and editing;
  • write an essay of literary criticism that develops an interpretive thesis supported by appropriate and correctly cited evidence; and
  • give and receive constructive criticism on written work.
Upon completion of English 1102, the successful student should also be able to
  • recognize and understand the elements of theme in literature;
  • understand and analyze the relationship of theme to other literary elements, such as plot, character, setting, figurative language and irony; and
  • recognize and appreciate connections between the theme(s) studied in the course and social issues.
  • recognize the characteristics of figurative language (such as imagery, metaphor and symbolism)
Please Note Course Prerequisites:
  • The minimum required score on the Douglas College English Assessment, written within the last four years, OR a final grade of "B" or higher in English 12, Literature 12 or English 12 First Peoples, OR proof of enrolment in a college-level writing or literature course, defined as a course that transfers to Douglas College as an English, Communications or Creative Writing course, OR
  • a grade of C- in EASL 0460, or a minimum grade of C- in both EASL 0465 and 0475, OR
  • a grade of C- or better in ENGU 0450 or ENGU 0455, OR
  • a Language Proficiency Index (LPI) score of 5 on both Essay Level and English Usage and a score of 10 on the Reading Comprehension section, OR
  • an IELTS score of 7 with a minimum score on all parts of 6.5 within the last two years, OR
  • a TOEFL (internet-based) overall score of 92 with a minimum of 22 in each of Listening, Speaking, Reading and Writing within the last two years

item.title: Course Schedule
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Play the audio below and you'll hear the course schedule / course procedures lecture:
[audio mp3="http://digitalcultureslab.ca/hybrid1102/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/1102-schedule_lecture.mp3"][/audio]
Note: Before plunging into the schedule each week, make sure you have read and understood the Course Procedures and are clear about what you are required to do each week. Week 1: Jan. 7 Topic: Setting and Context Text: Website ClassWork: Logging in to class website / Tagging Module / Website for completing the module (Due for Jan. 14 class). Homework Lab: Tagging Module (Due for Jan. 14 class) --- Week 2: Jan. 14 Topic: Setting and Context / Old Knowledge vs. New Knowledge Text: Mr. Penumbra’s 24-Hour Bookstore ClassWork: Tagging Module Homework Lab: Book Traces Assignment (Due for Jan. 21 class) --- Week 3: Jan. 21 Topic: Narrative / POV Text: Mr. Penumbra’s 24-Hour Bookstore ClassWork: Book Traces Module Homework Lab: View Source Module / Watch War Games (Due for Jan. 28 class) - You will need to rent / borrow (library) Essay #1: Questions Delivered --- Week 4: Jan. 28 Topic: Character Text: The Bug / War Games ClassWork: View Source Module Homework Lab: Essay Draft Submission and Review / War Games Module --- Week 5: Feb. 4 Topic: Authorship / Speaker Text: The Bug ClassWork: Essay Draft Review Homework Lab: No Lab: Essay Writing! --- Feb. 6 - Essay #1 Due: Midnight, by Email --- Feb. 11: (Reading Week: No Formal Classes) Topic: Poetry / Interpretation / Encryption Text: Code Poems, E. E. Cummings, Elizabeth Bishop, Agrippa: see modules below for links to texts ClassWork: None / No Classes Homework Lab: Encoding and Decoding Module Part I & Part II --- Week 8: Feb. 18: Mid-Term Exam (will take entire in-class time) Homework Lab: Four Perspectives Module --- Week 9: Feb. 25 Topic: Themes Text: Moxyland ClassWork: Four Perspectives Module Homework Lab: Differences Module --- Week 10: March 4 Topic: CyberPunk Text: Moxyland ClassWork: Differences Module Homework Lab: Photo Theme Module Part I & Part II --- Week 11: March 11 Topic: Games Text: Ready Player One ClassWork: Photo Theme Module Part II (Building Narratives) Homework Lab: Ready, Set, Play Module --- Week 12: March 18 Topic: Social Media Text: Ready Player One ClassWork: Gaming / Language, Audience, Author Homework Lab: Create Your Essay Profile Module --- Week 12: March 25 Topic: Hacker Work Text: JPod ClassWork: Create Your Essay Profile Module Homework Lab: JPod Casting Module --- Week 13: April 1 Topic: Techno-Industrialization Text: JPod ClassWork: JPod Casting Module Homework Lab: JPod Casting Module --- Week 14: April 8 / Take-Home Exam Pick Up: Attendance is Mandatory Topic: Take-Home Exam Pickup and Course Review Final Essay Due April 8 (returned with comment) --- Final Exam Due April 13, 2015 -- No later than 1pm in LLPA FieldBase (NW2600) Final Essay Due April 15, 2015 (no late penalty / returned without comment) --- No class materials will be accepted after April 15, 2015.

item.title: Course Procedures
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Note: There is an audio lecture for this course explanation if you go to the Course Schedule page first.
Because this is a hybrid course, there are some unique requirements. Hopefully, these requirements will be fun to complete and will illuminate the materials for the course. In order to be successful in the course, you will need to commit to, at the barest of minimums, trying. Classroom Meetings: As noted in the course outline, "face2face" classroom meetings will be conducted as if they were taking place in a lab setting. When you arrive at class, you should have completed the Homework Lab due for that day. The Homework Labs are designed to be discussed. They need to be attempted and followed through, but they need not be perfect. You need to be able to discuss the contributions you made to the Homework Lab and the outcomes you arrived at -- even if those outcomes are total failure. The point of the lab setting is to create a space where we can discuss limitations, successes, and failures. It is not a space to present perfect work -- leave that for essays. You should re-arrange the classroom desks so that you are sitting in groups of four or so (just push them together, removing the chairs that define the lecture-orientation). It should go without saying, but you need to have done the reading. All of it. Carefully. Before the class starts. You should arrive at class ready to play. If you are not prepared, I reserve the right to ask you to leave because you cannot possibly contribute to the class without having done any preparatory work. Work Away from Class Each week, along with the required reading, you will attempt to complete a lab exercise--or "module." I will introduce the module on the class website--usually the week before we talk about it--and your contribution will consist of a ~350-word "comment" discussing your experience(s) attempting to complete the module. Each ~350-word "comment" should address some or all of the following:
  • Reflect on the outcomes of the lab (what did it do for you? how did it help or hinder your understanding of the concepts under discussion for that week? Was it fun? Distracting?)
  • Make suggestions about how the lab relates to the text(s) or the concepts (i.e.: setting / character / a theme) under discussion for that week. (what does doing the lab tell us / fail to address / illuminate about the concepts under discussion in the class?)
  • Record your frustrations (with the platform, the lab itself, the concepts under discussion, or the reading of the text(s))
Remember: frustration is part of the process here. You should feel free to record your frustrations, successes, highlights, and lowlights. Everything is valid as long as it is thoughtful. You should absolutely avoid writing as if you are reaching for a grade. You are trying to be thoughtful and learn something, not "write for a C." Expectations for Work Away From Class I expect that you will be spending anywhere from 5-8 hours each week working on the materials for the course outside the face2face classroom setting, either through reading, the Homework Lab, or essay drafting (or all three). If you are doing less than that, you're not meeting the expectations for the class. Conduct Whether online or in the classroom, please make every effort to get in there and participate in the class discussions and activities. This class is for you; not me. You will ultimately get out of the class what you put into it. I'm not going to force you to play, but I'm also not going to richly reward sitting out and getting by with the minimum. Finally, please always be mindful of others and their experiences and their unkowns, be respectful, courteous, and positive always. We are trying to find a way forward.

item.title: Welcome - First Day!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Welcome to the virtual space for 1102.001: Reading Literature and Culture. Before we meet in person (or F2F, as the kids say) on Wednesday at the unseemly hour of 8:30am, there are a few things we should get out of the way. Below is a list of those things (the bolded titles are links to the pages - click on them!). Make sure you have gone through each item on the list before coming to class on Wednesday morning (really, really, really early in the day. Stupid early). Before we get to any of this, if you are using Internet Explorer (Microsoft) to view this website, there are some elements, such as audio and video, that will not display correctly. I strongly suggest using either Google Chrome or Firefox. In fact, if you don't have these browsers installed, please consider downloading and installing them before proceeding.
    The Course Outline / Syllabus
  • This is the formal agreement between you and me about the rules and requirements for the course. Make sure you come to class with any questions or areas you want me to address.
    The Course Procedures
  • This is an explanation of the course itself and how it will work. Again, take note of any areas you want me to address in person -- if you don't ask about it; I will not address it.
    The Course Schedule
  • This is where you will find the course calendar and schedule -- when stuff is due, what you need to read, what areas we'll be concentrating on, etc.
    The Course Website Screencast
  • This is a video showing you how to register with the class website and get yourself all up and running so that you can participate fully right from the start.
    The Mark-Up Module
  • This is the first week's module (you'll understand this "module" thing once you've looked at all sections above. Go ahead, be brave. Get started! (It's not due until the Jan. 14th class though)

item.title: Course Modules
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Each week, along with the required reading, you will attempt to complete a lab exercise--or "module." I will introduce the module on the class website--usually the week before we talk about it--and your contribution will consist of a ~350-word "comment" discussing your experience(s) attempting to complete the module. Each ~350-word "comment" should address some or all of the following:
  • Reflect on the outcomes of the lab (what did it do for you? how did it help or hinder your understanding of the concepts under discussion for that week? Was it fun? Distracting?)
  • Make suggestions about how the lab relates to the text(s) or the concepts (i.e.: setting / character / a theme) under discussion for that week. (what does doing the lab tell us / fail to address / illuminate about the concepts under discussion in the class?)
  • Record your frustrations (with the platform, the lab itself, the concepts under discussion, or the reading of the text(s))
Remember: frustration is part of the process here. You should feel free to record your frustrations, successes, highlights, and lowlights. Everything is valid as long as it is thoughtful. You should absolutely avoid writing as if you are reaching for a grade. You are trying to be thoughtful and learn something, not "write for a C." Grading Procedures for Modules Each module is graded using the criteria below as a guide; one point for fulfilling each criterium. Half marks will be deducted for repeated grammatical errors. (You can make a few mistakes, but the writing should be clear, correct, and understandable.) Modules are due before the class for which they are assigned - no late submissions allowed.
  • Worth /1> Depth of response - you are really engaged and reflective about the module's activity
  • Worth /1> Indication of relevance to the module's outcomes
  • Worth /1> Indication of connection to the text under discussion in class
  • Worth /1> Conversation and exchange with your peers - evidence of reading and responding to other comments in the module
  • Worth /1>Timeliness (done before Tuesday evening, for instance)
  • Total /5> Totals will be Emailed to you after every three modules and will include: 1) a grade out of 5 for each of the three most recent modules; 2) a running total of the total module grade for the course up to that point.
  • A missed module results in a grade of 0/5 - this includes missing the module because you did not have the password.
List of Modules
  • Week One: Markup Module (Due Jan. 14, 2015 - CLOSED)
  • Week Two: Book Traces Module (Due Jan. 21, 2015 - CLOSED)
  • Week Three: View Source Module (Due Jan. 28, 2015 - CLOSED)
  • Week Four: Essay Review Module (Due Feb. 4, 2015 - CLOSED)

item.title: Essay #1
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Engl. 1102.001: Reading Literature and Culture Douglas College Essay #1 (800-1000 words/ 3-4 pages) Draft Due: thesis sentence and one paragraph (about 1 page) Feb. 2, 2015 - 12pm (online submission / Homework Lab) Due: Feb. 6, 2015 - by Email Instructions: Using proper essay format and style answer one of the following questions. Higher assessments will result when the correct literary and analytical terminology is used to assert an argument that demonstrates knowledge applied in an original way. Please refer to the class syllabus (course outline) for general guidelines and format regulations. All late penalties outlined in the course syllabus apply and in no instance will late work will receive written comments. While it is not recommended, if you must use secondary sources please follow MLA citation method making sure it is both consistent and accurate. Plagiarism will not be tolerated. You must cite your primary source correctly. Email submissions only please; you will receive a confirmation Email within 24 hours. Please be sure to put your name in the file name (like this: wrightessay1.doc) when attaching the file to your Email.
  1. Discuss how setting influences how we understand OR contextualize one of the novels we have read so far.
  2. Using evidence from a novel we've read, discuss the nature of the narrator's relationship with his/her subject.
  3. Linking your discussion to one of the novels we have read so far, what assumptions about male OR female behaviour affect how we read male OR female characters and assess their actions?

OR:

The Unessay (indebted to Daniel Paul O'Donnell who came up with it and who I steal from liberally and completely here. The ideas and words below are his) Note: If you choose to do an unessay (awesome!), please let me know. The above due date holds, but there is flexibility about what you bring to the drafting exercise. The essay is a wonderful and flexible tool for engaging with a topic intellectually. It is a very free format that can be turned to discuss any topic--works of literature, of course, but also autobiography, science, entertainment, history, and government, politics, and so on. There is often something provisional about the essay (its name comes from French essai, meaning a trial), and almost always something personal. The Unessay allows you to:
  • Choose your own topic
  • Present it any way you please
  • Be evaluated on how compelling and effective you are
  • Why unessays are not a waste of your time
Unfortunately, however, as the Wikipedia notes,
In some countries (e.g., the United States and Canada), essays have become a major part of formal education. Secondary students are taught structured essay formats to improve their writing skills, and admission essays are often used by universities in selecting applicants and, in the humanities and social sciences, as a way of assessing the performance of students during final exams.
One result of this is that the essay form, which should be extremely free and flexible, is instead often presented as a static and rule-bound monster that students must master in order not to lose marks (for a vigorous defence of the flexible essay, see software developer Paul Graham’s blog). Far from an opportunity to explore intellectual passions and interests in a personal style, the essay is transformed into a formulaic method for discussing set topics in five paragraphs: the compulsory figures of academia.

The Unessay

The unessay is an assignment that attempts to undo the damage done by this approach to teaching writing. It works by throwing out all the rules you have learned about essay writing in the course of your primary, secondary, and post secondary education and asks you to focus instead solely on your intellectual interests and passions. In an unessay you choose your own topic, present it any way you please, and are evaluated on how compelling and effective you are.

Choose your own topic

The unessay allows you to write about anything you want provided you are able to associate your topic with the subject matter of the course and unit we are working on. You can take any approach; you can use as few or as many resources as you wish; you can cite the Wikipedia. The only requirements are that your treatment of the topic be compelling: that is to say presented in a way that leaves the reader thinking that you are being accurate, interesting, and as complete and/or convincing as your subject allows.

Present it any way you please

There are also no formal requirements. Your essay can be written in five paragraphs, or three, or twenty-six. If you decide you need to cite something, you can do that anyway you want. If you want to use lists, use lists. If you want to write in the first person, write in the first person. If you prefer to present the whole thing as a video, present it as a video. Use slang. Or don’t. Write in sentence fragments if you think that would be effective. In other words, in an unessay you have complete freedom of form: you can use whatever style of writing, presentation, citation,… even media you want. What is important is that the format and presentation you do use helps rather than hinders your explanation of the topic.

Be evaluated on how compelling and effective you are

If unessays can be about anything and there are no restrictions on format and presentation, how are they graded? The main criteria is how well it all fits together. That is to say, how compelling and effective your work is. An unessay is compelling when it shows some combination of the following:
  • it is as interesting as its topic and approach allows
  • it is as complete as its topic and approach allows (it doesn’t leave the audience thinking that important points are being skipped over or ignored)
  • it is truthful (any questions, evidence, conclusions, or arguments you raise are honestly and accurately presented)
In terms of presentation, an unessay is effective when it shows some combination of these attributes:
  • it is readable/watchable/listenable (i.e. the production values are appropriately high and the audience is not distracted by avoidable lapses in presentation)
  • it is appropriate (i.e. it uses a format and medium that suits its topic and approach)
  • it is attractive (i.e. it is presented in a way that leads the audience to trust the author and his or her arguments, examples, and conclusions).

Why unessays are not a waste of your time

The unessay may be quite different from what you are used to doing in English class. If so, a reasonable question might be whether I am wasting your time by assigning them. If you can write whatever you want and present it any way you wish, is this not going to be a lot easier to do than an actual essay? And is it not leaving you unprepared for subsequent instructors who want you to right the real kind of essays? The answer to both these questions is no. Unessays are not going to be easier than “real” essays. There have fewer rules to remember and worry about violating (actually there are none). But unessays are more challenging in that you need to make your own decisions about what you are going to discuss and how you are going to discuss it. And you are not going to be left unprepared for instructors who assign “real” essays. Questions like how to format your page or prepare a works-cited list are actually quite trivial and easily learned. You can look them up when you need to know them and, increasingly, can get your software to handle these things for you anyway. In our class, moreover, I will be giving you separate instruction on what English professors normally expect to see in the essays you submit to them. But even more importantly, the things you will be doing in an unessay will help improve your “real” ones: excellent “real” essays also match form to topic and are about things you are interested in; if you learn how to write compelling and effective unessays, you’ll find it a lot easier to do well in your “real” essays as well.

item.title: Course Description
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
In this course, we will examine artistic (primarily literary) representations of digital culture. We'll look at texts that represent coders, hackers, and computers analyzing how those texts reflect or interpret our digital world. In particular, we'll account for representations that suggest interpretations of digital culture that reflect themes such as fear, the apocalyptic, runaway patriarchy, and unbridled optimism. In short, the course will offer an opportunity to see how artistic production represents the structures of our digital lives.

Required Texts: Lauren Beukes: Moxyland Ernest Cline: Ready Player One Douglas Coupland: JPod Robin Sloan: Mr. Penumbra’s 24-Hour Bookstore Ellen Ullman: The Bug

item.title: Thinglink Test
