item.title: The Tagging / Mark-Up Module (Week 1)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Instructions: Due for the Jan. 14th class. This is your first module, so give yourself some time to complete it. You should allow yourself at least an hour, but two would be better. If it goes faster than that, great! But if it's frustrating, you'll have some time to deal with those frustrations. To complete this module, you will need to go to this place and read the instructions below. In this module you will be using CommentPress. CommentPress is a little widget that lives inside a website that allows us to "mark-up" text. What we'll be doing is looking in the text for names, places, things, that reference technology in Mr. Penumbra's 24-Hour Bookstore. When you find something, you should identify it, then provide a description or definition of what that place, thing, company, item, person is and how it is related to technology. The daring amongst you can provide a link to an example, picture, or audio / video--whatever. There are instructions about how to use CommentPress on the mark-up website and a screencast video that shows you how it works below. Make sure you read the instructions carefully and watch the video screencast before you go off on your own.

1102 - The Mark-Up Module - Using CommentPress from Digital Cultures Lab on Vimeo.

There are three sections to mark-up. One from the very beginning of the book, another from the middle, and finally, one from near the end. The idea is to give you a broad space in which to mark things up; so there should be plenty for everyone to contribute to. If you find someone has found a reference that you want to add something too, feel free. This is an exercise in exchange. We should all be working together to illuminate the text in an interesting way. Summary: Task: identify words / phrases / references to technology in any section of Mr. Penumbra's 24-Hour Bookstore on the class CommentPress site. How many words / phrases / references should I identify?
  • Try for at least 5, but do as many as you like. If you find someone has done everything, then add some comments to what's already been found. But trust me, no one can find them all. Look around!
Outcomes:
  • How does marking-up / tagging / identifying technological things in the text help us understand setting and the role it plays in the novel?
  • How does the process of marking-up the text make interpreting the deeper meaning of the text easier / harder?
  • How is the setting essential to understanding the novel and its broader point about the relationship between old and new knowledge?
Takeaways:
  • The text assumes an audience familiar with certain elements of reality. We know this because of the marking-up of words in the text.
  • Writing does not exist in a vacuum. Would your grandmother understand this novel, with all its references to technology?
  • Who is the audience for this novel? Is that audience reflected in the book's main characters?
  • What did you think of the CommentPress platform? Was it helpful in completing the task? How so or how not?
Task, Part 2: Remember to respond to some of the questions above (in "Outcomes" and "Takeaways") in the comment space below. Make sure you are logged in. Refer to the course procedures page -- the "Work Away from Class" section -- if you're confused about what you are supposed to be doing in the comment space below. And finally, if you're all the way down here and need the website where we're marking things up; follow this link.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Identifying technological things in the text allows for readers to understand when the story is taking place. The reader may be able to gauge what time period/era the story is taking place in by the pieces of technology described. The references may act as markers in time that the reader would recognize and place relative to themselves. By defining the time period, the reader may understand the importance of that piece of technology to the characters and their society.
The setting is essential to understanding the novel because we can grasp the significance of a major conflict. Because the story takes place in modern time, readers can easily relate to the story’s conflict of rapid change from books to computers.
Unfortunately, my grandmother would not understand this novel’s technological references. She, I would say, does not fall into the targeted audience of the book. I would say the book’s main audience is people approximately aged 15-35 years old. The targeted audience is reflected in the book, as the main characters would fall into the targeted age categories themselves. Clay, Kat and Neel are all young adults who are thoroughly ‘tech savvy’.
I think CommentPress is a really cool learning tool and discussion platform. I like how some comments gave a mini history of the references that I would have otherwise not have known and they made me realize just how much technology is a part of my life. While reading those excerpts for the first time, I hardly noticed how many references litter the pages. The comments really highlighted how much technology is integrated seamlessly in the book as well as in my own life.

The lab allowed me to learn more about the actual definitions of today's digital terms. It was actually fun going through the three chapters and spotting for internet or computer related words, it was like looking for Waldo or something. I mean, it was time consuming with finding the definitions, then coming up with your own definitions were tedious, but it was fun looking for gifs. Although it took a long time, it actually helped me understand more about the discussion this week ( setting and context). We are set into Clay's mind where he is very familiar with almost everything that computers offer us today: too much data, pirate libraries, hacking missions, reliable information that can be considered as illegal things. This lab describes the wide expense that computer brings into the the novel, aside from the fact that computers correlate with books, random but cool in its unexpected way.

Nice work Paula, glad you found it useful. You might think about how the book plays on traditional genres (another term will be dissecting in class): it's part detective novel, part quest, part love story, part science fiction. Think about how it employs the devices you expect from fiction-writing. How does it play off your expectations? (You don't have to answer now, just think about it.)
Also, where are the GIFs? I'm excited for the GIFs...

Thanks for this Maxine. You might press a little more on what you mean by "setting is essential to understanding the novel because we can grasp the significance of major conflict." What is the conflict? Between what and what? How is that important for "understanding" -- what are we trying to "understand"?
All this to point out that by contextualizing your thinking in terms of "because the story takes place in modern time [sic]" you are restricting your thinking and writing. The interpretation you might offer need not have anything to do with when the book was written. Instead, take the book on its own terms. What's the conflict in the book? How does that conflict REFLECT our current situation; not how does our current situation help us understand things in the book.

Marking up/tagging/identifying the technological phrases and words helps us to understand the age in which the book was written and to figure out whom the author directed this novel towards. The identification of these terms helps us to understand that the novel is directed towards those who were born in and have lived through the more resent technological age of computers and internet devices. The recognition of terms and phrases pertaining to the theme of technology helps to make an easier and deeper interpretation of the text because there is further analysis of the text. The setting of the story is essential to the understanding of the novel because it sets the theme of the conflict in the story, which is the old verse the new. The old refers to the older styles of gathering information and preforming hobbies, such as reading, to new ways of getting information and preforming hobbies. My Grandmas on either side of my family, are both very different. One would understand all the references in this book, and the other would not, she would need an explanation of most of the terms. The audience of this book are those who are under 40 or those who have adopted the technology as it has evolved. The characters in this book are very reflective of the technology age with the description of the items they use, along with their perspective of the world and the use of old knowledge and new knowledge. The CommentPress platform is good for being able to view the text and analyze it by each chapter and paragraph. It is really good to be able to comment and gather other student’s opinions in one area where it is open for review and discussion. It was helpful to complete the task of identifying terms and phrases because with a book there is not necessarily enough room to write down the words or identify them all. With identifying the terms and phrases there would be a high use of sticky notes and a highlighter which would not be ideal for rereading the book.

At first, I took the tagging exercise lightly. But after having thought of the number of technological terms in the text, it illuminated something I did not realize initially. In the beginning of the text, there seems to be a constant conflict between old knowledge—books and new knowledge—computers. This is marked by the constant contemplation of Clay as to why the bookstore's customer keep coming back for "old" books way before Clay was even born. Then I realized both generation's perspectives of gathering information. Clay which represents the computer-age generation who look down on people who read books and think of them as boring and old-fashioned. While on the other hand, Mr. Penumbra's boss, Corvina, think down on computer-age generations who regard them as tradition breakers. But later on towards the middle of the text, both generations close the distance and both are engaged in one another's fashion: integrating the new with the old and the old with the new. That is to say, books and computers and computers and books.
With all the technological terms contained within the text, the book is mainly focused on computer literate people. If my grandparents are to read this book, I am pretty certain I would have the pleasure of witnessing their contorted faces trying to make meaning of what they come across with. Not that it would be a polite and appropriate thing to do, but I can just picture that in my mind. Since the book is mainly focused on Clay's perspective, who is a computer savvy, I think that the book itself is an encouragement to explore past generations because the older generation is not boring, that they have their interesting stories to tell as well.
I hope I am doing this right. My mind is still on vacation mode.
Cheers.

You're doing it correctly. Some interesting thoughts here, especially in the first paragraph. Watch that you don't get side-tracked by the "grandmother" perspective. While it's important to get your head around how other readers might encounter the book, it's also important to think about that conflict you identify between old and new / books and computers. If you've read to the end, you know that it's decidedly analogue. So, despite the book's voluminous references to technology, think about what final statement the book makes... how does the book feel about books?

Good stuff Natasha. You might think about the differences in "tagging" a book using sticky notes and CommentPress. How is one different than the other, not just that it's different, but *how* is it different? You seem to suggest that marking up the book, for instance, inhibits re-reading. Why? And how does it do this? One way might be that it "pre-interprets" the book for the next reader or for you re-reading, with the notes and highlighter markings suggesting that there's only one way to (or there's a "correct" way to) read / interpret the text. Marking up the text by hand then limits the interpretive possibilities that CommentPress--which doesn't touch the book--allows.
See what I did there: essay material!

Due to its simplistic setup, my first experience using the Comment Press platform turned out to be quite enjoyable. The overall task was easy to understand, however looking back I realized I submitted a word that did not correspond to the paragraph I was tagging (whoops!). By identifying technological references, this task helps by developing the setting. The various references to tech-savvy vocabulary makes it evident that the story is taking place during a time when new technology, modern gadgets and the internet are starting to replace traditional practices, therefore becoming a reason for conflict between parties with opposing views. The contrast between Clay’s views on new technology is evidently different than those of Mr. Corvina, a clear example of a situation that is present in today’s society as well. In addition to the multiple technological references mentioned in the novel, the detailed descriptions regarding modern high-tech procedures provided me with a new perspective on the complexity associated with computer programming and all things technology. In regards to the references made to technology, I highly doubt my grandparents would understand any of them, perhaps with the exception of ‘internet’. Nonetheless, even I had some difficulty understanding what I consider to be more ‘advanced’ technological words such as ‘Ruby’ and the other programming languages mentioned by Clay. Clay, like many young people today, is well-informed of modern technological advancements and considers them to be beneficial for society. Even though he knows far more than I do, Clay still experiences situations during which he feels his knowledge and talent regarding technology is not up to par with his peers. In my opinion, this makes the audience relate to him more as many of us go through the same struggle at times. Regardless, Clay represents an individual with a personality and perspective not too different from many young adults in today’s day and age. It seems as if he appreciates technology as a method of advancement and improving day to day life, however, I’m not sure if he’s willing to give up a traditional book for a Kindle.

The CommentPress platform was easy to understand and helped complete the task easily. It was helpful in identifying some words that we may not have noticed or did not understand the meaning of due to other people having marked-up the word.
Marking-up/tagging allows us to understand the setting of the novel, from a high tech person’s point of view. By marking-up up the text I was able to better understand the sentences in the text, as there were some words in the text that even I was not aware of such as “time-series visualization”. So if the three texts had reoccurring words, due to them being marked-up one can know the meaning of the following sentences. Therefore making it easier for the reader to understand the setting and deeper meaning of the texts.
The setting of novel helps the reader understand of the border separating the old knowledge and new knowledge. In the novel the old knowledge does not wish to adopt the ways of the new knowledge, and the new knowledge believe that they have the answer to all solutions. So they both only acknowledge each other but do not wish to combine the knowledge they both hold to find the solution. Clay helps us identify a way where both the old knowledge and new knowledge can work side by side to solve a puzzle that could not be solved with just the old knowledge or new knowledge.
My grandmother would be able to understand the basic and simple references to technology that the novel was making such as a laptop. However, she would not be able to understand most of the vocabulary in the novel, as she was not raised in an environment that had lots of technology. Therefore, she would most likely not be within the age range for the audience of the novel. The audience of the novel would mostly consist of young adults who are aware of most of the references to the high tech things in the novel.

The text assumes multiple things that are familiar with the audience: the concepts of a laptop, everyone in the possession of a phone, social media (Twitter, facebook), huge internet based corporations such as Google, as-well as future developments such as a self-driving car. So it is safe to assume the audience that this text is targeting is perhaps from 13-40 or so. Older individuals would not understand the references made (Such as my grandmother). Concepts such as a mobile phone, Google, social media and a self-driving car would make absolutely no sense to my grandmother and many other seniors in that generation. Such a distinction between generations and technology is evident in Mr. Penumbra’s lack of tech-savvy language (Calling a mac a make and model, as if it was a car) and Marcus Corvina’s strong resistance towards technology in general.
It was evident that clay was dealing with two very different groups of people - symbolizing conflict between technology and older “ways” in clays dialogue. Clay regularly pointed out how the Company owned by Corvina was tech-savvy when it came to business, but backwards when it came to the reading room. There would be very technological savvy locations Clay would find himself in (such as the google campus) and then suddenly Clay would find himself back in Mr.Penumbras book store, or the reading room which forbid technology, including phones. The main characters, in many ways do represent the target audience. The main characters were all quite young, with the exception of Mr.Penumbra. Mat seems to be a middle ground between the integration of technology completely over old ways and keeping with the past. Clay’s narrative demonstrated this fact as he stated Mat was a dying breed of sorts of special effects artists who work with physical materials over digital effects. Neel and Kat were both quite savvy, as well as the main character Clay. I think the comment platform is very interesting because it can provide a new perspective on a problem. Such as someone seeing meaning something I didn’t catch or may have missed, or provide their interpretation of the text. Reading the comments others left was helpful, especially if you seem fixated on a single idea, the comments of others may help to broaden the scope.

The setting of this book is inside Clays mind, viewing the world under his filter. Throughout the novel, Clay finds that he can solve the riddle of the Manutius book by using all his resources, old knowledge and new knowledge. He does this by using Google, programming software, coded books, and elderly advice. If the setting were in someone else’s point of view, the novel would be written differently. The mindset of Corvina would result in a novel with no mention of using new knowledge to solve the code because he believes that technology can’t solve a man made riddle. In total, the deeper meaning of the novel is that there should not be a debate of whether old knowledge is more important than new knowledge, but both have their strengths and weaknesses so together they can provide an all around solid source of information. Hard copy books are easier to navigate and have infinite battery life, but Kindles are lighter and carry more novels. The characters that were focusing solely on technology to solve the code (Kat) came to a dead end and the characters that were using only old books to solve the code (Corvina) were not successful either. It was essential that the setting be in the mind of the one who solved the code to show how to incorporate both old knowledge and new knowledge into our lives.

The setting is taking place inside Clay Jannon's mind, which gives us a very one sided view to what is happening in the novel. Marking-up the text and looking for technological references helps show us the time of when the book was based and where it occurs. The technology advancements that we see at google is a large contrast as to the technology used with the unbroken spine. This acts as a foil in the novel and helps create a more clear conflict in the novel. Google is seen as the new knowledge since we use all the new technology to determine the new technology, whereas the Unbroken Spine doesn't use any technology and only refers to books to find new information therefor making this the old knowledge. The Old versus New Knowledge creates another conflict throughout the story and is one of the main ones, that helps Penumbra solve what the Codex Vitae means. No one was able to solve the Codex Vitae only using one form of knowledge but instead used both old and new knowledge to solve the hidden message. It was important to the setting that it was portrayed through Clay's mind since he was always using both old and new knowledge to solve his problems. If the setting had been in the mind of one of the other characters it would of been written very differently since most other characters only used Old or New knowledge and never combined the two, which is why it was only Clay that could solve Manutius.

Good comments here Rachel. Try to work through them a little further; this reads like you are listing things without really thinking about how things might combine or reflect one another (it reads like you are writing for me, making sure that you show me you notice what I think you should notice). So, you've covered all the basics and have a good sense of the plot, but what does all this mean? Why is it important? What makes it significant? Why even write / read a book like this? What might it tell us about the state of our current context? Push a little harder and goods critical thinking will emerge.

Nice work Ashley. What does this all say about how we see books functioning in today's world? Do you think you will ever accumulate a physical "library" of books that you own or will they all be online? And, how is reading different on paper as opposed to through a Kindle or the like? What we need to think about is how Mr. Penumbra's 24-Hour Bookstore prioritizes one type of knowledge over another--assuming it does. What might the novel be suggesting about the importance of books as physical objects?

Great Arman. You've certainly got the conflict down. Think about how what the text assumes--as you note in the first paragraph--affects your reading of that conflict. How is the conflict informed by the technological references you understand or how is the book itself a kind of codex for someone who doesn't get the technological references. Would a reader need to "decode" the textual reference to technology in order to understand it? Why or why not? And, what does that mean for the book itself--is Mr. Penumbra's 24-Hour Bookstore a codex vitae?

I found that the Comment Press platform was very helpful with analyzing the text. The amount of comments within the text about technology highlighted the importance of technology within the book. All throughout the book the text explains the constant battle between technology and books. The setting is thoroughly established through this conflict of the new age and old age of technology. Clay, the main character throughout this book, finds himself working in an old bookstore. This is ironic because Clay is very involved with computers and technology himself and finds that the bookstore is his polar opposite. The book develops this conflict of technology and books through Old Knowledge and computers, which also establishes the setting of the book and the time frame that the book may take place in. As a result of the OK and the TK conflict, the time frame may be where technology is greatly integrated within the generation and is proven in the book through the large involvement of google. The marking up of the text made the interpreting the deeper meaning of the text much easier. The significant amount of technology vocabulary made it clear where the conflict resides in. Marking up the text individually really helped me engage into the book and start thinking more critically about the conflict. The setting is essential to understanding the novel and its broader point about the relationships between old and new knowledge. This book can definitely relate to our culture today where our older generations are not as technologically evolved the younger generation. Some people that live within the older generation of books and old knowledge are finding it more difficult to adapt just as Mr. Corvina in the book. Other people within the older generation may be struggling but open to the new technology age just like Mr. Penumbra. Finally the new and younger generation that is more technologically engaged may relate to Clay and Kat as they are both accustomed and comfortable with technology.

When I was identifying technological things in CommentPress for this novel, it reminded me of technological things people nowadays are so accustomed to. For example, you see words such as Google, laptop, or internet in CommentPress. It helps me understand the importance that technology plays in the novel and in our own world. In comparison to old knowledge, current technology is a vital aspect in our day-to-day lives. We use technology to pay our bills, entertain ourselves, or do general research. In this novel, Clay’s group uses technology to decrypt the book of Manutius. Technology is a centerpiece in the story. My grandmother would not understand the references to technology. When I look at it from this perspective, the old world does not mesh with the new technology. Furthermore, the technology that exists today would only be considered a dream in her childhood. Just a few weeks ago I had to teach an elderly in my extended family how to use a laptop. It was very difficult to teach because in their view technology is too complicated nowadays. On a side note, they referred to a computer mouse as “the little guy”. Using CommentPress was something very new to me. In fact, this class would be considered my first partial online course. Using Blackboard and CommentPress are all new learning experiences for me. I was confused on how to use CommentPress in the beginning because I could not find where the 3 sections were located. After about 20 minutes, I realized you had to click on navigate to see the 3 sections. CommentPress was helpful in the sense that it showed words of new technology in the novel’s text. Once I found the 3 sections, I took my time reading over the texts and looking for key technological words to comment on. Most words were commented on by other classmates, so I tried my best to find paragraphs with 0 comments to write on. CommentPress seems like a useful tool to keep us engaged in the novel we are reading on certain weeks. The learning process is always important in the first week!

Identifying technological references help readers to understand the role it plays in the novel. These references serve a purpose for character development, for example, Clay uses wifi, 3d scanner, google, etc. and it shows that Clay (and all other young characters like Kat, Neel and Mat) are computer savvy and the new generation. It also helps readers to distinguish between the new generation and the previous generation. Clay is the new generation because he is using new technology to gain knowledge. In contrast, Corvina is the old generation because he is using books in order to find information. Both characters are very different because Corvina rejects technology as a way to find information because it lacks traditional knowledge while Clay utilizes technology because getting information is quick and easy. Moreover, Mr. Penumbra is between the new and old generation because he bought a new Mac and learning how to use it (transitioning from books to technology to find information).
This task also help readers to relate themselves to the characters and understand the characters better. We can relate to these words easily because we are all familiar with words like google, twitter, Facebook and we use technology for the same reason as the characters.
The audience for this novel is for those who grew up with technology because the audience can understand the technological references in the novel and they can also relate to the book’s main characters. My grandmother would not understand this book because she is not exposed enough to technology to understand the references.
I think CommentPress is cool way to discuss more about the book about its theme, characters, conflict between books and technology and apply that to outside of the novel. But for the task, defining terms is frustrating for me. It is hard to define technological terms because we/younger generation do not need to know the exact definitions since we grew up with it and its there for us already. That also made me realize how much we rely on technology.
I hope I’m doing this right as I am still in holiday mode. Thanks!

The setting is in Clay Jannon’s mind; however, the audience is us, or a small to large group of people that are not able to critique Clay right away. Most people are more willing to convey their thoughts when an opinion is not voiced, such as Clay can voice his thoughts to the audience without the risk of criticism, just how we can voice our opinions on Commentpress compared to how quiet we were in our first literature class. Most people do not want to make errors, like myself, and lower the chances of making errors by not talking or voicing their answers in class to receive instant critique or praise. Clay is the same, is not afraid to narrate his thoughts to the audience, even about a “beautiful late-night hacker girl” (The Prototype 31). I found this Commentpress assignment interesting because it got people to type and identify words that referred to technology. But what was really intriguing to me was that people often identified words that our parents would not understand, but not words that they would understand. The assignment “identify words / phrases / references to technology in any section of Mr. Penumbra’s 24-Hour Bookstore on the class CommentPress site” means exactly what it is. At first, I did not look at it and read the book as it is, but as I attempted to complete the assignment, I was astonished on how many words and references I missed such as Google, craigslist, and scanner I understood them by second nature. I treated them like any other word. Then I noticed I missed noticing words such as “lights”(The Prototype 62), “a piece of music”(64), and “bell tinkl[ing]”(Help Wanted 23) which would complete the assignment requirements just fine. Then I noticed in CommentPress that many people defined the words such as “laptop”(Help Wanted 5, The prototype 12, 41, The rebel alliance 24, 61) many times, instead of simple technologies such as a “ladder”(Help Wanted 1). Then I realized we, society, are losing our definition of what technology is, we are taking technology for granted, and we, the class, are demonstrating it by losing our touch with what we do have. Every time a new Iphone comes out, we disregard the old version for a new one, and expect more and more. Overall, I feel Commentpress can aid us in future projects such as it did for me for this one.

P.S. after rereading, I noticed I forgot some punctuation in my comment, so please excuse those! I also did not read the task and that lead me to point out unnecessary meanings. I cannot edit or delete anything here, but I'm sure it's intended for a purpose. *_*

The lab is a good learning tool as it helps learn about the exact meaning of some technology and computer terms. For example, I know that C is a computer language, but I don’t know what is about or how it works so searching the meaning helps to know more about terms. Besides, using all these technological terms and phrases are helping identify the sitting of the story that takes place in time reading traditions and customs started to change. The differences between Clay’s methods and Mr. Penumbra reflect partly the debate about if we should keep the books or we should shift to eBooks and googling any needed information. Another important idea of this novel is that we can use new technology to read and understand books much easier and faster. However, the end of the story proves that old knowledge and new knowledge can work together in harmony as an old mastery started in old books and solved by new computer programs. Furthermore, the relationship between Clay and Mr. Penumbra reflects that the liaison between old and new knowledge could be on and off, but they can work together to produce something significant. Indeed, new knowledge was extended from old one that started in papers and books; therefore, we can merge them without replacing one by another because the papers still have a lot to offer and a lot of knowledge could be discovered.

The incorporation of technological things within the text is important because it enables readers to envision the setting within the story line of the novel. The setting is described through the perspective of the novel’s main character, Clay. By identifying the setting, readers are able to better understand the major conflict within the novel, which involves new electronic technology (e.g. computers) versus old fashioned ways of gathering information (e.g. books).
The audience for this novel is for those who grew up in the technology era where technology is a big component of school related, work related, and leisure activities. The story may correspond well to young adults as well as older generations who have kept up to date with modern technology.
Clay’s character is a clear representation of the novel’s targeted audience because he is tech savvy and does not initially acknowledge the benefits of old fashioned print books at the start of the novel. in contrast to Clay’s character, the novel introduces Corvina, who is set on old fashioned books and ways. As the story progress the readers learn that certain characters of the story become more open to incorporating old and new technology in order to successfully decode the Codex Vitae.
Because the novel has many references to modern technology, I don’t believe my grandmother would be able to understand this novel. Without any background knowledge regarding modern technology, one might have trouble understanding the characters, context, and story line of the novel. For example the novel makes references to Apple, Macs, kindle, and even Google, which is modern technology that my grandmother would not understand.
The CommentPress platform was helpful because it lets you read more in depth as you analyze and interpret the text. The task to analyze technological terms helps show the importance of technology with reference to the novel. CommentPress is helpful because it allows you to see how other readers interpreted the text. The CommentPress platform was also simple to understand and easy to use.

By identifying the various technological terms in the text, I got a true understanding of how significant of role setting plays in this novel. Having the setting in Clay’s mind we see his savvy knowledge in various technological items. We also see how the society around him is transitioning from old to new knowledge with technology. The numerous references of technological items helps the reader understand how the younger generation with Clay, Kat, and Neel contrast from the older generation of Corvina and the Unbroken Spine. Ultimately, both sides are decrypting the book of Manutius, but Clay’s use of both old and mainly new knowledge shows how more efficient and effective his methods were in solving the puzzle compared the old generation. We can truly see the impact of new knowledge in the story with all the technological terms such as prototype, hacking, visualization, etc and how it took so little time to solve a 500 year mystery. These words give the reader the true perspective of Clay’s “new knowledge” mind and is something younger generations such as myself can relate to.
With the assortment of technological terms throughout the novel we can see the main audience of the story to be of one familiar with new technology (new knowledge). Being a person growing up in such technologically minded society I can relate well to Clay and his mission to solve the Manutius. Even other characters such as Kat were relatable especially for technologically advanced audiences. Someone such as my grandmother would not understand the references to technology and not be able to connect to the book the same way I do. She would more likely prefer to read a book from Corvina’s perspective (old knowledge).
Using CommentPress was very simple and easy to use. It was a great way to truly see the many technological terms that were used in the story. It really gave me the significance the new knowledge had in the setting of the story and ultimately why I felt I related well to Clay. I found using the CommentPress was a great “new knowledge” technique to help me grasp the significance of setting in this novel.

The CommentPress platform is amazing and incredible tool. When I opened it, there are 3 themes the same as the paperbook. There is number in front of each sentence to convert a title. Computer software can display a whole book on screen of a device such as Kindle. I can read them online or download from Kindle or iBook’s into technological products such iPhone, Taplet, laptop and so on. I have never known about the Kindle until I read through the Mr. Penumbra’s 24 hour bookstore book. Paper books or e-books help people to learn about new technology. The CommentPress helps me to understand the context, word phrases, and concepts of the novel shared by network technology. Also, new technology allows me to add my ideas and read through their comments using computer technology. All messages are immediately send out by high tech tools.
I think my grandmother will be able to know the novel because we are using new technologies to help her. If she does not understand abbreviated words and context of sentences, she can Google it. New technologies are easier to find out from the network rather than flip over some book searching for all the references. She might not know some computer terms but she can popularly understand what the story is from the book. For example, there is an old message hidden in the book from the five hundred year ago. Some readers tried to use computer technologies and power to decode the message but none of them could find out the secret of society. In the book, the main character Clay Jannon found the secret without computer technologies.
In my opinion, the book is very interesting and exciting for different types of readers. Videogames always attract a lot of teenagers and adolescences to play like Grumble character in the book. For instance, even though Mr. Panumbra has a lot of knowledge in his brain, he try to use computer technologies to solve the five hundred year old puzzle. Eventually, he could not figure it out. I think the main audience can be young people and adults like Clay Jannon. Clay Jannon used his talent and patience to solve the puzzle without using computer.

At first, I assumed that the main audience of Mr. Penumbras 24-Hour Bookstore were teenagers and young adults due to the many references to technology and the internet. Clayton even bluntly states that any person over 30 would find his technological terms difficult to understand. However, I soon discovered that with the exception of several young main characters (Kat, Neel, and Clay) the book revolved around many elderly people as well. It frequently empathized Penumbra’s wish for the integration of computers into the Unbroken Spine. This surprised me because most of the elderly people that I know do not feel that way. They believe that although technology has many positive outcomes, getting to an answer quicker only makes us more impatient. My grandparents, for example, would not be able to relate to Penumbra but instead more closely to Corvina, though not quite as severe and intense. They stubbornly believe in “the old-fashioned way” and have made little effort in learning how more advanced technology works. If they were to read the novel, maybe their opinions would differ slightly!
Even my parents, when reading this book, may not be able to take as much from the text as younger people would. They would relate more to the “old knowledge” found in this book such as getting to an answer through reading and working for it. The “new knowledge”, however, I can relate to in a sense that the most efficient and quickest way to solve a problem should be the method used most prominently.
The "marking-up" module for this novel has been great motivation to pay more attention when reading Mr. Penumbra 24-Hour Bookstore. I thought at first that it would be difficult and distracting to be thinking of references to technology while reading, but it proved easier than suspected. When technology came up in the text, I was quick to refer back to the assignment and consider the context in which the technological reference has been given. I liked the process because it forced me to think more about what I was reading and absorb the information. However, there were several times where I would go several pages without stopping before realizing I had skipped numerous technological references. These were areas that were exciting and sucked me right into the book. I had to go back and re-read the pages more carefully.

Marking up or “tagging” in this week’s module was a great method to help emphasize the role of technology in Mr. Penumbra’s 24 Hour Bookstore. The period of time in which I grew up happened to be amongst a huge technological revolution. Having that said, marking up the meanings of these different innovations and diving deeper into the meanings of them made me realize how much I have overlooked them in the past since they were terms I grew up using. The setting is essential in our understanding of old and new knowledge because at many points throughout the novel, we are presented with antagonistic means of how things used to be done versus how they are done, in a more efficient manner in present time. Similarly, as Dave mentioned in our class last week, we were reading a “book about books”, which made me make the connection of the significance of the old knowledge coming from the books in Mr. Penumbra’s bookstore over the new knowledge that can be seen in books today, such as this and through technological mediums. Although, that it may seem like old knowledge and new knowledge are opposing forces, if there was not old knowledge it would surely not have led to new.
Evidently, my grandmother would not be familiar with much of this novel if any. The main targeted audience are those that grew up around the nineties to the early 2000’s, and are the same people that heavily rely on social media, cell phones, and new knowledge in their everyday lives. With the use of Clay Jannon and Kat to demonstrate new knowledge, and Mr. Penumbra to demonstrate old knowledge, the audience was able to grasp the concept of the effects of technology in the 21st century.
The CommentPress platform was fun to use! Unique to any assignment I have ever completed, it enabled me to be more aware and focused of what I am reading.

Marking up, tagging, and identifying technology in the text helps us to picture and get a feel of the time period of the story. There are many words in the book that refer to common technology in this day and age which shows how significant the role of technology is to the book. The book is centered around electronic devices and hacking.
My grandmother would definitely not understand the terms referring to technology. Technology has grown and developed so much that my grandmother is most likely too old to know what these terms mean except for the “phone”. The main audience for this book is probably young men and women who are familiar with these terms and references. The book does reflect this age group because most of these characters are young men and women probably in there 20s.
The CommentPress platform was interesting to use as I have never used it before. It was pretty simple and straightforward to use and I saw it as a creative way to help make the book mean something. It was helpful in completing the task because of the easiness of simply commenting and the ability to see what other people commented is interactive.
The lab was helpful, it allowed me to read over parts of what I read previously and understand them better. It wasn't all that hard and it was interesting using a new platform that I haven't used before. It was a struggle to make the book mean something, but after looking for terms and describing them and seeing what other people commented and tagged, it helped me understand the book and its value a little more.

Tagging technological things in the text was definitely an eye opener for me. It became obvious that a lot of technology is used in this novel but it wasn't as blatant the first time I read through on my own. Going through and marking up technological terms made me realize I am so used to seeing and interacting with technology in my daily life that when it came down to defining something simple I really had to think about a formal definition. I liked that tagging certain paragraphs also clarified what some of the terms were. Personally, I am not tech savvy at all so seeing others define and clarify some of the terminology and references was really helpful.
The process of marking-up the text make interpreting the deeper meaning of the text easier in some ways and harder in others. For example, some basic terminology such as 'code' is commonly understood yet when coming up with a way to describe it can be challenging. It made me aware of the fact that some things that seem basic and simple at first can actually be complex without initially realizing. A way that I found tagging made the text easier to understand was having help from classmates and the clarification of more technological terms.
I find the comment press to be a really helpful tool so far. I appreciate that we can all share our opinions and get insight if we are stuck or offer if to others who might be frustrated or confused as well.

The lab for me was a good tool as it made me pay more attention to certain things, aspects, or point of views. When we had to do the tagging/mark up on CommentPress it made me focus on phrases that included technological aspects. Reading through everyone’s comments made me realize how technology impacts everyone’s life, what they use it for, and how they all describe it differently. Reading through those three chapters that were given on CommentPress I didn’t even realize how much technology was is intergraded throughout the text. The tagging module was really cool, I’ve never done anything like this but it helped me understand the context/setting of the novel.
We are the audience for this novel but the theme/setting takes place alone in Clays head. We can all relate to what was going on in Clays mind that there is just too much technology everywhere we look.
Its amazing to me how much our generation is accustomed and attached to technology. We rely on it for so many things but I think we forget the dangers of it too. When I first began to read this novel I just imagined having a local bookstore like that around here. Sure, you can go to the local library or and purchase a book. But, I find it neat how with every novel bought or sold back has such a history behind it. Clay gets the coolest perspective, and although it may not emphasize it in the book you can make your own inferences about how cool it would be to see all different kinds of people, from all different walks of life come in and somehow have something in common. In today’s day and age, I think it’s quite sad how we don’t have much of anything like that, I mean all the reading someone may need is available on the computer or their phones.

The tagging/ marking-up process helped us interpret the context of the book. Nowadays, many of us read over commonly used technology words such as internet, laptop or Google and typically will not think about the meaning of the word in the context it is in. We are the generation where this vocabulary is common knowledge to us but we will all benefit from finding the deeper meaning and reading more than one definition of a technological term. The Comment Press platform also emphasized one of the main themes in the novel: technology.
People in earlier generations such our grandparents and even our parents would have difficulties decoding the vocabulary in Mr. Penumbra’s 24-Hour Bookstore since they grew up in a time where they were not surrounded by technology. The intended audience of Penumbra’s 24-Hour Bookstore is for those who are 14 - 40. They would have background knowledge on the vocabulary used throughout the book and that way be able to understand the message. The majority of the characters were young and tech savy so the audience certainly does reflect on the main characters.
The setting takes place in Clay’s mind where he used Old Knowledge and New Knowledge to solve the puzzle. At the beginning, both Penumbra and Clay were stuck in their ways so to say and did not want to collaborate and teach each about old and new knowledge. The booked continued to jump from old to new knowledge. For instance, Clay toured through Google then not long after he ended up back working in the book store. In the end, Clay discovered a way to combine the old knowledge with the new thus, solving the conflict. The novel would have been completely different if it was told from a different characters’ perspective since none of the others used both old knowledge and new knowledge (Penumbra uses old and Kat, Neel, and Matt all use new).

I found comment press has a very simple design and is very easy to use. This made this week’s module quite pleasant to complete. However in terms of making the text easier for me to process it has not made a real difference, mainly because 95 percent of the terms I had already understood what they were. That being said after doing this module and paying closer attention to all the technology terms used in the book it is easy to see how another person could get lost in the language. A few things that this module does do though, is it helps the reader understand when this book was written, who the target audience is and where this book takes place. Based on the amount of technological terms it becomes quite evident that this book is directed towards a younger demographic. It also helps determine when and where this book takes place, for example the first kindle had not come out 10 years ago. Which makes it obvious the book was based in the last few years.
It is important to understand setting because it can help the readers appreciate the relationship between old and new knowledge. This is because the majority of the setting is within Clay’s mind and he is the link between old and new knowledge. There is the representation of old knowledge that is Marcus, and on the other side of the spectrum there is Neel who represents the new knowledge. Marcus who wishes to stay clear from computers is much unlike Neel who is a computer animator. Both of these characters do having something in common though and that is Clay. Clay unites the two sides and is willing to use any resource he has available to him, in order to crack the codex vitae. Whether that be using computers to crack the codes or paying closer attention to a book he once read, he and Ajax or the true links of old and new knowledge. Clay for demonstrating a love of books even though he grew up in heavily hi-tech era, and Ajax for showing his willingness to use computers on an ancient code.

The setting helps to draw the comparison between old and new knowledge. It is not a coincidence that much of the story takes place in San Francisco, California, a state that many people would normally associated with innovation and technology-Google, Facebook, Silicone Valley etc. Within that setting, you have both new knowledge and the old knowledge, as found in Mr. Penumbra’s book store versus the technology that many of the characters continually reference. Then, you have the city of New York, which was founded much earlier than San Francisco. I believe that the much older city of New York versus the newer city of San Francisco is another way of comparing old versus new knowledge. I say that because Kat’s character, for example, makes many references to technology based in California, such as google. Compare this to the events that happen in New York-which took place mostly in the reading room, which contains books that are hundreds of years old.
As for the intended readers of this book, I am not sure most people over 40 would understand many of the references. It is most suited to people in their 20’s-like most of the characters in the story are. To be honest, I had to look up some of the terms to know whether they were made up or not. This makes me think i’m not the only one lost on some of the references. As for comment press itself, i think it is a very helpful tool for this task. On the other hand, it is hard not to notice the reoccurring theme of technology in this book, as to name one example, there are dozens of references to google in this book.

Identifying technological things can help us understand the setting by seeing how pervasive these things (like google, the internet, cell phones and seemingly intangible things like 3D visualisations) have become in our lives. I don't think marking-up the text makes it either easy or hard to interpret any deeper meaning because technology is just a tool in the book. Tagging it sort of highlights the messages and adds a sense of contrast between "old knowledge" and the new way of doing things. The way technology is used shows that old knowledge isn't sacrosanct in the age of the internet and should be open to re-interpretation. It makes the book more interesting because it's easy to visualize this world where tech is everywhere, but as a plot device it could have been replaced with something else.. (the steps from A to B would be different, but we'd still learn the same lesson)
The book is definitely geared towards the younger generation, perhaps starting at people who grew up or were born in the 80's or 90's and onwards. I had one grandmother who was a little knowledgeable about technology and the internet, but anyone beyond my siblings going up the family tree would be really hard-pressed understanding this book fully. If they persevered to the end, they might ultimately "get it" but a lot of the context would be lost on them. Clay and Neel are very tech savvy and incorporate it into their daily lives, but Kat is definitely more immersed in tech culture. There is a pretty fair spectrum of technological involvement among the characters in the book, but there is more of an emphasis on characters who know a lot about technology.
CommentPress looks like a really useful tool. I think it will just take some getting use-to, but I found it hard to keep track of where my comments were.

After having read the book “Mr. Penumbra’s 24-Hour Bookstore”, by Robin Sloan, I found it very useful to mark up the text with technological references. The majority of this book was a fairly straightforward read, although there were some excerpts that were a bit more difficult to understand at a first glance. This is where marking up the technological references became helpful. While some of them were particularly obvious, others were not and required some research to fully understand. This contributed to properly understanding the plot, the general idea of the plot was clear, whereas some of the many different types of technology they used to accomplish it was slightly more confusing prior to the mark up module. Robin Sloan incorporates a variety of different references to technology that make this book seem to narrow down its target market to a younger generation, namely teenagers and young adults, who use technology daily. However, Sloan uses an interesting contrast between Clay and Mr. Penumbra which enables the reader to notice the differences and even some similarities between the newer technological knowledge of Clay and the more old fashioned knowledge of Mr. Penumbra. Even better yet, the reader gets to see the way how Clay and Mr. Penumbra combine their knowledge, both new and old to accomplish the same goal. This also plays a large part in the setting of the book. Clay must figure out a way to locate the Unbroken Spine, an ancient book cult and solve the Codex Vitae. Penumbra shares his traditional knowledge of this cult with Clay and Clay uses new knowledge and technology to Penumbra’s advantage, such as the GrumbleGear 3000 to infiltrate the Reading Room, along with some help from his tech-savvy friends, Kat and Neel. If my grandmother were to read this book, she would certainly be confused. Although reading is one of her favourite hobbies, technology is like a different language to her, and the constant use of those advanced technological references would likely hinder her comprehension of the book. Nevertheless, if the mark up module was available to all readers of this book, it would be more widely understood by people who do not yet have a complete grasp on technology.

I found the CommentPress fairly easy to use, although I knew most of the technological terms before hand this exercise made me realize how much I overlooked most of the terms while reading the book. The reasoning behind overlooking them was because I was familiar with the terms and what they meant, if my grandmother were to read it she would definitely have trouble understanding it. Mainly because she doesn't speak English, but the fact that the targeted audience is for younger adults. The contrast between old knowledge and new knowledge is significant, and shows just how much technology is taking over. The conflict between all the modern "tech-savvy" characters and the ones who protected the reading room which allowed no technology was prominent. And there is also the thought of libraries being so scarce nowadays because many prefer e-books on their kindles or audio books. I'm all for new technology but I love my paperback novels.

CommentPress is a wonderful and is easy to learn. It was helpful with the exercise for it showed other students comments and gave me a good understanding of what to do for the activity. Although being a hybrid class I felt that CommentPress allowed us to interact with fellow classmates. (the gif was funny)
The tagging/Mark-up Module exercise was a fun activity. Looking through the paragraphs identifying certain technological terms in the text help me understand Clay’s world a little bit better. Although being part of today tech savvy generation, the text allowed me to get familiar with certain words such as “pirate libraries”. This allowed me to really understand the setting of the novel, Clay mind.
At first I thought this book would be only suitable for our generation but with CommentPress and other sources, older generations could understand the technological terms used. My parents are slowly getting used to technology using tablets, laptops and cellphones, even having a facebook account. Thus learning the technological terms shouldn’t be hard for older generations, but as other stated that may be a different story for my grandparents.

item.title: Welcome - First Day!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Welcome to the virtual space for 1102.001: Reading Literature and Culture. Before we meet in person (or F2F, as the kids say) on Wednesday at the unseemly hour of 8:30am, there are a few things we should get out of the way. Below is a list of those things (the bolded titles are links to the pages - click on them!). Make sure you have gone through each item on the list before coming to class on Wednesday morning (really, really, really early in the day. Stupid early).
    The Course Outline / Syllabus
  • This is the formal agreement between you and me about the rules and requirements for the course. Make sure you come to class with any questions or areas you want me to address.
    The Course Procedures
  • This is an explanation of the course itself and how it will work. Again, take note of any areas you want me to address in person -- if you don't ask about it; I will not address it.
    The Course Schedule
  • This is where you will find the course calendar and schedule -- when stuff is due, what you need to read, what areas we'll be concentrating on, etc.
    The Course Website Screencast
  • This is a video showing you how to register with the class website and get yourself all up and running so that you can participate fully right from the start.
    The Mark-Up Module
  • This is the first week's module (you'll understand this "module" thing once you've looked at all sections above. Go ahead, be brave. Get started!

item.content:encoded: The link to the first quiz is live. (The link above will take you to a Blackboard login page if you are not already logged into Blackboard. Enter the same credentials on the Blackboard login page that you would if you were logging in from the Douglas College website (student ID# / first six digits of your MyDouglas password). If you have difficulty with the link above, or the Blackboard login page, go to the Douglas College website and log into Blackboard. Select Engl.1102.001 Reading Literature & Culture and then click on "Quizzes" in the left-hand menu.) Good luck!

item.title: Book Traces Module (Week 2)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Instructions: Due for the Jan. 21st class. This module is about context, codes, and interpretation. It's also about how context informs how we understand and create meaning out of objects and things we read. A rough synonym for context is setting, which we have talked about in class. Setting is a literary term we use to help situate, or position, or place texts so that we can talk about them intelligently and generate discussion about what they might mean. Context does the same thing, but it's much more fluid and can apply to things outside the text itself. Context can include other literary terms such as narrative, and intertextuality. In short, context is a way of thinking about how setting, narrative, intertextuality play together. It is a way of interpreting and understanding how the text is put together or "constructed." Understanding how something is put together allows us to interpret it better. We can compare it to other things put together in a similar way (to other novels, for instance), or about similar things (to other stories), or that have similar parts (hackers as characters). In sum, contextualizing a text by understanding how it fits in with other things is an important step to making it mean something. There are many ways to mark up a book--you marked up words in the last module. Mr. Penumbra's 24 Hour Bookstore takes books as one of its primary subjects--along with codes, mythology, cults, collectives, collaboration, old and new knowledge, hacking, new media, and technology. The book also relies on our assumptions or expectations about books--the context in which we find books is the bookstore, for instance or, computers give us a context in which to solve codexes but the meaning of life lies outside the coldness of technological computation. This week's lab tries to get you thinking about how something is "marked" by others and how that mark governs how we receive the "thing" and interpret things about it, such as the order in which it is presented, its age, the group it belongs to, how it is / has been used (its context!). Below are a few examples: [caption id="attachment_73" align="aligncenter" width="296"] The bar code marks the book for a computer so that it can be tracked.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_74" align="aligncenter" width="225"] Each "Douglas College" stamp is a different font. These differences allow us to make the assumption that the books were purchased at different times.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_75" align="aligncenter" width="300"] How many of you know what this little pouch used to be for? It's a historical mark that allows us to surmise how old the book might be.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_76" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Where do these codes (numbers / letters) come from and what do they do?[/caption] [caption id="attachment_77" align="aligncenter" width="640"] The pencil marks in here tell us something about who is reading the book and how they are reading it.[/caption] Summary: Task: Go to the library and seek out a few books from the stacks. Take a look at how those books are "encoded," how are they marked, situated, or represented outside their subject headings--avoid the obvious like "this is a history book in the History section," that's lame. Think about how the book--or object--is put in context. Outcomes: Think about how books are encoded already and how this plays out in Mr. Penumbra's 24-Hour Bookstore:
  • Describe how your books are marked? What might these marks mean? What do they tell us about the book and its history, audience, content, or context?
  • How does the library organize itself? What are the underlying principles behind the organizing system and how are these codes that need to be deciphered?
  • Imagine you are discovering the Douglas College library in some distant future (like 4400CE) and you need to disentangle it, what rules would you write down to help others use it to discover Old Knowledge (OK) and why?
  • How does Mr. Penumbra's 24-Hour Bookstore use conventions you've discovered about books above to make the story compelling?
Takeaways:
  • Avoid situating texts in made-up contexts, such as assuming it was written when people were less literate. Instead, look at the text and use what you see about it as the guiding principle for contextual assumptions
  • Take account of your own assumptions about reading, organization, and interpretation. Are those assumptions borne out through the text? Or are you simply relying on your assumptions?
  • Context often determines how we read or "decode" something. If we find the book in a College or University library, we assume it is of a certain quality or intellectual level and read it accordingly. Whereas if we pick up a magazine at a Drug Store, we approach reading much differently. Texts often try to pressure our "decoding" forcing us to engage with new ways of understanding the text's context
  • Any analysis always begins with surfaces. You need to have evidence for a context in order to place the text within that context.
Task, Reminder: Remember to respond to some of the questions above (in "Outcomes" or ") in the comment space below. Make sure you are logged in. Refer to the course procedures page -- the "Work Away from Class" section -- if you're confused about what you are supposed to be doing in the comment space below.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
The first thing that I noticed is that almost the books in the Douglas College library the bar code starts with "1 5400". The purpose of the bar code enables the scanner to know that these books belong to Douglas College by that number. Also each numbers near the end of the book identify what book that is.
What really interest me us in the reference section, the codes on the side of these reference books are used to identify what type of book it is by using letters. This is how the library organize itself. For instance, “ML” books are about music/references to music or “J” books have articles/journals/papers about parliament. Below the letter, there is a number and all the books have that same number comes from the same series/author. As we get toward the bottom of the code, they identify these books by versions and what year it was published. Also, most of the reference books in one aisle have stamps on top of the pages, meaning that they are purchased at the same time or organized/sorted out on the shelf at the same time. Furthermore, these books are situated in the area where there is nobody there, which means these books are meant for specific people such as people studying music, law, nursing, etc.
Some of these books (mostly law books) from the reference section are from 1896 or dusty on top of the pages. There were no pencil markings, and so I would assume that barely anyone uses it since younger generations would not understand it because the book is out dated/out of context. The way the library organizes makes me see these books differently, for example, I would not understand or disagree about some of the papers written in the law book because it is outdated, similar the way Clay does not understand old knowledge out of old books.
Clay uses similar conventions that I have discovered about books because there is a section in Mr. Penumbra’s bookstore that is only used by the members of the Unbroken Spine (located many feet from the ground). Those books are used to break the code for internal life and members do not “understand” the books because it is out of context.
Overall the lab is really frustrating for me because it is hard to describe the book in terms of context and make connections to Mr. Penumbra’s 24-hr Bookstore.
I hope that I am doing this right.
Cheers

Before starting this assignment, I was lucky enough to have books rented out from the library for my Criminology class. At first glance, these books look very old as the writing on most pages points it out. The library seems to be in need of a “newer” edition of these books. What is evident from looking at these books is the markings that clearly show they are from the library. The barcode also supports this concept. Furthermore, it clearly says “Douglas College Library” on top of the barcode. It doesn’t take a genius to figure out where this book came from! However, another important observation is the published year written on the side markings. By looking at all three of my books, the markings show me that my oldest book was published in 1988, while the latest one was published in 2000. When I look inside all three of the books, the circling or underlining of words show me that they were of great importance to the previous readers. Maybe these books were used for research? Maybe for school assignments? The circled or underlined words clearly were vital to whoever was reading it. When I try to analyze the context of the books, two of the three books give me a general idea in what I am about to read. One book has Aboriginal people hugging on its cover with the title “Returning to the Teachings: Exploring Aboriginal Justice”. The second book is called “Canadian Mental Health Law and Policy” and it has a red cover. These observations give me the general context in what the book is about or what the text will revolve around. However, the third book is a complete mystery. The cover and back is completely grey with no title on either side. When I tilt the book sideways, the title is shown in small writing. The title is “Resistance and Renewal”. However, this analysis does not give me the general context of the book. I would have to open it up and read it to know what it is about. Simply reading the title does not give me any hint as it can still be about anything. Without this module, I would have never analyzed a books marking or context. People generally never look for these things as books are just used for reading content inside.
Aaron

Of the various types of books I saw, I noticed several cook books were stained with splatters of food and oil. Perhaps the readers were cooking while looking at the recipes or maybe flipping the pages with filthy fingers. The more stained pages could suggest that those recipes are favoured, tastier, or just messier to cook. Also, the cook books with more pictures tend to be more worn down which may suggest that readers are actually more visually attracted to the food than to recipes that are text alone. Something I have also noticed about all books in the particular library I explored was that they all have marks on the bottom. These marks signify how many times a book has been circulated over time. This in itself could give a great indication of how old a book is in general or compared to the other copies. Could even give an indication of how popular that book is. This way of tracking circulation is, however, being phased out which subsequently may signal what time period that particular book is from.
The library is organized by mediums and then more finely by a numbering system. The main sections include books, magazines, CDs, and DVDs. Each medium is then divided again several times over for various reasons whether its targeted audience, genre, or subject to name a few. For example, within the medium of books, the books are divided into fiction and non-fiction. I took a look at non-fiction and found that non-fiction is then divided into 10 different groups. Each group then corresponds to a range of numbers that are divided even further by category and ordered by author. These numbers are ordered accordingly by Dewey Decimal Classification numbers. The books’ codes can be deciphered using the Dewey Decimal system because each number corresponds to a specific subject.
I have no idea why, but I find making up rules so challenging, not to mention frustrating! Its probably because I hardly pay attention to rules... Anyhow, my one rule for 'disentangling' the library in the distant future would be to "memorize the category names and numbers of the universal library system known as the Dewey Decimal System and use those range of numbers and their respective categories to FIGURE IT OUT!"... Festina Lente people!
On another note, the Unbroken Spine’s thirst for knowledge puts into perspective how much knowledge there is in the world. One of the great reasons why the story is so compelling is that it points out how one could dedicate their whole life to decoding, reading, and understanding information of this world, but never decode, read, or understand it ALL. Whether it is OK or TK, no one will ever know it all. It reminds me of a short story called the “Library of Babel”. Both the novel and the short story encompass the idea that even though there is a definite amount of information to consume, there is far too much for any one person to take in.

Looking through the books at the library I noticed that out of about the one hundred books I looked at all of them have a bar code. This ensures that the library keeps tract of the books that are checked out and checked back into the library. The bar code would also be a security feature as an alarm will sound if you leave the library without checking out a book. Another feature that many of the books have is a flap on the first page of the book. Some of these flaps include a date which says something about when the book was received by the library. Also on the tops of several of the books is a Douglas College stamp. These stamps all have different fonts with different colours. The library has probably changed it's stamp and ink colour a lot over the years. It is clear that the library wants to maintain the books and make them last since many of the paperback books have a plastic covering on the outside.
The majority of libraries organize themselves using the Dewey Decimal Classification System. There are ten broad categories in this system such as arts and religion. Since colleges and universities typically have an even broader spectrum of topics, they use the Library of Congress Classification System which is the system the Douglas College library uses. On the bottom of the spine of each book you will find an abbreviation of the topic and the initial of the authors last name which makes up the call number. The bottom line is the publication date. An example would look something like this: BJ 1496 L476 2009 With this system, similar topics are grouped together which makes finding books much easier. If a library was organized at random it would take hours to find a book you are looking for.
If someone were to discover this library in the future there would be some things they would need to know. First of all, topics are grouped into sections. Once you find the section that your book will be under it shouldn't take you too much longer to find the book. I would also describe to them how the Library of Congress system works. But, when in doubt, use one of the computers in the library to find a book you are looking for or ask a librarian.

The library marks books in various ways with library barcodes, library name, and some form of the Dewey decimal classification system. These methods create an identification tool for the property of the library. Looking at my own books, there is only the barcode that came on the book when it was printed. The books on my bookshelves are organized into genres like the library but we did not add a classification system to organize it. There are no names on the bottom of my books. However on children’s books that belonged to my brother or I, contain our names on the first page of the book. This was to identify that the book belonged to us when we had to take a book to school. The difference between personal and public books is the name to which the book is identified by. A public library name on a book means that the book has been seen by many people with that membership and a book with one person’s name or no name is either private use or family use. The organization of the library, like my own, has the principle idea of organizing the books by the type of usage they may go through and the content to which they keep. Books for research will all be in the same section of the library and organized by subject and type of content. The Douglas College library, in some ways has this type of organization. The library is divided up into sections through the use of numbers which is reflected first in the Dewey Decimal system and represents the type of information in the book. The letters then represent the author or publisher. In many ways this relates to how Mr.Penumbra keeps his bookstore. In the back of the bookstore, Mr.Penumbra keeps books with a different contents and usage from those at the front of the bookstore. This type of organization in the bookstore reflects that of the library and sections that are for those with a membership and those without. The setup of Mr.Penumbras bookstore makes the story compelling because it peeks the interest of belonging, in the sense of books and the type of people using them. It compels the reader to ask what type of people get to view these books and why the store is assembled the way it is.

My book has multiple markings on it; the most obvious ones are the ones that let the individual know that it is a library book. The book has a Douglas College Library stamp on the bottom of the book, the stamp is very faded and difficult to recognize and read. This suggests that this book was purchased many years ago since the stamp on it is no longer legible. The book also has the little pouch on the first page for bookmarks and most new books in libraries no longer have that present as well. The pages on my book are yellowish colour with staining towards the edge of the pages, which further demonstrates how long ago this book was purchased.
