The book has no cover image, it is just a plain blue hardcover book. Due to it lacking an image on the cover and the bright colour of its cover, it makes it a novel that will stand out. Most people would stop and look at it out of curiosity to see what it is about, as it doesn’t even have the title of the book on the cover. My book is a children’s book, which is probably why it has a bright cover compared to the normal dark colours most novels have. Although it has no images on the cover, the book itself has plenty of images inside that would suggest to someone just skimming through the pages that it is a children’s novel. The font in the book is larger compared to normal novels since its most likely easier for the children to read it. Also it’s composed of short stories rather than one large story with chapters, since children usually read short stories. I think the library organizes itself by genre, since I found this novel with other children’s book. Also when I was looking for another novel it was with other classic novels, so I am assuming that the library is set up according the genre of the books. Mr. Penumbra’s 24-Hour Bookstore uses these decoding methods to make it interesting for the reader. They point out marks that are obvious or we would not be able to put together until it is mentioned and that keeps the reader guessing.

When looking at several books at the library the first thing I noticed was the barcode on the top of the books. Each Douglas library book was given a barcode with the digits starting with 1 5400. I assumed this meant that the book belongs to Douglas College. I’m guessing this lets the library know who checked a book out and when a book is checked back in. After looking into the books I also noticed a Douglas College stamp that’s somewhere at the start of the book, usually on the top corner of the first couple of pages. Just from this it’s easy to understand that the book belongs to Douglas College. When opening the books I noticed that some had a pouch but nothing inside. From what I remember the pouches were used as a check out sheet but as new technology came in I guess this wasn’t needed anymore but it could also be what the example showed, historical mark that shows the books age. When analyzing the spine of the books I saw certain number and letters a book was given. At first I wasn’t too sure what this meant for I rarely go into our school library to read. I later found out it was a way of how the library organized itself. The code would first have a letter, for example “GV” which was books about physical education. Afterward a number is stated below then a number/letter code and then the year it was published. With this it’s easier to find book in a certain genre. One last thing I noticed was another stamp with a date and a year. This maybe indicates when the book was purchased?
When analyzing one book I came across some pencil marks. From the looks of it a student was studying fitness fundamentals. Key points in the text where underlined such as “aerobics means using oxygen”. After flipping a few pages after I found an old receipt with other books that focuses on fitness and health, being checked out all at once. This gave me the assumption that the student had an interest into health and fitness and could be in sport science.

When looking at the various books I have taken out from a library, I notice that they’re marked by barcodes in the front page. This is for the purpose of the library so the books can be scanned and be kept tracked of and to update the library’s system about the inventory status of the book. I also noticed in the first couple of pages of the books there are dates stamped which indicates when the books were received by the library. An interesting mark I found in a book was the top corner of the certain pages were folded which I assume was used as a book marker by a previous reader. And in some books the pages were also ripped and appeared more worn than others. I can assume that the books that look worn and have ripped pages have been read more.
The books also have letters on the spine of the book which is used in reference to the type, and section of the books. This is a way for the library to organize their books and a way for people to easily find the books they are looking for. The letters and /or numbers correspond to specific genre and types of books thus making it simple for someone to find the specific books or books within that genre or specific subject. Mr. Penumbra’s 24-bookstore uses similar conventions by the way his book store is set up and also how Clay uses the Mac plus to find certain books requested. The book store also has members like how a library has members, and in Mr. Penumbra’s 24-hour bookstore its members uses a card with letters and numbers just like how a member of the library would use a library card. The story is compelling because of the mystery and adventure elements and how the story shows the progression use of technology from the beginning of the book till the end. From Clay starting his job at the bookstore, Clay’s quest to break a code in a book, to the actual decoding of the book.

The first thing I stopped to think about as I started walking through the aisles of books in the library was how organized and systematic they were. I noticed how they were all in rows assigned from left to right, placed upright side by side to one another, except in the case where a few books were too tall for the shelf and had to be placed sideways. The first visible code from a majority of the books was the Dewey Decimal barcode taped onto the spine on the books. I happened to be looking in the 700 section of the library, which encodes for Arts and Recreation, where I found a book on rites of passage.
The book was marked in several ways, first and foremost with the call number of HQ 796 K487 1977. Secondly, I opened it up and saw the pocket on the first page. It was however only partially there as it seems like someone has previously tried to rip it out since it was of no use anymore. Back in elementary school when I signed out books from our school library, filling out my name on the little card was my favourite part. Another mark I saw on the book was “doggy ears”, or every English instructor’s worst nightmare. Users in the past didn’t have a bookmark, a scrap peeve of paper, or even a paper clip to mark where they were up to reading the book, so they felt the need to ruin the pages by flipping over the top right bit, by a couple centimetres, to do the job. The book was over three hundred pages so it might not have been something someone wanted to read all at once.
The underlying code for the books organization as mentioned is the Dewey Decimal Classification, a numerical system for organizing nonfiction books based on ten different subject categories numbered 000’s; 100’s; 200’s and so on. Within the ten different categories lie subcategories, which are decoded by the second two digits, ei: 123. The conventions used in Mr. Penumbra’s 24 Hour Bookstore makes the books compelling because it not only the books themselves that tell the story of old knowledge, but their sequencing and unlocking them in that sequence.

Having seen a variety of books on the shelves, I've noticed that some books had a brighter and sharper countenance than the others. This suggests that the brighter looking ones were more recently bought or less used than those with a darker appeal in colour. I've also noticed the complex and complicated numerical and alphabetical coding on the spines of the books. I suspect that this is done to group them according to the topics which they cover, followed by other numbers for titles and volumes of the books.
One particular book that I had picked out of the shelf is called the "Bread and Roses." It doesn't have any "Douglas Library" stamp anywhere. This suggests that this book was probably purchased before they started stamping the books, or they merely forgot or missed stamping it. Also, the book hasn't been used much as it is still really stiff in structure when you open it.

For this module, I went to the library looking for books that had some sort of markings in order to learn more about their history. All of the books in the library had a bar code sticker, usually taped on one of the covers. The sticker has ‘Douglas College Library’ written above the bar code, and a series of numbers below it. This bar code sticker is scanned when checking out a book, resulting in the book’s information to appear from the library database. The library database, or catalogue, allows one to determine whether or not a book is available, where it can be found and when it is expected to return, thus proving to be an organizational tool. In addition to the bar code sticker, the inside cover of my book has a small, empty pouch. This pouch was once used for signing out books - or at least that’s how I remember it during elementary school! There would be an index card where you would write your name and the date you borrowed it and it would be kept inside the pouch. This is a much older technique that does not require the use of computers which allows one to assume that this book has been around for more than a decade. This assumption can be further proved by the remnants of another sticker on the inside cover with the date September 27th 1978 stamped under the heading ‘Due Date’. Not only does this stamp give a rough estimation of how old the book is, it also demonstrates another example of an organizational technique used when technology was not the go-to option. Overall, the book itself seems to be in good condition, perhaps as a result of insignificant use, but regardless it carries some clues to its history.

The books I analyzed in the library all had markings on them, with some markings on everyone and others having very unique markings. All the books in the library I saw had bar codes on the outside and each had their own Douglas College stamp. The bar code gives the book a tracking number for the library computer system while the stamp shows that it belongs to Douglas College. The books also all had letters with number on the side that are organized alphabetically so readers can find books very efficiently just like the system Clay used in the bookstore. Through seeing both newer and older much more worn books I could see many differences in the markings. The older books were the ones that tended to have more unique markings. Many of the old books had a pouch inside of them with one book I looked at dating back to 1982. Other books had writing in them, worn out pages, ripped pages, water spots, and even highlighted pages indicating that they have been used significantly by past readers. These marks can tell us the history of how old some of these books may be, the audience from what genre the book is, and the context of what the book may be about.
The Library at Douglas organizes itself into sections such as non-fiction and fiction and the further into categories such as policing or the history of Canada. Books that are next to each other have very similar content. Everything is organized with the alphabetical code system that makes it easy for readers to find the book they are looking for. If I was discovering the library in the future some rules I would suggest to them that certain genres or categories are placed in the same sections just like the bookstore in the novel. However, with Mr. Penumbra’s bookstore it sections the books into where the back of store has the books normal people wouldn’t be interested in and only certain people (Unbroken Spine members) get to see it. It makes the story compelling because the reader wants to know the context behind the books and why these people are the only ones who get to see these mysteriously hidden books. Who knows what could be hiding in the Douglas College Library.

Looking through the library bookshelves, I found several specific markings on books that caught my attention. I could piece together a story from older books before that of new ones since they are little more than glossy covers and crisp pages. Their placement in the library tells what kind of book they are, normally by genre and alphabetically by author. Their spine gives us an idea of what the book is about, displaying the title and usually the writer. However, the wreckage of the book is where the magic happens. One novel was obviously ancient because it was hanging together with no more than masking-tape and lamination. Another had doodles all over the cover and the inner pages, indicating that a prior user was somewhat disrespectful of both the author and the college itself. It’s important to be observant of the context in which something remains in order to gather as much information as possible.
Many of the books have interesting titles to draw individuals in. They also create captivating covers that spike one’s interest and force you to pick up the book and start reading. Mr. Penumbra’s 24-Hour Bookstore, for example, compels readers by way of the title and by the first few sentences of chapter one. The writer makes the introductory paragraph very exciting so you are unable to put the book down and are seduced into reading further. And, who wouldn’t want to read about a 24-hour bookstore whose owner has a unique name like Penumbra?
In the Douglas College library, I made quick assumptions almost right away of the content of the racks. The books are expected to be educational and used for school purposes. I would have thought that all the books would be presenting intelligent topics or be stories used in classes. However, upon my visit, I noticed many leisurely novels such as Holes and even the Twilight series. I was somewhat surprised and thrown off by the presence of these titles in a college library which indicated the expectations that I held for its contents. Thinking about it now, the purpose of libraries are to promote reading. Thus, if all the college books were used for classes only, there would be little selection for those who just want to read for fun.

I only had one book taken out from the library for my educational psychology class. I noticed the standard, obvious bar code on both the front cover and edge of the book. The edges are worn out and had a couple of post it notes peeking out from the top, along with tons of underlining and highlighting which tells me that the person or people before me actually made good use of the book while studying. Although since it's to be returned there wasn't much care for the book. Since it's mainly used by college students for classes I had already assumed it would be pretty worn out and the highlighting inevitable. - Then I looked at the books my younger brothers had taken out from their school library, which had the little cards and pockets on the inside of the front cover detailing each sign out. A few of the books had doodles, which again, is expected from elementary school students. I figured their conditions wouldn't be the greatest, but to my surprise they have taken care of the books very well. The most used system is the dewey decimal classification, but if all the books were categorized alphabetically and by genre it would be the easiest way to remember where the books are located no matter what time period we are in. Mr.Penumbra's bookstore was more interesting because there was an entire section unknown to the public eye, and only a certain few people were able to take them out This strikes curiosity which made the book compelling. How could have they been admitted to Mr.Penumbra's library? They must have had a completely different set of barcodes (if any at all) in order for the unbroken spine members to be the only ones to be able to take them out. Over all, this was frustrating because I don' t have a knack for detail and this made me impatient.

The books in the library are shelved according to the Dewey Decimal System, as others have mentioned.. this system sorts books by their genre (fiction vs non-fiction, and progressively more narrow) and are assigned a corresponding number. Within a similar subject matter, they are sorted by author and titles.
The books I found weren't marked too much on the pages by readers, but it was easy to see where the most read sections of the book were, judging by the wear on the spine and the subtle ways the edges of the pages were worn and discolored. I'd say from my assumptions of the readers that they were respectful of the text and/or the fact that it wasn't their property and therefore didn't chose to mark up the text. Perhaps they photocopied sections they needed.
I'm really not sure how I would create rules to disentangle the library in the future because I already know how the library works. I might try to map out where each type of subject matter is stored with a floor plan and try to determine which number/letter combination was similar between books of the same subject, then I would probably try to refine sub-categories within those areas and see which letter/number combos related to that. It makes sense because I've always seen books organized that way, and it's similar to how I organize my books at home.
In Penumbra's 24-Hour Bookstore, he sorts things by genre as well, but uses different criteria for it. The "regular" books that would be bought/sold in a normal bookstore are at the front of the store and sorted on different shelves; the special codex vitae books are all towards the back and are strictly for borrowing. I'm curious about whether the books are shelved according to chronology, name/author or something else (judging from the data visualisation Clay created that showed the face when he put in the data about which books were taken out). I wonder if there are some books in that store (and in the college library) that will never be borrowed or read at all

While observing the variety of different books in the Douglas College Library, I noticed they were all marked up, some were marked up similarly and others were marked up differently, but every type of mark had its own purpose. First of all, every book comes with a barcode in the top left corner. Of all the books I saw, the first five numbers of each barcode were the same, 15400. The rationality behind this same number at the start of each barcode is so that when it is scanned, it will automatically be recognized as a product of the Douglas College Library. Secondly, the majority of the books in the library come with a “Douglas College Library” stamp on the top. The stamps come in all sorts of colours and fonts, but mostly tend to be either black, red, or blue. This is to indicate the various different times of arrivals of these books, since if they came in at the same time, they would be stamped with the same colour and font. Also, some of the books come with a pouch on the first page, however these books tend to be the older ones and we can use these pouches to guess the age of the book.
The library seems to use the Dewey Decimal system to organize their vast collection of books. In the bottom left corner of the books, there is a white sticker, each containing four lines. For example, BL 240 R877 1961. The last line is the year of publication and the second line is a number grouped into hundreds. Each of these groups of hundreds numbers serves the purpose of indicating the genre of the book, such as history, technology, or philosophy.
If I were to rediscover the Douglas College Library in the distant future, I would hope that some new rules would have been implemented. Personally I think that books should be organized in categories first based on genre, and then based on author’s name in alphabetical order, and last but not least, separated by century of publication, so it would be easier to find old knowledge on different shelves instead of being mixed in with more recent books.

After searching through various books, I found some check out receipts that were left in some of them. Some of these dated as far back as 2003. This is a possible indication that those books don't get checked out frequently, but this is not certain. However, all the check out receipts showed multiple books in the same subjects. This gives a possible clue as to the audience of those books i.e history majors, perhaps, checking out multiple books on history. One check out receipt listen two books that were both available in the library at the time.Both books had pages highlighted in yellow marking. It appears staff members also wrote, in pen, inside the book, to indicate that the highlighting was noticed March 2004. The check out receipt for those books showed that the items were due March.2003. This is an indication that the same people could likely be highlighting multiple books in the same way, while checked out at the same time. Other books I saw were highlighted differently; some had post it notes left inside, and others had passages underlined in pencil.
As for Douglas library specific markings, red ink seems to commonly identify the year 1995, but not always, and the year 1995 often contain pouches inside the books.
The library uses an alphanumeric system to group the same subjects together. The numbers and letters themselves are ambiguous but they indicate a specific location where items can be found.

I noticed that the majority of the books in the library at Douglas were fairly old. I found this out because the books that were older had yellowed pages at the edges and had bent corners. The fiction section seemed to have the most use because the books were worn out and some had rips taped up. I like the worn out books because they’ve been taken out a lot so the stories are probably good. I found the section with the encyclopedias and they had a lot of dust on them. This is probably because students do not go to this section when they have a multiple sets of encyclopedias on their phones and computers. There were some magazines hidden in the back of the library probably because they are also available online. It seemed that items that could not be found easily online, like novels, were near the front of the library and the items that could be online were in the back of the library.
People make a lot of assumption about reading whether they want to or not. The most popular assumption is the classic saying “don’t judge a book by its cover.” Even though everyone knows not to do this, they can’t help but be slightly more interested in books with exciting covers. As well, most the time as readers are reading, they are constantly trying to figure out the climax of the story. The best kind of stories are the ones that keep you second guessing your assumptions with new clues to what the resolution to the conflict in the story will be. This will keep your reader interested in a book. The setting of a story can also change the assumptions of the reader. “The Bug” is a good example of this because the setting is in a computer programmers mind so the reader might initially think that the story line will be very logical and bland. With further reading they will find the story line that is very enticing.

For this weeks task I chose books from the coquitlam library that I found to be marked up differently than some of the others. For example, at this public library there are different sections marked off for targeted audiences such as the teen section, kiddie corner etc. I noticed right away that the books in the kids section were almost all laminated with crinkled edges and bright coloured animations on the covers. The ones tucked away and lined up tightly together were situated on the back shelves. From the context, since the covers weren't on display, and once the books were pulled out and the covers had faded pictures with a brown tinge to them, it implied they had been there for some time and that kids didn't find these books as popular anymore. You could also tell these books on the back shelves were old due to the pockets on the first page that have cards that used to be for writing your name and date on before signing out a book. I remember doing this in elementary school however it is not required to do so anymore. Another section was the self help section and one of the books I chose belonged to the "How to.. for dummies" series. These books are marked with bright yellow and black markings on the cover and are commonly known for helping people complete tasks in the simplest way possible. The one I picked up In particular was for help with using Microsoft office, you could tell a lot of people didn't know how to use this program because the pages were bent, indicating people wanted to save the spot they were reading. some parts were highlighted, indicating that those sections in particular were important (even though i'm pretty sure you're not allowed to mark up a library book) but either way the condition it was left in showed traces of someone who had trouble understanding their software and marked up the book to help them understand. I noticed that one section of the library had books marked up with numbers and letters, aka the dewey decimal system that has been mentioned so I wont repeat it again and the other half was only organized alphabetically by author. Honestly, I find the dewey decimal system to be confusing and feel like alphabetically arranging books makes more sense, especially by author. If I had to help people from the future find OK, I would explain how computers can search by keywords and authors within that database to find any book that the library has. This task definitely made me realize I need to go to the library more often.. just like in Penumbras 24 hr bookstore there is a lot of old knowledge to bring out of the bookshelves.

In some of the dictionaries I was looking at they were all marked up, different uses of specific words were underlined and starred. The hard cover of books looked like they have seen better days, as the edges were folded in and the paper has started to tare. Some of the books I was looking at were not all the same height or width, even though they may be about the same thing written by different authors, each had different amount of information. This reminded me when Clay was in the underground library in New York and was searching for Penumbras codex vitae and he noticed that all the other bound members of the “cult” had their books small, tall, skinny, and large etc. I found some books were very dusty and old to the point where the paper has turned a yellow color that indicated they are quite old.
The reference section interested me the most because of all the history and information there was and how organized it was. Every date was in exact order. In old news articles/journals some of the pages were torn and ripped up, meaning in that particular time many people used it as a reference or an event/person was popular and everyone was reading about it.. In some areas of the library I noticed a lot of the books were organized in periodical manner that reminded me of Penumbras book store and the waybacklist. The library organizes itself by numbers and barcodes. I noticed the barcode for Douglas college started with “1 5400” indicating that all books belonging to Douglas start with that number. Also the library seemed to be set up into different genres.
For this lab I thought it was different but at the same time it made me realize and make a connection with Mr. Penumbras 24 Hour Bookstore that every single book is different in it’s own way (obviously) but some say there are good books and bad books but, are there really though? I mean people put their all into books and write for reasons us as readers may not understand.

When going through the library I went to the biology section first and found a lot of thicker books with hard covers. These gave me clear indications that they were text books. Also when you went to open these text books in a few of them I found some sticky notes stuck to certain pages with notes on them reminding the person of what was on the page and paraphrasing what they were learning. You can tell that the people who borrowed these books from the library were studying or trying to learn new subjects with great deal of focus from all the notes you see everywhere rather than reading them for pleasure. In the older, more used textbooks I found a few with writing directly on the pages and people had highlighted important parts on certain pages. I also went to another section that was filled with older novels, and you could tell they were older from the colour that they had turned a tinge of yellow from sitting on the shelves and for being used after so many years. There were a few books that had coffee stains and the paper back books had bends in the cover and creases. You can tell that these books had been used a lot from the wear and tear compared to some of the newer ones that barely even look like they've been touched or moved at all. I also went to a section in the library where I found blue dots on all the labels along with letters and numbers. I knew that the letters and numbers on the labels of the spine corresponded to the dewey decimal system, but the blue dots indicated that the books were not in english but in French. This was helpful in the sense that if you knew you were looking for a novel in French you can just automatically look for the blue dot on the spine of the book and it narrows down your search a lot. Like most libraries it is organized by the Dewey Decimal system. Even though I personally find it confusing to try and learn it, since I am not in libraries all that often, it is useful that all the libraries around where I live use the same system. If I were to try and help someone look up old knowledge in the future this could come in handy since you only need to explain it once in one library and almost every other one that they go to it will be the same system. If I could I would make the organization a little less complicated. Rather than using letters and numbers I would probably just go alphabetically since everyone knows the alphabet and it would be easy to look books up if you know the title, only downside though subjects of the same genre wouldn’t be in the same section like it is now with the Dewey Decimal system.

A couple of the books I borrowed were drawn from Tommy Douglas Library. These books have different markings compared to the ones from Douglas College Library. These ones have numbers at the bottom indicating its location according to genre located at the spine of the books. Under these numbers, the first three letters of the author’s surname is also provided for readers to easily locate where these books might be. A particular book actually has a black dot, with the author’s surname, indicating that it’s from the teenage or young adult book section of the library. Aside from the barcode stickers at the front of the books, they also have the “Burnaby Public Library” stamp at the top. Each book also has different fonts, thus bought at different years; some have it very bold and striking, while others are extremely thin to the point where I can’t see some of the letters. One book in particular has a stamp on the first page, it indicates that the book was withdrawn, and I believe that this book is actually free since after scanning the book out, the librarian blocked out the barcode with a black marker. Perhaps the book had to be liquidated for a better copy? Considering its paper is truly yellow stained and its cover’s battered state. Or maybe, the library needed space for a better book? Either way I felt sad for the book for some reason, it felt as if it lost its home; the place where it used to live since it was stamped last June of 1999. I’m guessing Penumbra and the cult-of-black-robed-New-Yorkers felt the same way I did whenever someone’s life or book was burned in the library. Mr. Penumbra’s 24 Hour Bookstore used codes similar to our libraries today to make the story compelling with how the books are uniquely named: very uncommon and hard to pronounce book titles. Aside from the uncommon names, these books have their letter U’s spelled as V’s, it separates the books that are being encoded for the answer to eternal life than the ones that are for sale and ordinary ones.

The books are marked differently, not all, but most. I suspect it is because of the material the library has on hand to use to mark books; However, the books in the library have a basic marking on the side of the book: the first two letters of the author’s last name and serial number. The marking of books change as technology changes as the little pouch in books were replaced with barcodes to scan and record with efficiency instead of getting the card, signing your name/date, having the librarian record it into logs… yatayatayata. TK is, most of the time, faster than OK, but can be faster than either if they are balances, and the library can parallel with the book. It can take a person five minutes at most to find and sign out a book by using TK and OK instead of having errors for TK and time inefficiency for OK. It is important to know most of us want “things” as fast a possible. If you were hungry, would you want your food at restaurant in five minutes, or thirty minutes (assuming the food is equal in quality)? I think the context is time, and the economy dwindling because of TK. Take for instance people are losing jobs because of machines (e.g. ATM’s, self-serve machines in grocery stores, etc.) that do a better job than people; However Clay was able to crack a code that thousands of computers could not crack, and sheds light to OK by finding a balance between the two knowledge’s. Anyways, That is my intake on “decoding” the book and the assignment you have given us.

The context of where we find the text tells you something about the targeted readers for the book of choice. If you were to target intellectuals you would aim to gain a spot upon a library or college shelves, whereas magazines such as GLAM and such are not targeting intellectuals per say, but the materialistic individuals whom enjoy light reading and getting caught up within the gossip of the superstar world. Not only does the context of where we find a book give us insight to the targeted readers, but also to how we will approach the text itself. If I were to find a book in 7 – 11 I may not even give it a second thought to picking it up and reading it just because of the context in which I had found it in. Whereas if I were to find the same book at say a Chapters under Heathers Picks I may pick it up and scan a few pages. That may be because I am a book snob, or I would relate it more towards the place in where I encountered the book. As well as where a book is spotted, upon the covers of the books are the titles in which there may also be illustrations giving the reader some insight to the style or content of the book and draw readers in. For example harlequin romances often feature a picture of a woman’s figure that some would find enticing, luring in their readers with visual aesthetics. As well the covers of books done by multiple authors tend to follow the same style, almost like the authors signature on the outside of the book, claiming it as one of their creations. At least that’s what I think, it could totally be that the publishers have domain over the visual creations for the books and the publishers are the ones marking the covers in their choice of font, colour and visual style. Either way book with the same authors tends to have similar “markings” upon their covers.
Courtney Wilson

item.title: View Source Module (Week 3)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Instructions: Due for the Jan. 28th class. This module is about looking behind the surfaces so that you are aware of different ways of approaching things--in others words: perspective. It's also about how our point-of-view (POV) informs how we understand texts, create meaning in them, and decipher what might lie under the surfaces (what might a character really mean when they talk about something? What might the symbolic meaning be and why is that symbolic meaning even there?

Perspective and point-of-view are character-based approaches to interpreting texts, something we'll get to more next week, but it's always helpful to be aware of your own point-of-view or perspective when it comes to thinking about how you read or interpret a text. This awareness of your own perspective ties in nicely with your awareness of context, narrative, and setting in that how you understand context, narrative, and setting is informed by your perspective (or the character's perspective). Understanding your point-of-view or perspective lows you to more acutely understand the perspective or point-of-view in the narrative when you need to write essays or decipher symbolic meaning. As I noted last class, all of these things are tied up in our expectations for the text we are reading. Understanding our perspective allows us to be more accountable to our expectations.

In sum, now that we understand how things are "marked" (setting) and "put together" (narrative), we need to think about about why and how they are marked or put together the way they are. In other words, what are the character's motivations for telling the story the way they have? What does the narrator expect the reader to know already and why do s/he expect that? What assumptions does the narrator assume which are informed by the setting in which he is telling the story (think about time/space here--why tell the story in the past tense? Or the present tense? for instance.)

The narrative point-of-view then tells us a lot about what the narrator knows and the choices s/he is making when they re-tell the story they are telling. They can choose to emphasize certain things (repeated symbols) or leave out things (who is Grumble anyway? why didn't we find out Penumbra was a ex-computer whiz until the end?).

When we read, we are always interpreting by looking beyond surfaces ("Is that egg salad sandwich fresh?" "That shirt looks really nice, bet it's expensive"). In this module we'll look under the surface of websites and think about how our perspective of the web is dependant on our point-or-view.

Summary: Task: As we reviewed in class, right-click (or ctrl-click) in your browser without highlighting the page and click on ""view page source" or "view source" (in Chrome, Firefox and IE). It's complicated in Safari (https://discussions.apple.com/thread/4325736). You will then see a whole bunch of code. Pick a website you visit frequently. Avoid plain, single-purpose sites like Google; they don't show a lot. You might want to try a few Douglas College webpages.

Outcomes: Think about how your perspective of websites (the WYSIWYG experience of viewing them) is completely different than how they are coded (what the computer reads). Think about how this dichotomy plays out in the conflict between old knowledge and new knowledge in Mr. Penumbra's 24-Hour Bookstore:

  • Describe how the code looks to you. Does it add anything to your experience of the website itself?
  • How does the webpage organize itself? What are the underlying principles behind the organizing system and who or what does the deciphering, and from what perspective?
  • Think about the experience of "reading" a web page. Who or what is "reading" it and how are they / it processing that reading? In other words, by encoding the website a certain way, an html coder tells the browser how to read it, or display / organize the information. What does this say about the role a coder's perspective plays in how you receive information on a website?
  • How does Mr. Penumbra's 24-Hour Bookstore highlight to social conventions of coding and coders while obscuring the real drudgery that goes on behind the scenes (to say nothing of the actual level of technical expertise?

Takeaways:

  • Avoid being unaware of your own perspective or the character's perspective. Everyone has a point-of-view that informs how a story is read and processed.
  • Pay attention to how things are organized and presented to you. What things (characters, ideas, symbols, objects) are presented to you repeatedly, at key moments, to obscure, to highlight, etc.
  • Remember that POV is often determined by cultural perspective. Identifying the POV of a novel can tell us lots about the main characters, the narrative, the setting, and the assumptions that go into organizing and telling the story.
  • POV is as much about how we read the story as it is about how we see the story being told to us. Try to account for how things are withheld, revealed, obscured, undeveloped, etc., and figure out why that is the case. What's the story NOT telling us in order to TELL us.

Task, Reminder: Remember to respond to some of the questions above (in “Outcomes”) in the comment space below. Make sure you are logged in. Refer to the course procedures page — the “Work Away from Class” section — if you’re confused about what you are supposed to be doing in the comment space below.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I went to http://education-portal.com/academy/lesson/binary-language-of-computers-definition-lesson-quiz.html and viewed the source code. The code looks different, in terms of presentation, compared to the webpage. The code looks to be ten to twenty times the size of the webpage; Moreover, there are links that lead to more codes. Why is the code large, yet, the webpage is small? There must be a giant story behind every solution. The website has a mission and biography, (http://education-portal.com/pages/About_Us.html) to give free education… and to be remembered. A team of people created many complex scripts, to obtain most likely money, or recognition. I feel this collates with Clay because he’s telling a story about his experience being a clerk in a bookstore, while giving limited knowledge along the way. Take for instance how he tells the audience about Kat wearing a red shirt all the time, when later in his STORY and in point of view, we learn about her having several of the same shirts. I feel Clay limits the knowledge he conveys to the audience, because he wants to be close immortal as possible, an excuse to tell a story from how he experienced his adventure for the first time. I think the closest thing to immortality is leaving a legacy behind. Clay did just that. He told his story to thirty-eight students and a teacher to an English Lit. Class, and to thousands of other readers. There’s a good chance he won’t be remembered after this class is over, but at least he told us an adventurous legacy of decoding someone who left a legacy to be decoded, and will be remembered by some people. Moffat also leaves his story in his “Dragon Song Chronicles”, coded. We were a told a story in his prospective. Clay became as immortal as anyone can ever get. I think one of many messages Robin Sloan conveys is immortality can never be achieved, but leave a legacy behind and become remembered to merit pseudo-immortality.

The code has a generous amount of symbols, with occasional words that are in English and some that seem to be random letters jumbled together. There are some words in blue, some red and occasionally there are black. I find this incredibly complicated to follow, mostly because this is new knowledge to me. The only thing that is added to my experience of the website itself is appreciation for the people who must’ve spent hours putting this together. The experience of ‘reading’ a webpage is clearly more complex and time consuming for the programmer than it is for the intended audience. The page I chose for example was one from the Douglas College website- an FAQ page. The audience for this page would be prospective or current students who have questions and/or are trying to find information. When reading the webpage from the student’s point of view, the student sees information in paragraphs that is logical and easily comprehended. There are bolded titles, green boxes with the Douglas logo, overall a concise list of answers that is a breeze to scroll through and find what they are looking for. From the programmer’s point of view, there are so many tedious symbols that have to go in a particular order and they read the web page in a way that will look logical from their perspective. Clearly each symbol, colour and letter needs to be in its specific spot or the final webpage will not be correct. Reading from the programmer’s perspective shows they have to apply their understanding of new knowledge to make their codes correct and then that will allow the codes to tell the browser how to read it and display the information properly. Clearly from the programmer’s point of view, reading a webpage is a complicated task that must be done in a precise manner. It involves reading code which isn’t something that everyone understands. From the student’s point of view, rarely do they take into consideration all the codes that are present and needed to make the webpage exist, and often just read through like any other material.

I found that the code of the webpage Netflix was in black, blue, and red and the dominant colour was different for each section of writing. The coding takes away from the positive experience of a website. Websites are supposed to be easy to follow and appealing to the eye whereas the code is the opposite of that. Unless the reader has experience in computer programming, the decoding is impossible. Since the creator of Netflix wants a popular use of their website, they will change the appearance to be easily navigated by anyone. The website is full of pictures and few words to draw in the viewer and help them understand what is available to watch. By withholding the code, the user will be able to control the website with ease. I also tried to click on some of the links on the page with the code to find out where they connected. It was cool to see that the code is the same as the website but just has a different appearance. The pictures that are on the original Netflix page are just turned into code. As well, the links to the movies were hidden in the code. Some links connected to pages with just more code, which really shows the amount of work that had to be put into the design of the webpage. There were large spaces between the coding sections so I clicked on links in multiple sections and it seemed that the code was spaced out according to different categories on the webpage. The website is very organized and easy to use. On the home page there are categories of movies that can be scrolled through as well as a search bar and a browse tab for further searching. My take away from this module is that withholding information can change the appearance and appeal of a website like the POV in a novel can change the mood and the moral of the story.

The website I chose to analyze the code is Facebook. This online social media service has a simple to use setup that makes it easy for people to browse other profiles, exchange messages, post photos and status updates, share videos, etc all in one website. Its pretty crazy to think how hard it would be to make a setup to have all those different features work. Looking at the code gives me another perspective of how the website functions. The code seems to be sectioned with about three lines each I'm guessing for each different post. None of the words in these sections make sense to me, but I can see how each section represents each different post and allows the website to have a simple organized set up for its users to use. Seeing the amount of work it takes to allow Facebook users such as myself have straightforward quality experience makes me appreciate the long hours it must take to make these codes work so the website can function. The role that a coder has in having the user of the webpage receive the information clearly is critical. The coder for example with Facebook has to know how to communicate codes to the browser so that users of the website can use all the features distinctly. The coder must have to use the perspective of a user so they can organize to codes so the website can be displayed to both function and be appealing to use.
With Mr. Penumbra’s 24 Hour Bookstore we can see the countless years of hard work it took members of the Unbroken Spine to attempt at deciphering the code. The story highlights the viewpoint of the coders in there struggle to attempt to solve this 500 year mystery. Clay’s “new knowledge” perspective allows him to solve the code through the use of modern technology to find the meaning behind the Manutius. This novel truly gives the readers the drudgery of coding and the amazing things that can be created from it.

As I study the code of the Douglas College website it appears to be very complex and confusing. There is a section at the top where the "DOCTYPE" and "html class" is described. When I scroll over the html class the whole webpage becomes highlighted so that part must have to do with the programming of the text on the page. There are only a few English words in the coding; the majority of the code is letters jumbled together. In the bottom half of the code there are two main sections: one describing the element style which include colour and margin information and the other section includes an image of the layout of the webpage. It certainly does not add anything to help me understand the webpage in greater depth. If I was a computer programmer and had background knowledge I would be able to decipher, interpret and probably recognize the code.
The webpage is organized in such a way that the textual elements of the coding section are at the top and the elements of the text are at the bottom on the coding information. A typical webpage organizes itself with having a large title at the top to give the reader an idea of the topic. Then, usually, there are several subheadings that allow the reader to locate information in a more timely manner. The reader (audience) decodes the information on the webpage from their own perspective since information can be portrayed in different ways and can easily be misinterpreted. Since I picked a "Study at Douglas" webpage, the audience would likely be people who are thinking about becoming future students at Douglas College. The website designer and coder play a critical role in displaying the information on a webpage. If not coded properly, the reader could miss information or become confused if the information is not organized and laid out into readable, legible sections. Therefore, it is critical that the coder think as if he was looking at the webpage from a reader's point of view.
Mr. Penumbra's 24-Hour Bookstore relates to the coding of a computer webpage. The member's of the Unbroken Spine have spent countless hours in an attempt to decode the Manutius. It isn't until Clay uses his new knowledge through the use of modern technology that this mystery is solved. Both coding for a webpage and coding of the Manutius takes a lot of tedious work that many people take for granted but when it is complete it sure is a creative work of art.

When looking at the page source of CNN’s website, the code is incredibly overwhelming. You could say it assaults my poor retinas. The code spans the entire width of the page and continues down for a long while. In a way, my experience of the website is heightened, because like Michaela and DNO, I too have found a deeper appreciation for the hard work from the writers, programmers, coders, anyone involved in the creation of such quality work. I could imagine the production of one online story involves a process of collaboration that requires a lot care and meticulousness, while running on a tight schedule.
The coder’s perspective of how a website should look influences users to navigate the website in a certain way. The codes they formulate are essentially translated by the browser so that the user can receive the information in a particular way. They control how users take in the information by encoding it for both the user and the browser to understand. In a way, the coder is the middle man.
Within Mr. Penumbra’s 24-Hour Bookstore, the adventures of Clay and the gang highlight the social conventions of coding and coders. For instance, Clay’s descriptions of utilizing Google’s book scanner and the software Hadoop to miraculously decode a codex plays on how many people view technology- that we all just throw things at Google and it will spit out an answer. The idea of Hadoop itself is extremely complex, beyond the understanding of millions of people, yet Kat gives a very plain explanation in order to keep the story simple for the reader. The book hides the level of expertise required to code and how hard coders work to produce encryptions, websites, or software like Hadoop, etc. I’ll admit, I have no idea of how coding is done, but can imagine that this kind of work requires more than a little brainpower and care.

The code just looks like jibberish to me, with the odd phrase or command thrown in.
The webpage (Youtube) is set up like the typical video/media website. Content of the page is orgaized with the video at the centre, an account panel at the top right, navigation panel at the top, with related and suggested videos on the side. Youtube has a comments section aswell. The code was organized in massive blocks of text with characters such as "is.container).not('#priam_more_friends,.priam_friend_selected'):"
and is broken up with sections of what seems like names for certain features or commands class="watch-secondary-actions yt-uix-button-group" data-button-toggle-group="optional">. I really have no clue.
In the menu on Netflix, there were no breaks in the sections. It was just one massive page of characters and text.
When you "read" a page, you are reading commands from an Html Coder, that was written in code specifically for the page. The browser then takes this code, and then produces another code that we recognize as the user-interface and language.
For example, a symbol going round and round on YouTube means "buffering". A triangle with the point facing to the right, means "Play". Two Vertical bars side by side indicates "Paused".
Mr.Penumbras bookstore really does not relate to the technical level of coding at all, even when Clay was designing his virtual library. At most he just complained in his head about the difficulties, but it didn't show what went into writing code.
Most likely the expectations of the audience was that they were not proficient in coding so they would not be able to appreciate the full level of monotony and repetitive hours that are involved in coding. Secondly, in terms of context, if a large majority of Clay's internal dialogue shifts to complaining about the negative aspects of coding and the technicalities of it ,the focus of conflict perhaps woudnt of been Old knowledge vs New Technology, but perhaps Clay vs Code. Being a first person narrative, this would greatly impact the context of the entire story.

As I clicked on the page source for mmafighting.com the code popped up and there was an explosion of colourful symbols, letters, words, numbers, and links that never seemed to end. There were continuous lines, some broken up and some aligned. As I scrolled down the page it felt like I was in an action movie trying to diffuse a complicated bomb. It is amazing that a person could put all those numbers, letters and symbols together to create such a simple looking and user friendly website. Like others in the comment press I am impressed and have much more appreciation to those who are in the field that work with codes and developing programs and websites we see and use daily. The webpage is organized by a big title at the top of the page and then a bunch of videos and mma news articles as you scroll down the page. The videos and articles are also organized from the recent date being at the top page, while older dates are descending as you scroll down the page. When I looked at both the code and the webpage I can see that some of words in the code match to where they are seen on the webpage. For example, on the code page the title “mmafighting” is right at the top and also on the top on the webpage. Organizing the webpage for readers to simply look at videos and articles in order from the most current date makes it efficient and simple for the readers to use since readers like me want to keep up to date with most current events.
In Mr. Penumbra’s 24 hour bookstore we see that Clay uses his new knowledge to try and decode Manutius, this new knowledge includes using modern technology such as computers, scanners, and google. While members of the unbroken spine choose to use old knowledge which is having members read throughly. We see that the book itself is like a code to a webpage as the code is translated through a browser it shows up as more then words, numbers and symbols. Just like how one of the codex vitae was seen differently once decoded. In the end we see that it takes both new knowledge and old knowledge to solve the code, which shows the importance of both new technology but also still using old knowledge.

For this module, I viewed multiple codes belonging to the websites that I visit frequently and I noticed some differences amongst them. Some websites, such as Facebook, seemed to have what looked like more ‘complex’ codes with numerous rows of mixed up letters, numbers and symbols, none of which were of any understanding to me. However, other websites such as Twitter or 8tracks had more blank space visible, perhaps indicating a simpler code. Our Digital Cultures Lab website was the easiest to comprehend in my opinion because the coding was not difficult to understand. The instructions, the comments and other information visible on the website were easily spotted in the code (as well as some hidden information). As a result of viewing the codes of different websites, the ‘WYSIWYG’ idea makes me realize how something so easy for many of us to use is an extremely well-put together and detailed piece of work done by individuals who not only tailor to the minds of the users, but that of the computer as well. Old knowledge versus new knowledge and how the mind processes information all depends on the point of view of a certain individual. Mr. Penumbra’s 24-Hour Bookstore was narrated by Clay’s character and the readers experienced the story through his perspective. Clay’s personality, his above average knowledge of technology and the fact that he worked at the bookstore all played into his version of the adventure. If this same story was told through Kat’s POV, Penumbra’s POV, or even Corvina’s POV, the references to technology could have been more advanced, more focused on negative attempts or perhaps not even mentioned at all. Similarly, individuals who refrain from using new knowledge may not be able to comprehend something considered quite simple, such as Facebook, whereas those who understand how to maneuver their way around the internet may not know how to decipher a code. Regardless, what an individual considers to be old knowledge and new knowledge seem to be relative to their point of view.

My level of familiarity with HTML Code (HyperText Markup Language) although very basic, gave me some understanding of what exactly I encountered for this module, to which was from the login page of myDouglas. In highscool I took an “Intro to Business Computers” course where we had to make our own coded website, something very simple and what Clay and Kat could likely achieve in a deep slumber.
Looking at the code itself, I notice the different tags, colours – black, blue, purple, red, if-then commands, and links to other pages that will occur with the click of the mouse on a certain symbol. There are series of commands that enable a webpage to display what it does and how it does; a surface layer so easy and trivial to navigate by users versus the complex codes on the deeper layers that make it what it is. The HTML code to me represents the dichotomy of old knowledge and new knowledge in Mr. Penumbra’s 24-Hour Bookstore by Clay, being tech-savvy and capable of unlocking the code that the Unbroken Spine members spent tireless years slowly unfolding. The point of view coming from Clay’s character in the novel is someone that is innovative and looking for simpler ways of getting things done. Until late into the novel, the reader is led to believe that Mr. Penumbra falls directly on the opposite side of that spectrum, in my opinion to further contrast our initial preconceptions with what we see on the surface, versus what something actually is.
The novel does a great job at mentioning truly complex concepts without steering off readers that may have no prior knowledge of. As Maxine (class member, I can do this right?) mentioned in her response, how Kat was able to give a simple explanation for the deep and layered concept of Hadoop. Examples like this, and how for instance Clay coded and stated frustrations that came with the codes, without providing anything too technical that the average reader and non-coder wouldn’t understand. Had there been more complex ideas coming from Clay, it might have taken away from the context of the story itself, since it was a first-person narrative. As a reader we were not too concerned with the actual coding behind Clay’s work, but rather the outcome that occurred as a result of it, much like the experience with a webpage.

For this module, I viewed the source for the front page of www.cimorellimusic.com. The first impression that I got was, "Wow, this is nowhere near as colourful or neat as the page I was just on. The source page is just a bunch of random words in different colours with a couple words from the front page everyone sees, on the code page. It doesn't really add anything to my experience on the website, just confuses me a little bit, but I could appreciate the amount of work that it takes to develop a page that seems so simple.
Everything is placed into categories, for example: the youtube videos for the Cimorelli band are all placed together on the source page, and it is all colour-coded. The underlying principles behind the organizing system is that everything that is of similar code are grouped together so when viewers view the actual webpage, everything will be there neatly for them to view. I believe the website developer develops the codes, and a computer system program automatically deciphers the code, though this, I am not 100% sure.
The role a coder plays in website developing is massive. Even if a computer system program does decipher the code, the coder would still have to provide the program the codes to crack, otherwise there is nothing there for the computer program. Viewing the source page, it also tells us how the coder wanted the viewers to view the website in a certain way, for example: grouping the Youtube videos together, so that provides easy access for the viewers if they are trying to locate the Youtube videos for the band. Looking at the source page, you are able to tell that it takes a series of hard work to develop a website that is easy-to-use for regular computer users just visiting the website, and also makes it that the viewers do not have to look at the source page to find what they are looking for, as that will make it difficult for the average computer user, very quickly.
This is relatable to Mr. Penumbra's 24 Hour Bookstore is how we are told very simply, how Clay develops his virtual library, and how Kat explains how the the program Hadoop, and Google's Book Scanner works, but in a dumb-founded way so that the readers can understand plainly, when in reality, the process, programs, and technology used to achieve such things can be greatly confusing. The same can be found when viewing the source codes for the front page for www.cimorellimusic.com. Out front, we see a webpage that is easy to navigate and use, but inside, there are multiple series of commands, strange symbols such as, "( ), ," etc., and different words and sentences in multiple colours. For something to be made, there is always a series of hard work, and confusing steps that must be taken to achieve such a great work.
When we are reading books and other things, we only pay attention to the things that stand out to us, and don't really pay much attention or thought to the things that seem minor. In Mr. Penumbra's 24 Hour Bookstore, we are given a brief description on how the Google Book Scanner operates, but never a full in-depth explanation, because it is not necessary for the story to advance. But a small explanation does help, that we can relate this to this module. What we see on the outside is nice and easy-to-use, but if we go in deeper into the source codes, it becomes confusing quickly. So, if we just take a quick look at a source code page, we can gather some of the things on it, but most of it will just fade away. And, this helps us to understand what we are viewing, and where the things we view can be found.

I chose to view the coding for the National Hockey League website, as it is one I visit often, and I was surprised to find the equivalent of many pages of coding. This really goes to show how much work it takes to create a website and organize it as desired. Although, the immense amount of coding can come across as overwhelming and complicated at first glance, if you take the time to actually read it, you can start to see how it relates to the website. For example, in the coding of nhl.com, you can see the thirty different NHL teams organized alphabetically. Compared to the coding, the website is far more simple to read and understand, and everything is properly organized into their respective sections making it very easy to navigate the site. To those who are unfamiliar with computers, the coding could seem like an entire new language due to its technical layout of writing. Clearly, coders have to be very thorough when designing a website to ensure optimal usage for visitors. Even just one little mistake could ruin the whole intended layout of the website, as every different section of the page must be correctly linked to its proper next section that should appear after been clicked on. Now when I will read this webpage again in the future, I will be more thankful for the ease of reading that is provided for me and anyone else who uses this website. This is thanks to computers, who will understand coding better than humans ever will. The coding in this website, and many other website relates to Mr. Penumbra’s 24 Hour Bookstore, because in the book, Clay has to decode the codex, and to do so, must count on help from Kat and her team at Google, who require advanced technology in order to do so. This affirms the complexity behind coding, and goes to show the reliance that many people have for computers to make things easier to understand for them.

I went to http://www.buzzfeed.com/ and the source code looks very organized and spaced out just as the website itself. Mr. Penumbra’s bookstore highlights the importance of coding throughout the book. The first website I chose to check out was the Douglas College homepage, the first thing I noticed was that it had columns numbered from 1-871. It all looked like a bunch of gibberish to me, something I don't understand nor have I ever really thought about. The main colours of the code were green, black, blue and dark purple. The blue corresponded to links of any kind that were available, and the rest of the colours were organized in a way I couldn't decipher because I am not a programmer, or know much about technology in general. I noticed how precise it must all have had to be in order to come together so well. The second webpage I decided to look at, in comparison was YouTube, which is a much larger, more advanced site by the looks of the source code. For instance there are 3449 columns for YouTube, the dominant colours were black, and blue for links again I would assume? Then bits of purple. Speaking from my personal experience I don't think many of us put a lot of thought into the pages we visit and the countless, tedious hours spent behind the scenes making it (depending on how advanced the site is) We read/scroll through and from my perspective, for the most part everything I went to the site for is there, well organized. Then again, from a programmers or coders perspective they probably take a closer look at sites, even with habit and can likely point out errors or ways they would have made it differently. They can read and understand the codes whereas I am completely clueless. Mr. Penumbra's Bookstore highlights the importance of both old knowledge vs. new knowledge. The new knowledge like Google's book scanners did the work for you, quickly getting the answers we were looking for. While the members of the Unbroken Spine decoded the books themselves, which is much more time consuming and takes much more knowledge than we credit for. We prefer new knowledge but it's important to maintain all the old knowledge because without it, Clay wouldn't have been able to solve the codex. It is equally important to be able to enjoy the new knowledge, and appreciate the old knowledge.

For this assignment, I decided to view and analyze my twitter homepage’s source code. (https://twitter.com/) When I clicked “View source” on my homepage, a minimized page popped up. The first thing I noticed on the page was a bunch of numbered lines of writing all in different colors made up of red, green, blue and black and because I am no computer genius, I was wondering why there was different colors in this code and if the colors had a different meaning to them. I felt like Clay when he first opened one of the coded books in Penumbra’s bookstore and didn’t have a clue what they meant. Whoever designed this website did an excellent job coding it because the codes look very intricate, organized and extremely long -containing 9053 lines-; also, from experience there is usually no glitches on the website and it is very popular as well. The second thing I notice was that some of the red words in the first section were in different languages (ex. ۜ۞-۪ۨ-ۯۺ-ۼۿݐ) and maybe this code was designed so that people from different countries could use this social media website in their own langue. There was also two words in blue that kept reappearing as I scrolled down: Function and Return; I wondered why these words were used so often, maybe they were key words that represented something on the website. The process of reading this source code was difficult because I seriously have no idea what these phrases, colors and symbols meant and I never thought about how a website works and gets created until this assignment. It is interesting to see the difference of my twitter homepage, as I have always seen it and then the codes that put the website together and make it function. In conclusion, the point of view differs from the users and the coders. The users see a nice blue twitter page with a bunch of random tweets from different people and the coders see a long list of symbols and phrases in different colors that makes the website run.

I chose the Reddit.com and Tumblr.com source codes to look at for this module. They were very different from each other, Reddit had 13 very long lines of code, which looked deceptively simple and happy until I "wrapped" the long lines of text to fit within the text box margins. I looked it up and it's written in a language called Python, which is supposed to be designed to be a simple, forthright and readable type of language. Obviously for people with experience in writing or reading code, which is not me. I think it's probably a very wordy source code in this case, because the whole point of the website is sharing links or text, voting them up or down with a "karma" system, and talking about them. If it were a primarily video or image focused website, then the code would look a lot different. (also as soon as I opened the source code viewer I automatically said TLDR - too long didn't read - to myself) Generally the code gave me the same impression I got of the user-end of the website when I first started using it, very wordy and it takes a bit of time to get use to the organization because my only other experience with website codes was when I dabbled in HTML when I was a youngin'. The Tumblr dashboard source code was a more visually appealing source code to look at. They even arranged 8's o's and other letters and characters to make a text art version of their website name at the top of the page. I don't have to scroll down very far and I see some notes that the designers left about tagging queries that I would never have known exist if it hadn't been for this assignment. In comparison to Reddit, Tumblr uses about 1080 lines in their code and a lot more symbols than letters and recognizable words. Both sites are based around sharing links, text and images, but they take very different approaches in their code.
I think that it's an interesting choice to reveal Penumbra as an ex-computer whiz closer towards the end of the book, because it retro-actively gives some insight into how he might be thinking and reasons why he does things in contrast to the rest of the members of the Unbroken Spine. His office in the book store with all those piles of books and papers and other items are kind of like the source code that shows how he thinks and he himself is the user interface end of Penumbra, so to speak. After thinking about this for a day or two, I've thought of some parallels to experience in my life between Penumbra and my dad. My dad had a study (the basement) that was very like Penumbra's office, piles of books and papers with random old computers... I knew he had a way of organizing it, but it was never quite apparent to me from just looking at it. He was very interested in math (had a phd in it), logic and philosophy... and every once in a while he'd boot up his old Commodore 64 and write little programs. Yet he was never really interested in the new desktop computer my sister had, but it could have just been that he got a bit left-behind and caught up in his projects.
I hope that wasn't too wordy and that I actually somewhat hit the point of this exercise..

For this assignment, I went on tsn.com as it is a website I quite often browse. When I right-clicked and viewed page sources, I came across a bunch of codes written on different lines. From looking at these codes, it seems a lot of hard work is put in to creating different webpage’s. In my point of view, it seems creating a website takes up a good chunk of labor. The different codes and texts give out the reaction that creating a website is not just a straightforward task. The vast amount of codes is used to develop the structure and layout of the website. The codes show us what we see on the website. The coder’s perspective is very important in how we receive information. As Michaela commented, it involves reading code which most people might not understand. If we type something in Google, we expect to receive information on that topic. A person with general knowledge of Google will know how to use its functions. However, if they try to take a look at the webpage’s codes, they most likely will not have knowledge on what the codes mean. My “experience” was similar in this pattern as I did not know what any of the codes on the tsn.com webpage meant. Furthermore, it was my first time seeing codes for a website.
