They help us gain fast and easy access to knowledge. In my point of view, it requires a vast amount of skill and know-how to create codes for websites properly.

After clicking on the source view for the Digital Cultures website and National Geographic website all visuals were shown as their codes: basically a bunch of letters, numbers and symbols all organized to tell the computer to output what visual. The symbols majorly used were the “/” “[ ]” “ ‘ ‘ “ and “=”. The organization of the coding for the website looks at first glance in almost paragraph form, with lines of coding almost a half a page long. The links for picture images also follow to another page of coding, which when I found out I found myself thinking ‘a picture really is worth a thousand words’ as I was scanning the gibberish on the page. From the codes there’s not much I can decipher, but from the groupings and the general positioning on the page I can assume which parts of the webpage they code for.
I worked two years ago editing the Douglas College Athletics Homepage, updating scores and photos and adding schedules, but that was nothing like the coding shown on those webpages. The only part of that job that relates to this would have to be the navigation of the site by the URL. Basically it was laid out as a general URL, but the numbers within the ending of the URL determined which team page you were taken to and the year. For example if at the end of the URL I entered “3/3/” that would have taken me to Softball, 2013’s page. This has lead me to pay more attention to the URLs used in majority of sites, trying to find shortcuts in navigation.

After looking through several different website codings, I stumbled upon Facebook. The original source of the page was full of colourful (blue, black, red, and green) letters, numbers, and symbols all jumbled into a seemingly huge mess. I thought it was interesting that for an individual trained in website design and coding, they would easily be able to read and understand their meanings. However, from my point of view, it was as hopeless as looking at the scribbles of a completely foreign language, unable to translate it into my own. Although, I did spot numerous words that actually made sense- such as different links on the facebook page and etcetera.
I thought of the original source page as a kind of “behind the scenes” to the actual webpage. It was as though the site is designed to be a glamourous facade, hiding the mess of symbols that created it. Most websites are designed to appear simple and easy to navigate through, however the codes show that the work that had gone into the website was quite the opposite. It goes to show you that something seeming so simple can have such a complex and intricate background that only some understand. Few people think about this when they quickly scroll through pages and pages of social networks or news articles. It requires so little effort to use a website and make no acknowledgement of its inner workings.

Expanding on the "behind the scenes" analogy, I wanted to add that the coding of a website would be to Clay from Mr. Penumbra's 24-Hour Bookstore, for example, as the makings of a movie would be to a producer. What I mean is when the average person watches a movie, they don't think about how the movie is made, the score, or how each shot was planned. From their perspective, It is only a story. However, when an individual who studies filmography watches a movie, they will notice the difficulty of each scene and the steps that were taken for it's completion. Similarly, a website designer like Clay notices aspects of a webpage that the average person would not give a second glance. They understand how it was created and the effort that was put into it's making.

It's very interesting that you linked the patterns and organizations of coding to the behaviours of the bookstore's customers. I had never really thought of his observance of the customers as being a characteristic that he received from his knowledge of coding!

I do a lot of online shopping so it was a no brainer which website I was going to look at. For this module, I choose the JustFab.ca website which is an online store selling women’s clothes, purses and what they are most importantly known for are shoes!!! The webpage was designed to be girly and eye catching with the main theme colours of hot pink, black and white. The theme colours are important in a web design because it catches the interest of the online shoppers to further explore the website and to look at the different products.
The content of the page is organized by having the title of the company in the middle in the very top, bolded in hot pink and black font, and all in capital letters. On the top right is an account login for new and returning customers. Below the title of the company are six sub-headings; home, top sellers, our story, press & celebs, VIP membership and getting started, allowing customers to easily identify what they are looking for. At the very bottom of the webpage has the contact information of the company. The whole web layout is very organized and clear.
Behind this very girly, fun, and colour website, it is coded into different words and symbols. For example just the top of the webpage indicating the title is :
JustFab
Looking at the different codes and words it all looks gibberish to me. Each word corresponds to a purpose allowing the webpage to come together. Having one letter or word in the in incorrect spot could mess up the the overall layout of the website. From the programmer’s point of view, the webpage needed to be catchy, simple yet girly to attract customers from the moment the webpage loaded. After seeing the web design from the surface and seeing it in symbols, reminded me there is more than one perspective and not everything is all glamorous. This is important to remember because to truly understand a story, a problem, a situation...etc. all perspectives must be taken into account.

The code is a language created for computers in order to form an image which creates the website. The code behind the face of the website does not really change the experience with the website itself, other than to those who have experience with website creation. The web page organizes itself with the type of website it is and sets up the image of the page. The title and subtitle links follow and as the coding continues down the page the seen contents of the page for the viewer are written into the code.
The form of this code converts the computers inputted language into one that is visible to everyone as a written human language on a web page instead of as the computers language. Reading is done by both the computer and the human viewing the web page. The computer reads the code by understanding a language that has been created by computer programmers for the computer to relay as another image on the screen. The way the computer programmer inputs the language can reflect personal preference and taste. This changes the perspective and point of view of the web page because of the creator’s tastes and companies tastes are inputted into the site. Much like an author to a book the creator hides text and connections. Within Mr. Penumbra’s 24-Hour Bookstore, there was an element of both coding by the author with hiding messages and connections. There is also physical coding of the books within the store.
There is a pattern to the way in which Mr. Penumbra’s bookstore is organized. The books that have the codes for the Unbroken Spine members are stored in the back of the bookstore where the normal books that everyone can read are at the front. The books at the back follow a similar structure to the way that websites are written due to the fact that rules to the language is known only to those who have written or programmed it.

I analyzed both Tumblr and our Digital Cultures Lab source sites and found letters and numbers that are foreign language to me at first sight, compared to the simplicity the websites show us. Tumblr consists of about 400 and more lines containing the codes for the website: blue hyperlinks or letters that are in colour purple and sometimes red text. Interestingly enough, I have a little bit of old knowledge with programming websites since I took a Technology class when I was in high school back in the Philippines. I remember that you always (or usually) end the coding of the website with “” or start and type any text with this “<” symbol, also keywords head, title, footer. I remember having to make our own website as a final project which took a lot of time and attention to complete; placing hyperlinks for a specific colour or background you chose, the amount of text you would like your reader to see or the information you enter in your site. The amount of work was absolutely ridiculous. One simple error perhaps a wrong symbol that you finish your code with, completely changes the look of your website. Essentially, what we see from the surface is always different from what is actually being shown to us. Interestingly enough with my old knowledge with this, I found the answers from our quiz today (and some other stuff) from the source page off our class’ website. The perspective of knowing what was behind the making of these websites, completely changes my attitude towards how everything was made, similar as to how I viewed the novel Penumbra’s 24 Hour Bookstore. I always wondered what was going on in the minds of authors making or creating their stories. Questions such as ‘did this happen to him in real life?’ or ‘how did he come up with this idea?’ would come up to my mind whenever I read a novel. The author, Robin Sloan, must have so much knowledge that he is suppressing from what he actually experienced or thought when he was writing this novel. The amount of information hidden in the website’s source must be how much Robin Sloan is hiding from us. The programmer, similar to Robin Sloan, is the main knowledge provider to when we use such websites or read the novel. Thus, knowledge whether old or new with the source of a website or novel completely depends on how you see things; on what your perspective truly is. Clearly from my perspective, my understanding of the novel is that it’s trying to imply to us, the digital age community, that new knowledge such as computers is not the answer to everything but the answer is within ourselves, as cliché as that sounds.

I searched some image codes like HTLM,QR and WP it have plenty of symbols, numbers, letters in different fonts and sizes and short words arranged in certain order. Some codes look like pieces of art and others like puzzle; for instant, Morse code it’s contains letters or numbers and beside each line of dots and dashes. To me these cods are hard to understand and complicated but I enjoy the images. Searching and reading about codes makes me appreciate and value more computer programmers work and creativity by develop codes and break it down for machines like computers to understand and help to create apps and website. I chose CTV News website to study. The website is well organized so user can easily locate the information they are searching. The home page organizes by the CTV News logo at the side of the page with strong colors like blue, white, red and green. under the title there are icons specify the news like icon for resent news, local news and news program and each one lead to more specific news and the web site is full of newest news videos . Also to make users feel included and connected they make it possible for people to share by adding links to social media like twitter and Face book. The code for the website is consisting of some recognizes words, symbols, letters and lots of links. It is very huge code reflects the effort taken to develop the website and make it easier for user. It was my first time reading or searching about code and this experience give me some knowledge about how code helps to organize and layout what we see in the screen it’s like a writing tool in computers

Just to narrow your comment to narrow questions: Why is it important we prefer methods that are not time consuming? Why is it important the maintain old knowledge? I think we need to maintain old knowledge because technology today is too one sided. We need old knowledge to fill in the flaws of modern technology. I mean look at this.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jIRg93qa7Gw
Notice how the robots are fast in responding to each other but give answers that aren't suitable for the question. I won't answer the first question, but enjoy the video, haha.

After looking at the thousands of lines of code required to make an interactive webpage, with various drop down menus, for example, it becomes clear how much work goes into making such a web page. As someone with little to no knowledge of programming, this is something I was relatively unaware of. A coder puts in hard work in writing the code so that the user can have a simple and easy to navigate experience. The programmer is the person that dictates what your website experience will be like and the code is the structure of the user experience. Individual differences from person to person, as well as cultural differences, would dictate how the code is structured and how that would change the user's experience of a web page. Therefore, other countries that use different domains that those we are familiar with, could have web pages that are unfamiliar, less appealing and more difficult to navigate. The actual level of technical expertise required to code is something that is lost on many people. That is why Mr. Penumbra's bookstore never goes into great deal about the actual process of coding, unlike The Bug. This helps to keep the theme of technology more interesting and exciting to the majority of readers, by focusing on the users experience rather than on the structure of coding.

For the module, the website source i am using is the current Digitalcultureslab.ca. Unlike Youtube or Instagram, the source of this page is less mumbo jumbo to me. It is a website mostly designed for us to comment on.Therefore, the source is simple compared to those multifunctional websites such as Facebook or Snapchat.
I looked into the lines and tried to understand a little using basic programming skills that i learnt long ago. It actually brings me back memories of me studying programming. Our instructor was nerdy but strict, zero tolerance to mistakes. A website is combined with a lot of simple functions and orders. It's not like computers today can understand a lot more complicated commands. They are just faster at solving huge amount of tasks, and each task links to one another. A mistake or "bug" might jeopardize the whole program which is build up with time and effort. And finding the "bug" is even more difficult. Just like the codes for the Unbroken Spine members, they follow a similar way as website sources. It is systematic, and the progress is time and effort consuming. On the other hand, decoding requires the same.

After looking at a couple websites that I frequently go to, I decided to also compare Google’s coding. I noticed that Google’s coding has no use of white space or indentation. It is all jumbled up together and it’s mostly all black. Whereas, if you look at Youtube or Craiglist, they use a lot of white space to allow you to easily identify which section bellows to which coding. They also have red, green, and blue in the coding. I guess it represents the hyperlink or special codes that make up the website. If you look at Craiglist, they have a lot of sections and hyperlinks that lead you to different categories. One could see the resemblance from the website to the coding because it has a lot of indentation to show when each section starts. To be honest, it looks like gibberish to someone who does not understand the language code of HTML and CSS. Since one cannot understand the mastermind behind the coding, they begin to appreciate the creation and structure of a website – whether it be simple or complex. Although Google is a simple website, the coding is very difficult to follow. Looking at the codes allowed me to realize that there is a lot more than meets the eye to a website. If I place the codes on one half of my screen, and the website on the other half, I can slightly follow along to identify which code belongs to which structure or format on the website. In addition, I found that the more line space and indentation there are (when a new code starts), the easier it is to follow or read. It makes it easier on the eyes; whereas, with Google, it is a pile of letters slammed into a document with no organization or structure.

Ashley! I totally agree with you when you mentioned your takeaway from this module. I didn't know how to put what I was thinking into words, but its true, information can change the appearance and appeal to something that we all may like (which sucks but sometimes for the best) just like the POV in a novel can change the mood/moral of the story, how we view a character, or our opinion of a whole book.

The first website I went to was my Twitter account and I really didn’t understand any of it, it looked like a foreign language to me (ie. ۞-۪ۨ-ۯۺ-ۼۿݐ-ݿࢠࢢ-). I tried to read through the page source, I managed to pick out a couple words here and there but there were a lot of symbols and words I didn’t understand. For experienced “decoders” I think would be able to grab more from codes just because they know/understand what certain words, symbols, phrases mean. I noticed that when you scroll quickly up and down there is a pattern on the left part of the screen that looks like a squiggle all the way up and down the page. I went to the Douglas Library website as well to compare and they all were different but had the same criteria. There was a column on the left side of the page (1-970 on the Douglas Library site), there was different text colors such as orange, green, black, blue, and purple. The difference between the Douglas Library site and others was that there were actual links highlighted in blue you could click on. Once I opened a link it just sent me to another page source full of codes, which were all structured and organized. It was interesting to see a page with images, links, information etc. translated into “code”. I don’t think the page source adds anything to my experience personally because I don’t understand what everything means. In the book Clay and his friends are computer geniuses and lived for unraveling codes so for some people who find codes really neat, I think it’s great but for me I don’t understand how it works but maybe who knows, maybe I could be like Penumbra and find it fascinating once it’s explained to me. Thinking back to the book I can see how difficult and frustrating it would be to pick through and sort out codes without the help of a computer or machine but the had the tools, resources, and patience whereas I think people growing up in the "technology era" lack in some of those areas, we rather get it done the fastest/easiest way.

I decided since nearly everyday I am looking at my blackboard account keeping upto date on all my courses, that I would check out the page source for their website. When I first looked at it there were a few spots where I could pick out words that made a bit of sense to me but when you look at it as a whole none of it made much sense. It all looked so foreign to me since I have no experience in creating web pages and any sort of computer programming. I then started trying my best to piece together the lines of the page sourcing and tried deciphering what it says. Certain lines I could tell were the links to the specific classes, or the notification portion. I also noticed that specific words were colour coded but I am not sure why they are since you can't click on them and it doesn't take you to an external link. Maybe it was a way for the programmer to sort everything out and find the main parts quicker?
I now realize that there is a lot of effort that gets put into creating a website - a lot more than I thought. I do know from some friends who have designed websites that even if one comma is in the wrong place that it can throw off the entire webpage and you can see it differently. After looking at the page source, it didn't really change my perspective on the webpage that I was on. It made me realize that even though the page is easy to navigate there must of been a ton of effort that was put into it without me realizing it, so it was neat being able to see a glimpse of what was behind the making of the webpage, even if I didn't understand it.
In Penumbra's 24 hour bookstore, Clay gives a bit of a brief description about different software programs but he never goes into much detail. The first gave us a general idea, just enough to show the new way of searching for things and encoding and decoding which help paint a better picture of the book. If it had gone into more detail I don't think I would of liked the book as much.

I agree with you Breanne about if I had more knowledge of programming it could of made more sense to me and change my perspective but since I don't it didn't help me further understand the page at all. You also have a good point on how coding webpages takes time and patience and that decoding the Manutius also takes time and patience and how the two link together fairly well, I never thought of it like that, but putting it into that perspective makes more sense.

The internet is a vast and mysterious place but the site I visit most frequently as it is my go- to place is “https://www.netflix.com“. The code itself begins with a lot of gaps and simple “internet language” as it makes up bits and pieces of the website, as I proceed down to observe the codes it descends into a something much more complicated. Some words are blue and some are mahogany, when you keep scrolling you come to see a series of numbers making up important information and data. Nothing really adds to my experience from the codes but I do have a new found fascination for website designers as it is a tricky job to make sure the presentation is up to par with the brand. The webpage is neatly organized in a series of movie/ TV show windows with a quick summary of the plot if you hover over the box with your mouse. The underlying principle is to ensure web browsers have a smooth experience with the website and are completely satisfied with the navigation aspect. The decipher is the webpage designer and simply brings ideas to life, it is important to view the page from a browsers perspective as it is very crucial for a simple viewing experience as it always guarantees satisfaction. An HTML coder dictates your viewing privileges as much as they please, they have the power to change certain aspects of a site and change your whole experience with internet surfing. In the novel “Mr. Penumbra’s 24 hour book store” by Robin Sloan, it heavily highlights the importance of how old and new knowledge are to different generations and how forms of knowledge is merely a POV. There are just some things that you need old and new knowledge for, it’s important to have an understanding of both and to know when to use the two. For example, Clay solved the mystery of the Manutius in a day while others using old knowledge have been struggling to produce an answer, this shows that new knowledge should not be underestimated and it shows that sometimes new isn’t always bad. I believe that the novel has a metaphor for the people of the “Unbroken Spine”, they are the back bone of old knowledge just like how Kat is part of the back bone of Google .

item.title: Essay Review Module
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Instructions: Due for Feb. 4, 2015 class. This module is about helping you understand where your writing needs improvement by looking at the work of others. The idea here is to recognize and avoid the errors that lead to poorly executed essays in the draft stage before it counts. Summary: Task: As we discussed in class, you should comment on at least three of the rough drafts submitted online to the class website. What should should I be commenting on?
  • Does the rough draft make sense? If it does, how? If not, how not?
  • Does the rough draft address the question? If so, how? If no, how?
  • What would you change?
  • Are there transitions, is there a logic?
  • Is the subject narrow enough; can the essay really get at the details?
  • Does the rough draft appear to include "things"; real details to discuss, clarify, and define? What are they?
  • Syntactical or grammatical errors
Outcomes:
  • How does looking at the work of someone else help you write better?
  • How can you apply the process of editing some else's work to your own?
  • What could you take from the example to make your writing better?
Takeaways:
  • Essay writing is all about the craft of editing. If you do not spend time editing and shaping the essay, it will suffer.
  • Watch your assumptions. Taking into account the assumptions you make about what your audience understands is key both to developing a relevant subject for your essay and for writing an essay that accounts for its audience.
  • Writing essays is not something you do for your instructor. In fact, it's about writing well because you have something you think might be interesting to someone; anyone.
  • Take account of your process. What do you need to change about the way you approach essays? If you didn't implement those changes, but know that you need to change something, ask yourself what's up with that and take steps to address it.
Here's a list of the drafts:
    Aaron's Draft - No Title Rachel's Draft - No Title Paula's Draft - "Dragon's Are Man's Best Friend" Jonathan's Draft - "Mr. Penumbra's 24-Hour Bookstore / Character Relationship" Angela's Draft - "Damsel in Distress" Jessica - "Not Always a Storybook Ending"

item.title: Aaron Bhadrasen - No Title
item.dc:creator: Aaron
item.content:encoded: The setting has a tremendous affect on what happens in the story. When the story is contextualized, the reader gains a perspective and sense of where the plot might be headed. When it comes to understanding the plot of a story, the setting often plays an important role. A stories setting is more than just a backdrop of the plot. It often plays an important role in developing the stories events and themes. While not all stories develop their settings, some evoke vivid associations of particular times or places. In order to contextualize the plot, the reader’s engagement, and the clear development in the setting is crucial. The setting serves as much more than a mere vehicle to cement readers in the time and place within the story. It is a psychological force upon how we understand. In modern stories, the setting stands as an influence that helps readers sense what is happening with the characters. The grasp of the plot keeps people engaged more and more. This means that the reader is fascinated or immersed into the story. Before soaking up the story, a compelling setting is what hooks readers into the narrative. Being engaged in the narrative will keep the reader flipping through the pages for hours on end. The select setting of the narrative is what keeps the reader thinking and visualizing. The development of the setting is also very important if we are to truly be enticed by the story. The careful construction of the setting will present the readers with what they are getting into. The structure of the setting has the potential to escalate, or potentially de-escalate the narrative. In order for the storytelling to be effective, the setting should provide a backdrop that is both cognitively and emotionally compelling. A good example of this would be the development of mood and tension. A stories mood and tension is one of the aspects that consumes the readers mind. The development of these atmospheres builds into the reader’s interest, or disinterest. These are just a few ways the setting can be contextualized. The reader’s engagement in the narrative and the clear development of the setting influences how we understand.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I need to see some actual things in here Aaron. You don't even state what the setting is before you tell me it's important. In fact, there's no mention of what book you're dealing with in here. What is the focus of the essay? It better not be "setting" alone because that's far too general. There needs to be far more detail and specifics, a few references to either Penumbra or The Bug depending on which you decide to use are essential. Right now what you have is an encyclopedia entry without a lot of analysis about how setting works in one of the novels we have read so far.

I would add for the rest of you: thanks to Aaron for getting this started. It's a great example of how you should NOT be writing. This draft violates almost every bit of advice I have given you about writing in class:
- address details not generalized terminology--name the setting, don't just write setting--what colour is your cat? - move from the specific details out into more generalized claims, not the other way around, like this does. No detail at all. Just what you would read in a dictionary. Common knowledge. - Don't teach your reader. I know all about setting. What I want you to show me is how you think the setting--whatever you think it is--is working in the book. What's it doing? How does it work? - I could ask "so what" about EVERY sentence in here. That means every sentence in this example is a potential ESSAY. Not just part of a paragraph on setting, but the basis for an entire essay - do not waste time contextualizing "setting" as a term. If I taught you what the term means, assume I know all about it basically. I can google it. What I want to know is what you think the setting is ad why that's important for understanding the book as a comment on a cultural moment. What does the setting say about our current fascination with technology? Answer that and you might have something, if you tell me what the setting is--google? Bookstore? Clay's brain? The codex? Clay's car? The airplane? - THING THING THINGS!!!! STUFF!! EXAMPLES!!!
You all owe Aaron a great deal for getting this outta the way. There's plenty of time to fix things.
And there should be a damn title. ALWAYS GIVE THINGS A TITLE! ALWAYS!

And how about some paragraphing people? Needs to be some paragraphs in essays. An essay cannot be one paragraph or three, needs to be more, follow a logic, be organized, categorized, logical -- like the ones you read all the time on the web, in magazines, newspapers... like TedTalks.

You should stick with the past tense in your essay, because this will make your writing smoother and easier to read. You should also avoid using the word “we”, you have used it three times.
The setting has an effect not affect, because the setting has changed the story it is not changing the story, and due to the fact that the novels we have read are both past tense. If you would like more about this, check out: http://www.quickanddirtytips.com/education/grammar/affect-versus-effect.
I think that you are writing your essay for the first question, and for that question you are writing for either how the setting influences how the novel is understood or how the novel is contextualized. In your draft you are writing about both. To contextualize the novel is to place the story in a certain context, and to understand the novel is to see the intended meaning of the setting. The novel that you are focusing on needs to be clarified in order for you to provide evidence and be able to discuss your thoughts. You need structure and paragraphs too.

Good, insightful, comments Natasha. I'm glad someone mentioned the affect / effect -- it's one of the tougher word rules to master, but essential in this case. Only one issue. While I sense that you are driving at the switching of tenses in the draft, always best to write in the present tense. This avoids the passive voice ("has been said" vs. "says"). As a rule, the story events in a text are always described in the present tense in essays: "Ethan works at..." not "Ethan worked at..." and "the character notes that..." not "the character noted that..." The only time you use the past tense is when you are referring to real-world timeframes, like the book itself: "The book WAS WRITTEN in ..." Or, in the case of historical moments: "Having lived within the context of discrimination, the author..." So, if you're describing textual events or writing your essay: present tense. If you're situating the text in a context outside the story events or your essay: past tense. And, always the active voice!

Aaron, from my understanding you chose the first essay question- what may be helpful is to narrow your focus on setting further by first picking one of the novels to use as an example and then choosing a particular setting within the novel. By writing about one specific setting you can then choose what it has to do with the rest of the story and why its important. I know this is a rough draft but I have a hard time figuring out what the point is you're trying to make here/ what the thesis is. Also a lot of the language feels repetitive. In the beginning you have many sentences about setting that are worded differently but mean the same thing. For instance : "When it comes to understanding the plot of a story, the setting often plays an important role. A stories setting is more than just a backdrop of the plot. It often plays an important role in developing the stories events and themes." When you write your essay I would recommend looking for repetition in your sentences and cutting out filler words that you don't need.

It's very descriptive Aaron, which is good. Some of the things I would suggest is to tell the reader which novel you are writing about.
Another thing is that it is a little repetitive, as you said, " When it comes to understanding the plot of a story, the setting often plays an important role." and " It often plays an important role in developing the stories events and themes." You could probably leave out the "It often plays an important role..." in the second sentence.
Besides that though, it's very well-thought out, plays on good key points, just try to elaborate on your points with specific examples, and the formal writing gives it a well-educated tone. Nice work!

Aaron, you didn’t do a horrible job but there are definitely a few things you could fix to make your essay awesome! First, this needed a title; I wasn’t sure who or what your essay was about, which book you were focusing your essay on.
You don’t need to explain what the setting/plot etc. are about, as you need to assume and know the readers already understand what those terms are and how they work with one another, so there is no need to try and teach us knowledge we already know. Also, this seems like you explained parts of the actual essay question with isn’t necessary.
I think you are basing your essay off the first option we were given…
“Discuss how setting influences how we understand OR contextualize one of the novels we have read so far.”
Focus on discussing either how the setting influences how we UNDERSTAND or CONTEXTUALIZE one of the novels you’ll have a great essay. You also need to address what novel you are going to reference. Don’t just base your essay telling us how plot, setting, narrative, character is all connected and how they make a good novel. WE KNOW!
I would’ve liked to see you at least focus on one book so we could give you more of a direction about addressing a novel. I think once you figure out whether or not your going to focus on how the setting influences our understanding or helps contextualize one of the novels you will have a great essay. Try not to sound too repetitive when discussing your ideas. Some of your sentences really don’t need to be there, i.e., “Being engaged in the narrative will keep the reader flipping through the pages for hours on end”. Its just not relevant whatsoever, so just be careful you don’t ramble on about nonsense.
Remember how to paragraph your thoughts, ideas; it just looks professional and organized. It will come when you have your topic picked and decide what book you are going to talk about.
I hope this helped, good luck with the rest of your essay!

Hi Aaron
There are definitely a few areas you could focus on in order to improve your essay. First of all, you have no title. As mentioned above, without a title the reader has absolutely no idea what to expect, what book you're writing on etc. Likewise, I think it would be beneficial to mention the novel you are referring to in the beginning of your essay as part of your introduction just to inform the reader. Also, I think you are describing more of the general concepts and terms rather than relating them to the novel of your choice - after all, connections need to be made back to the story. Overall, it seems as if you know what idea/concept you're writing about and all you need to do is bring that back to the story. Good job for being the first one up!

I agree with the other commenters that this really feels like a long-winded definition rather than an essay talking about one of the books we've read. Rather than defining these terms, you should really focus on showcasing an example and explaining why it is relevant to the overall effect of the book. The logical flow of ideas isn't really apparent to me in your writing, some of the sentences feel like they should be organized the opposite way you wrote them. (for example, the first 2 sentences - "The setting has a tremendous affect on what happens in the story. When the story is contextualized, the reader gains a perspective and sense of where the plot might be headed." - First you say that setting has a tremendous *effect* on what happens, then you go on to context. Setting and context are certainly related but they're not the same, and it was really jarring to have you switch gears like that so quickly and I got confused about what you are really trying to write about) After reading the entire thing, I know you understand how things work, but they do need to be tied into an specific example.
I, personally, don't mind there being no title, as long as it is apparent what you will be discussing within the first sentence or two, but I suppose now I know that I should include a title in my essay too.

Hi Aaron,
After reading your first paragraph, I came to realize that most of your content was about the setting. I felt like it was more of a definition of what setting is rather than what the setting is in the book. I also feel like it would have been better if you included a title because it gives the reader an idea of what they're reading and also it gives the paragraph more credibility because it owns a title.
I like how you go into detail with your explanations; however, you tend to repeat yourself more than necessary. For example, there was a sentence that was worded into three different ways and you repeated them one after the other. "Gets the reader engaged more and more. Hooked onto it. Engagement.." and so forth was all used within the 3 sentences. I think you can be more concise with your sentences and there is no need to repeat it over and over in different ways! :)

item.title: The Unexpected Fall of Ethan Levin
item.dc:creator: Ashley Jongejan
item.content:encoded:
It came as a surprise when Ethan committed suicide because the reality of his mental situation was masked by the assumptions that were made about his character. Ethan is read as a stock nerd character and along with that title comes assumptions of an intellect with a bright future. The novel first introduces Ethan as “a senior engineer for client-side computing”(6) so right away he is labeled as important and intellectual. As the novel progresses, this character trait is brought along, reassuring the reader that Ethan can handle the stress in his life.
Without the proper qualifications, Ethan gets a complicated computer programming job, showing he is very capable. Harry gave Ethan the job in full faith that he could handle and succeed at it. Despite the questioning of other coworkers that had masters and PhDs in computer programming, Ethan started getting assigned the most technical of assignments.
Ethan was seen as just another programmer as he should be. Impatient, defensive, and condescending, are all traits of programmers that are expected so there was no reason to the stress of the workplace to cause Ethan’s suicide. Harry still didn’t think Ethan was crazy when he was in the ceiling panel above his desk trying to rip out the lights. Harry “admitted that he might have noticed how Ethan Levin was coming unglued right in front off everyone’s eyes, how the bug as it kept on in its Jester personality, was unnerving Ethan to the point of disintegration”(199). Ethan was even convincing himself that he was fine, further hiding his true thoughts. He was convinced that his life would be fine again when he found the bug. Ethan had so much drive to find the bug that he was expected not to quit, to keep working until he found it. He had this idea that everything would be alright if he found the bug. He could repair his life and move on just as soon as the bug was dealt with.
 
Ashley Jongejan

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
The transition between the first paragraph and the second paragraph needs to be a bit smoother. I think the addition of a few words or another transitioning sentence at the end of the first paragraph would make it work better. The last line of the first paragraph is good but might be better served later in your essay.
In the quote from page 199 it should be “of” instead of off. There is a lot of summarizing and repetitiveness of how Ethan’s life will go back to normal, maybe consider analyzing why the audience thought this because of his character and character traits.
This draft makes sense and answers the question of how the assumptions of a character affect how we read the character and their actions. This is a good start to an essay.

This is a great start to your essay! I was impressed by the depth of your thesis and the analyzation of Ethan as a character. I noticed that a few of your sentences are run on sentences. Instead of using a comma, in some cases it is better to use a period. You could also use a semicolon to make the sentence flow.
The first sentence of the last paragraph of your draft seems a little awkward, maybe you would consider rephrasing it. I also think the second paragraph could be expanded on... consider writing about the opinion of Ethan's co-workers.
Overall your essay is on track and you are certainly answering the question.

Good job on using an example to illustrate your point, and on the draft. It seems like you are answering the third question
I'm wondering/unsure if you are perhaps implying that maybe the bug is some sort of personification of Ethan's increasing instability, when relating that to how he lied to himself that this bug was nothing/lying about his mental health.
I also noticed how you pointed out Ethan's robotic/methodical way of thinking, such as "fixed problem, now I can move on", and related that to the "stock nerd" character, very insightful.

Overall I like that your rough draft addresses Ethan’s lack of qualifications and how its related to the destruction of his mental health. Its true that he wasn’t qualified but evidently not knowing the basics or how to read the core dump made him crazy and was the reason he over looked the simplicity of the mistakes that caused the bug in the first place. The draft makes sense however I would recommend maybe starting the essay with an argument or question to make the rest of the paragraphs flow more coherently. I think it was a good idea to incorporate the stock character idea and your examples will support your essay well.

Great start! I liked how you got right to the point about Ethan's suicide and elaborated on it in detail later on in your paragraphs.
However, your third paragraph seems rushed, as " how the bug as it kept on in its Jester personality," was a little confusing to read. Maybe transition over to talking what Harry thought a little smoother. Also, watch your spelling, for example, "right in front off everyone’s eyes." Instead of "off," it would be "of." But, overall, it is well-written and well-thought out with very good examples to go along with it. Good job.

I like the idea how you choose to analyze a character from the Bug and how Ethan is different from our stereotyped version of programmers. As breannesmith said, the first sentence of the last paragraph is quite confusing. You went from “Impatient, defensive, and condescending, are all traits of programmers that are expected so there was no reason to the stress of the workplace to cause Ethan’s suicide.” And then transition to “harry still didn’t think Ethan was crazy”. I feel like there’s no transition so I don’t quite understand what you are trying to say there. But overall, good start and good ideas in your essay.

item.title: Damsel In Distress
item.dc:creator: Angela Proszammer
item.content:encoded:
Assumptions are made daily, almost instinctively by each one of us. Assumptions often leading to quick judgements about character, about personality and commonly jumping to conclusions. There is this constant notion that male characters must be strong, willing to fight to the finish, to rise above all and be the hero they are set out to be. After all, they must save their damsel in distress.
Being the dominant male character in The Bug, Ethan Levin shows us that being the noble hero for the male is not always the case; it is just the opposite. Successfully working as a programmer for a start up computer company Ethan is already presumed to be the generic, stock, computer geek. Ethan is made out to be important and clever by always being able to one-up his coworkers as he was the only one ever on schedule. Being that Ethan dealt with fixing bugs on a daily basis The Jester’s first few appearances didn’t phase him. It was not until The Jester became an office joke, recurring spontaneously unable to find a core that this stock assumption of rising above and fighting to the end undergoes a long downward spiral.
As the story continues, Ethan reveals himself to be the damsel in distress in need of saving, saving from the state of turmoil The Jester has released. Even with all of the misfortune Ethan was facing in his personal life, he is expected to find the dreadful bug that had been eating away at him. Finding the bug would allow him to begin piecing his life back together. Unfortunately, The Jester wasn’t going down that easy and with Ethan being set up as someone who could handle the stress was ultimately the cause of his unexpected demise.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
I enjoyed reading the first three paragraphs of your essay. I can tell it was well thought out since each paragraph transitions well into the next. A few things to fix would be punctuation since there are some missing commas. Also, I'm not sure if you want to tie your thesis more into The Bug and Ethan... something to think about.
In my opinion the last sentence of the second paragraph could be rephrased. It seems as if you are talking about the past in the first part of the sentence and then the present in the last part of the sentence.
Many of your ideas can be expanded on. I think it would help the reader understand your essay if you expand on your ideas using seperate paragraphs. For example: one paragraph for his failed love life, one paragraph about his career and how he was sent off to workshops that he never really wanted to attend and maybe one paragraph about his habits and his home life - drinking, his neighbours and Martha?

I really like that you challenged the expectations of the reader when you chose the title “Damsel in Distress” yet chose the damsel to be Ethan Levin. I think that’s a really creative way to challenge people to think differently about male characters. The draft makes sense and you described Ethans character clearly enough for the reader to understand why it was such a shock (for most of us) when he ultimately committed suicide. The subject is narrow enough because your focus is on male character assumptions and Ethan is a great example of this. I find your introduction to be intriguing and also easy to follow which makes it a great start to an essay. The only thing I would change is to maybe add some support directly from the novel but other than that you are off to a good start.

What is your thesis statement? You have just made statements about assumptions. These are fine but you should clarify what your essay will ultimately argue or talk about and which character.
The second sentence in the first paragraph is either incomplete or needs to be lead instead of leading. Start-up is hyphenated. Phase should be faze. Try to stay away from clichés, like in the last line of your first paragraph; rephrasing that will make it stronger. Stay away from using “us” like in the first sentence of the second paragraph.
How does Ethan’s character come across as being “set up as someone who [can] handle the stress”? What evidence is there to prove that he is a strong character? What makes the reader think this? Being a computer geek and working successfully does not show strong character but intelligence and perhaps dedication. If you were to expand on these questions, I think your essay would be stronger once finished.
Good start and it is a fairly focused and narrow topic.

With reading through some of the other comments made, I have to agree that this beginning portion lacks a bit of focus to get the rest of the paper started.
I think you are stating too many assumptions, rather than facts about what has happened and what they actually mean about Ethan being the “damsel in distress” and the bug.
In the opening of the second paragraph, it sounds to be a bit repetitive with calling Ethan the “dominant male character” where you could simply refer to him as the “protagonist” and then explain your ideas. Overall, it’s definitely a good start to the essay, try to find more direct references from the novel to support your thesis.
Malak

I really enjoyed reading this part of your essay. Right away I was interested and wanted to read more. I liked how you made the reference about a "damsel in distress" but the damsel was Ethan. Right away I'm thinking "oh it has to be a female" character. It made me think of viewing the characters differently (gives us a different pov which I like and I'm sure everyone will too).
You didn't talk to the audience as if we haven't read the book which was nice because I knew exactly what you meant describing characters and events in the book. I'm not sure what part of your essay this is in but just be careful your clear on your thesis and what your essays about.
So far you've been really specific and to the point. Although, I would try to expand on some of your ideas and seperate the different ideas so we aren't confused and your essay flows better.
Great job so far, good luck with the rest of your essay!

Great shift here! I like it a lot. As you move through the editing phase, think about defining the characteristics of the damsel in distress. Readers need to know where you're coming from with that... don't assume they know. And, this will also give you a set of criteria within which to explore Ethan's character -- how is he a damsel in distress when... You needn't go hunting in Wikipedia or whatever for definitions of damsel in distress btw. Just think about what you mean by the phrase and then give us an introduction that foregrounds the characteristics you see as important in the phrase for the essay that will follow. What's important is that you are laying out the THINGS / STUFF you will deal with in the text that suggest Ethan is in fact activating the literary trope (there's a big word for ya) of the damsel in distress.

I definitely think you have an intriguing and relevant topic here. I think you can go a few different directions though. You have a broad topic that can be narrowed a little bit. I also wonder, was finding the bug really going to fix his life, or was the downward spiral already past the point of no return (having his gf cheat on him and then leave him etc.. ). Maybe Ethans demise had more to do with inability to cope with stress, turning to drinking and isolating himself socially, rather than the stressor itself. Again, I think its a very interesting topic as I for one was surprised at the way it turned out. I think there is a lot of truth about what you say about our assumptions of gender roles in this story, or any story.

I love the genderbent title-essay!! Had piqued my interest! I may suggest changing some grammar such as "in need of saving; saving from the bug" instead of a comma? I like the transitions, smooth yet not forced as if you're trying to piece together a half-hazard essay. Another thing may be to expand upon Ethans life outside of The Jester and work? Still overall I love the concept of using Damsels in Distress for this. Kudo's!! (Koodose? I'm not exactly sure how you spell it."

item.title: Mr. Penumbra's 24 Hour Bookstore/Character Relationship
item.dc:creator: JonathanWong
item.content:encoded:
“Wise, old, smiley,” these are some of the words that Clay Jannon, the narrator and dynamic character in “Mr. Penumbra’s 24 Hour Bookstore,” are some of the words he would use to describe his mentor, Ajax Penumbra, or simply, Mr. Penumbra, in the novel. In Mr. Penumbra’s 24 Hour Bookstore, Clay and Mr. Penumbra are not only colleagues in the story, but also friends, partner, and they definitely have a teacher-student relationship, as well. This is evident in how they are portrayed in the book, some examples include:

Clay going out to New York to rescue Mr. Penumbra because he simply cares for his well-bring. Another would be Clay assisting Mr. Penumbra in obtaining the Codex Vitae: a book from the late Aldus Manutius that guarantees immortality to anybody that cracks the code within. Lastly, would be Mr. Penumbra mentoring Clay in running his 24-hour bookstore, and teaching Clay the ways of the Unbroken Spine in New York City.

This shows that Penumbra and Clay’s relationship is based on more than just business, it is based on loyalty and friendship. Penumbra trusts Clay personally to run his bookstore, and to share personal, deep secrets of the Unbroken Spine with him, even entrusting Clay with recovering the MANVTIVS codex vitae from the depths of the Unbroken Spine. It would seem that Penumbra looks at Clay as a type of “family” to him, a position that seems rather rare in Penumbra’s world as we go venture throughout the story.

Clay’s relationship with Penumbra is not surprising though, because Clay does seem very friendly and open to others, thus drawing in other people, such as North Face (Daphne) from Booty’s, Kat Potente from Google, and Edgar Deckle from the Unbroken Spine. He does a very good job in bringing people to him, as well as seeking them out, too. All these elements certainly assist Clay in developing relationships with the characters in the story, as well as driving the story forward in a way that is entertaining seeing as Clay is the main character/narrator in the story, too.

Mr. Penumbra is no slouch either in the “making friends” department. He is friendly, always cheerful, and soft-spoken. All attributes that are useful in drawing others in to certain individuals.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Your essay is off to a good start. In the first paragraph, the first sentence is a little repetitive. It might also help to read it aloud to catch some of the grammatical errors. I don't think it is necessary to say "some examples include" instead a smooth transition into the next paragraph would be sufficient. To help the reader understand your essay it might be better to break each one of your examples into separate paragraphs. Currently it seems a little choppy.
When transitioning into your third paragraph it is not exactly clear what you are talking about when you say "this shows". Also the last sentence in this paragraph is a little awkward. Maybe consider rephrasing this by using more formal words.
Make sure you tie each paragraph in with your thesis. This will help your audience understand the message of your essay and the different components in your essay that relate to your thesis.

The main idea of your draft is well thought out but what you may want to consider is how you structure your paragraphs. For instance the first paragraph ends with a colon and leads to the next with examples to support your thesis. Although your examples are good you should incorporate them into your writing a little smoother instead of just listing them. I also noticed you have a lot of run on sentences and some words that don't really make sense for example "slouch" wouldn't be a way to describe someone. Like Breanne said above, you may want to read this out loud but I think you have a good start here.

I liked the ideas in your essay as the concept was thought out well. On the other hand, your essay does not flow and as a reader I had to keep stopping abruptly because of the grammatical errors. When listing the evidence, be sure to piece the sentences in a way that isn't so confusing. I suggest that some of your sentences can be reworded and be put in different parts of the sentence and new vocabulary can also be introduced to clear up confusion.

You approached this topic in an interesting way and made some really good points. Try to avoid repeating “are some of the words” twice in the same sentence. Your ideas do tie together with your ideas behind Clay and Penumbra’ relationship, although you may want to reconsider rearranging your paragraphs and revising for spelling errors. Some of your sentences appear to be too short and some other appear to be too long, maybe use some transitional words, I think that would really help. Other than that, I think you have many good examples to back up all of your ideas.

I suggest that you look up proper MLA formatting. As far as i know, titles are underlined or italicized, not quoted, but do correct me if I am wrong. This rough draft would have a stronger effect if the paragraphs were formatted correctly: topic sentence first, then the body, then concluding sentence that leads to the next topic for smoother transition.

Hey Jonathan, your first sentence is a run-on with a repetition of “are some of the words”. The essay can also use some good essay structure. You can connect some of your paragraphs together and make them sound good. However, you use good detail and you give a good description of the two characters relationship. Aside from a few minor errors, you are off to a good start.

I have to agree with Breanne and DENISEHUA- your paragraphs are choppy or lack 'flow'. You have some interesting points and evidence to prove Penumbra and Clay’s relationship is more than just colleagues, but all of it seems to be jumbled up throughout the paragraphs. And although you have direction, you don’t ever explain WHY your points are important. You have a good start in the third paragraph by stating something about their relationship, and giving evidence too, but its lacking an explanation! For instance you could benefit greatly by explaining why it is important that Clay was entrusted to recover Manutius’ codex. What makes Clay so important to Penumbra and vice versa? Penumbra could have easily told Oliver Grone the secrets and have him recover Manutius’ codex…

Good start, but like others, you need to narrow your focus. Sentences such as "Clay and Mr. Penumbra are not only colleagues in the story, but also friends, partner, and they definitely have a teacher-student relationship, as well" are too wordy and try to encapsulate too much information. Pick one thing and go from there. How is their relationship that of teacher-student? What might that tell us about the characteristics of learning, for instance?
How do Penumbra and Clay offer up a different paradigm for the teacher / student relationship? How do you mean "teacher" and "student"? How would YOU define those terms in this context?
See, there's plenty just in that dichotomy for a short essay. Do you really need to cover "colleagues" and so on? And then, what do you mean by these other terms? They'll all need to be defined as well. A lot to cover in three pages. NARROW THE FOCUS.

The character relationship between Clay and Penumbra is a very interesting one in how they quickly bond so well and has lots of areas to write on for an essay. I had to read the first sentence a couple times to get it though. "are some of the words" is said twice and doesn't make the sentence flow. But, I see the idea behind it and it is a great first sentence to get the essay going. I like the comparison of how they are both friendly and can draw individuals and is why they bonded and worked together so well. Maybe focus on a certain part of the relationship cause it does seem a little broadly focused.
As stated above, opening "Wise, old, smiley" was unique and it made me curious as to where this was going lead. Sadly that same sentence was structured poorly, had too many commas and orobably

woops accidentally hit post.
Anyways, It has too many commas and probably has 2 or 3 sentences worth of content. As stated previously, reading your sentences will help you catch grammar errors and typos.
Also, you speak of the character relationship but you spend a large majority of the essay proving that Clay and Mr.Penumbra were indeed friends. You point to specific scenarios, which is good, but what does their friendship mean? Why have you decided to zero-in on this friendship specifically? Assume that we know about their friendship, and instead, you should focus on what their friendship says about _______ . Don't waste chunks of your essay pointing out details, try to tie them together.
As it stands, you conclude your draft by stating that the attributes of being friendly and cheerful are attributes that we seek in friends - it is not a very thought provoking thesis. You are on the right track and have demonstrated your ability to find facts and organize them, but what needs work is the lack of content discussing the connections and meaning/impact behind these facts in the story.
Good work on your essay, hopefully this helps.

item.title: Dragons are Man’s Best Friend
item.dc:creator: paulamanrique
item.content:encoded:
Clark Moffat in Robin Sloan’s, Mr. Penumbra’s 24-Hour Bookstore, just like Ajax Penumbra, creates the very meaning of a wise old man. Wise old man, its definition as striking as Clark Moffat’s character, is an elderly stock character who provides our protagonist with wisdom; answers to the protagonist’s many questions.  Clark Moffat fulfills this stock character as he subtly, almost secretively, guides our protagonist, Clay Jannon, the key to everlasting life through his novels: Dragon-Song Chronicles. Clark Moffat plays an important character in the novel as the wise-old-dead-man who arms Clay with wizards and dragons in his obsession with finding the key. As a wise old man, Clark Moffat instills in Clay and us, readers, that everlasting life is the lasting relationships we make with the people we meet through the choice he made between publishing his codex vitae or Clay’s beloved novels.

Although Ajax Penumbra could be the wise old man, Clark Moffat separates himself with the sole reason that he has died and is still able to push through his knowledge to Clay. Assumptions with the stock character make us think that Moffat will be guiding Clay as he solves for the answer. And he accomplished this despite his death;  Moffat lead Clay away from using technology and set him in the right path through his stories about his dragons.  Truly, he had the wisdom and made the right choice to publish his novels. Initially, Moffat as the wise old man character is not evident because of how Clay brings him to the story, though as we move on, Moffat has driven us to the answer ever since Clay mentioned how he loved Moffat’s works in the beginning of the novel. As can be seen, The Dragon-Song Chronicles tell the story behind the intriguing answer to everlasting life in a very discreet way. It is definitely exciting to discover that the chronicles tell the actual story behind how everything started. Consequently, the novel by Moffat describes “Griffo [making] an instrument so perfect that even the dead must rise to hear its call” (199), the very reason why they say that it is the answer to living forever. Moreover, Moffat clearly confirms our assumptions that he is indeed wise, thus leads our protagonist to the fulfillment of his quest.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Your essay starts of very well; the topic you choose to do your essay on is clearly understood in the first paragraph. I would recommend to not be very repetitive in your paragraphs, you repeated Clark Moffat multiple times, maybe it would be simpler if you just used the last name instead of writing his full name. I would also recommend to just keep your paragraphs in third person. There were times when you referenced to yourself or other readers by using “us” which is a first person point of view.
Your rough draft is well structured and easily understood. It's great to see how you have incorporated Clay's favorite book into your essay, this added color to your topic. Very insightful.

So far your essay chunk is pretty good! I would watch out though with being too repetitive (for example, "wise old man" in my opinion was used too much which almost made me want to skip a couple lines and begin reading again). You did a good thorough job of explaining details clearly for the reader, again watch out about describing certain things because we've read the book as well. Overall, you've done a really good job so far! Good luck with the rest of your essay.

Hey Paula, your essay is very well structured. I like the comparisons you make between the two characters as they are very accurate and detailed. Just as Jasmandeep stated above, you might want to avoid using words such as “us” or “our”. Furthermore, you can’t “assume” what we as the readers think. Other than that, you are on the right track to writing a great essay.

Extremely well-written, Paula. It is very descriptive, it gives out key examples in the novel, and the paragraphs are well-structured, as well.
The only thing that I could probably suggest is you don't always have to mention "Clay" and "Clark Moffat" by name so many times.
Anyways, I liked how you used Clark Moffat as a comparison with Clay, instead of the usual "Mr. Penumbra and Clay" comparison, which I did. Keep up the good work!

Hi Paula The excerpt from your essay sounds interesting as many others have mentioned. I think it's extremely creative how you used Clark Moffat as the center of your essay because his character was important to Clay although it was not mentioned as often. I think you made good connections between Moffat's novels and his codex vitae which makes a strong point. I am wondering what other points you have in mind to mention in your essay. Great job

Great start and great title. Well done. You might work toward cleaning up some wordiness. Take the last sentence of the first paragraph: do we need "us" in there at all? Why are you mentioning the audience? Is the audience important or do you just need to concentrate on the Moffat / Clay relationship characteristics. What does it matter that the audience identify with that?
Also, second paragraph: do you need Ajax in there? Why draw our attention to him? I get that you are trying to set Moffat apart from Penumbra, but this sets up a false dichotomy. In other words, everything works fine without mentioning Penumbra (just take that sentence out) and the argument / description you offer here is much more focused if he's not in the frame of reference.
So, clean things up a but and let the essay tell you where it wants to go... very holistic, but trust me; it'll tell you what it wants to talk about.

The essay portion you provided is very descriptive and the. The paragraphs are structured well, which helps make the writing clear. I like the idea of Clark Moffat’s importance in the story and your insight of why it is. Great start to your essay but like other classmates, I have noticed that there are a lot of repetitive words that are probably not necessary. Overall I have enjoyed reading your essay so far, great job!

Perhaps you should use a word like "embodies" or something along that line instead of "creates" when you say that Clark Moffat and Ajax Penumbra ressemble the stock character of the wise old man. I am also not sure about your assertion that there can only be one wise old man character in the book. But perhaps it would be best to not mention Penumbra outside of the introductory section of your essay.
The last few sentences get a bit confusing... "consequently"? and "moreover"? maybe they should be switched, because the last sentence is more of a conclusion and the one preceding it just has a piece of evidence.
Definitely a good start :)

Hi Paula, Your rough draft is well structured and easily understood. I liked how you connected Clark Moffat to Clay; beside your title is attractive. In the second paragraph you mainly wrote about Moffat and Clay, so I’m not sure why you wrote about Ajax in the beginning and then he disappeared from the content. As it mentioned previously, by using “Us” yon are reflecting a personal assumption. Other than that, well done and good luck with the rest of your essay.

Hi Paula, Your rough draft is well structured and easily understood. I liked how you connected Clark Moffat to Clay; beside your title is attractive. In the second paragraph you mainly wrote about Moffat and Clay, so I’m not sure why you wrote about Ajax in the beginning and then he disappeared from the content. As it mentioned previously, by using “Us” yon are reflecting a personal assumption. Other than that, well done and good luck with the rest of your essay.

"Dragons are Man's Best Friend”. You have an engaging title as it is the first thing I noticed before reading your essay. It’s compelling in other words. I also like your description about Clark Moffat and that even though he is not the main character of the book, he actually plays a large role in aiding Clay to solve the code. So good analyzing there and the first paragraph has flow. That makes it easy to follow. For the second paragraph, I have no criticisms as you analyze Moffat very thoroughly and how important he is to Clay. So good luck on your easy writing!

I really like this essay draft- I think that the topic is interesting and explains the captivating title. You didn't use the easy way out and use basic characters- instead you seem to have found different and unique connections. It's also well structured, however I noticed some choppiness in your sentences. It doesn't flow as well as it could. The first sentence is explanative, though I feel that it can easily lose the interest of the audience with it's length. Great writing!

Hi Paula,
There is not much to say about your first draft - which is a good thing. I like how you structured your paragraphs neatly and it was very easy to understand and follow. The information that I read was easily processed because of the easiness on the eyes. Also, your title gave me a glimpse of what to expect!
Overall, I think your rough draft was well done.

This is an interesting topic to pull out of the story! I like that you chose it!! I would keep pushing with it and use the same charisma/personality you have in your title - which by the way, is the best - I would encourage trying to describe Moffat as something other than a "wise old man" get a little creative with it

item.title: Rachel Peckinpaugh - No title
item.dc:creator: Rachel Peckinpaugh
item.content:encoded: Looking from the outside in for Mr. Penumbra's 24-Hour Bookstore, the store looks as though it is a normal looking store in the middle of San Francisco. Nothing about the store front stands out other than the fact that it is a bookstore right next to a bar. Once you step inside your opinion changes in the way that you don't think of the store as what we would think to be a normal bookstore, such as Chapters. The store is designed so that at the front, you have common books that anyone would buy, but in the "way back" section you will find books that belong to the Unbound Script. The store plays a big role in the setting and leading us to where the book goes next. It all starts in this tiny bookstore, shelves lining all the walls and aisles from the ground to the ceiling that has a sort of mysterious feel behind it. This starts off the novel of how Clay Jannon will discover the Unbound Script. Just like the Unbound Scripts main headquarters, there is a building there that hides their true identity. The Fortes Lente Company is all above ground in the building in New York, while beneath it there is the whole underground area where people of the hidden society can find Manutius, the Codex Vitae. The bookstores true identity is hidden at the front so that when you first walk into the store you will find all these books that would seem like normal books to find in a bookstore, but if you know where to look, you will find the important codex vitae of many of the members of the Unbound Script in the shelves at the back hidden by darkness. The way the bookstore was set up and how the narrator, Clay Jannon, describes the place you get the sense that something more is happening in this bookstore than what meets the eye. This sets up the entire book and in what direction the story is headed. The way the bookstore is also described sets up very well the theme of old knowledge vs new knowledge. With the bookstore looking old, musky and dark you can really visualize that it is old knowledge that you find within this bookstore.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
I'd be careful when starting sentences with the word "This", you start multiple sentences with “This”, and it comes across as unclear at times. Another tendency I noticed was that throughout the essay you were speaking in second person, not that it’s technically wrong, it might just cost you marks if you don’t utilize it properly. It’s better to stick to third person past tense in my opinion for the type of essay you are attempting.
The analysis between the book store and the Fortes Lente Company is accurate as they both operate under the ruse of an ordinary, boring, location. Relating Mr.Penumbras 24hr bookstore to our expectations of a typical book store is, and a typical book as-well is also a very insightful comparison. Perhaps you could go into detail about what is “expected” from a typical book, and you can describe how Mr.Penumbra’s bookstore, and the books inside the book store, violate these expecations.
However how does old knowledge exactly relate to the narrative that Clay Jannon use to describe the bookstore? Clay Jannon was definitely intrigued by the appearance of the book-store, and in particular about its odd dimensions. Can you think of any tell-tale signs of the Fortes Lente Company that were out of the ordinary as well, hinting that there may be something unusual going on? And did the narrative serve to point this out?
You also mentioned narrative, conflict of old vs new, as well as setting of the book store at the end of your essay. You will find it easier to narrow in on just one of these aspects, and draw examples from the novel. Your comparisons are well placed overall when discussing expectations vs reality with the two settings, in my opinion that was the strongest part of your draft

Ey. It pains me when I, the reader, is addressed in your essay, so please restrict your self from using "you" or "your" as I want to be apart of your essay. I don't. You're also summarizing a great deal. It's alright to summarize a minor detail, but everything about the bookstore is too much. We already know that. You mentioned the bookstore represents OK and never bothered to expand on new knowledge, because I don't know the very definition of new knowledge? You repeated how the bookstore is important at least three times. If this is your intro paragraph, I'd suggest narrowing it a great deal by: not summarizing a great deal, repeating points, and sticking to a nice and narrow point that your paragraph revolves around.

Thanks for the rough draft, it's evident that you've put some thoughts into it, so that's awesome. But your draft sounds more like a summary than trying to analyze how the setting has influenced your understanding of the story. (assuming that this is your topic). Therefore, this draft somewhat fails to address the topic question. I suggest that you narrow it down more and try to avoid the obvious details. We all know that the bookstore is in San Francisco, but perhaps you might address why it would be in San Francisco and not elsewhere? Would the story be the same if the bookstore was in Surrey?
I hope this helps, editing or evaluating drafts isn't my thing.

In the approximately 350 word excerpt you gave, you used the word bookstore/store 18 times (I was curious so I checked). I think writing about the bookstore itself is a great idea, and one that might be overlooked by a majority of the other students, however I had trouble pinpointing what your thesis was and what this special “bookstore” had to do anything with.
I think you need to avoid summarizing too much facts that the reader already knows about the book, providing some description of the bookstore is good, but not when you’re explaining a bulk of the plot with it.
As for some of the outcomes this week, I think this module is going to help the editing process of my essay because it has led me to look at the finer details, such as assumption making and plot summarizing that may take away from the overall impact my essay has. I think when I am to edit my essay, I’ll look at it objectively and ask myself what others might think about the points I am highlighting and what they mean.
Malak

I like the way you wrote about this topic. You have a very good introduction and it makes me want to keep reading on. All your information is clear and concise and relates well to the points you are trying to make. My only suggestions would be to reformat this so that it is not just one large paragraph, that way it is easier to read and it separates your ideas allowing the reader to better process each one, and also use more transitional words to connect the sentences that are generally shorter. Regardless, you are off to a really good start.

Hey Rachel, great start but you do have a few errors. One of noticeable things is the use of words such as “you”. You also start many sentences with “the” or “this”. It is better to start off sentences NOT using these words. You can use better words to start off sentences. One of the tools I personally use is a thesaurus. It will definitely help you in this aspect. Another noticeable thing is the essay structure. The clear way to start off is by your thesis and by talking about the main points you will be talking about. Before I submitted my first paragraph I thought it was just a regular 350 word assignment like yours. The good thing is we still have time to make our improvements. Great try and good luck with your complete essay!
