I felt like your essay was mostly about summarizing the book although it did had some good insight but it wasn't specific enough because of the use of "This" or "That". I suggest rewording you sentences so the reader will know for sure what you are trying to target. I am not entirely sure if using second person and addressing the reader as "you" is very necessary for a formal draft, try sticking to third so the readers are not awkwardly pulled in the essay.

All the comments are steering you in the right direction. I would add that you be careful about your format and logic. This needs some paragraphing and FESTINA LENTE, not what you have -- make sure you are spelling and naming textual examples correctly, otherwise you look real lazy.
There's also a lot of pointing here. You need more showing and less telling. What does all that you have described mean? What purpose does it serve to the story? How does it drive the narrative in a particular direction? Try to get at these questions and you'll have something. Push toward the deeper meaning... give your pointing some significance!

After reading your essay its clear to me that you are writing about the importance of the setting and how setting affects understanding the story. Although some of it does sound like a summary, I can see that you trying to put together ideas. I would also try to narrow the focus on the setting. Overall It seems like you have a lot of insight and ideas on your topic.

From your essay the reader can understand what your main topic is for your essay. As suggested in the previous comments, I would also recommend avoiding using words such “you” and use alternative words such as the “reader” or the “individual” because it would make your writing better for a formal essay. I think that you may have a lot of different of ideas about how the bookstore is the setting that puts the book together. But I would recommend focusing your idea on one specific reason about the bookstore that makes it an important setting and focus on the different aspects of that, rather than naming all the reasons why the bookstore is important. All in all, your essay has plenty of different of topics you can chose to narrow from and you seem to understand the bookstore setting well enough to produce a great essay.

When you say "you" so often in an essay, it really feels like you're telling me what to think, rather than just explaining the details so that I can be convinced by what you want to discuss and whether you have any valid points to offer. I'm also not sure that you need to mention the *Festina* Lente Company if you are writing about Penumbra's store in this essay. It could be that in this draft you didn't have enough time to expand on your thoughts on how the Festina Lente Company relates to the setting of Penumbra's 24-Hr Bookstore, but unless it is used in order to highlight the differences in specific, instead of general ways, perhaps it should be left out. Finding the evidence in the book will definitely help fill out your arguments, but you have a good base for your essay.
Also, some of the flow of logic and wording could be improved. I find what always helps me is reading it aloud to myself and tweaking it from there.

Hi Rachel, I enjoyed reading your draft and I understood that you are writing about the setting and how its affect the story. But I think what you wrote it’s more a summary about the book store and how its look like and I couldn’t got a lot about old knowledge vs new knowledge . Yes the bookstore looking old, musky and dark so there is old knowledge but what about the new knowledge. I think what you wrote is good but it’s general and it’s not leading to specific ideas. Overall you have good understanding for the story and there are a lot of good ideas in your draft.

I think that the content in your draft is great, however your sentence structure and flow can use work. There were several times that I was lost and other times where I wasn't sure what your point was. I also don't recommend addressing the audience ("you will find", "you get the sense"). In addition, I'd advise you to look into some different transitional words so that you can start off your sentences with more grace. Try to be a little more careful with your wording so that it reads easily, also. Although I liked your opinions and explanation of the novel, I wasn't completely sure what the topic was. I found that it frequently switched from setting of the bookstore to the setting of the Festina Lente headquarters and back to the bookstore again. Maybe try to stick with one area or expand on both places in different sections of your essay?

Hi Rachel,
After reading your paragraph, I thought it was quite a bit for one paragraph. I as a reader would have preferred for it to be in multiple paragraphs because it is easier on the eyes and it would be easier to follow along and understand the content. It also allows the reader to organize the information that they are reading.
I also came to the conclusion that it was more of a summary. As an introduction paragraph, I understand that you're supposed to give the reader a little information so that they could understand the background. However, the way you summarized may have been a little bit too much - especially for someone who has already read the book. You just need to include enough information so that the reader knows the basics and it refreshes their memory for someone who already read it.

I enjoy the describing of the bookstore in detail but I feel it is boarderline summarizing entirely about the store itself. What are you connecting it too? It's unclear. Use paragraphs to break up larger bodies of text like this it will be more effective. Also as mentioned before refrain from assuming we haven't read the book. We have, so tell us your thoughts about it without having to spell it out for someone like your grandma who hasn't read it. This will make the essay much neater and more concise.

item.title: Not Always Your Story Book Ending
item.dc:creator: Jessica Funk
item.content:encoded:
Mr. Penumbra’s 24 hour bookstore was not a typical romantic storyline. Clay and Kat had a unique relationship that not many stories will include. Boy meets girl, they both fall in love and live happily ever after. Robin Sloan did not have this kind of love story in mind. Not every relationship in every book has to have a happy ending where the boy and girl end up together. In this case, Clay and Kat are a prime example of the couple that does not last forever.
Adventures and mysteries are irresistible. Clay’s life consisted of adventure and mystery. This made Clay intriguing for Kat. Clay was deeply involved in solving the code of the Unbroken Spine. The 500 year old mystery was to keep Kat’s attention until the code was solved. The two young adults spent all of their time together researching and discovering different possible answers to the code. However, just like all adventures, their relationship would come to an end.
Clay is a web designer that has been laid off due to the collapse of the economy. This sent Clay on a mission to find a job to help him get by until he could find another job that would suit his fancy. Clay ended up with the night shift at Mr. Penumbra’s bookstore. He quickly became aware of the unique traits of the bookstore. Clay is a curious character and began to question the real purpose of the library. He discovered the Unbroken Spine and began to solve the mystery. Clay became obsessed with solving the code and would not stop until he found the answer. Clay is comparable to a video gamer or a computer geek, although not to that extreme. He is curious enough to take the investigation into his own hands and learn to solve for himself. Though he is involved in the researching through books and the library, Clay also brings in the strategy of researching through google. Clay represents the balance of old knowledge and new knowledge through books and computer technology. His balance between the two was slightly influenced by Kat the google programmer.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
I really enjoyed this excerpt right from the beginning as I felt drawn in from the opening few sentences. Although there is a lot to say for Clay and Kat, I felt as if you got down to the point right away in explanations given.
Reading through, in the last paragraph you begin with “Clay is a web designer that has been laid off due to the collapse of the economy”, which to me sounded like you were explaining too much of the plot rather than assuming your audience has read the book already. Consider changing that to “Following the collapse of the economy that led to Clay being laid off…” or anything on those lines so it doesn’t sound like the reader has no idea of what you’re writing about.
Overall, what I think is a really great start to the essay!
Malak

The first paragraph is a good start in addressing the question about discussing the relationship of Clay and Kat. The third line of “Boy meets girl…", however, suggests that the sentence is explaining Clay and Kat’s unique relationship. Its confusing in a minor way as the sentence is not supposed to. I see how you might ‘clear up’ the confusion with the subsequent sentence, but its best to just keep everything coherent from the get go. For example, you could write “Robin Sloan did not have the typical love story in mind of boy meets girl, they fall in love and live happily ever after. Instead…(explain briefly how Clay and Kat don’t last forever)”.
The second and third paragraphs don’t really make sense with your initial direction. They kind of go on to really summarize the book, not even the relationship. I would suggest writing about WHY their relationship gives meaning to the book. Why did it fail? What do we have to learn from their relationship?
I am also confused as to where the direction of the essay is going (in the 3rd para) when you suggest Clay’s balance of OK and NK is only slightly influenced by Kat. That in itself could be an entirely different essay. While each paragraph has a narrowed focus, they each go off in a different direction. Pick one idea and run with it!
Good luck!

The comments above are good. Take those into account. You might also look at sentences such as "Clay and Kat had a unique relationship that not many stories will include..." You are making an incorrect assumption here. There are many stories that include a boy meeting a girl and some sexual tension ensuing; in fact, there's tons of those!
Point is, make sure you are not making unnecessary assumptions just to make things "sound" like an essay. Everything you mention should have a purpose to your subject. Sentences like the above suggest that you are trying to find a way of distinguishing the story from others when, according to your subject, you do not need to... the big question you beg here is: were Clay and Kat ever designed to be together?
Push your ideas.

Hi Jessica I enjoyed reading the first few lines of your essay. Like Malak said, the third paragraph focuses too much on the plot in my opinion. Instead of describing the story, it would be better to explain or give examples on why Clay and Kat's relationship didn't work out. Was it because Google failed to solve the code ? Was Kat not compatible with Clay in the first place? Did her new job at Google have anything to with their relationship falling apart? There are many reasons you could use to support your thesis, thus making your essay stronger. In addition, your last sentence regarding Kat's 'slight' influence over Clay's perspective of old knowledge and new knowledge was slightly confusing to me because I couldn't understand what you were trying to say. Perhaps that's another, separate topic area you could divulge in for your essay. Great ideas though!

After reading your first paragraph I believe the idea is that relationships in a story do not always have a happy ending. This is a interesting idea and essay topic. I believe you are on the right track by using Clay and Kat from Mr. Penumbra’s 24-hour book store as the focus on your essay. I also can see where you are trying to go with the second paragraph but I agree that third paragraph sounds more like a book summary. I think if you are trying to do an essay on the relationship between Clay and Kat, then you could give reasons on how and why the relationship is important to the story.

Your essay had an interesting start and the topic chosen for your essay was clearly understood from the first line. However in the third paragraph you start to discuss Clay’s relationship with a different subject. I think this might cause your essay to have too many ideas but bot info on just one specific one. So I would recommend focusing it on Clay and Kat’s relationship or Clay’s relationship with the old and new knowledge. There also isn’t any transition on the paragraphs so maybe add words or sentences that flows the paragraphs together. However, you do have two great topics that you can chose from between paragraph 1&2 and paragraph three that would produce an interesting essay.

Good idea for an essay it really shows what drove the relationship between Clay and Kat and why it eventually ended. I like the few short sentences you have like "Adventures and mysteries are irresistible" it is a good starting sentence for the paragraph and gets the text flowing nicely. It seemed a few times you were getting away from the idea of their relationship and instead focusing solely on Clay's character but I'm assuming you are going to expand on Kat's character as well. No grammatical errors other than the one's already said in other comments so good start.

Hi Jessica, I enjoy reading your draft. After reading the first paragraph, I though your essay will be about Clay and Kat relationship but the second and third paragraph did not led me to the same though. I enjoyed reading the third paragraph, as it is summery about Clay circumstances and his interest but nothing to do with Kat; beside, you wrote about old knowledge and new knowledge at the end of the paragraph ( books and computer technology) and linked with Kat which could be foundation for another interesting essay. Good luck.

Hi Jessica, your ideas were nice. Your essay was grammatically correct and there were little to no errors, aside from that I feel like you should elaborate on your ideas more. The structure and the ideas are there but I suggest expanding on them so readers are not left guessing. Here are some questions that may help: Why/ how was clay's new/ old knowledge influenced by Kat? Could there be a possible way that their relationship could've been saved? Hope this was useful!

I think that if you are to talk about the question of whether Kat and Clay were good together, or meant to be together, you could consider mentioning how she was far more intelligent than Clay, and how that helps to drives the story. He doesn't have her level of ambition and intellect and so what unites them, only temporarily, is cracking the code. When they no longer have they, they quickly realize they are not meant to be.

item.title: War Games Module - Character Details
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Instructions: Due for Feb. 4th class. This module is meant to get you thinking about the specifics of characterization so that you can better discuss what those specifics might mean to the themes in a text. The idea here is to see how establishing a baseline "read" of a character can give you a solid footing for building a more robust argument about themes in the text. As we have done in the past, this exercise is a way of interpreting and understanding how a text is put together or "constructed." Understanding how something is put together allows us to interpret it better. We can compare it to other things put together in a similar way (to other novels, for instance), or about similar things (to other stories), or that have similar parts (hackers as characters). However, before we discuss other things, we need to have some specifics. To put it bluntly, we need to establish what we have in front of us so we can discuss how it is similar or different to something else. We also want to position ourselves so that we can clearly distinguish what it is a character signals. Summary: Task: After watching War Games, make a few suggestions about the specific qualities of at least two characters from the movie --can be big role or small roll, but must be in the movie, somewhere. Outcomes: Think about how these specific qualities suggest "stock" elements. Then, think about how those "stock" elements point our interpretation and expectations in a certain direction.
  • How do a character's personality traits cause suspense and suspicion? What are the specifics of those traits and how do they work to cause suspicion or suspense?
  • How do character traits drive the narrative forward? (For instance, a particularly belligerent character might prevent an easy resolution ot the story; or, a particularly crafty criminal might create conflict where there wasn't conflict previously.)
  • How do specific character traits come together to make the character appear stock? And, once you've figured this out, what's different about THIS character's characteristics that make him/her interesting or uninteresting? (Who do we focus on and why?)
  • Which specific character traits of David Lightman match those of Ethan Levin? Which traits are quite different? What's different about the narrative outcomes and why?
Takeaways:
  • You're always safer making assumptions if you compile textual examples around a central part of the text--how are settings alike, how are characters similar, but different. "No facts but in THINGS."
  • Take account of your own assumptions about character types--nerds, rockers, emos, hipsters, etc. Are those assumptions borne out through the text? Or are you simply relying on your assumptions? Does the text play with your assumptions to create suspense, make a point, or resolve conflicts?
  • Characters often determine how we read or "decode" a theme. Charafters often try to pressure our "decoding" by distorting personality traits, forcing us to engage with new ways of understanding the representations, themes, and conflicts at play in the text.
  • Any analysis always begins with specific examples. You need to have specifics in order make general assumptions. Once you have established that baseline, you can move on to make more general commentaries.
Task, Reminder: Remember to respond to some of the questions above (in "Outcomes" or ") in the comment space below. Refer to the course procedures page -- the "Work Away from Class" section -- if you're confused about what you are supposed to be doing in the comment space below. Some of the characters in War Games:
  • David Lightman
  • Dr. John McKittrick
  • Dr. Stephen Falken
  • Joshua / WOPR (are these two characters maybe?)
  • Lightman's science teacher
  • Jennifer Mack
  • General Jack Beringer
  • Pat Healy
  • Watson
  • Col. Joe Conley
  • Beringer's Assistant
  • Capt. Jerry Lawson
  • Lt. Steve Phelps
  • Mr. and Mrs. Lightman
  • Mr. Liggett
  • Joshua Falken (the "real" one in the video)
  • Any of the missile launch dudes
  • The voice of the woman on the loudspeaker in NORAD before WOPR / Joshua magically takes over

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Dr.Stephen Falking is difficult to fit into one category. As at one point he appeared to be unphased by the prospect of the world going into nuclear holocaust and civilization being exterminated.
He directly opposed the protagonist (David Lightman) at the point of confrontation between the two characters. Being a combination of an absent minded professor (Not knowing how to disarm WOPR, and being unalarmed by it, as if he knew it was faulty in it's inability to learn futility) as well as directly opposing David Lightman he becomes a sort of Black-Knight. (Think Darth Vader in star wars, who has a change of heart near the end of the film and makes up with Luke Skywalker as hes dying)
Stephen Falken also has a change of heart, when he swoops in with his helicopter, and uses his authority and recognition in the U.S. Nuclear Command center to give David Lightman acess to Joshua/WOPR. However, in all honesty, Stephen Falken was not a very interesting character. It wasn't very clear why he had such an odd, "oh well who cares" out look on life. And the change of heart he had didn't make any sense to me. It seemed tacky and lame that he swooped in on a helicopter to save the day.
David Lightman is a hero, of course, but a reluctant one at that. In the beggining of the movie, David Lightman just wanted to play video games. He was not looking for any sort of adventure that involved saving the planet from nuclear war. Infact, when he first contacted Joshua/WOPR via his odd, old school floppy disk and dial up rig, he was treating the interface as if it was a video game. It was only when he got a glimpse of the news, that he realized he was 'playing with fire', so to speak.
David Lightman was immediately put off by the gravity of the situation, and pretended nothing had happened. Hoping it would go away, he was reluctant. And only after grasping the severity of the situation he caused, was he only able to undergo the quest of stopping the nuclear missles from being launched. David Lightman's character is also quite one-dimensional. It doesn't explain really why he has such a fascination with computers and the internet, and it doesn't explore the other facets of his character. As the reluctant hero, we don't know WHY he is reluctant, and spends so much time in his room.
The characters I discussed have properties that make them "Stock" characters, but no, they are not interesting characters at all.

David Lightman, the protagonist in the movie WarGames, is a somewhat interesting character at the same time, as he is only 17 years old, and possesses a vast knowledge of computer hacking and technology, although possessing the same mindset throughout the whole story. He is introduced as being a sneaky individual that is an avid computer hacker, as he knows where the school keeps their weekly password, he knows when to obtain it, and he is able to hack into the school computer system to change his grades. David Lightman is a hero in the movie, but not by choice. At first, his only intentions were to play games so he hacked into “Joshua,” an artificial intelligence program created by Dr. Stephen Falken. Only when Lightman realized that hiding from the problem that he started would do no good, and is caught by the government that he was able to start World War 3, did he decide to intervene and deactivate Joshua before it was too late. David Lightman is somewhat of an interesting character, as he is the protagonist in the story line, but his development is very one-sided. He is the one that caused the problem, and he is the one that fixes it in the end. He doesn’t do anything out of the ordinary, such as, betray the government, or cause the problem to escalate even further.
Dr. Stephen Falken, the anti-hero in the story, is a fascinating character in the story. When he is first introduced, he seems to be smart and interesting; as he created Joshua the computer program who is named after his son, and shortly after, “passes away” after Joshua was deemed futile, as it seemed he could not learn the difference between right and wrong. Throughout the movie, Lightman and Jennifer track down Falken; he is shown to be living by himself on a remote island. Falken sees himself as a failure because of Joshua, and does not seem to care for anything anymore even when Lightman and Jennifer explained to him that Joshua was able to start World War 3. However, as Lightman and Jennifer seem to have failed to convince Falken to assist them, Falken’s character development completely turns around, and he is more than willing to help them. This is captivating for the audience, but it never is explained why Falken suddenly had a change of heart, but the audience is given to speculate that Falken needed time to process what Lightman and Jennifer told him, and because of their words, decided to help them. Dr. Stephen Falken’s decision definitely played a key role in driving the story line forward, as Lightman might not have been able to deactivate Joshua without Falken’s help. Falken’s character turn-around certainly helped Lightman, and came to a positive outcome. Both David Lightman and Dr. Stephen Falken both have qualities that entitle them to be “Stock” characters, Lightman being the “Hero” and Falken being the “Anti-hero.” However, in character development, Lightman was one-sided as he always had the same mindset throughout the whole movie, thus making him less interesting than Falken, who had a complete character turn-around which drove the story forward, and helped Lightman come to a successful outcome, making Falken a more interesting character than Lightman, the main protagonist in the story.

David Lightman’s Science Teacher
David’s science teacher in the opening scene can be described mean, scary, and belittling instructor to those students who don’t perform well. David arriving to class late set up the Science teacher for the typical scenario of handing back an exam to him with a bold letter “F” right on the front. Likewise, when giggly Jennifer is unable to answer the Science teachers question since she was clearly not paying attention (or genuinely did not know the answer) he is prompted to then hand back her exam to which also had the same bold letter “F” on the front. These two events help provide evidence he is a stock character because of his inability to change, or adopt a different reaction to essentially the same occurrence – he remains flat. Likewise, these events help drive the narrative forward since they give the viewer insight to David’s and Jennifer’s characters and how they might coincide throughout the rest of the movie.
Jennifer Katherine Mack
Unlike the Science teacher, Jennifer Mack plays one of the main roles in Wargames. She acts as David’s love interest and helps him throughout the movie to. The stock elements that she initially possesses are that of a dumb and bubbly teenage girl, leading to the suspicion that she might not have too much to offer for the development of the film. We see Jennifer though, near the beginning of the movie to be undecided of the help that David is trying to give her by changing her Home Economics on the districts computer system that he’s hacked onto. She seemed hesitant and didn’t want him to enable her cheating at first, but the next time we see her character she is asking politely for him to be of her assistance. I think this ties up with the film very well because it shows Jennifer’s roundness, and hints that she will evolve further as it goes on.

The protagonist of Wargames, David Lightman, bears a stark resemblance to Ethan Levin of The Bug. They are similar in that both men are on a quest to stop something harmful. The early events of the movie lead David in a hot pursuit to stop Joshua(the WOPR’s artificial intelligence). Believing Joshua to be just a simple game, David begins playing global thermonuclear war. However, this causes the United States military into believing that the Russians are firing nuclear missiles. In the novel, Ethan Levin is in his own pursuit. His aim is to bring down a computer bug that freezes the whole program, jeopardizing the company. The character of David Lightman is a very interesting one. He is a very intelligent hacker with the knowledge on how to change his own school grades. David looks like the typical high school kid who just slacks off in school. He has no urgency in focusing on his school work; however, he does spend a lot of time on his microcomputer hacking into programs. The assumption of David is that watching tv or hanging out with friends is what peaks his interest. The opposite of that happens in the movie as he spends a vast amount of time on his microcomputer hacking or looking into whatever he wants. This is evident when he tries to use his computer to find information on a set of forthcoming computer games. A scene with David’s high school classmate Jennifer also points out to his different type of personality. As David tries to walk across to his computer, Jennifer blocks his legs in between hers. The classic assumption is that David might make a romantic move on Jennifer, but he does not. David does not have the stereotypical character-type of a guy who just wants to make out with girls. The movie tries to play out that something might happen in this situation but it does not. The relationship of David and Jennifer only culminates later on in the movie. Throughout this movie, it is evident that David is not a stereotypical nerd. He is intelligent, but not in the way most of us might think.

Mr. Liggett David Lightman’s science teacher is introduced in one of the first scenes. He represents the stereotypical high school teacher no student likes. He comes off with a condescending attitude and he fails to show any compassion for his students. In the scene set in his classroom, David ends up arriving late for class and Mr. Liggett is shown to react sarcastically, ultimately poking fun at him. Likewise, by showing the entire class Jennifer’s failed test mark with a giant, red F, Mr. Liggett mentions that her unsatisfactory results are the outcome of her not paying attention in class. Although this may be true, it still is no way a teacher should behave with a student. His character in general is flat as he doesn’t contribute to the story in any significant way and neither does his character develop throughout the movie. The type of stock character he portrays, the rude, unpopular high school teacher, may add slight elements of humor for some but otherwise leave his character rather uninteresting. David Lightman David Lightman plays the protagonist in the movie. He is an example of a character that starts off by getting himself in a conflict unknowingly, ends up trying to solve the problem he created and ultimately ends up saving the day. He represents the stereotypical stock character of a young, teenage geek who keeps to himself usually because he is too busy with his obsession of sorts (computers). Because of the conflict associated around his character, I think it makes him interesting and round due to the fact that he plays the problem creator in the beginning and the problem solver at the end.

The NORAD lady who announces the missile launch countdown is definitely a cause for suspense in the film. Her clear, calm, and yet commanding voice is a defining character trait that drives a great sense of urgency in her respective scenes. She indicates that time is rapidly running out and that in turn causes tension to build. The other characters, now extremely panicked, are pressured to resolve the problem of the world blowing up. Her character’s actions act as a vehicle for plot. She motivates the other characters to ‘make a move’, which is crucial to any story. In a way, she sparks suspicion in the audience about whether the missiles will actually launch. The NORAD lady’s calm voice and precision seems like the kind of stock character of a dutiful government controller. What makes her interesting is that she is actually terrified too. While her voice conveys that she is poise, her eyes say that she is petrified to be counting down to her potential death! She causes the building of friction- for rising action to occur just before the climax. She makes everyone else act desperately which keeps the audience entertained.
Jennifer Mack also sparks suspicion in the film. Her mysterious and flirtatious behaviour around David has the audience wondering whether some sort of romantic relationship will form between them. Her actions can be very provocative, but David is clueless to what she means. That leaves the audience thinking that the romantic link may not be exactly inevitable. David is the type of nerd hacker stock character that is blind to pretty girls like Jennifer Mack. Which leads me to identify that Jennifer Mack as a stereotypical dumb pretty girl. Malak, in the comments above, points out how Jennifer may seem like a round character when she initially resists David when he changes her Science mark and then changes her mind. This is also an example of why she is interesting despite her stock characteristics. The audience thinks she has a heart of gold by doing the right thing (and is crazy enough to be content with an F), BUT when she changes her mind, people begin to reconsider their stance on her character. We find out she is fun and awesome, but also quite a badass- which is proven to be an incredibly intriguing character trait!

The corporal in the infirmary (cannot recall his name, if mentioned) that was supposed to keep a watch for David Lightman as he was held for questioning represents a stereotypical stock character. He is the type of character that is trusted to guard the door and make sure David, in this case, is where he is meant to be; the carelessness of this character leads to a roadblock for the FBI agents. Instead of keeping his mind focused on the task at hand, the corporal sees the opportunity to flirt with the pretty woman who also works there. His neglect and lack of attentiveness ultimately lead to David's escape, all while he was striking out with the blonde woman on the computer. David's escape causes suspense for the viewer, allowing the minds to wander, it also moves the plot along and makes it a little more dramatic (Will David be caught? The movie could have ended much quicker if the corporal paid attention. What will happen next?)
As many have already mentioned, David Lightman is also the stock character type. The computer nerd, intelligent but prioritizes his hacking abilities over school work (hence having to change his grades) He is more focused on finding new video games than spending time with a girl, and avoids taking responsibility of the fiasco he caused by hacking into the 'game' until it is almost too late. Lightman, and Levin share some similar and very different qualities. They both wanted to stop what they unintentionally started. Lightman with the war game he thought he was playing, Levin with the bug he thought he created. Lightman was able to live to see his doing be fixed, showing character growth. From an ignorant young boy to someone who understands the consequences of his actions, fixing them before it's too late. On the other hand, Levin's character disintegrated as the novel progressed. From a prestigious programmer to a broken man ending his own life as a consequence to all the doings he wasn't able to fix. Both characters are intelligent, and have a thorough knowledge of technology, coding and hacking but only one succeeds to finish to have their happy ending.

Lightman’s Science Teacher: Lightman’s Science Teacher is a stock character because he is shown as what a typical high school science teacher would be in most movies. His students do not pay attention in his class as most of are receiving rather low marks and are having their own conversations. Lightman’s science teacher embarrasses him and his fellow classmate Jennifer Mack, so when the Lightman makes a joke about him, it can be understood that the relationship between his student and himself is the same. Since he does not enjoy them not paying attention in his class and would prefer to not have them in his class and they do not want to be in his class as well. However, the stock character that Lightman’s teacher represents allows the viewer to understand Lightman from another perspective. One may pick out the fact that Lightman received a low mark in his biology class and does not wish to participate in it that much since it is hinted that is always sent to detention by the same teacher. But when he is smart enough to change his mark for that biology course so one may perceive that he may just be a lazy person. This is also proven false in the film when Lightman takes the time and effort of trying to find the number of the game company so that he could hack the company and play the games before the program was even released. So from this one can suggest that Lightman is not dumb or lazy but he has no interest in that course. Lightman allows us to understand how exactly his science teacher is stock character between the student teacher relationship they share. Lightman’s science is an uninteresting character as he only has a small role in the movie and is mostly there just to let the person watching the film understand a bit about Lightman’s background.

Someone watching the movie would describe David Lightman at the beginning to be what we would describe as a typical hacker. He was lonely, didn't have many friends, genius with computers and was always looking for new things to hack into. These are some of the traits that David possessed and which made his characteristics like a stock characters. What makes David interesting is that normally we would think of hackers as being geeky, or timid and shy but David isn't necessarily like that. When he found out what he had hacked into he decided instead of hanging out in the background he would try and stop Joshua and become the hero in the movie, which isn't a typical stock trait of a hacker.
David Lightmans specific character traits of a hacker start the story off and create the conflict in the first place but he is also the way the movie moves forward. At first he wants to impress the girl, Jennifer Mack, by hacking into the school's data base and changing their grades. Then he moves on to trying to impress her even more by showing her that he can hack into larger companies, or so he thought. When he found out he was the reason that their country was on the brink of a nuclear war, his character traits changed and he became more of the hero type. He escapes from the guards under lock down by being smart and using technology to his advantage, then he gets out and searches for Dr. Stephen Fawlken to come help him stop Joshua, since he was the one that programmed it in the first place. With David's changes in personality the movie was able to move forward. If he had stayed the same guy and not change from a hacker personality type to a hero, then the movie would not have ended the same, most likely the war wouldn't have been stopped.

Jennifer Mack
Jennifer Mack’s personality traits create suspense in the movie. First, she seems like a silly typical teenager that doesn’t take things seriously as we see her joking around with the biology teacher. Typical teenager stereotypes include rebellious, trouble-making, lazy and immature. That’s the stock element of her personality and I thought that’s who she is going to be throughout the movie. She changes throughout the movie, she is willing to help her love interest David and trying to stop Joshua from her country being blown up. This shows that she is not lazy and thoughtful, different from her stock characteristics.
David Lightman vs Ethan
David Lightman’s character is very interesting. At the beginning of the movie, seeing that he has failed his biology exam, I assume that he is either lazy or not smart. When he starts hacking through his school’s grading system and the game about wars, we see that he is very intelligent and so focused in what he is doing because he is obsessed with hacking since it’s so interesting to him. He prioritizes his hacking (his interest) over school, Jennifer and spending time with family. At the end. I feel like his character does change a bit. He went from fiddling and hacking to something dangerous that he is unaware of and then trying to fix Joshua so his country/ or the world will not blow up. I think at the end through David’s experience, he sees that technology can cause severe consequences because technology is more than what you’re dealing with. David is similar to the Bug’s Ethan Levin, who prioritize the Jester over his girlfriend and other social relationship. Ethan is obsessed in one thing, “the Jester” like David with his hacking. Although these two characters have similar stock character elements such as nerdy, busy with their “interests” and highly intelligent, they also are different from another. Ethan is lonely, shy (or quiet), insecure and pessimist while David on the other hand is silly (when he jokes with the biology teacher and hack to play games) and not as depressed.

Mr. Liggett, David Lightman’s science teacher, is a stock character in the movie. He is not a fully rounded character and serves the purpose to further the development of David Lightman’s character. The science teacher is a flat character and is a strict and unforgiving teacher that is not very fond of David. The bitterness towards the main character shapes the way David is seen and portrayed as at school. Mr. Liggett is a teacher that not many students are a fan of and is not necessarily a fun character in the movie. His character plays a very minor role in the movie. The science teacher is not further developed through the movie as he does not appear very evidently throughout the film. This is why Mr. Liggett is a flat stock character in this movie.
David Lightman is the main character and the protagonist throughout the movie. David is a round character that is an intelligent young boy with no ambition. He is a lazy student and is snarky with his teachers. David is a hacker and decides to hack into a program so that he can play a video game. Ultimately, David causes the problem of potential world war 3. David becomes the hero in the story as he has to work to solve the problem that he created. However, David’s attitude towards the whole situation is more of a bitter outlook. As a result of David’s lazy persona, he is reluctant to help and does not want to be involved in the situation any more than he already is. As soon as David realizes the intensity of the situation, he decides that he has to help and has to move somewhere else other than his room to hack into the program and prevent the war.

Hey Malak,
Good post about the movie, I accidentally watched the belated sequel WarGames: The Dead Code but they generally follow the same story line.
It's interesting that you described her in that way because in the 2008 version she is the smart, witty, "know-it-all" type of girl but similarly she does also play the boys love interest.
In the movie I watched Annie plays the role of Jennifer and she sounds like she has the same role and characteristics.

There are many factors that can drive a narrative forward, for example, Dr. Falken's lack of sympathy and hope for humanity inadvertently put everyone at risk for a major world war. His own personal struggle with himself lead to a standstill in the operation to deactivate a computer program, of artificial intelligence, named "Joshua" from possibly starting an all our war. When David and Jennifer convinced Dr. Falken to help stop the capable machine, the whole plot turned around and Dr. Falken and David Lightman combine their intelligence to stop the computer. Dr. Falken is a round character with a back story, he changes throughout the movie to become one of the two heroes.
David Lightman is a very typical slacker, nerdy, video gaming teenage boy that qualifies to be categorized under "nerd". Like most teenagers , he is alienated from his parents as they have no clue about his life. David is very intelligent with computers, his knowledge with them goes beyond an average person and he is very talented with hacking, as it is safe to assume he was self taught. His knowledge created conflict but also solved it, it is very suspenseful. What makes David interesting is the fact that he had the ability to solve things but doesn’t apply his super genius skills to school as we see in the first part of the movie, David has no desire to succeed despite his talents. This makes everything interesting especially David because no one expects a low achieving teenage boy to save the world from destruction. It is expected to have a big buff hero in a movie but it is never expected that a "nerd" would.

David Lightman is not your typical “geek”; although he loves video games and computer hacking, David actually prevails to be a pretty sociable dude. In the beginning of the film, David comes running into the classroom late, making jokes about the teacher, leading him to be sent down to the principal’s office; where David and his principal discuss his “behavior problem”. In a way, David can also be characterized as a “bad boy”. He gets sent down to the principal’s office a lot, which means he likes to act silly and doesn’t really care about school. His grades are not that good either, considering he hacks into the schools network to change his failing grade into a "C". The ladies love him; well one in particular, a “queen bee” named Jennifer Macs, who likes David’s humor and admires his strange computer skills. What really drives the narrative forward is when David becomes over obsessive, as he tries to hack into the war games hard drive. He digs deep into his research and doesn’t sleep or go to school until he cracks the password. This reminds me of Ethan Levin’s character in the novel “The Bug”, when Ethan becomes over obsessed with trying to fix the bug and when he fails it completely ruins him. If David didn’t figure out the password, it would of probably would of ruined him too.
Dr. Stephen Falken, when introduced in his documentary seemed like a very intelligent man and a creator, who loved computer programming. He was passionate about his work and proud of Joshua. When David and Jennifer found him in his secret hideout, although he was still intelligent, he was no longer proud of Joshua or interested in knowing about what was going on. He did not have the intent or ambition to help David save the world. Falken can be stock characterized as a “Stingy man” because he did not want to contribute and wanted to the world end. Dr. Stephen drove the narrative forward when he came to his senses and helped take David and Jennifer to the headquarters to help disable Joshua. The mysteriousness of Falken made the film more suspenseful, by thinking they were doomed until he returned with a helicopter, ready to help.

Dr. John McKittrick, the guy who introduced the computer machine WHOPR, a computer program to react to impending threats of nuclear war to protect the USA, to NORAD is a flat character. From the beginning to end, he is an angry, determined, and confident character. He possesses a stock element of a professor: intelligent, scientist figure, inventor, etc. Moreover, his angry and bold personality creates an atmosphere of suspense, especially in the part where WHOPR played a simulation game of nuclear war between the USSR and the US. The on-going conflict between him and the general has created a division between pro-computers and anti-computers running the nuclear defence system. General Beringer's antagonistic and pessimistic role in the movie has created an interesting conflict. He embodies a stereotyped general figure well: all knowing, mocking, scornfulness, and portrayal of authority.
From observations, the assumptions about character types are bourne out through the text. The character types in stories/movies/novels is what drives the story along to a more interesting topics and arguments. Character types play a vital role in building up the story, just as important as setting.

Dr. Stephen Falken was portrayed as the crazy scientist who believed that all life must come to an end at some point. He comes off as being villainous to some degree but then has an epiphany to help the kids get back to the base and help David stop Joshua. He is portrayed as the mad scientist because his work with the computer ended for various personal reasons which is used to make him seem unstable and socially inept. He eventually is forced to come to his senses by David and takes them to the base to help Joshua/WORP to understand that there is no winning side to the game he is playing.
Lightman’s Science Teacher is a classic stock character of a teacher. This is because the professor is shown as not putting up with the students and having a mutual hate relationship between the students and him. He is portrayed as the teacher that will send all the students who miss behave to the principal’s office and will not tolerate students that do not have the right answers.
David Lightman and Ethan Levin have a few similar characteristics and traits which include their idea to not attend the situation right away and to see if the problem will correct itself. Both are dedicated to fixing the problem and in their missions to fix the problem they in turn changed with their task.

Dr. Stephen Falken causes a great amount of suspense in War Games because he it seemed that he is the only one who could stop the nuclear war. David couldn’t figure out how to stop the computer so he went to find Dr. Falken to save the world, but despite Davids pleading, Dr. Falken wouldn’t help. Dr. Falken was also driving the narrative forward when doing this. The story would have been cut short if he had just went along and fixed the computer. The fact that Dr. Falken couldn’t even fix the computer when he finally decided to help David caused more suspense. This delay in saving the world was a great way to bring more action to the story and make the movie less predictable.
Dr. Falken is a stock mad scientist who has come up with a revolutionary product that seems will change the world for the better. Despite this stock character trait, Dr. Falken doesn’t actually initially try and help save the world from his product. . A normal stock scientist usually feels the guilt of his creation is does his best to fix it. And furthermore, when he decides to help, he couldn’t even figure out how to fix it. This makes Dr. Falkens character quite interesting because it leaves the audience on edge about what his next move will be.
David Lightman and Ethan Levin have the same qualities of stock nerd characters but they also have a lot of differences. David does not succeed very well in school, but he is a very smart boy. He really enjoys playing around with his computer and hacking into sites. He is actually very personable for a nerd and he even attracts a girl. Ethan went down a different path. He succeeded in school and almost got his PhD, but he could not solve a simple bug. Ethan does not like computer programming and when the stress of work became too intense. Faced with conflict Ethan begins to break down to the point where he can’t solve the solution. He was also so distant from his girlfriend that she ended up cheating on him. David and Ethan show how characters can have the same stock character traits, but be very different.

David Lightman one of the main characters and the protagonist is seen as a care free, intelligent yet under achieving teen who spends his time playing games in an arcade and hacking into systems on his computer. David is portrayed as intelligent but lazy, care free and rebellious as he has smart remarks for his teacher and is constantly in the principal’s office. He also changes his grades by hacking into the computer system which shows his intelligence yet laziness. All these traits that David possess cause suspense as David’s intelligence and computer hacking skills are the only way that can stop “Joshua” in the game “Global Thermonuclear War.” At the beginning David is seen as a carefree teen who just wants to have fun, but drives the narrative forward by becoming obsessed with hacking into a system in which he can play games. This leads to him to playing the game “Global Thermonuclear War” with “Joshua.” This potentially starts a war that ultimately only David can finish. David’s character then changes as he seems more serious and caring.
David Lightman has similar traits like Ethan Levin as they both are seen as intelligent, Ethan a programmer and David who likes to hack into systems. Both can be seen as obsessive, Ethan who is obsessed with the Bug and David when he kept trying to hack into the system to play games.
David Lightman’s science teacher is seen as a typical science teacher, from his appearance to the way he acts in the movie. He is portrayed as the serious teacher that is not liked by his students. This is evident as characters David makes remarks to him and is sent to the principals office. David Wightman’s science teacher is a stock character because there are no changes in his character throughout the movie.

So for this weeks Movie Module, I mistakenly watched the wrong WarGames Movie. We were supposed to watch the 1983 movie but I watched the recent one, “WarGames: The Dead Code” which is a belated sequel to the original shot in 1983.
Will Farmer (who is similar to David Lightman in the 1983 movie) also plays the protagonist in the movie. Will is the smart, kind, generous, young man. Right away I knew the entire movie would be based around him solving or breaking a code that seemed to be impossible. He’s a high school student and right away has more knowledge about hacking, and fixing bugs than a regular teenage boy. He’s introduced to computers by his old neighbor who has continuous computer problems and each time Will fixes the problem, about two days later the computer is hacked again.
As the movie goes on Will finds out that he the government has something to do with it and a game called “Ripley” and he tries to stop whatever they are up to. His personality caused the suspense through out the entire movie because he was so driven to destroy Ripley; he kind of took us on a crazy adventure with him. I found him very quick and smart with whatever situation was thrown his way.
Another character I found was interesting who in my movie didn’t have the biggest role was Joshua. Joshua was a programmed game but in the end helps defeat Ripley. He’s a major/central character as he is vital to the development and resolution of the conflict that takes place throughout the story line. Joshua is a minor character but serves qualities to complement Will.
Will is more of a “stock” character, he’s exciting and gives the movie suspense and I could tell right away, although some stock characteristics can be boring I found Will to be a good example of a stock character.
Characterization for a story or movie allows us to empathize with the antagonist or protagonist so that we can feel what is happening to them is happening to us as well. It helps bring out their motives (which in this case is to destroy Ripley and “beat the game”). Overall, I really enjoyed the movie! I’d recommend it for those who enjoyed the 1983 version!

David's mother felt like a stock character to me. She was the hardworking, busy and distracted real estate agent doubling as a mother who probably didn't pay as much attention to him as David would've appreciated. It seemed that all they cared about were his grades and since David was able to hack that system himself, there would be no issues with his mother or father. They mentioned something about their son spending a lot of time in his room but then the phone calls begin and his mother is back to focusing on work.
With regards to Ethan Levin, he and David are both consumed with problems that start as something small and harmless and then grow into serious life threatening issues. For Ethan it was his mental well being and the collapse of Telligensia and for David it was the nuclear war that he unknowingly declared as he thought it was just a game. Both these characters have tenacious attitudes towards their technologies- they get completely obsessed with solving code. Ethan gets so obsessed that he loses his mind and eventually commits suicide and David continues to hack into the computer and into Joshua to get access to a video game. They both are relentless and stock nerdy characters.

Malvin
For those who might not remember, Malvin was the man in the glasses who took the paper away from Jim. He had a very high pitch voice and a noisy personality. When Malvin first makes an appearance in the movie he was socially awkward for he places himself into the conversation between Jim and David. Malvin is a flat supporting character and due to his personality I quickly assumed he was a stock character, a nerd. His characteristic happened to remind me of another character that is quite similar from the show Big Bang Theory. That would be Sheldon Cooper. Sheldon and Malvin share multiple characteristic but what I found the most that resemble each other was that both think of themselves higher in intellect compared to others. When David asked how he should start his search Malvin was quick to respond “are you stupid” and “I got this all figured out”. Malvin character traits also drove the narrative forward because without Malvin suggestion of how to start the search, David wouldn’t have been able to continue.
David Lightman
David Lightman is the protagonist in the movie. I thought he was a very interesting character. He’s a young boy with knowledge of computers and hacking that most boys his age have no idea about. He first came as lazy, due to him changing his grades and showing up late to class, but throughout the story I soon to learn that David isn’t a lazy man. He put a lot of effort and work to access what he thought was a game and to fix his mistake. Although he might not double bag the garbage to keep his dog out, David is a hardworker.

I really appreciate your thoughts on the differences between Lightman and Levin. Lightman definitely seemed to be better able to adapt and bounce back from set-backs than Levin.. kind of an interesting comparison between someone young, who has the whole world in front of him versus someone who's in the process of getting chewed up by the processes of life events and being unable to cope without the sort of optimism a young person feels with their life still bright and full of promise. (I also like that you brought up the officer in the infirmery... although he really made me uncomfortable with his creepy/sexual harassment approach to trying to woo the nurse)

David Lightman, is the main dynamic character as he essential to the development and solution of the conflict and his personality changed as the movie move forward. In beginning of the movie, the main personal characteristics of David were a teen not doing well at school and likes playing arcade video games. While he messing around his computer trying to hack to video games, by chance he hacked in to WOPR and he started to play one of the listed game called Global Thermonuclear War. Dived discovered that he wasn’t playing but unknown he hacked a top-secret military system that helps the Air Force decide what to do in the event of a Soviet attack. Soon, David personality change and he tried to fix the problems by searches for Dr. Stephen Fawlken to ask for his help. David is the protagonist personality in the movie as he started as irresponsible teen creates a big problem ending to be a hero trying his best to solve it. WOPR or Joshua is an interesting character in the movie (maybe the antagonist) although it’s a computer playing the game but its ads a lot off suspense and suspicion to the story. As Joshua was playing its simulating Soviet attacks on the US, and all the efforts which done by David (the hero) were to stop it.

I don't think that Stephen Falken was that hard to place into a category.. I'd say he was the eccentric genius/hermit crossed with an anti-hero complex... He was a genius, came up with a revolutionary idea of teaching a computer how to learn and run scenarios to predict outcomes, but when faced with personal tragedy he withdrew from the world and continued doing pet research projects ( like the pterodactyl remote controlled flying machine). He didn't want to be involved with the matters of the world, but his morality wouldn't just let him stand by when he was confronted with the fact that he could potentially save the world even though he didn't consider himself a part of that world anymore.
The girl, Jennifer Mack, was definitely a stock character.. It was kind of neat that they showed a couple different kind of students that don't get good marks. Matthew Broderick's character was really smart, but seemed bored with school so he didn't apply himself, while Jennifer just didn't care for intellectual/academic pursuits at all and didn't apply herself. She was basically a girl-next-door, potentially a love interest but Broderick's character was too passionate about cracking the puzzle to pursue her until it's resolved. It seemed to me like she was mostly there to ask the questions the audience might have been asking about this new-fangled technology and what hacking was... and occasionally bail him out of a sticky spot. Perhaps that's pretty cynical of me.
I think a writer can utilize character tropes as tools to move the story in the way they want to... Using an old crone trope vs. a maiden would allow them to drive a story in a way that readers would either accept as in line with their assumptions about the lives of the characters and what choices they would make, or draw attention to the character by putting a twist in there. Such as how Ellen Ulman had Kat not behave in a way that one might expect a young woman to behave.. she is a big nerd, highly intelligent, and seemingly not interested in a long term relationship because of her work. Women are usually assumed to want to settle down and have a family or put a relationship before a career. I don't think that WarGames made any significant changes to the stock characters, and it didn't make the movie not entertaining, but it was pretty predictable as an 80's movie.

General Beringer was a tough, confident character who always maintained his composure, even as a nuclear war seemed imminent. He was also computer illiterate, and preferred to use men instead of computers to launch the missiles, if it were necessary. He was also rational; he waited for the last possible second,to be sure it wasn't a real attack from the Russians. It seemed he could be the stereotypical overly aggressive military man, who would strike first and ask questions later, but proved to be otherwise.
David's science teacher was condescending and enjoyed handing out poor grades to his students.He does not represent the stereotypical view of a teacher, that is, someone helpful and caring.
Dr Stephen Falken: Initially cold, distant and unemotional, who had given up on life. Later in the story, he returns to the way he was depicted earlier in the movie, as caring and compassionate. David Lightman called him out on this, saying "I know you weren't always like this"-when he was being distant and cold at their first meeting.
Jennifer: Intelligent, but not in the same way that David Lightman was. She was book smart but not tech savvy, as she was didn't understand much of what David was doing with computers. She was also very curious and inquisitive-always asking questions.
oops, got my authors mixed up! Meant Robin Sloan - not Ulman!

Joshua and WOPR are certainly different characters even though they call the machine by his name. Joshua is not too described in the movie except for the very fact that he is indeed Falken’s son and died at a young age. He is loved by his father so much that Falken named his prized invention after him. Ultimately, Joshua is the final answer, or should I say code, to enter in to the WOPR’s system, proving his importance to his father. He is the code to the back door as hackers would call it; leading the protagonist to open up the malevolent intelligence that is the WOPR. I am not too familiar about the specifics of what type of stock character Joshua could be, but I could say that he reminds me of Lily Potter. Lily protected Harry all these years with love and protection against the death that Voldemort was to set upon Harry. Similarly, Falken used his son’s name because of his love for his son like he loves his work. Moreover, Falken set Joshua as the barrier to protect himself from the dangers of what he had made, what the computer might bring, and also to protect his son from it (I might be straying off topic here bringing in Technophobia and Harry Potter, just trying to prove a point).
WOPR on the other hand, is the independent computer that learns by experience. It is such an interesting character that it thinks on its own and knows who it works for. It was initially made to learn from what has been thought to it by Falken, yet in the end learns by itself. In the beginning you could tell that the movie makers made the character really suspicious, scary, and almost cringing to hear it talk once it did. It seemed that the year they made this movie was when computers started to be on the bandwagon. They show the frightening side of the character to let the watchers know that computers cannot be trusted. It surely created the conflict between the protagonist and the men in blue suites, and the machine. Also the machine reminds me of Ethan Levin. Both were very obsessive with winning, too focused, and knew they were witted. I actually enjoyed the movie; it had humour, and romance of course, even with its war commentaries, and quite the dark theme.
I like your connections you made between War Games and the Bug! You brought to my attention things I never thought of before reading this!

Hi Nicole!
Thanks for recommending the 2008 version of the movie. I was supposed to watch it but decided to watched the 1983 version since the setting from what the trailer on Youtube showed appealed to me. It's great to know that the movie followed in on Joshua's character, he is like you have said, vital to the conflict in the movie. I would also recommend to you the 1983 version of the movie, you know how they say the originals are better?

Throughout the movie War Games there are certain characters that drive the plot forward. David Lightman is a tech savvy seventeen year old boy who has a passion for computers. He is a stock character because he plays the role of a typical teenage boy. He doesn't try very hard in school, spends a lot of time on his computer, is quite the troublemaker, and doesn't have his priorities straight. Unlike most teenage boys, he finds a way to hack into the school system where he is able to change his and his classmates report card marks. Then he does sometime beyond the expectations of any stock character: he comes close to ending the world by hacking into War Games which he is at first under the impression that it is only a game but it turns out to be real and very serious.
David's mischievous and sneaky personality causes suspense especially when he continues to do things such as running away from the police and the officials, hiding in not so secret locations, and frequently becoming very close to being caught. In one scene he manages to escape with a tour group and gets back on their bus to leave the grounds. It is suspenseful when he appears to get caught but it turns out an official was only impatiently reminding him to stay with the group.
David and Ethan have quite a few things in common. They both work long and hard in an attempt to decode a computer system. Also, both Ethan and David's issues could potentially have an effect on a larger group of people. The Bug is at risk of jeopardizing the company and War Games puts the entire United States Military on alert as they believe the Soviets are going to attack with nuclear missiles. These life changing problems put an immense amount of pressure on both Ethan and David's characters.

In the movie “War Games”, suspense and suspicion is often caused by the protagonist, David Lightman, who manages to keep the viewer on the edge of their seats for some particular scenes. David is surely a stock character as he can be seen as what some might call your typical teenage boy. In other words, he is a trouble maker at school, he does not seem to care about his grades, and he likes video games. However, there is one thing that stand out about David. He is extremely tech-savvy, and can even hack into his high school’s grading system to change his grades from D’s to C’s, B’s or even A’s. What makes him even more interesting to focus on is when he hacks into what he thinks is a computer game called “War Games”, although it is way more than just a game. Precisely, it is a program where you pick a country to target with missiles, appearing as if it were a game, but with real life consequences. When David realizes he has accidentally put the United States of America in jeopardy, he forgets about his lazy slacker attitude he always had in school, and embarks on a difficult adventure to save the future of his home country, where he demonstrates rarely seen before traits such as determination, unpredictability, and problem solving.
Another stock character is David’s science teacher, who picks favourites (David is not one of them), is very serious, and likes to pick on people who misbehave in class, namely David who arrives late, and has his own side discussions while the teacher is talking. This leads his teacher to publicly announce to the class that David received an F on his exam. Although the teacher is only in one scene, he does not appear to have any characteristics that make him out to be different than the viewer would expect, and does not have any contribution to the plot or outcome of this film, making the viewer forget about him almost immediately after his scene ends.

item.title: Essay Draft
item.dc:creator: jessicanicks
item.content:encoded: In the novel “Mr. Penumbra’s 24-hour bookstore” by Robin Sloan, the main character Clay Jannon encounters a librarian named Ajax Penumbra, who introduces Clay to the Unbroken Spine Fellowship and seeks help in Clay, to solve Aldus Manutius’ Codex Vitae by using technology. In the beginning of the novel, it appears that Clay has a lot to learn from the wise, bookkeeper Mr. Penumbra, but when Clay solves the Founder’s Puzzle through his 3-D model replica of the bookstore, Penumbra suspects that using computers might be a faster way to solve the codex vitae; therefore, leading them to encoding key of immortality.    The nature of Clay and Penumbra’s relationship is that both of them have something to learn from one another. Going along with the theme of old knowledge verses new knowledge, Penumbra teaches Clay about old knowledge (the codex vitaes and the Unbroken Spine) and Clay teaches Penumbra about new knowledge (computers and technology). Penumbra helps Clay drive the narrative by introducing him to the waybacklist and informing him about the Festina Lente Company and the secret book lover’s fellowship. The two then works together as partners, along with other computer wizards to try to decipher the code by using Google.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: You have a really good thesis for the relationship of Clay and Penumbra, along with supportive information. However, I would recommend you put your thesis at the end of the first paragraph instead of the beginning of the second paragraph, but that’s just me. Be sure to revise for grammatical errors and add some more information by expanding on key ideas a bit more in detail, it seems a bit too short. Also, I think you you dived right into the plot of the story at the beginning of the introduction, maybe start with a hook to capture the readers attention.

You have a good starting point for a thesis. It needs to be focused a bit more. You might consider discarding the old knowledge / new knowledge dichotomy because it clouds the point of that sentence. In other words, what you're really asking yourself here is what are they learning from each other? Try to pin that down and work from there--then you'll have a really clear sentence that can guide you in finding some evidence of what they are looking for. There's a lot to cover in the sentence as it is, so you'll want to refine the approach as you find examples.

I have to agree with DNW, that you should pick one thing they learn from each other and really expand on any evidence found. From there you could ask why that exchanged information is important or what it means to the overall story. Furthermore, the first paragraph summarizes the novel more than anything. It does kind of set up where you are going with the essay, however, you should focus more on the exchange of knowledge between the characters and less on minor factual like Clay is the main character who encounters Penumbra, who introduces Clay… and so on. Instead, dive right into what you want to say. We all know what you’re talking about, so go ahead and explain why their exchange of knowledge is important!

The draft here is very clear and makes sense. The comparison between old and new knowledge and then using them together by learning from each other is a great point and has a lot to work with for an essay. It seems you might be writing a few run-on sentences. The first paragraph has only two sentences maybe split some into smaller sentences. Didn't find any other syntactical or grammatical errors other than that though good work.

I find your thesis is interesting: old technology versus new technology. It’s something we all can understand when we are reading the book and something we can all relate to. I think that your first sentence is a bit hard to follow, maybe shorten a bit (it’s a little bit too long). However you provide a good short summary about the book as your introduction. How about providing a hook so you can engage the audience about your essay? And then you can start your summary from there (or out it in your body paragraphs). I also agree with Jordan, you should put your thesis at the end of your introduction paragraph so it can lead to your body paragraphs better.

"In the novel “Mr. Penumbra’s 24-hour bookstore”, the main character Clay Jannon encounters a librarian named Ajax Penumbra. Penumbra is old, tall and thin, and filled with knowledge; just like his bookstore. Clay on the other hand, is young and hip, who’s skilled with marketing tactics and computer, webpage design. The nature of Clay and Penumbra’s relationship is that both of them have something to learn from one another: old knowledge verses new knowledge. Penumbra teaches Clay about old knowledge (the codex vitaes and the Unbroken Spine) and Clay teaches Penumbra about new knowledge (computers and technology). " what do you think about this intro?

item.title: Reading Week Module: Interpretation and Encryption -- Themes!!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
We've entered the second half of the course. As a result, we will be turning a little more forcefully toward the analysis and discussion of themes. In particular, we'll be looking at themes that coalesce around representations of people interacting with technology and the broader cultural, physical, and emotional world that accompanies the representation of people interacting with technology. This module should help you become more familiar with what exactly constitutes a theme. In other words, what is a theme and how is it helpful to understand texts using themes or, more excitingly, how do themes in texts help us understand the world? Themes help us to place texts in intelligent spaces so that we can properly relate them, or decode them. We're trying to understand how texts are encrypted and how we might better interpret what's useful about them--this includes our own work / writing, or even the profession we choose to enter. There's not much in the world that doesn't involve some kind of interpretation, decryption and encryption. This module, unlike the others, requires a good deal of work on your own. Try to understand what a theme is and then make a judgement about what you think the theme might be. There can be multiple themes in one text, so there's no "right" answer that you're looking for--you are trying to identify in the poem's content, or in its form (that one is important), some relationship to technology and/or its representation in a cultural, artistic, or social way (or not!). For this week's module. You need to do 5 things:
  1. Read William Gibson's poem Agrippa and the accompanying context pages
  2. Read and download this .pdf from Ishac Bertram that gives a few examples of "code poems."
  3. Read Elizabeth Bishop: "Sestina"
  4. Read E. E. Cummings: "r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r" and "1(a"
  5. Okay, so you've read a few poems, now, for Friday Feb. 13th, think about some of the themes that might come out of reading these poems and write in your suggestions in the comment space below before Friday Feb. 13, 2015. These themes can be gut reactions -- like "confusion" for example, or "I understand the ones that are not in code." The idea here is to capture your reaction to the poem's content--as much as you can get at the meaning of the poem.
Check back here on Friday for the second half of the module. MAKE SURE YOU STUDY FOR YOUR EXAM!!!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
I think time is a minor theme in the poem “Agrippa” by William Gibson. Moments in time are evident by photographs and using these photographs, people decode the image to understand what happened while the photo was taken.
Collectively, all the code poems suggest that people everywhere around the world struggle with the same problems at some point in time. Underlying our differences, people are very much the same species. While reading “DAILYGRIND” in particular, I took away the idea of routine. That people’s days begin, they go about their lives, their day ends. Boredom from the repetition of routine is a common problem in many people’s lives.
While reading “TWOFACED”, I recognized that people’s thoughts can contrast with what they are saying. The facade of kindness can mask what people are really thinking in day-to-day life.
Elizabeth Bishop’s “Sestina” was a more interesting and challenging poems in terms of theme. I did take away the theme of coincidence. The grandmother believes that the almanac foretold the rainfall and that she herself was going to cry, but that could have very well just been an accident. The almanac relays historical information that indicates what is likely or could happen in the future, but by no means predict the future.
In both E.E. Cummings’ “r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r” and “l)a” both suggest that reading is a form of decoding. Initially its difficult to understand what the words are even saying until you connect the letters or rearrange them. The visual structure of each poem threw me off, but after later contemplation gave meaning to the poems. For instance, in “r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r”, some of the jumbled up letters make little sense, but after rearranging them they read ‘grasshopper’. In addition, the obscure letters mixed with symbols are similar the movement of grasshoppers- hopping and jumping and never staying in one place too long. In “l(a”, the poem looks like a bunch of letters, but after connecting the letters, I deciphered that is said “l(a leaf falls)oneliness”. The idea of loneliness is emphasized by the title, what the poem spells out, having the word ‘one’ present in a line and the structure of the poem looking like a 1.

It is quite probable that memory is one of the themes contained in the poem "Agrippa." Memory that got awakened when Gibson finally unties the old black book titled "ALBUMS CA. AGRIPPA" (2nd stanza). I've also noticed how descriptive he gets when he sees the pictures. He starts off recollecting his memories from 1919 about his "'pappa's sawmill," to his mother, dog, old house, etc, until he aged through the years.
