When he comments about the "mechanism" could it be possible that he's referring it to the mechanism of how pictures are taken and how pictures flood the mind with memories?
The code poems are brilliant. I've never seen anything like it before. Code poems are playful. In particular, I really like "TWOFACED" because it's humorous and at the same time reflective of reality. Many of us even realize this truth that being two faced is genetically programmed in us.
"Sestina" recycles the same words. Majority of what it's about is still undecipherable for me, but the description is vivid and somewhat has a gloomy environment. The "r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r" and the "[l(a]" are both really confusing. The codes or disarranged letters makes it hard to be understandable. In "[l(a]," I can see three words— "leaf falling," "loneliness," and "oneliness." (l (a le af fa ll s) one l iness).

The theme for the poem “Agrippa” could be memory, as the poem refers to the speaker opening a “black book” to look at photos. Observing the photos could be a way to reflect on the memories of the speaker and his feelings towards the history of the photos.
After reading the code poems I was extremely frustrated as I did not understand what the themes of poems were. But what I did take from reading the code poems was that both codes and poems are similar in that they both meant to express ideas and have meaning. Referring back to the source module we did the codes in the page source all had meant something and were in specific parts of the page for a reason. Just like the poems “r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r” and “l)a” the structure is important to express the meaning of the poems.
As I read the poem “Sestina” I noticed that objects are personified as a human. For instance the lines “is watching the teakettle's small hard tears dance like mad on the hot black stove.” Also the object almanac is “clever” i the third stanza it states “hangs up the clever almanac.” And in the last stanza it portrays the almanac to speak in the line “ Time to plant tears, says the almanac.” To me the theme to this poem could be personification of objects.
After reading both “r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r” and “l)a” several times and becoming more confused I turned to google for help. From there I realized that the poem’s letters needed to be rearranged. The letters r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r turns out to be grasshopper and is the poem numerous times, even after rearranging the letters I did not really understand the poem but believe the theme is about structure and form. When you lay out the lines horizontally in the peom “1)a” the letters connect and form the words “a leaf falls” and “loneliness.” The theme to poem is similar to the poem “r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r” as the structure and form are important and needed to “decode” the words.

There is no shortage of evidence that the poem "The Agrippa Files" by William Gibson is about the longing for memories that are enclosed in the photographs mentioned. Throughout the poem the author wrote a lot about past experiences, lives of family members, the description of the present and past. The poem has a dark sentimental vibe to it that makes readers feel a certain type of way.
The code poems are quite interesting and well done in my eyes. I feel like the poems are about character and the lack of care we put in our lives as well as the lack of care of others. Code poems such as "Unhandled Love", "Daily grind" and "Two Faced" has a malicious ambiance to it. "Unhandled Love" was a tragic short poem about the non- appreciation of love, it kind of confused me, questions such as: Who /What are you voiding? What is the main? Are you talking about a person? From working too hard in "Daily Grind" and not taking care of yourself gives a sense of selflessness in character but also a lack of care towards the self. "Two Faced" is just plain malicious, it shows a lack of character and the lack of morality.
"Sestina'' by author Elizabeth Bishop was a thought provoking poem. The theme appeared to be about the essence of time and the effects it may have. The grandmother grows old and grows some what feeble in her mind while the young granddaughter has oblivious and light thoughts. The grandmother is clearly unhappy, trapped in her own thoughts of helplessness. It could be the cause of a seasonal affective disorder and the weather, everything might seem to move slower in time.
The poems "r-pop-h-e-s-s-a-a-g-e-r" and "[(1a]" by E.E Cummings seems to be a puzzle of some sort but analyzing the poem over again produced no solid link. This poem's purpose could be to confuse it's readers as a different form of artistic poetry. It could be just a fun poem that leaves the reader plenty of time to use their imagination. The theme could be about the limitless possibilities poetry and literature can inhibit.
Overall, I feel like the purpose of the poems were meant to be decoded and analyzed by the reader, some themes were dark and some were playful.

For the first poem, “Agrippa,” the main theme is memories. Gibson writes about a character reliving there past memories with their family through the photo album. The theme is evident when the character is explaining what is happening in each image of the album, letting the reader know of his or her family’s story. However, I did not understand the symbolism for the mechanism or how it helps support theme. I could barely understand what exactly code poems by Bertram were saying, let alone find a specific theme that linked them all together. The only I was able to understand was “TWOFACED” because it was the simplest of all the other poems. It did not have many symbols that distracted you from what the context was saying. Also the concept of being two faced is something that is so common that it requires little thought to understand what the poem was suggesting. However, most of the other codes (poems) required a lot of thought to understand. One that was simpler than “TWOFACED” was “UNHANDLED LOVE” but with it being so simple I just could not decode that code. The theme present in the poem, “Sestina” may be sadness or grief as everything in the poem has tears. The poem gives the reader a very gloomy feeling as even something as simple as the condensation of the kettle is described as though the kettle is a living being that cries. Towards the end of the novel, “the child draws a rigid house and a winding pathway,” this may be the grandmother’s house. The child most likely drew a house it was familiar to, therefore the man drawn on the house may have been familiar with the child as well. This man could have possible been the child’s grandfather who has passed away, hence why the grandmother feels the house chilly or why she everything in that house is crying. Therefore, this causes me to believe that the theme of the poem may be grief of a loved one. The last two poems by E. E. Cummings were similar to the poems by Ishac Bertram in the sense that both poems were written as codes with symbols. The poem “[l(a]” was easier to understand compared to the first one by E. E. Cummings, as the second poem had been decoded by the blogger who had posted. But “r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r” was far too confusing for me to decode, so I could not find a theme for that one either.

As it has been pointed out in previous comments, I too, believe memory plays a role in the theme for "AGRIPPA". As it goes through the book, the photographs allow to recreate the lost memories. Try and piece together what was going on when the pictures were taken. Continuing onto the Agrippa Files it is mentioned how a diskette was used to encrypt the book this could mean that it was meant to be 'lost' as the poem mentions in the beginning? For the code poems it reminded me of our source code module and I immediately thought "great, more codes I won't understand" but as you look closer you're able to somewhat decipher these. "twofaced" was the most simple to 'decode' as it applies to almost everyone in one way or another. Saying one thing and meaning another also goes hand in hand with poems. Having to think is this what it really means or is there a subtle underlying meaning behind what is being said? You never really know what is going through the authors mind, unless specifically told. The following two poems by E.E Cummings was frustrating to say the least. I was able to read (or make up a meaning) "as we look upon....can be rearranged...grasshopper" but quite frankly it didn't make much sense to me. I assume you are supposed to rearrange the letters/words to make it into something understandable but I was unable to do so. And the only reason I was able to understand the second one "[l(a]" was due to the explanation at the bottom. These rely more on your visual senses than anything, piecing together parts of a puzzle to see the big picture is what is necessary to decipher them. Lastly, "Sestina" repeats the words at the end of the line and thanks to Google I found out that is partially the point of a "Sestina" poem. For this one, the vibe was more gloomy. The weather had an impact on it, and just how the scene was set up. It seemed as though the grandmother was missing/grieving the absence of someone (grandfather, son) maybe? As at the end "the child puts in a man with buttons like tears and shows it proudly to the grandmother." which makes the grandmother sad. The almanac may be showing a specific date or anniversary of something almost as though it is trusted to tell the future?

Other Themes in Agrippa include industry and manufacturing (ex.woodworking). It appears the economy of the town of Wheeling, West Virginia, described in the poem, was historically strong in these resources.
As for Sestina, I believe that the use of personification creates a theme of fantasy, i.e objects interacting with humans. Or maybe the grandmother is losing her grip on reality and imagining these things, and so hallucinations are a theme.. I'm not entirely sure.
Regarding the poems written in code, I think that twofaced represents societal expectations. By that I mean, we can think one thing of someone, but it is totally inappropriate to say exactly what we think of that person. This poem seems like something I would normally associate as a man encountering his ex-girlfriend/wife on the street and they are forced to talk. The others don't make a lot of sense to me, based on what I feel is lack of programming language knowledge. As for E.E Cummings, those poems somewhat resemble how a computer might read a web page, or how programmers code web pages. The theme could be changing people's interpretations (by arranging words in a non-unorthodox way).

In the first poem, "Agrippa" the main themes that I got were nostalgia, death and war. These themes tie into each other and I found were the most dominant throughout the poem.
My initial reaction to the code poems were frustration and confusion. E.E. cummings poems make sense when you read them in a different order than just right to left. for 1)a after it was pointed out in the commentary I noticed I got some meaning from it when it was read vertically at once. I get confused when poems are in code because I don't know how to read it and the brackets and spaces confuse me. As for "sestina" I got the theme of tragedy and possibly tradition or the passing of knowledge. I found this poem and Agrippa the easiest to follow or take themes from due to their format and familiar language.

In William Gibsons poem “Agrippa” there is a theme of memories through time. The Kodak photographs and the items described in the poem are the keys to the memories accompanied to the images. There is also a theme of travelling and wisdom in the poem, through the various scenes described in the poem and through the change of ages.
I think it is really interesting that "Agrippa" has an encryption-like effect that makes the poem disappear which like the memories attached to the photographs described in the poem and his father, these parts of life disappear to those except for those who are determined to remember it.
I really like this line in Continent in the introduction: the structure and function of these new languages give them special advantage in clarity. The Coded poems are really interesting and have the theme that language is transferable and that what is visible on the outside is not always what is being thought or visible on the inside.
“Sestina” has a theme of patterns and the recognition that the process of one thing in the past will have the same or similar pattern in the present and future.
“r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r” by EE Cummings is an interesting read because the copyright for the poem is 1923 which predates computers and computer codes. It is even more interesting because E.E Cummings poem reflects the coding patterns of computers. It is also a code to figure out and rearrange the orders of the letters into words and to figure out the meaning of the poem much like his other poem “1)a”. These two poems by E.E. Cummings are interesting because of the code theme and the assertion to themes and events that occur in daily life, like the thought and act of loneliness and oneliness.

The theme I found most evident in “Agrippa” is memories. The numerous dates though out the poem show the memories through the photo graphs. William Gibson uses these photos to symbolize a past memory or experience.
I found the coded poems really interesting and how the codes wordings followed a pattern. It’s a way of showing that almost anything can be poetic. I had trouble understanding the meaning behind most of the coded poems. The poem that really caught my attention was two-faced. We can see the two sides of the poem and have the coding was patterned to be opposite as well.
I found Sestina to be a very depressing story. It starts off talking about September which is a stressful month with usually the start of school for most kids. The story continues to talk about things such as tears and rain and I believe is referring to themes such as sadness or sorrow with the grandmother.
When I first read r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r and I have never been so confused in my life. As I continued to look over and over it I saw grasshopper at the end. I looked back through the poem to see that it seemed those same letters were mixed throughout it. Im not sure what the theme could be in this poem or if its more of a puzzle. With 1(a I used the same idea of mixing letters and saw the word loneliness. The one is separated from the liness which could be representing the theme of solitude.

In Agrippa, the first thing I noticed is the use of descriptive words. The writer uses detailed description for the subject. Examples of these include chalk-like white pencil, the grass needs cutting, and the gun lay on the dusty carpet. The theme revolving around in this poem seems to be memory. He talks about his grandfathers past and what he did for a living. The author also writes quite a bit about the present. When I read the coded poems, I was really confused as to what they were talking about. I understood some parts, but the overall structure and themes were confusing. Maybe in Unhandled Love the theme is love? My confusion turned to a brief chuckle when I read Twofaced. The response to “Hi! So great to see you!”, was something that got me thinking what the codes meant. The “greet” might be this positive response while the “think” is a negative response in the person’s head. “Fucking bitch” is what the person might be thinking inside their head. Sestina was a really descriptive poem to read. I am not quite clear as to what the theme might be, but the poem clearly revolves around the grandmother and child. I found that age may be something that the author is trying us to get across to. In one of the lines, the grandmother is feeling cold. As the grandmother puts wood into the stove, with crayons the child draws a rigid house. E.E. Cummings poems were very unique. The letters are rearranged in the first one and they are difficult to perceive. The only clear word I can see is “grasshoppers”. I can visualize the word grasshopper in my head but the other words are hard to identify. The second poem was easier to identify as their was a description. A leaf falls represents an action, or what is happening. When I look at it from this perspective, I feel that loneliness is the theme of this poem. Loneliness represents the single leaf falling. The description helps me understand how to LOOK and READ this poem. Without the description, there is only confusion.

I started off by reading the poems by Ishac Bertran. The poems contained symbols associated with code and I didn’t really understand the meaning behind them except for the poem, “Two Faced” which I actually found to be quite humorous. “Sestina” was a poem that had a certain feeling of sadness to it. Tears were used multiple times in the poem and in expressed in various forms and I think that may be why I jumped to thinking the poem related to themes of sadness or loneliness. The poems by E.E Cummings were different than the others due to the way they were structured. The poem “r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r” was confusing to say the least. However, I understood the gist of the poem as it started off with the letters of the word ‘grasshopper’ rearranged, and then the letters were rearranged again, and the last line ‘ to rea(be)rran(com)gi(e)ngly ,grasshopper;’ just rearranged the letters yet again to form the word grasshopper. The second poem ‘- [l(a]’ had a theme related to perspective in my opinion because as a leaf falls, the tree becomes ‘lonely’ so to speak while the leaf gains independence, or freedom from the tree and achieves ‘oneliness’. The poem ‘Agrippa’ was also confusing to understand. The poem itself was like a story however I couldn’t really understand what the speaker was referring to. After reading the context pages, I learned more about the history behind the poem however it didn’t help me understand any new information about the poem.

In the poem “Argippa”, William Gibson provides the reader with a very lengthy poem which continuously hints out memories by writing with vivid descriptions that come with various different dates about a specific photo album. Perhaps this is the possible theme of the poem although there appears to be a deeper meaning. The poem includes additions, II, III, IV, V, and VI, which uses repetition of the word “mechanism”. I am confused as to what “mechanism” refers to in this poem but I believe that it is symbolism for a deeper meaning.
Out of the four poems that were written in code, I was not able to decipher them and pick out a theme for any of them. Even after rereading them a couple times, I was still confused. These poems really reminded me of the view source module because these poems honestly could have been the source code for a website, or at least in my mind they could have been. I was equally confused by the poem “r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r” by E. E. Cummings. It was written in a way that is similar to code, but not quite like the poems that resembled the source code of websites. The words of this poem were scattered all over the page. I did not understand why some words were on the left, some on the right, and the odd couple of words in the centre. The use of brackets only made me more curious as to what this poem is really about, because I highly doubt that it is just about a grasshopper.
I thought that the poem “Sestina” by Elizabeth Bishop was a little mysterious. It is not clear to me why the grandmother is trying to hide her tears. Why is she trying to hide it, and what caused these tears? There is an abundance of personification that can be found in this poem in every single different stanza. I liked the writer’s use of personification, because it made me interpret the poem differently then I would have if inanimate objects like the almanac, stove and kettle were not given human emotions.

The theme in “r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r” is the process of decoding. The "“r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r” poem at first makes no sense, but it guides you from the original garbled mess of letter,to the solution. Within the "r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r" grouping of letters, lies an embedded solution: which is "grass hopper". And perhaps the grasshopper is a metaphor for how we can "leap" from idea to idea, until we arrive at the conclusion. But I personally found a minor theme of disappearance in this poem aswell. When I first opened it, I truly had no idea what the title meant. Once I solved it, I always refer to it as "Grasshopper" when I see the mess of characters. I no longer can see it in the same light that I initially did, the "code" title was replaced with 'grasshopper', and I cannot revert back.
The theme in "1(a" is ambiguity in code. How the same thing may be interpreted differently, depending on it's structure. The entire poem delivers most of it's impact with HOW it is structured, not the words that it contains. If the poem just was laid out as:
"1(a leaf falls) oneliness"
the code would of lost much of it's emotional impact. The code can be ambiguous, but the method of it's delivery may carry as much meaning as the code itself.
In "The Agrippa", the medium is just as important as the words in delivering the theme. The poem would self-destruct, and cease to exist after it was read and displayed once. The theme of memory, how it just an imprint, is demonstrated here. Memory is just an imprint of time,and once the moment is gone, it disappears. Technology (photos, writing, painting) are ways of coding experience,memory, emotion into other forms.
The code (which is colors on paper - photographs) is deciphered by our mind to bring us back to a memory, an imprint of an event, in the past.
The theme in "TWO FACED" was Deceitful code. How "public string" can be modified to mask, or throw off, what is happening in "Private string". I also noticed the structure: How the "Private string" falls underneath the public, as if it is a sub-script, running in the background.
The theme in "DAILY GRIND" is the boring repetition, and how the unemotional language of code can represent that best. Code is meant to seem as impersonal and indistinguishable as possible from any other programmer's work - as described in "The Bug". The medium is just as important as the content in this poem.
The other two 'code poems' are unclear to me.I assume "UNHANDLED LOVE" is a reference to the function of "Handle" that a computer can carry out, but this poem seems to be written for an audience who is familiar with coding. I am not at all familiar with coding, so I do not have the 'key' for this poem or the other "DANCING WITHIN" code poem.
Sestina is confusing to me aswell. There was so much focus on the stove, and almanac it really confused me as I was expecting a poem about technology. The poem assumes I know what an almanac even is - I googled it, it seems to be some sort of annual magazine. So this poem is obviously very old.
A possible theme I may have extracted is faith in technology. I realized how an almanac at that time was not considered 'old and how perhaps people thought that they may hold the ability to foretell the future - like how we believe technology can today.

The poem Agrippa describes someone uncovering memory after memory as they look back on their life. The speaker also describes his feelings towards these photos. This poem's theme has something to do with the speakers life story and all of the memories he or she has learned and grown from.
The tone in Sestina is quite sad. The grandmother appears to be going through some sort of hardship and is easily brought to tears. It appears that she does not want to show her emotions to the child and therefore she makes an effort to distract herself form the realities. I think the theme is sorrow since there does not seem to be any uplifting or joyful moments whatsoever.
I was not able to understand or piece together any of the code poems. Although I do believe it would be a creative and intriguing task to construct a poem with certain letters and numbers each having a different meaning, I would probably explain my ideas and motives to my audience so that they would begin to see the meaning of the poem. For example, throughout some of the code poems several curly brackets are used which would at least make them somewhat significant. Similarly, after reading the final poem r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r I was extremely puzzled and did not know where to start in terms of finding themes for the poem. At first from seeing the word "grasshopper" at the end I thought that the poem might be telling a lesson to a child or just someone in need of advice. As a child my dad used to make jokes that I was a young grasshopper. This poem being written in code, could be deciphered differently by each person who comes across it. It takes some imagination and maybe personal experience to uncover the meaning.

I think my comment is late, but I'll have a go at it anyway.
The Agrippa files poem was very difficult to read, I found it easier to watch the video that someone posted in the context pages that showed the emulation of the program and read it that way. I think one of the themes was about time through generations of a family and their personal life. The imagery of the shutter falling signified the closing of periods in the writer's life, and the poem was organized with clear sections, like the chapters or phases of his life. I've tried thinking about how "the mechanism" factors into the theme, but haven't come to a theory yet.
The code{poems} were pretty cool and clever. They seemed to be focused on the inner vs outer workings of certain aspects of daily life and the way people think. I loved Two Faced, it kind of reminded me of the module which we looked into the source code for different websites, and discovering all the secrets coders had left in there, I wonder what I'd find looking at the "source code" of people and seeing what really goes on in their heads, especially if it was arranged in that way.
Sestina was nice, I hadn't come across that particular type of poetry before. I think it's about the struggle of womanhood. The almanac and how it mentions moons and "equinoctial tears" really makes me think of the cycles women go through during the course of their lives (menstruation, the maiden/mother/crone stuff). The grandmother has lived through them already and is looking at the child (presumably a girl) and seeing how she is starting to or will soon become effected by it.
The two poems by E. E. Cummings were really cool as well, I liked how they were organized and that I had to read them over to glean meaning from them. "r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r" was really confusing, so I'm not sure if that's part of what the theme would be, but there must be more to it. I did notice that I was constantly required to re-arrange the letters and interpret what the brackets were meant to do, and it does say "rea(be)rran(com)gi(e)ngly"... "become" in the bracketed letters, and "rearrangingly" between those, so I guess it would be about decryption. I'm not good at anagrams, but I'm pretty sure there are a couple of those thrown in, because otherwise it has some utter nonsense. That could be part of the point, though. [l(a] was more straightforward for me, about loneliness and whether it is a bad thing or neutral. "loneliness" "a leaf falling" and "oneliness" are pretty serene ideas and don't really have anything polarizing about them. I think that the reader's personal experience with those images would greatly affect the meaning they take away from it.

William Gibson’s “Agrippa” contains a theme of family history, a photo album, and the Kodak camera. Gibson returns to the main concepts of the numerous familiar memories that he describes throughout the text. It presents a sense of nostalgia and reminiscence of his past, relating it to the photo album and the camera that took the photos.
Ishac Bertran’s project of code poems are so clever. Each poem is written in a different code language like Java, C++, and C#. In order to truly translate the poems, one would have to be well versed in that particular coding system. They seemed at first to be little more than a clutter of codes together but once you pay more attention, you can detect the patterns and meanings of the words and symbols. To me, they were examples of the flaws in humanity. “Dailygrind”, by Paul Illingworth, entertains the monotony of North American culture and the pain staking routines of the average person. “Twofaced”, by Jason Kopylec also presents a certain fault in character that some individuals have, an act of “backstabbery”- acting as one person to one’s face and another behind their back.
“Sestina”, by Elizabeth Bishop, could contain several different themes. I found that the most prominent was the sadness and gloomy vibes of the text. There was a constant stream of words like “tears, “failing light” and “rain falls”. Another theme that was extremely obvious was the reoccurring words in each verse. The same words were used in different ways. For example, “tears”, were referred to as the old grandmother’s tears, the teakettle’s tears, the “buttons like tears”, the “little moons falling down like tears”, and several others. The writer used the same process with Almanac, stove, house, child, and grandmother.
E.E Cumming’s “R-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r” and [1(a] are incredible confusing to me and take a lot of time to deconstruct without reading the descriptions. I feel as though one would have to be quite experienced in order to fully understand their meanings. I do like, however, the fact that they are unique and complicated but at the same time they are simple in the fact that they can still easily get their point across. It’s as though both poems just want you to work for it. “[1(a]”, for me, presents a theme of loneliness while “R-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r” is a jumbled mess of words. The leap to becoming a grasshopper? It’s confusing and is a complete puzzle to solve. I love the idea that these project but it’s difficult to decipher.

I believe the theme of “AGRIPPA” is reflection. Now, having read a lot of the other comments on this module, it is safe to say that memories are another great underlying theme as well, however reflection made more sense to me.
The photographs in the album serve as the memories, but memories are simply fragments of time if not interpreted further into something, or coded. Reflection is what occurs once memories have been thought about, or looked at, and transformed to have meaning in the present day.
The code poems to me made a lot more sense than AGRIPPA, although still slightly frustrating. Unhandled Love, for instance, theme could have been forgetting. Initially, in the first line, we see “class love” there and present, but by the end love is thrown away, as if it never occurred. Dailygrind was a poem that was fairly relatable in the sense that it counted hours and minutes of time between being at work and being asleep. The theme for it is probably most simply, worklife. For the code poems, I think their themes are overly simplified because of the effort taken into decoding them.
Finally, the EE Cummings’ poems were the ones that interested me the most. It took a bit of time, and creativity to figure out the literal words behind the syntax, but once unraveled the meaning behind them was clear. In “[l(a]” the words taken from it are “a leaf falls”, “loneliness” and “oneliness”. As mentioned by the response directly following the poem, the leaf falling is in between loneliness. “A” leaf, meaning one, falling from a tree of many leaves to the ground where it will then become “one” with the others, leads me to believe the theme of this poem is solitude as a form of being included. One cannot be a part of a greater entity without simply being one on its own.
(Also, sorry for commenting so late in the game, I spent this reading week with the flu only to get an infection of sorts and put on antibiotics - only to have rare adverse side effects which sent me back to the doctors. Thanks for understanding!)

In the first poem “AGRIPPA”, I think it is about nostalgia because the poem keeps recalling memories in the past such as, “W.F. Gibson Jr. and something, comma, 1924” and "Papa's saw mill, Aug. 1919” because the years suggested that. Also the first few paragraphs describe a photo album book, so it seems like the narrator is looking back to his or her past. The next poem “r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r” is quite confusing and did not understand the meaning of it. I think the author is trying to emphasize the structure of the poem which kind of reminds me of codes. I think the purpose of the poem is to play the reader and trying to confuse them because it is not common how a poem is written that way. “Sestina” is quite a sad poem because I guess it’s the tone of it. For example, “She thinks that her equinoctial tears and the rain that beats on the roof of the house were both foretold by the almanac, but only known to a grandmother” and “But secretly, while the grandmother busies herself about the stove, the little moons fall down like tears”. This paragraph suggests that the grandmother is hiding her sadness from the child (the child might also be distracted by watching the tea kettle). Or it could be that the child does not understand what the grandmother going through. Like this quote, “Then the child puts in a man with buttons like tears and shows it proudly to the grandmother”. To the child, that picture represents a man with normal buttons but to the grandmother, she perceive that image as something tragic, a sad memory that was at one point, happened in her life. The poem by Bishop was really interesting because one can relate it to real life, not everyone could understand other people’s emotions. The code poem by Allen is very “artistic” kind of poem. Like the poem by E. E. Cummings, the author is emphasizing the structure of the poem. It structured literally like codes and I think it’s trying to provoke the reader that codes are confusing and something that non-programmers will never understand.

As many other mentioned before me, Agrippa theme throughout the poem is memory; however, the poem was very confusing. While reading it I felt lost at times and confused to what the poem was trying to say. Other than that I came with a simple assumption the poem theme was memory with hints that were given throughout the poem. There could be a deeper meaning, but I wasn’t able to identify it.
The coded poem: DAILYGRIND, UNHANDLED LOVE, TWOFACED and DANCING WITHIN, were all about codes. Once again looking at code left me dumbfounded but I found this was easier to read than the earlier module we had. TWOFACED was my favorite out all the poems. The humour it presented was enjoyable and something everyone could relate too.
The EE Cummings poems. What can I say? I thought it was very interesting with the way it was presented, but one must unravel the poem to understand its meaning. I felt the theme was to look at it at a different point a view like codes. The poem r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r was very confusing. I had absolutely no idea what it was trying to say and till I know I don’t get why it all over the place scattered -btw to whoever SBD is, the poem did an amazing job to confusing me-. 1(a was a lot easier to understand. At first it was confusing, but the visual of the poem really helps out the reader and the response below was great help. Both poems remind of me how confusing codes are but once you understand it’s fascinating. It’s a whole new world you never knew about.

The poems Sestina is the most I liked. I think it about a sad story due to death or loss of loved one and all the memory behind that. There are a lot of symbols present the feeling of sad and lonely. Tea time that consider a social time all family members gather, enjoy and chat, here there are only a sad grandmother and a child left alone. September is Fall month that is cold and sad, leaves fall and rain stand for the loss. The repeating of words like tears and house suggest that somebody was living with them, but he was not there anymore. Tears suggest that there is tragedy or death could lead to tears in grandmother's eyes. The cup of tea which is “full of dark brown tears” suggest that the grandmother cried a lot for long preyed of time because tea time remind her with her lost. “She thing the house feels chilly” stand for an empty house that was full one day, so there is no warm anymore. “Rigid house” stand for old strong hose that survive from attach or tragedy. The child draws for “a man with buttons like tears with winding pathway” reflects that somebody left and did not come back. I think the theme of this poem is human mortality and the feeling surrounding that and it's more general as people could feel the same after tragedy loss. The poems “r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r”, 1)a” and code poems its attractive. It was written in different stretcher and some code, but it was hard to get the theme behind without read about it in websites. I’m not sure what the theme could be, and why it was written in this way, I found using the regular way of writing the poems even if using difficult symbols is much worthy and pretty.

The poems "Sestina" & "1(a" were by far the most powerful to me, and while it took a while to decipher E. E. Cummings works, the short but sweet style of "1(a" really had an impact. Both had themes of a darker nature, with "Sestina" comparing tears to many different things leads me to think that the theme of this poem is one of sadness and loss, some sort of sad happening to create the tears. In "1(a" the reference to loneliness and a single falling leaf are repeating the same thing, a feeling of being alone, the only one et cetera. Good poem for Valentines Day (okay sorry - had to take a stab at the fruity holiday)

In William Gibson’s poem “Agrippa” is reflecting on memories. The poem had breaks between stanzas that were “II, III, IV, V, and VI” so perhaps the roman numerals can resemble how many steps there are to break the code. The phrase “mechanism itself” is a clue to there actually being meaning and a code beneath the words. From what I gather, maybe the dates and names “W.F Gibson Jr., 1924, Papa’s saw mill, Aug. 1919, Moko 1919, Aunt Fran and [obscured], Ford on Dixie 1917, Arthur and Ford fishing 1919, Ford Sr., Moma July, 1919, Moma and Mrs. Graham at fish hatchery 1919, cryptic mark: H.V.J.M.[?], Papas mill 1919, Ice Gorge at Wheeling 1917, Steamboat on Ohio River, Our Wytheville House Sept 1921, W.F Gibson 1921, Mama Jan. 1922, etc., combined give you the key. If you rearrange all the letters and numbers maybe it cracks a code or gives you the key to cracking it. The poem is based on Gibson’s memories, triggered by a series of photographs. It analyzes how mechanisms affect our perception of reality, while appearing as a mechanism, while at the same time it can be destroyed by one.
While reading Ishac Bertram’s poems Daily Grind/Unhandled Love/Twofaced/Dancing Within” frustrated me immensely. I couldn’t “decode” them or even fully understand them. From what I could somewhat gather from the four poems was that they were underlying our differences but at the same time reflecting our reality. They represent our lack of care, drive, but also the boredom and frustration of routine?
I loved reading Elizabeth Bishop’s poem “Sestina” as it had a somber but also tender feeling. Picking out a theme from the poem was challenging. The repeating pattern of the words “almanac, stove, house, child, tears and grandmother” to me maybe suggest that both the child and grandmother are left alone but yet they have each other and there is still love within the household.
4. “r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r” by E.E. Cummings was so different and fun. Obviously when I first began reading it I was like “what the heck is r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r?!” and each time after the word was rearranged gave life to the poem I think. It’s clear that the poem was constructed to look confusing just as a code would be but it all has an underlying meaning which in my opinion may be relevant to humans. Making a connection that sometimes we (humans) jump from one idea to the next or one decision to the next and eventually we will get there and find our place? Just like the code in Mr. Penumbra’s 24-Hour Bookstore, the code was confusing and the goal was to find it and have the key to an immortal life, but really the code is so simple and about friendship and love.
[1(a)] may have been my favorite. The fact that you could gather more than one word/phrase from the words was brilliant. You can gather the word “loneliness” and “a leaf falls”. Not only is there meaning behind this but there it gives you a visual as well. A falling leaf suggests loneliness. Another word I picked out was “oneliness” which is I think means wholeness. So although the poem may be about loneliness it also may suggest of being whole or one with yourself or something.
(Sorry for the late post, was away and didn’t have access to internet for half my trip! Thanks!)

The main theme of the first poem was reflection. The poem starts off introducing what seems like a photo album. “Agrippa” seemed to show the lives of the poet’s mother and father. The theme of reflection also included the passing of time through the album. The code poems really took me by surprise. I was really interested in the format that the poem was laid out in. I think that it took creativity of a poem to a whole other level. At first I found it frustrating to decode the poems, but decoding got a little bit easier as I continued to read. Daily grind is about the Daily grind of life. One day goes by and another day starts the daily grind all over again. I found it interesting that the format of this coded poem was very computer like format. I think the layout could almost be similar to viewing the source code on a normal webpage but to a less extreme. Sestina was a cute but deep poem. I found this poem a little bit harder to decipher. I’m not really sure what to make out of the poem, however I did find that the mood of the poem was set at the beginning of the poem when the author described the setting. There was use of personification through the duration of the poem. “r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r” was by far the hardest poem to decode. Once I was finally able to understand and pick out words from the poem I really thought it was very creative. The poem had the word leap spread across the page as a visual image for the actually meaning of the word. I was not able to pick out a theme. I just found that reading the poem from what I can understand was describing a grasshopper and what the grasshopper actual does.

item.title: Essay #2
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Engl. 1102.001: Reading Literature and Culture - Hackers in Literature Douglas College Essay #2 (1000-1250 words/ 4-5 pages) Workshopping as per Module due for March 25, 2015 With My Comments: Due April 8, 2015 Without Comments (Grade Only): Due April 15, 2015 Instructions: Using proper essay format and style answer one of the following questions. Higher assessments will result when the correct literary and analytical terminology is used to assert an argument that demonstrates knowledge applied in an original way. Please refer to the class syllabus for general guidelines and format regulations. Please note that because of the extended deadlines, no essays will be accepted after April 15, 2015. All essays must site sources according to the MLA citation method, making sure it is both consistent and accurate. Plagiarism will not be tolerated. Email submissions are preferred, but not mandatory. Please be sure to put your name in the file name (like this: wrightessay1.doc) when attaching the file to your Email. wrightd@douglascollege.ca. If you want to hand in your paper by hand, please deliver it to the LLPA Fieldbase at NW2600 (there’s a dropbox on right-hand side of main fieldbase doors if it’s after hours) before the final due date. Questions:
  1. Choose one thematic element (i.e. hackers, technology, knowledge, friendship, race, the self, the quest, gaming, etc.) you think has relevance to one of the texts we have studied since Feb. 6, 2015. After refining the thematic element into something more manageable, show how the text comments on the characteristics of that theme. This question does not ask you to simply point out how a thematic element is present in a text; rather it asks you to show how the text portrays and comments on that thematic element. This question asks you to explore how the text defines your theme--or presents its characteristics--in a significant way.
  2. Choosing one text we have encountered since Feb. 6, 2015, discuss the significance of ONE cultural OR literary OR social practice present in that text. You are being asked to reflect upon how the text represents or uses cultural OR literary OR social practices. You need a thesis that clearly articulates what the significance of the practice means to our reading of the text. For instance, how it influences our reception of the text. It’s not enough to simply point to the cultural / literary / or social practices present in the text, you must make a suggestion as to the significance of these practices and the context they provide for an interpretation of the text.
  3. Using one of the texts we have encountered since Feb. 6, 2015 as evidence, define the characteristics of digital culture. What is digital culture as you see it, using the texts we have encountered as evidence for that definition?

item.title: Reading Week Module II: Encoding / Decoding
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
In case you haven't caught on, the Reading Week modules have been about the theme of encoding and decoding. If you haven't had a look at the earlier module, I suggest you go back and have a look. I like starting the discussion of thematics with encoding and decoding for two reasons: 1) it's a nice way to think about interpretation or, how we interpret texts; 2) I like introducing first-year students to the ideas of Stuart Hall who I think offers us an interesting way to approach the act of interpretation in a digital age. Thanks to all those who engaged with the interpretation and encryption module that threw down a little poetry for a change. It's clear from what I have seen from those who participated that we are on the cusp of a decent understanding for what a theme actually might be. However, most of you didn't really delve deeply enough--probably because I didn't ask you to so no hard feelings--into the back story of William Gibson's Agrippa. To sum it up real quick: he encrypted the poem, which was sold on a floppy disk only, so that it would only scroll by once and then lock; remaining forever encrypted and inaccessible unless one could decrypt thereafter. Agrippa is an interesting way of thinking about how we perceive the reception of creative texts. For instance, I am sure a lot of you watch or download torrents, stream American Netflix, or otherwise hack a system to access some kind of restricted content. This act is, in and of itself, an act of interpretation. You are figuring out, either on your own or through your network of enlightened contacts, how to reinterpret the restrictions placed upon the delivery system of the content you want to access. All of which brings up Stuart Hall. He is probably best known for a piece he wrote way back in 1973 entitled "Encoding / Decoding in the Television Discourse." You can go and find it if you're really keen, but looking at the Wikipedia page should suffice for now. The big takeaway is that there are three kinds of readers:
  • Dominant
  • Negotiated
  • Oppositional
  • The dominant reader decodes the text exactly as was intended. Now, as we have discussed in class, we can never be sure of the author's intentions, but we can usually agree on a kind of surface reading that everyone takes from the text. For instance, we all agree that Agrippa is about memory, or that "r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r" is about a grasshopper. In class, I have always used the "cat" reference. We all understand bascially what a cat is. The dominant reading of a text is what most people would understand it to be about.
  • The negotiating reader decodes the texts by negotiating between the dominant reading and one that suits his / her own interests or aims. You guys do this all the time when you listen to me lecture. You hear me talk about the definition of character and setting and narrative, but you are also interested in how knowing about character and setting and narrative will get you an A. Most of you understand the terms only insofar as they will get you an A. You negotiate between knowing what everyone knows about character, but you clearly reject some of the examples or explanations I give because they are not relevant to what you will be tested on. We frequently read texts this way; we believe most of what a character talks about, but something about how they say it for instance makes us suspicious of his/her motivations. in short, we negotiate between the dominant meaning--a cat--and the meaning we have--my cat is yellow so I picture not just a cat, but a yellow cat--my cat.
  • The oppositional reader can decode the dominant message, but chooses to reject that meaning because it doesn't really apply to his/her social, economic or cultural situation. Also known as resistant reading, the oppositional approach does things like question the representation of gender or sexuality and challenges the cultural assumptions represented in the text. We might apply an oppositional reading to a TV show like the Brady Bunch that idealizes a family dynamic, but at the same time seems to condone divorce. We might also perform an oppositional reading if we are not inclined toward heterosexuality--two cowboys in the isolation of the desert playing with each others guns or two women caressing each other's underwear in an advertisement might have entirely different possible readings than the intended literal meaning (if you're giggling right now over the last two examples, you're doing oppositional reading). Oppositional reading then still decodes the literal meaning, but it rejects it in favour of another perspective based on a different cultural, economic, or social viewpoint.
OK. Phew. Now that we're through that here's what I want you to do:
  1. Reread William Gibson’s poem Agrippa and the accompanying context pages
  2. Reread and download this .pdf from Ishac Bertram that gives a few examples of “code poems.”
  3. Reread Elizabeth Bishop: “Sestina”
  4. Reread E. E. Cummings: “r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r” and “1(a”
  5. Now, revisit the themes you recognized in the poems--the ones you wrote about in the comments--and try to EXPLAIN how your reading was dominant, negotiated, or oppositional. Then, take one of the examples above and try to read it in either a negotiated or oppositional way, writing about your conclusions in the comments below.
Notice how each of Stuart Hall's readers always knows the literal meaning. It's important to lay out this context when you are writing about or interpreting texts. If you explain the dominant reader's perspective, and then show how you read it "differently" then you're doing good things. If you simply show me the dominant reading, that's okay but it's not too thoughtful. Doing the exercise I lay out above should help you understand how the dominant or literal meaning of a text can lead you into interesting interpretations that move past the basic "understanding" or the text and into the "application" of the text that you need to show in post-secondary contexts. Finally, a word about the exam. The exam content can include anything up to this module. Make sure you are aware of the parameters so you are not surprised. The exam can, and will, ask you about anything from Jan. 7th through to Feb. 16th, 2015.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: In my previous module, I felt that memory was the theme for Agrippa, and loneliness was the theme for l(a. I recognized the word grasshopper in r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r, but I was unclear as to what the theme was. Now that I take a look at it, maybe the theme is grasshopper? It is the main topic of the poem but I am not quite sure if a subject can be a theme. I hope I get some clarification on themes next class. Even for the other poems, I was not quite clear on the themes. My readings for Agrippa and r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r were dominant as I understood what the text was about. I did not understand each line of these poems but I knew what the text was referring to. When I read r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r, I rearrange the letters and I see the word grasshopper. The word grasshopper is rearranged in 3 lines and it is spelled correctly on the last line. Furthermore, if you read the second last line it says “rearrange” in scrambled letters. This gives me a huge reference as to what I should do with some words in the poem. When I read Agrippa, past references lead me to believe the poem centers on memory. I recognize that past tense references to the grandfather. For example, when David refers to a cat, I recognize what he is talking about. For these poems, I do not understand the bottom line of what the author is trying to say but I understand what he is attributing to. The surface of what the poems are about is clear, but the actual narratives lead me to some confusion. In l(a, I felt loneliness was the key word from this poem. “A leaf falls” represents an action for one single leaf. In this case, I see the leaf as lonely. When I read the whole poem, I feel that loneliness is what this poem is about. When I re-read Agrippa, I found two examples of reading the oppositional way. Half way through the poem, the writer talks about accidently discharging a gun. The writer is “absolutely alone and in awareness of the mechanism.” This means that he knows how the gun works. He is aware and has experienced how the weapon works. The next line says, “like the first time you put your mouth on a women.” I easily see this as a reference to sex or kissing a women, but the writer is referring to how it feels like to shoot a gun your first time. Another example is in the text “spreading out to where the long trucks groaned.” This text makes me imagine an actual truck groaning, however, the writer is referring to the trucks engine sound. People often use the word “groan” with people’s reactions, but in this example the truck is not actually grunting or whining. I had to really look for this second example as it was not as easy to find as the first one. In my opinion, reading the oppositional way is interesting in the sense that we often use it with sexual related dialogue.

I agree with you, that "rearrange" is a hint. I actually totally skipped over that when reading the poem and didn't notice it. "Leap" stood out to me much more. You noticing "rearrange" , being very literal, and me noticing "Leap", (being symbolic in my intepretation) demonstrates dominant vs negotiated reading in practice.
My reading was dominant for “r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r” as I tried to figure out the theme. I would be able to pick up on grasshopper, in “r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r” but I tried relating that to the course concepts. At first dominant, (Grasshopper) I attempted to go further say that the theme of the poem was to outline the “process” of decoding (negotiated). When I revisited this poem again, with the intent on having a negotiated perspective I began to see the Grasshopper as a metaphor. This is indicated to me by “Leap” and “Arriving”. Grasshopper is a metaphor for the mind decoding and jumping to a conclusion.
An example I recall from a class discussion is how Academic Grades can be a code. Such as A, A, ,A+,B.A- . The seemingly meaningless assortment of letters is ‘code’, and our mind ‘decodes’ it, and leaps to the conclusion “this person is smart” With “TWO-FACED” I had a dominant perspective of reading. I realized the theme was about hiding one’s true thoughts. Publically, the greeting is polite and proper. Privately, the thoughts contrast with vulgarity rudeness. When I revisit this poem, with a negotiating perspective, the format of the poem stands out much more to me. Being written in code, “Hi! So great to see you!” represents the generic. “Private String” represents the true, decoded thought that has to be ‘coded’ into publically acceptable speech. Assigning myself a stance on the material, such as negotiated, allowed me to be more conscious of the relationship to this poem to the setting of the course. Instead of just thinking “This poem is about being two faced. Done” I tried to relate it to previous concepts we described, and the theme of technology in the course.

I found that in “Agrippa” I was more of a dominant reader finding that it was about memory and I found it hard to decode further into it because the message of memories in the form of photographs was so dominant in the text. Whereas when I read the code poems in “Continent”, I was trying to decipher what the meaning of the punctuation and the ordering of the words had meant to the author and how I interpreted them.
I was able to decode and rearrange most of the words in “r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r” and “1(a” by E.E Cummings. Rereading “r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r” I noticed that it was more about change and role models due to the idea of becoming and looking up too. “1(a” has more of a theme of self-reflection. Rereading these, I found that it was more in a negotiating reading style than a dominant or oppositional way.
I think that I am more of a negotiating reader because as I had read the texts I found that it was hard to differentiate between what I found the text to mean and what the most likely meaning of the text was. I found that my own thoughts, views, and values gave the text a different meaning than what the author probably meant and what others in the class would think about the same text.
An example of where I had read in a negotiating style is in TWOFACED by Jason Kopylec in a Java coding I read the poem as how the author had intended it due to the title of being twofaced and in a public environment. What I had to debate in the poem was the use of the term class. I found it to at first mean a social class but also to mean in a class setting such as one at a public school or college or university. I found that I was trying to differentiate between what the text actually was trying to say because of what the speaker is saying to what they are thinking and how it can be applied to both the social class and to be in an actual physical class.

Good comments both. I would add that "dominant" or "negotiated" or "oppositional" do not require any understanding of the author's intentions per se. Rather, they require that you get the basic, literal meaning, without any of the underlying interpretations. What's crucial is how this might lead you to a theme. So, taking "Grasshopper" (we'll go with that title for clarity, but it's not correct) into account, we might think about how Cummings is representing the natural world and the random, chaotic elements of it through poetry. For Agrippa, and this is why I directed you to the backstory about encryption, we're looking at a theme of memory and access. In other words, our memories are often encrypted by our cultural experiences. I know a picture of my father in an entirely different way than you do. Those specifics go a long way to illustrating the "encoding / decoding" concepts of interpretation. I would read a picture of my family based on my cultural assumptions and experiences with my family, but you would read that same picture in an entirely different way, often framing it within YOUR family experiences (negotiated reading) or with your cultural experiences (you are adopted, say, which would lead to an oppositional reading). All of which pressure my dominant reading and give you more ways to talk about memory, family, and so on. The idea here is that technology is a theme, but "encryption" is a better theme to discuss The Bug or Mr. Penumbra's 24-Hour Bookstore. There are also a number of different ways to think about "encryption" (Stuart Hall gives us three possible approaches for instance). That's what we're going for here in a nutshell; the literal meaning gives us a broad category, but it's our job to look and negotiate a reading based on how we approach the text and what we approach it with. We narrow the focus to something more manageable.

Think about what criteria you have that allow you to identify as a "negotiated reader." What are the things--name them--that you experience or bring to the table that allow you to negotiate that reading? If you can get at why you are negotiating, then you'll have the substance of what we're trying to do with themes.

Of all the poems that I have read, "Agrippa" stands out to be the most obvious to me. As previously mentioned, "Agrippa's" theme revolves around memories from the photographs the author is examining. For this poem, I categorize this as dominant reading for reasons of repetitive reference to what he sees in the photos. The author's descriptions of what he sees in the photos paints a vivid image in the my mind. The photos stand out to me as a representation of the memories encoded in each pixels of every photographs he viewed, and that I can easily relate to his experience of retrieving memories from photos.
The “r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r” is also dominant reading because towards the end of the line it gives the reader a clue with what to do with the poem to make sense of it— simply rearrange the words it "becomes... grasshopper." Although at the same time, this can also be categorized as negotiated because a reader can reason that the poem is not all about the grasshopper. As I try to decipher the “r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r” in a negotiated way, I can say that this poem is about how us, about our daily life. There are times when we feel like we are out of order or disorganized like the words “r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r,” but in the end, we "become rearrangingly" okay. The disarranged letters and words caught my attention and interest more than the word grasshopper which led me to compare how this poem is laid out and what life is.

My reading of “Agrippa”, the code poems, “r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r”, and “l(a” was more dominant probably because the themes were more obvious and clearly relatable. I find no reason to reject their meaning or interpret the poem differently in a more interesting way. Perhaps, I am a brainwashed drone who understands poetry in only one way… Anyhow, the literal meaning of these poems strike me as the most important.
I like to think I interpreted “Sestina” with a negotiating perspective because the poem is more open to interpretation (and it took me a long time to think of my ‘original’ idea). The idea of coincidence comes to me because the poem has all the repeated words throughout it. It seems kind of ironic. The repeated words of a sestina are by no means accidental, but the story suggests that some events seem to be predicted, but are actually just coincidental.
When reading “TWOFACED” again, in a negotiated way, I can’t help but relate the poem to good ol’ Harvey Dent. Watching a lot of Batman movies growing up has influenced me to connect themes that play on appearance vs. reality/public vs. private to characters and similar themes in Batman. Gotham’s very own two-faced villain, is a very public figure who is initially an awesome district attorney, but becomes the city’s worst nightmare. Harvey Dent is literally a public representative of government whose job is to fight for justice against major crimes. However, the evil things Dent does in private is exactly what his job as DA is set out to eradicate. On another note, even the parentheses in the poem look like coins which are signature to Dent’s character as he flips them to make major decisions.

My interpretatations of the readings were negotiated, in such a way in that they are likely related to my background and/or interests. For example, in Sestina, whereas some people talked about loneliness as a theme-which makes sense given the reference to tears, I had another alternative. I believe that my themes of imagination, and/or hallucinations, could be strongly influenced by the many classes in psychology, including abnormal psychology, that I have taken. To give an example, I look at the way the poem mentions "Time to plant tears, says the almanac"-as a sign of a possible psychological disorder, such as schizophrenia. Also, the way the grandmother "sings to the stove"-communicating with inanimate objects.Therefore, my background and interests are probably guiding the way I decode these readings. Another example relates to AGRIPPA. I mentioned the themes of manufacturing/woodworking, as I noticed they were mentioned several times. This may be a reflection of my interests, as well as my background as I spent a few years working in a sawmill-which is another word mentioned specifically more than once in this poem. Looking back at my original answers for themes, I now believe I have a better understanding of why I answered in such a way.

I had a similar experience when reading Agrippa. I also find it difficult to look deeper into the meaning of a poem when you have past experience with a similar topic. It's not always easy to change your beliefs once they are already formed and typically have been formed for a while.

I agree with you Brian! When having previous knowledge on a topic such the theme of sadness and sorrow in Sestina, my mind imediately went to some sort of depression or other mental health issue. Therefore I think we are both taking on the role of a negotiating reader since we understand the text (dominant reader) but we want to relate the information in the text to our interests and previous experiences as well.

I read the poem Agrippa as a dominant reader since I understood the message and had a similar response to my peers. I recognized that the person in the poem was uncovering photos that each represented memories through his or her lifetime. Out of all four of the poems, I certainly was able to decipher this poem very easily as I did not have to reread it several times as I had to for a some of the other ones.
Coincidentally I have read the poem Sestina before, only I have read it in another language and sung it with my choir. It is because of this that I read this poem as a negotiating reader since I also bring previous knowledge to the table by just reading the title. It was a very emotional piece for us all to sing and we often brought the audience to tears. The word "tears" is used several times throughout the text which emphasizes that the grandmother is experiencing pain and suffering.
I think I Bertram's code poems take a certain kind of person to have the patience and determination to solve the mystery of the meaning. It is for that reason that I believe I read this poem as a oppositional reader since I feel I am quite resistant to it. I do enjoy reading poetry but when it comes to the point where it is a challenge to discover the intended meaning let alone decoding the literary terms I tend to give up.
When reading E.E. Cummings poems I identified the overall meanings prominently. It stood out at me that 1a) is about loneliness since the word is formed in the last few stanzas. The poem r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r likewise, seemed quite simple to me to recognize the overall meaning was about a grasshopper. Thus, I read this poem as a dominant reader because E.E. Cummings clearly intended for the audience to grasp this concept.

For the poem “Two Faced” by Ishac Bertran, I demonstrated dominant reading. I understood what the poem’s message was in a literal sense as it describes what happens in one’s mind versus what one’s visible behaviour is. For the poem “Sestina”, I demonstrated dominant reading. I understood the underlying theme of sadness through the repetition of ‘tears’ and the actions of the grandmother. For the poems by E.E Cummings, I demonstrated dominant reading as well as negotiating reading. It is clear that one of the poems is about grasshoppers and the other poem is about a falling leaf. However, both the poems are also structured uniquely and I think that their structure plays a role in what I believe to be a theme of perspective. For the poem “Agrippa”, I was initially quite confused as to what the theme was. However, after reading the poem again, I picked up on memory as playing a part of the poem’s overall theme which demonstrates dominant reading. After attempting to read the poem “Sestina” in a negotiating manner, I can associate death to it as well. The drawing that the child makes of a man with buttons like tears could be of the grandfather who passed away. Also, the house seems chilly to the grandmother perhaps due to loneliness. Likewise, September could be the time of the year when the grandfather passed away thus signalling a tough time which is why the almanac says it’s ‘time to plant tears’. By using details mentioned in the poem, I can become a negotiating reader in order to further interpret the themes and meaning behind the poem.

I found this module quite frustrating due to the fact that I do not understand poetry very well or the meanings behind many of them. I feel I was more of a dominant reader while going through "Agrippa" because I was able to grasp the literal sense of it; memory. This goes along with most of them, especially the code poems since I took more of a literal meaning to them but not much else. Not being able to decode them for other than what they were intentionally. Also not knowing the authors intentions for it but being curious as to what they might mean and how it relates to what we've been discussing leads to more of a mix of a dominant and negotiating reader. If reading "Sestina" as a dominant reader, I would take the literal meaning of the text and in this case might conclude that this elderly woman is crazy, talking to inanimate objects, acting strange, living in a creepy house. On the other hand, as a negotiating reader I would be more interested in tying it into grief, loneliness as my first thought was that this woman lost someone beloved, and the signs of the chilly atmosphere was to emphasize the unhappy, grieving mood she is in. Overall, I think I am a mix between a dominant (only getting the literal meaning intended) and a negotiating (adding my opinion/thought process of what is useful) reader in some instances.

I read the poem “Agrippa” as a dominant reader. As each stanza was about a different photograph in the photo album, i interpreted it exactly as it was written to me. Each stanza created different imagery for me, but the imagery was all in a picture. Although I stated that there was probably a deeper meaning, I was not able to look past the obvious, because reading this poem was just like flipping through an old and memorable photo album.
Reading the poem “Sestina” made me read like a negotiating reader. The first time i read through it, i had already programmed my mind to look for the theme of the poem, since that is what the previous module suggested for us to do. Since I did this, I unintentionally closed my mind to noticing other distinct things about the poem. After having it read it the first time and realizing that maybe I had read it too quickly due to the fact that I did not fully understand it, I read it a second time. The second time, I read it more slowly and didn't try to narrow my focus on finding anything specific. By broadening my mind, I then discovered all the personification present in the poem and the changing effect it had on the reader.
I read the poems, “Daily Grind”, “Unhandled Love”, “Twofaced” and “Dancing Within” as an oppositional reader. What these four poems all share in common is the style in which they are written, known as code. These code poems appeared extremely difficult to understand and interpret at a first glance. Even after having read them once or twice, I could not decipher any hidden meaning or themes. Apart from understanding what individual sentences and words meant, I was unable to piece it all together, making me reject the coding style. Similarly, the poem “r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r” was written in a unique way, kind of like coding, but not entirely. It took me a few times to realize that the title, was a rearrangement of the word “grasshopper”.

I agree with you Angela, I found this module frustrating as well. Like you I have a hard time understanding code poems and look at them in a literal sense instead of what they could further represent. I find it interesting that you see the elderly women in "Sestina" as crazy, after reading it again I can see your point but initially I hadn't considered it.

Make sure you take into account the context of Agrippa, Romney. It was originally encrypted so that one could only read it (or see it) once and then the poem was hidden from view unless you could decrypt it. Knowing this, think about how that would complicate your reading -- you were not told that the poem would encrypt itself when you bought it. Would the poem's meanings be so "obvious" if you read it once? What would it mean to your interpretation that the poem was locked down? Why would the poem do that? Trying to answer these kinds of questions gets you out of the "I read it this way" kind of comment that's above and into the more analytical comment that begins, "now, if I read it this way under the conditions of the poem's publication, what would that be like and why is that important to how I understood the poem?"
More about what things mean and less about what they are.

Breanne, your comments around the Sestina are bang on a negotiated reading. You might think about how the meaning of the poem is different or comes across differently when it is sung. Is there something about the singing that makes the poem's meaning different?
Also, remember that simplicity does not necessarily mean you read it dominantly. You could read oppositionally and still THINK you are reading it literally. That's what makes the "encoding / decoding" things so interesting. You don't KNOW you are reading it oppositionally until someone gives you an alternative. Like the saying: A fish does not know water exists until it is beached.

Try to phrase things not in terms of what you did -- "I demonstrated a dominant reading" -- but instead frame things around why that is important. I don't need to know the "what" you did; I need to know "why" and then most importantly why that is important to the reading of the poem, or the interpretive possibilities that are locked in the poem.
The more you direct your thinking away from "this is how I read it" toward "this is why I read it like I did" the better off you will be offering an interpretation of the text that carries some weight and offers an application of the knowledge you possess.

You might be frustrated because you are conflating two different things. The literal sense of Agrippa is NOT memory--that's an interpretation of what the poem is about. The literal reading is that it is an individual looking over a photo album filled with pictures that have meaning to him/her. You are negotiating the "memory" part and that is the "meaning behind" the poem. Often, students are too intimidated by poetry--you have the interpretation already set and then think it's too easy so it cannot be correct. But, if you keep Stuart Hall's ideas in mind, and take your "dominant" reading as the "old woman is crazy," you might ask the following questions: what words in the poem suggest that she is crazy? How is that a dominant reading--in other words, saying she's crazy is an interpretation and it needs support from the poem. The second you do that, you are negotiating the reading to some extent. Something from your own sense of things--a gut feeling--has told you she's crazy. You're job in textual analysis is to point out some evidence that supports that gut feeling so it seems more valid. It's not just a hunch, but a substantiated argument. Stop trying to peg yourself as "dominant" or "negotiated" and instead think about HOW you read the texts and HOW and WHY you read them the way you do.

Hey Breanne!
I just wanted to comment on the poem "Sestina" and your comments about it. I googled sestina and found out more about it. I find it really cool that you already had some background knowledge about the poem to begin with especially in another language.
The way I interpreted the text and the reoccurrence of the word "tears" was in fact suggesting that the grandmother and child were in some type of pain and the tears symbolized their mourning.

While I was reading “Agrippa” it’s clear looking back that I was reading it as a dominant reader. The poem wanted me to realize that yes, this poem is in fact about memory. I think I was also probably reading it a bit as a negotiating reader. I felt I negotiated between the dominant reading and what my own interest in the poem was. For example when I said that the poem was based on memories that were triggered by a series of photographs and that it analyzes how mechanisms affect our perception of reality. A photograph, which can symbolize a mechanism, triggers our memory of what once was but at the same time it can destroy it. Reading that poem I think anyone can make their own connections to what the theme is which are memories, good and bad.
I think reading Bertram’s poems the “Daily Grind/Unhandled Love/Twofaced/Dancing Within” I was being an oppositional reader. I couldn’t gather or figure out some of the themes or how they all connected to one another (which was frustrating) but I think it was because non of the themes never applied to me so I just rejected the entire poem and it’s meaning.
The only poem that I could clearly gather meaning of was Bertram’s “Daily Grind” poem. Being a negotiating reader, I made the connection to my own life of how boring and painful routine is sometimes. I think almost everyone can relate to being frustrated and bored with the same routine time after time. I was reading the poem, agreeing that yes, routine is boring but I also just drifted off thinking about how boring and how much my life is lived through routine.
I found “Sestina” to be one the more enjoyable poems to read, maybe because it just intrigued me and the meaning was obvious but it also had deeper meaning behind it. Reading this I was a negotiating reader I think, just because even though everyone probably understood the basic idea of what the theme was I still tried to gather as much as my own opinions from the text that suited what I wanted the poem to mean. The grandmother and the child are left alone, the tears suggest an obvious tragedy in both their lives. They symbolize the realness of someone mourning over death. Although both the child and grandmother are alone they are together and still have a house filled with love. That’s at least what I wanted to gather from the poem.
With E.E. Cummings poems I read them as the dominant reader. Specifically for the “r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r” it’s clear that the poem is about a grasshopper but it was difficult to understand what was being said or symbolized by the grasshopper. Although for [1(a)] reading as a dominant reader I understood it was about loneliness but extracting words and phrases (“oneliness” and “a leaf falls”). To me a when a leaf falls it falls alone, suggesting loneliness. But the word “oneliness” (even though it may not be a real word, ONE is in lONEliness) to me represents being whole with yourself. Even if your alone it doesn’t necessarily mean your alone.
