You might ask yourself WHY you were trying to "decipher any hidden meanings or themes"? What were your expectations for the code poems and HOW did that effect how you approached the poems?
From where I sit, your reading was tainted from the get go because you expecting something from them that might not have been there or you were looking for hidden things--which means you were decoding the poems in a specific way. Ask yourself why you felt compelled to do that--because this is a lit class and there must be hidden meanings in the assigned reading? THERE MUST BE!?!?!? Or, you don't understand code and therefore thought that there must be something mysterious in the poems? Or, you expected something that wasn't there?
Try to free up your expectations, or at least account for them. Ask yourself how you are approaching a text and what biases you bring to the table when you approach them -- how then do you account for those biases? How do they influence how you approach the text and what you expect to get out of them?

Yup. You might also think about how those tears are attached to other items in the poem other than the grandmother and the overall mood that creates. Who is doing all this crying anyway? And what does that mean to the act of mourning? What's being mourned exactly? How much do we know about what affects the lives of others? How does the poem mimic that lack of insight, but acknowledge that we often know something is up...

Great readings Nicole. You could flesh a few of these out and figure out what the criteria for what's here--in other words, how is your reading here, if we push it, suggesting that the poems have a particular perspective on being alone, for instance? How might you characterize that based on what's in the poems and your expectations and finally how you negotiate the terms in the poems through your own lens.

The first time that I read “r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r” I made the assumption right away that the poem was all gibberish and that it was annoying. This shows that I read this in a very negotiated way. I understood that the text was about a grasshopper but when I read the mixed up words, I immediately read what I wanted to read. By re-reading the text in a more dominant way, I found more clues of the theme. The poem is still quite confusing but I was able to decipher words and phrases such as become, rearrange, gathering into, as we look, and obviously grasshopper. While I’m still struggling with finding a theme in these words, by reading the poem in a different manner, I was able to make more sense of it. The theme that I came up with the first time that I read “Agrippa” was memories. It was difficult for me to find a more specific theme is this poem because the sections didn’t seem to have a lot of close similarities to them. When I reread this poem, I tried to do it as an oppositional reader. By doing this I discovered that I could find a multitude of different meanings in the text as long as I had evidence to prove it. From one perspective I read the poem as the acceptance of war and guns in our modern age and how society got to that point. The poem romanticized guns by saying that it was “like the first time you put your mouth on a woman.” In that time, it was also very common for men to be fighting the war, which encourages violent behavior. I might be just pulling ideas out of nothing but I’m just trying to find other potential meanings out of the text.

Initially the way I was reading the poem “Agrippa” was in a dominant way as I understood the basic idea of the poem. I understood that the poem involved nostalgia when he was going through individual memories and reminiscing through the Kodak photos. Nostalgia, war and death were still the most prominent themes to me. Since I gathered the main themes at the end of the poem without questioning the implications further or making more of an effort to further explore the poem or what else it could represent, it would be classified as dominant reading. When I read through the code poems, I was getting frustrated because I couldn’t get past the dominant way of reading. Since they were foreign to me, I couldn’t apply them to what I already know or have them influence the way my thoughts. This meant I wasn’t reading in a negotiating or oppositional way. Going back and re reading the poems was easier because after viewing how others interpreted or read the poems gave me clues to better understand what the themes are and what the author is trying to get across. I attempted to change the way I read “Sestina” from dominant to negotiating and even though it took some effort I feel I was able to get past the most basic meaning and into how my interests aim to change what I take from it. For instance to me the basic idea of the poem is that an elderly woman is obviously troubled by something- the tears and the keeping herself busy in the kitchen so the child doesn’t see are cues that she is upset. The almanac it seems has said something that causes her distress or foreshadows something terrible is about to happen or has happened already. Overall the main idea I take from “Sestina” is that a tragedy has occurred and the grandmother and child are coping with it in their own way. To read it in a negotiating way I took this idea further and thought of how the gloomy setting and dismal behaviours described could be something to do with their mental states. Since I am a psychology major I tend to relate everything to this field because it interests me. After reading the poem again in this new way I thought it could be possible that the poem could represent mental health. It’s possible that the grandmother is depressed and that she feels worse at different times of the year based on her ‘equinoctial tears’ which refer to the equinox which happens twice a year. Some people deal with seasonal depression and are only depressed at certain times of the year so it could be possible. Anyways this poem probably isn’t about that but I applied it to my interests and this is what I could come up with that made sense.

After rereading “Agrippa” I can say that I was a dominant reader. The text of the poem predominantly consisted of stanzas about pictures in a black book. These pictures which I believe were meant to bring up memories for the author also created certain visualization from me. I also agree that the my personal experiences may change the way I perceive a photo and even literature. Reading “Sestina’ the first time as a dominant reader I thought the theme was personification of objects but after rereading the poem I felt as if I fit in the negotiating reader. I read “Sestina” right after “Agrippa” which may have affected my perspective of the “Sestina” poem because I believe the poem is now about memory. Reading certain stanzas that mention tears and the picture a child draws makes me believe the poem is about a sad memory. I was also dominant as I read “r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r” again. “r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r” is about a grasshopper as it is throughout the poem numerous times. But I felt I was also a negotiated reader because rereading the poem brought up thoughts about codes in The Bug and how the theme could be about perceiving visualizations differently. Overall I found this module difficult because I am not really into poems and had a tough time trying to figure out the themes. (Especially the “code poems”)

These past couple modules have been quite the struggle for me. I have always struggled with understanding poetry, on top of that deciphering what the poems mean. I find that when reading a poem that I struggle to understand, I tend to be a dominant reader and take the poetry for its literal meaning.
When I was reading “Sestina” I was similar to almost everyone else who read the poem. To start, I began to read the poem as a dominant reader. The setting was described at the beginning of the poem, which can be taken literally. There is nothing that I have relate necessarily to my own life in the setting, but just take the description that the author is giving me. The poem goes on to talk about an older lady and frequently personifies different inanimate objects which would be strange to read as a dominant reader. I then began to read the poem in a different perspective of a negotiating reader.
I found that reading through this I am a dominant and a negotiating reader as I start to read every poem in a literal manner, however, the moment that the literal meaning of the poem begins to sound crazy, I turn my perspective to a negotiating reader. When I read I look to see which outcome of the poem makes the most sense.

“[l(a]” at first sight is uniquely written like page source made to confuse. It was not the usual poem I have encountered before; its meaning foreign if I was not attentive to what is hidden between each line. In “[l(a]”, I first understood it as a falling leaf, leaving its home one by one. Interestingly the author crafted the poem to a falling leaf, five sets of two letters each having lines, then lastly an “l” by itself, in its own line. The poem signifies that of loneliness, being separated as expressed on the last line. My initial analysis thus, shows dominant reading. As opposed to what the poem shows from its appearance, I think that the poem can also mean being one with something else, one with a different crowd rather than being alone. As evidenced by the word “oneliness”, it could also be pulled out from the word loneliness, which means being compact or strength in who you are as an individual. I can compare this to a high school graduate moving on to further her knowledge, moving on from where it planted its roots, for it to become stronger, to become a newer tree; a better person. I also think that loneliness might not be pertaining to the leaf, but instead to the tree. Moreover, it may describe a tree that becomes lonely during winter time, alone without the leaves that keep it warm. I can’t even explain how insightful this poem was written, reading this brought me from reading by the surface: dominant reading, then relating it to myself: negotiated reading, and lastly oppositional.

When I reread “Agrippa”, I was (as many other people) a dominant reader because my first thought was the poem is about “memory” and many of my peers agreed. I have the same experience as Maxine when she said she tried to read it in a different perspective. The years, flashbacks, objects that represents the past makes the theme of the poem obvious so literal meaning stands out. I feel like there is no “hidden” meaning behind the poem, at least in my experience. Maybe because I could not relate to the poem, so I could not be a negotiated reader. When I read Sestina for the first time, I was a dominant reader because the word “tears” shows up most of the time. So I was just reading the poem (not really thinking about it) and understanding just the text. For the second time, I noticed the word “almanac” and I looked it up, it means calendar. Since the grandmother sad and depressed, she is probably worried about aging and time passing too quickly. For example, “time to plant tears, says the almanac” and the word September at the beginning. I guess this makes me a negotiating reader since I agree what my peers said about the grandmother being sad but sad for different reason.
For the other poems such as “ “r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r”, I think I was an oppositional reader because I interpreted the text a lot differently from my peers. I knew the word grasshopper at the end but I didn’t know the grasshopper was part of the title and the theme until David mentioned this. I thought the poem was about codes because that is our theme for the course. When I read it for the second time, I finally got the message: the second last sentence re arranging become grasshopper. The author is trying to “annoy” us that the poem is about something simple (a grasshopper) and grasshopper can be annoying.

After reading the first poem Agrippa again I see that my initial view on the theme of it was very dominant. I touched the surface on how it was based on memories. Seeing each stanza was based with a year I focused too much on the fact rather than on the detail behind it. This is too broad and does not tell us the true meaning the author is trying to present through the poem.
The themes of sorrow and sadness I got from Sestina because of the use of words such as “tears” and “rain” was more of a negotiating style of reading for me. I interpreted the ideas of sadness and sorrow from those words and looking in detail in the story of those words meanings. Also with the first line starting with September I use a negotiating style of connecting it to my own interpretation into how September is usually a very stressful month for me with school starting.
I tried reading Sestina in a oppositional way of how the grandmothers story was happy and cheerful. Doing this gave me a different perspective of the story and gave me some a new perspective of the meaning the author is trying to say behind the story. I saw the close connection between the grandmother and the child and that they are suffering from a loss or tragedy. The story is very sad but the connection and love they have is wonderful.
With both the coded poems and r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r and 1(a my interpretation of the themes very all very dominant. I only looked at the surface of the codes and the patterns that made and the unscrambled letters but not the meaning behind them. I see the poem says grasshopper for example but what is the author intending by it. I hope I can improve my interpretation skills behind these poems so I can see the authors true intention behind these poems.

For “Agrippa” my reading was similar to most of the comments as my perspective of the poem was through dominant reading. I had read it to understand the generic theme about memories present throughout the entire poem. I did not look for a deeper meaning or another idea for the poem nor did I reject any other ideas present in the poem. My reading was also dominant for “TWOFACED” as I just read the main concept of being two faced in our everyday language. However, if you think with a negotiating perspective, then being two faced doesn’t so seem bad. The poem makes it obvious that most people do it and how it may be a bad thing, but when I think of it realistically it would be impossible to not be two faced. In some situations it would be worse to be brutally honest to people than to just lie because sometimes I prefer to just lie to people and agree with them if I know that I will not see them in a while. So maybe from my point of view it could also be an oppositional reading method. The only negotiated reading I did from all the poems was “ Sestina” because the dominant reading made the theme related to grief. However, my negotiated reading is what decided that the grief was related to the lost of a loved one, who may be the grandfather of the novel. I predicted it was a grandfather due to the grandma’s random crying and the child’s drawing of the man. I also guessed that maybe the weather or season was related to being around the time of the grandfather was deceased.

After going through the poems again and re-reading my discussions of them, I think that I am a mix of a dominant and a negotiating reader. For example, when I read “Agrippa”, I did very little to extrapolate the deeper details and meanings of the poem. I noticed that I was only pointing out the obvious themes and concepts. A dominant reader only sees the text for what was intended and what other people would also assume was intended. With “Sestina”, I used the same process. The information that I collected was basic and easy to find.
However, for some of the other poems, instead of seeing them for what the author might be trying to portray, I connected the situations to my own life and own experiences. For example, my older brother had taken several computing science courses and is quite well versed. When I showed him the poems, he noticed the different kinds of languages right away (Java, C++, etc.). Once I realized that the poems were more complicated that I thought and not what I had expected, I began to assume that I wouldn’t be able to decipher them without understanding the code. I noticed the main themes in each poem, like the dominant reader, but I rejected some of the more complicated verses knowing that I probably wouldn’t be able to understand them. This shows that I was a negotiating reader because I was caught between discovering the author’s intentions for the poems while knowing that there are much deeper meanings- supposedly beyond my reach.

After rereading "r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r and 1(a " I was able to grasp the utmost basic understanding a for person who does not possess high and precise analytically skills with poetry. The contents when unscrambled were just the surface, who knows if the author is trying to convey a deeper message (I would like to learn how to analyze these types of code poems for future benefit). For example "r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r" unscrambled may be "grasshopper" but I, for one, is unsure of what the author E.E Cummings is trying to convey. I would also like to state that I was a dominate reader with "Agrippa" because it was very straight forward as I was able to skim the surface or encryption and memories with physical belonging such as photographs.
Almost everything I learn is hard to grasp unless I incorporate content to my own interest, I am careful of not being bias to try and understand what the author is projecting. I took the reading of "Two-faced" into a negotiated approach to understand the short poem. It is probably safe to assume everyone experiences or at least seen the petty dramas that comes along with high school. It wasn't long before I associated the content of the poem to catty, jealous and insecure girls back in the days to suit my own interest. The words in the poem rang, as it is very immature to use that kind of vulgarity behind someone's back. As I reread the depressing poem "Sestina" I couldn't help but to have negotiating as well as opposing views towards it, as my own grandmother was a happy and positive being before she passed. The grandmother in the poem was clearly unhappy and the reasons were unclear, being so, it led to a lot of possibilities and room for inference. In society and on television I've seen, the elderly are often portrayed as bitter and sad whereas I've seen some happy and enjoyable elderly people.
Hope this comment isn't too late! I hope you can accept this. Thank you

As I read the poem “Agrippa”, I was trying to read it like a dominant reader. I reread every line, trying to imagine the imagery exactly how the author intended. As the author saw each picture, he also encoded the pictures with a very detailed description. While describing the old photos, Gibson used other senses like smell and touch; rather than just site. An example of this would be when Gibson describes the smell of the “pitch” as “the sweet hot reek”. Memory is a theme that stood out to me in this poem because with every picture, Gibson gave an extremely detailed description, as if he was the one taking the photos. These photographs are the memories of his life. These are relatives and friends that have passed on. I’m assuming they’re now diseased because it is called “the book of the dead”. I wasn’t quite clear what Gibson meant by “the mechanism”, this is when I started to think like a negotiating reader. The mechanism might be a symbol for what is now losst or forgotten. The people in the photos might be dead but the memory of them still remains in the narrators mind. The “r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r” poem was much more intriguing to me because I admired the way it was laid out. It looked confusing at first, like a code. There were random letters, brackets and the lines but once I took a closer look at the poem, it started to make a little more sense to me. Perhaps I’m reading the poem like an oppositional reader, but the theme in this poem was like a grasshopper. The way the letters jump around and change places are just like how grasshoppers do. Also, the only word the in the poem was the word grasshopper but rearranged differently in every line. My favorite line in the poem was “rea(be)rran(com)gi(e)ngly” because it spells become and rearranging, and if you rearrange the words they spell grasshopper.

I feel a bit out of this world when reading “Agrippa”… because I feel the author’s intentions are to pass on memories to the reader, just as the speaker carries memories from reading the “black book” (Gibson, William “Agrippa”). I feel like a dominated reader when I think the theme is memories, and passing them is the closest you can get to immortality, just like penumbra’s bookstore. However, “r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r” can be interpreted differently for every person due to its abnormal format as a poem because everyone can reference different meanings. For instance, I do see grasshopper a couple of times in the poem, but I also see that grasshopper is a reference to “The karate kid”, one who is new and willing to learn. With this, I feel the author’s intentions to say that, at the time of when the poem was published, we are new to computers, and need to learn how computers work, and we will encounter problems here and there just like in The Bug; problems such as encoding and decoding codes, such as the poem itself. Furthermore, I conclude that the theme for “r-p-o-p-h-e-s-s-a-g-r” is learning. But someone can interpret it as a bug, which eats crops and is a nuisance to society. “Sestina” can be interpreted as a sad poem, due to its symbolism. The adjectives such as “dark”, “failing”, chilly all make the poem feel dark. The grandmother is alone with the child while “hiding her tears”, giving the reader ideas of unfortunate events such as the grandfather dying, giving the poem a depressing tone. One can assume the theme is loneliness, because there is only the grandmother, and child in a house surrounded by rain, making it sound dark. However, one can interpret the theme as depression if they use an oppositional reading by assuming the child has down syndrome. The child draws “inscrutable house[es]”, giving the idea that the child has certain limitations from drawing a square and a triangle. Overall, I think you’ll interpret different themes based on what kind of reader you are.

Cool. I should use all five of my senses to relate to imagery when I read a poem. I feel the mechanism is William's memories, and how he can always laugh when people memorize his memories. Just how he managed to pass his memories to us, he can laugh in peace knowing that he passed on a legacy.
I don't think the theme is grasshopper. I think the theme is something what the grasshopper represents. You can be a negotiated reader, and interpret what the grasshopper really means. Depression? Loneliness? Learning? It's up to you.

*furthermore, I think you'll be a different kind of reader if you change your POV. a good example would be comparing oppositional and dominant reading E.g. You would assume a couple had some form of physical contact if they both walked out of a household washroom. But if you read and observed them in the washroom, and all they did was talk and get ready for a dinner, then your interpretation would be different.

item.title: Four Perspectives Module
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Instructions: Due for Feb. 25th class. If you've read Moxyland, you know that the story is told from four different perspectives (Kendra, Lerato, Tendeka, Toby). This module asks you to think about perspectives by engaging with definitions--a really important way of dealing with themes. To complete this module, you will need to go to the library. Task: Below is a list of themes (well, there's really just terms, words, concepts). What I want you to do is come up with four different definitions for one of the terms listed below. There's a few restrictions: 1) you can use only one on-line search (so, Google OR Wikipedia, but not both and then it's off with the internets); 2) two of your definitions must be from a dictionary (a paper-based one) and an encyclopedia (a paper-based one); 3) one of your definitions must come from a human being. Then, write out your definitions in the comment space below. Try to vary the term you choose, we don't need 35 entries on dystopia. What do I mean by different definitions, exactly? The goal of this module is to get you thinking about how a term can be defined differently by different perspectives. The reason I want paper-based sources isn't because I hate the internet, but because an encyclopedia and dictionary are likely to be out-of-date and thus offer a different angle than Google or Wikipedia, which are both updated constantly (maybe). Finally, the human being will often offer something vague or discursive (look up that word in the dictionary!). If it turns out that all the definitions you assemble for the module are identical, well then so be it; but I doubt this will happen. Make sure you identify the source (dictionary name and date of publication, encyclopedia name and date of publication, my mother, Google, etc.) Here's an example of what you should produce (but with a lame term): Cat:
  • Google:
  • noun 1. a small domesticated carnivorous mammal with soft fur, a short snout, and retractile claws. It is widely kept as a pet or for catching mice, and many breeds have been developed. synonyms: feline, tomcat, tom, kitten, mouser; More a wild animal of the cat family. "a marbled cat" used in names of catlike animals of other families, e.g., ring-tailed cat. historical short for cat-o'-nine-tails. short for catfish. short for cathead. short for catboat. 2. NORTH AMERICAN informal (particularly among jazz enthusiasts) a person, especially a man. verb NAUTICAL verb: cat; 3rd person present: cats; past tense: catted; past participle: catted; gerund or present participle: catting 1.raise (an anchor) from the surface of the water to the cathead.
  • Dictionary (Merriam-Webster, 1967):
  • a small animal that is related to lions and tigers and that is often kept by people as a pet; a lion, tiger, leopard, or similar wild animal; a man
  • My Friend Jane:
  • So cute! Cutest thing in the world! LOL cat!
  • Encyclopedia Brittanica:
  • Domestic cat (Felis catus), also called house cat, domesticated member of the family Felidae, order Carnivora, and the smallest member of that family. Like all felids, domestic cats are characterized by supple, low-slung bodies, finely molded heads, long tails that aid in balance, and specialized teeth and claws that adapt them admirably to a life of active hunting. Domestic cats possess other features of their wild relatives in being basically carnivorous, remarkably agile and powerful, and finely coordinated in movement.
Summary: Notice how each one of the definitions is slightly different? That's what we're going for because it allows us to think about themes in a way that narrows our focus and gives us a clear picture of how diverse the conversation about that theme is already. And just so you know, we would never quote any of the definitions we find in an essay--this is a way into writing and thinking, not part of the main event. Here's the list of themes: biotechnology, dystopia, utopia, nanotechnology, digital technology, hierarchy, hegemony, privilege, tension, race, cyberpunk, indulgence, totalitarianism, government, gender, corporation, consent, ecology, signal, control, autonomy. *Remember, only pick one of the terms and define it four ways as directed above. Have fun!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Utopia:
Dictionary (New Websters, 1992):
"Any ideal state, constitution, system or way of life"
My coworker Brent:
"An ideal living arrangement, where everyone is happy"
Wikipedia
"A utopia is a community or society possessing highly desirable or near perfect qualities. The word was coined by Sir Thomas More in Greek for his 1516 book Utopia (in Latin), describing a fictional island society in the Atlantic Ocean. The term has been used to describe both intentional communities that attempt to create an ideal society, and imagined societies portrayed in fiction. It has spawned other concepts, most prominently dystopia."
Encyclopedia:
To be completed asap (I will reply to my own comment)

Totalitarianism: Google: Totalitarianism is a political system in which the state holds total authority over the society and seeks to control all aspects of public and private life wherever possible. Dictionary: Funk & Wagnalls Standard Desk Dictionary, 1977 A government controlled exclusively by one party or faction, and maintained by political suppression. My Dad: Totalitarianism is a system where by very few people at the top control all the rest of the masses.
Encyclopedia: Webster’s, 1983 n. 1. The practices and principles of a totalitarian regime: the totalitarianism of Nazi Germany. 2. Absolute control by the state or a governing branch of a highly centralized institution: Totalitarianism aims at suppressing initiative as well as individualism. 3. The character or quality of an autocratic or authoritarian individual, group or government: They suffered under the totalitarianism of the father in their patriarchal house hold. [TOTALITARIAN + -ISM]

Biotechnology
Wikipedia:
“the use of living systems and organisms to develop or make useful products, or ‘any technological application that uses biological systems, living organisms or derivatives thereof, to make or modify products or processes for specific use’.”
My mama:
“The advancement of modern day methods through technology to explore bioengineering.”
Dictionary (Oxford English Dictionary, 2008):
“The exploitation of biological processes for industrial and other purposes, especially the genetic manipulation of mircro-organisms for the production of antibiotics, hormones, etc.”
Encyclopedia (World Book, 2012):
“The term for techniques of managing biological systems for human benefit.”

Utopia:
Wikipedia: “The word was coined by Sir Thomas More in Greek for his 1516 book Utopia (in Latin), describing a fictional island society in the Atlantic Ocean. The term has been used to describe both intentional communities that attempt to create an ideal society, and imagined societies portrayed in fiction.”
My brother, Niko: “Paradise."
The Universal Standard Encyclopedia (1956): “Name given by Sir Thomas More to the imaginary island which he makes the scene of his famous political romance of that name. More’s satire, for the “island” is England, obtained a wide popularity, and supplied the epithet Utopian to all impracticable schemes for the improvement of society.”
Canadian Oxford Dictionary (2004): “Noun 1. An imaginary or hypothetical place or state of things considered to be perfect; a condition of social or political perfection."

Government:
Google: Noun 1. The governing body of a nation, state, or community. "An agency of the federal government"
Dictionary.com:
Noun 1. The political direction and control exercised over the actions of the members, citizens, or inhabitants of communities, societies, and states; direction of the affairs of a state, community, etc.; political administration: Government is necessary to the existence of civilized society.
Student Athlete:
Political System imposed on a country or place.
Oxford Dictionary:
Noun 1. The group of people with the authority to govern a country or state; a particular ministry in office: the government’s economic record successive Labour governments

Gender:
Wikipedia: "Gender is the range of characteristics pertaining to, and differentiating between, masculinity and femininity. Depending on the context, these characteristics may include biological sex (i.e. the state of being male, female or intersex), sex-based social structures (including gender roles and other social roles), or gender identity."
Dictionary (Oxford English Dictionary, 3rd ed. 2011): Noun 1) In some (esp. Indo-European) languages, as Latin, French, German, English, etc.: each of the classes (typically masculine, feminine, neuter, common) of nouns and pronouns distinguished by the different inflections which they have and which they require in words syntactically associated with them; similarly applied to adjectives (and in some languages) verbs, to denote the appropriate form for accompanying a noun of such a class. Also: the fact, condition, or property of belonging to such a class; the classification of language in this way.
My brother Steven: Someone who has a female or male identity, regardless of what they were born with.
Encyclopedia Britannica (2013): "an individual’s self-conception as being male or female, as distinguished from actual biological sex. For most persons, gender identity and biological characteristics are the same. "

Consent:
Collins Gage Canadian Paperback Dictionary (2006): V. "To give permission, either willingly because one agrees, or by giving in to the wishes of others."
Google: noun -"permission for something to happen or agreement to do something." verb-"give permission for something to happen."
My friend, Melissa: "Being aware of and agreeing with all given terms and conditions of an arrangement."
Only had an Encyclopedia of Psychology at home so hopefully it's alright.. Encyclopedia of Psychology (Oxford, 2000): "A principle of respect for each individual's right to choose whether or not to take part in such activities."

Last part of my definitions (Utopia)
Encyclopedic Dictionary of English Usage (Prentice Hall, 2nd edition,1993): (from Greek./ "no place;" title of 1516 book by Thomas More. Perfect society

Wikipedia:
"Totalitarianism is a political system in which the state holds total authority over the society and seeks to control all aspects of public and private life wherever possible."
My friend Matt:
"Government owned state, along with total ownership of property, businesses, assets. Strict rules, often are absolute. Unusually large amount of GDP goes to military spending. Less freedom of speech, alienation of rights are often common-side with totalitarianism. State controlled media, as masses need to be swayed to follow total rule. Also has the characteristic of 'removing' political opponents and 'noisy' minorities. Afraid of internet, and social media, as they are unable to be controlled by state (Facebook, YouTube, Twitter, Instagram).
Examples include : Soviet Union, North Korea"
I'll update with the dictionary and encyclopedia definitions later, they aren't in the ones I have at home.

My word: Hierarchy
Wikipedia: “An arrangement of items (objects, names, values, categories, etc.) in which the items are represented as being ‘above,’ ‘below,’ or ‘at the same level as’ one another”.
The Merriam Webster Dictionary: “A ruling body of clergy organized into ranks” 2. “Persons or things arranged in a graded series”
Encyclopedia Britannica: “A ranking of positions of authority, often associated with a chain of command and control”
My Mother: “A ranking of importance/power”

Consent:
Wikipedia:
Consent is agreement or permission to do or allow something.
My friend, Elise:
When you are allowed or given permission to do something.
Dictionary (Webster's Dictionary and Thesaurus 2007):
To agree, to give one's permission (to consent the operation). Agreement, permission.
Encyclopedia (Encyclopedia Britannica):
Consent, in ethics and political philosophy, an act of permitting something to be done or of recognizing some authority. Granting consent implies relinquishing some authority in a sphere of concern in which one’s sovereignty ought otherwise to be respected. Consent is, under certain conditions, generally taken to have deep moral significance, but scholars disagree over what forms of consent generate what sorts of obligations and what conditions make consent morally and legally significant.

Wikipedia: Gender is the range of characteristics pertaining to, and differentiating between, masculinity and femininity. Depending on the context, these characteristics may include biological sex (i.e. the state of being male, female or intersex), sex-based social structures (including gender roles and other social roles), or gender identity. My brother: Gender is what describes males and females. Oxford Dictionary of English Etymology, 1966: Gender is any of the three ‘kinds’, masculine, feminine and neuter, of nouns, adjectives, and pronouns; kind, sort. Encyclopedia of Psychology, 2000: Gender is a cultural category that contains the roles, behaviours, rights, responsibilities, privileges, and personality traits assigned by that specific culture to men and women.

Gender
Google "'Gender' refers to the socially constructed roles, behaviours, activities, and attributes that a given society considers appropriate for men and women."
Dictionary (Grolier New Websters Dictionary, 1992) "the classification of words, or the class to which a word belongs by virtue of such classification, according to the sex of the referent (natural gender) or according to arbitrary distinctions to form a syntax (grammatical gender)|| (pop) sex (male or female).
Friend "Gender is the way that people express their sexual identity."—Gel
Encyclopedia Britannica "in language, a phenomenon in which the words of a certain part of speech, usually nouns require the agreement, or concord, through grammatical marking (or infection), if various other words related to them in a sentence. In languages that exhibit gender, two or more classes of nouns control variation in words of other parts of speech (typically pronouns and adjectives, and sometimes verbs). These other words maintain constant meaning but vary in form according to the class of the words that controls hem in a given situation."

Hierarchy
1) Wikipedia: “A hierarchy is an arrangement of items (objects, names, values, categories, etc.) in which the items are represented as being "above," "below," or "at the same level as" one another.”
2) My brother: “It’s the ranking of people or things from high to low.”
3) Oxford English Dictionary (1976): “Whenever persons join or otherwise enter into a plurality pattern they almost invariably take their places in an implicit or explicit hierarchy, and consciously or unconsciously expect the fact that there are ranks above or below them.”
4) Encyclopaedia Britannica (1910): “A term commonly used in ecclesiastical language to denote the aggregate of those persons who exercise authority within the Christian Church.”

Corporation:
Wikipedia: A corporation is a company or group of people authorized to act as a single entity (legally a person) and recognized as such in law. Early incorporated entities were established by charter (i.e. by an ad hoc act granted by a monarch or passed by a parliament or legislature).
Dictionary (Webster’s New World Dictionary 1994): a legal entity, usually a group of people, that has a charter granting it certain legal powers generally given to individuals, as to buy and sell property or to enter into contracts.
My Friend: “Apple Inc.”
Encyclopedia: corporation, specific legal form of organization of persons and material resources, chartered by the state, for the purpose of conducting business.

Dystopia:
Google: A dystopia (from the Greek δυσ- and τόπος, alternatively, cacotopia, kakotopia, or anti-utopia) is an imaginary community or society that is undesirable or frightening. It is literally translated as "not-good place", an antonym of utopia.
My friend Jay:
“It’s like a make belief world”
Dictionary (Canadian Oxford Dictionary):
Noun. A nightmare vision of society, often as one dominated by a totalitarian state
Encyclopedia(New World Encyclopedia)
A Dystopia is the vision of a society that is the opposite of utopia. A dystopian society is one in which the conditions of life are miserable, characterized by human misery, poverty, oppression, violence, disease, and/or pollution.

Dystopia
• Wikipedia: A dystopia (from the Greek δυσ- and τόπος, alternatively, cacotopia,[1] kakotopia, or anti-utopia) is an imaginary community or society that is undesirable or frightening.[2][3] It is literally translated as "not-good place", an antonym of utopia. Such societies appear in many artistic works, particularly in stories set in a future. Dystopias are often characterized by dehumanization,[2] totalitarian governments, environmental disaster,[3] or other characteristics associated with a cataclysmic decline in society. Dystopian societies appear in many sub-genres of fiction and are often used to draw attention to real-world issues regarding society, environment, politics, economics, religion, psychology, ethics, science, and/or technology, which if unaddressed could potentially lead to such a dystopia-like condition.
• Dictionary (English Dictionary -1994 ) An imaginary place where everything which is as bad as is it can be. • Librarian from Douglas college : Its opposite of Utopia please or community highly desirable. (I asked more than 12 random people no one of them knows the meaning of dystopia). • Encyclopedia : ( New dictionary of the history of ideas, 1974) Dystopia is utopia’s polarized mirror image. Dad place Land has eliminated most class distinctions, but with a concomitant loss of individual freedom and artistic creativity.

Word: Indulgence
1. Wikipedia
“In the teaching of the Catholic Church, an indulgence is "a remission before God of the temporal punishment due to sins whose guilt has already been forgiven, which the faithful Christian who is duly disposed gains under certain prescribed conditions through the action of the Church which, as the minister of redemption, dispenses and applies with authority the treasury of the satisfactions of Christ and the saints"
Indulgences allow for the remission of the severe penances of the early Church, which was granted at the intercession of Christians awaiting martyrdom, or at least imprisoned for the faith. They draw on the Treasury of Merit accumulated by Christ's superabundantly meritorious sacrifice on the cross and the virtues and penances of the saints. They are granted for specific good works and prayers in proportion to the devotion with which those good works are performed or prayers recited.”
2. My Friend Jenny
“The act of exciting ones senses for purely selfish results.”
3. Dictionary: A supplement to the Oxford English Dictionary Volume 2: 1976
“(Without preposition.) To gratify a desire, appetite, etc; to take ones pleasure; to ‘partake’, i.e. (too) freely of intoxicants. (pg. 292)”
4. Encyclopedia: Britannica
“Bohemian religious controversy.”
Encyclopedia: New Catholic Encyclopedia
“Authoritative grants from the Church’s treasury for the remission or payment in whole (plenary indulgences) or in part (partial indulgences), valid before God, of the debt of temporal punishment after the guilt of sin has been forgiven. This definition of the Code presumes that sin must be first forgiven before the indulgence can be gained.

Cyberpunk:
Wikipedia : Cyberpunk is a subgenre of science fiction in a future setting, noted for its focus on "high tech and low life".[1][2] It features advanced science, such as information technology and cybernetics, coupled with a degree of breakdown or radical change in the social order.[3]
My Friend Erika: "cyberpunk is like... an alternative fashion style.. I describe it as space themed clothing. for literature.. spacey post apocalyptic scenarios?"
(going to be at the college shortly, so I will find the paper based definitions and post those in a reply)

Encyclopedia: Tate, C. Neal. Governments of the World: A Global Guide to Citizens' Rights and Responsibilities. Vol. 4. Michigan: Thomson Gale, 2006. 188-192. Print.
"Totalitarianism was the term employed by the Italian fascist leader Benito Mussolini (1883-1945) who took power in 1922, to describe the new type of regime he hoped to, and by 1927 partially did, establish in Italy. Although Mussolini did not invent the term, he brought it into common usage, and generations of political leaders, intellectuals, and scholars have continued to employ it, not in the positive sense Mussolini intended, but as a description of a political system fundamentally at odds with basic human values." (188)
The encyclopedia then uses the analysis of Carl J. Friedrich and Zbigniew K. Brzezinski who in their "Totalitiarian Dictatorship and autocracy (1956)" to define the characteristics of totalitarianism. These include:
1)An official and all embracing ideology
2) A one party system
3)the imposition of terror
4) Mass mobilization of the population.
5) A lack of genuine pluralism
6) A monopoly on the armed forces/law
Dictionary: Random House Webster's College Dictionary (1991)
"adj. 1. noting or pertaining to a centralized government that does not tolerate parties or differing opinion and that exercises dictorial control over many aspects of life. 2. exercising control over freedom, will, or thought of others, authoritarian; autocratic. -n. 3. an adherent of totalitarian principles or government

Nanotechnology: • Google:
o “("nanotech") is the manipulation of matter on an atomic, molecular, and supramolecular scale.”
• Dictionary ( Canadian Oxford Dictionary 2ed, 2004):
o “Noun, the branch of technology that deals with dimensions and tolerances of less than 100 nanometres, esp. the manipulation of individual atoms and molecules.”
• Encyclopedia Brittanica:
o “The manipulation and manufacture of materials and devices on the scale of atoms or small groups of atoms. The “nanoscale” is typically measured in nanometres, or billionths of a metre (nanos, the Greek word for “dwarf,” being the source of the prefix), and materials built at this scale often exhibit distinctive physical and chemical properties due to quantum mechanical effects. Although usable devices this small may be decades away (see microelectromechanical system), techniques for working at the nanoscale have become essential to electronic engineering, and nanoengineered materials have begun to appear in consumer products. For example, billions of microscopic “nanowhiskers,” each about 10 nanometres in length, have been molecularly hooked onto natural and synthetic fibres to impart stain resistance to clothing and other fabrics; zinc oxide nanocrystals have been used to create invisible sunscreens that block ultraviolet light; and silver nanocrystals have been embedded in bandages to kill bacteria and prevent infection.”
• My friend John:
o “Microscopic controlled machines, something man made and advance in the technological field.”

Government
WIKIPEDIA: A government is the system by which a state or community is governed.[1] In the Commonwealth of Nations, the word government is also used more narrowly to refer to the collective group of people that exercises executive authority in a state.[2][3][4] This usage is analogous to what is called an "administration" in American English. Furthermore, government is occasionally used in English as a synonym for governance.
In the case of its broad associative definition, government normally consists of legislators, administrators, and arbitrators. Government is the means by which state policy is enforced, as well as the mechanism for determining the policy of the state. A form of government, or form of state governance, refers to the set of political systems and institutions that make up the organisation of a specific government.
DICTIONARY: Webster's third new International Dictionary Unabridged, 2002 1: The act of governing 2:The office, authority, or function of governing
My 11 year old cousin, Jessica: Obama and power
ENCYCLOPEDIA: The World book Encyclopedia, 2012 Government is an institution that establishes and enforces rules, provides services, and manages other affairs for a group of people. The term may also refer to the process of ruling or excising power.

Cyberpunk -
no entry in the gigantic dictionary, Webster's New World Dictionary and Thesaurus- "noun, science fiction describing a future filled with violence, computers and drugs"
Also no entry in the Encyclopedia Britannica (micro or macro -pedias) circa 2005, however I did find an entry in Encyclopedia Britannica online: "Cyberpunk, a science-fiction subgenre characterized by countercultural antiheroes trapped in a dehumanized, high-tech future."

Hey!
Just reading your post I found it really interesting/kinda funny that we as humans and google define hierarchy as people, things, objects, values and so on. Whereas, old dictionaries and encyclopedias define hierarchy as people and people only.
I found that the encyclopedias defined a few of the themes religiously. Looking at it through a religious perspective I can now see how it's relevant to many different cultures.

UTOPIA
Roommate’s Mother (February, 2015): Utopia – means paradise, heaven “Everyone has their own idea of utopia”
Wikipedia (February, 2015): “A utopia (/juːˈtoʊpiə/ yoo-TOH-pee-ə) is a community or society possessing highly desirable or near perfect qualities. The word was coined by Sir Thomas More in Greek for his 1516 book Utopia (in Latin), describing a fictional island society in the Atlantic Ocean. The term has been used to describe both intentional communities that attempt to create an ideal society, and imagined societies portrayed in fiction. It has spawned other concepts, most prominently dystopia.”
Dictionary (New Websters, 1992): “Any ideal state, constitution, system or way of life”
The Universal Standard Encyclopedia (1956): “Name given by Sir Thomas More to the imaginary island which he makes the scene of his famous political romance of that name. More’s satire, for the “island” is England, obtained a wide popularity, and supplied the epithet Utopian to all impracticable schemes for the improvement of society.”

Gender
My Social Geography Classmate Jamie: “Gender is a social construct to which society has greatly based the categories of people as being either male or female and has ignored the aspect of individual preference and identity.”
Shorter Oxford English Dictionary. (2002). Oxford University Press Inc, New York, United States. Volume 1 A-M. Fifth Edition. p.1081: “1.Kind, sort, class, genus. 2. Any of the classes (masculine, feminine, neuter, common) of nouns and pronouns distinguished by modification which they require in words syntactically associated with them and roughly corresponding to the sex or sexlessness of the objects which they denote; the property if belonging to such a class; the appropriate form for accompanying a noun of one such as class; the classification of nouns and other words in this way, as a grammatical principle. 3. State of being male, female, or neuter; sex; the members of one or other sex.”
The World Book Encyclopedia (2011). G Volume 8 A Scott Fetzer Company. Chicago. p.80: “living things are classed as male or female, and things without life as neuter, or sexless. In the same way, words are said to belong to the masculine, the feminine, or the neuter gender.”
“Gender.” Wikipedia. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gender: “Gender is the range of characteristics pertaining to, and differentiating between masculinity and femininity.”

Biotechnology
Wikipedia: Biotechnology is the use of living systems and organisms to develop or make useful products, or “any technological application that uses biological systems, living organisms or derivatives thereof, to make or modify products or processes for specific use.”
My Friend Terrence: Using bacteria to transform a chemical into another chemical through bacteria consumption then harvest the outcome. Advancing our knowledge in biology so we can use it later on for future technology.
Oxford Dictionary: The exploitation of biologic processes for industrial and other purposes, especially the genetics manipulation of microorganisms for the production of antibiotic, hormones, etc.
Encyclopedia Britannica: The use of biology to solve problems and make useful products.

Hierarchy 1.online Wikipedia is an arrangement of items (objects, names, values, categories, etc.) in which the items are represented as being "above," "below," or "at the same level as" one another.
2.dictionary Websters Dictionary, 1981 a graded, system of people or things
3.encyclopedia Encyclopedia Britannicam 2013 ranking of positions of authority often associated with a chain of command and control.
4. friend levels of control and supremacy

Hiearchy:
Wikipedia: “A hierarchy (from the Greek ἱεραρχία hierarchia, "rule of a high priest", from ἱεράρχης hierarkhes, "leader of sacred rites") is an arrangement of items (objects, names, values, categories, etc.) in which the items are represented as being "above," "below," or "at the same level as" one another.
A hierarchy (sometimes abbreviated HR) can link entities either directly or indirectly, and either vertically or horizontally. The only direct links in a hierarchy, insofar as they are hierarchical, are to one's immediate superior or to one of one's subordinates, although a system that is largely hierarchical can also incorporate alternative hierarchies. Indirect hierarchical links can extend "vertically" upwards or downwards via multiple links in the same direction, following a path. All parts of the hierarchy which are not linked vertically to one another nevertheless can be "horizontally" linked through a path by traveling up the hierarchy to find a common direct or indirect superior, and then down again.”
Dictionary (Webster’s Third New International Dictionary, 2005): “A form of government administered by an authoritarian group”
My friend Ruksar: “A triangle showing levels of stuff with the importance level of each thing getting higher and higher”
Encyclopedia Britannica: Hiearchy (Greek hierarchia; from hieros, sacred + archein, rule) is a kind of order, supposing existence of higher (or more sacred) and lower (less sacred) levels of reality. Order, in its turn, is a linkage of fundamentally different elements by means of general law, so that the whole is greater than a simple arithmetical sum of its parts. Since order presupposes difference, it often takes the form of hiearchy. The place of an element in the hierarchical order is determined by the same laws of the while, which are constitutive of the order itself.”

SIGNAL
Webster’s New English Dictionary – Compact Edition - “(noun) a sign, device or gesture to intimate a warning or to give information, esp. at a distance; a message so conveyed; a semaphore system used by railways; in radio, etc, the electrical impulses transmitted or received; a sign or event that initiates action.” - “* vti (pt signaled) to make a signal or signals (to); to communicate by signals.* adj striking, notable.” My Sister, Carla - “An act or sign, or action that gets people’s attentions.” Wikipedia - “Signal ([in] electrical engineering) referred to in communication systems, signal processing, and electrical engineering "is a function that conveys information about the behavior or attributes of some phenomenon".” Encyclopedia Britannica - **[specifically fog signal] “fog signal sound or light signal emitted in fog or mist by lighthouses and buoys to indicate a shoreline, channel, or dangerous stretch of water and by vessels to indicate their position.”

Hierarchy
Encyclopedia Britannica: "A term commonly used in ecclesiastical language to denote the aggregate of those persons who exercise authority within the Christian Church"
Dictionary "A ruling body of clergy organized into ranks"
My sister "A form of ranking who is in charge and has more power"
Google "a system or organization in which people or groups are ranked one above the other according to status or authority."

Word: Ecology
Wikipedia - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecology
The scientific analysis and study of interactions among organisms and their environment, such as the interactions organisms have with each other and with their abiotic environment.
Dictionary – Oxford Canadian Dictionary of Current English (2005)
The branch of biology dealing with the relations of organisms to one another and to their physical surroundings
Encyclopedia – Encyclopedia of Environmental Biology (Academic Press) Volume I
The study of organisms of a particular habitat, such as a pond or forest, together with the physical environment in which they live.
Human – former classmate from biology course
The study of organisms with ecosystems interacting with one another.

Wikipedia A utopia (/juːˈtoʊpiə/ yoo-TOH-pee-ə) is a community or society possessing highly desirable or near perfect qualities. The word was coined by Sir Thomas More in Greek for his 1516 book Utopia (in Latin), describing a fictional island society in the Atlantic Ocean. The term has been used to describe both intentional communities that attempt to create an ideal society, and imagined societies portrayed in fiction. It has spawned other concepts, most prominently dystopia.
Webster's Revised Unabridged Dictionary (1913 + 1828) 1. An imaginary island, represented by Sir Thomas More, in a work called Utopia, as enjoying the greatest perfection in politics, laws, and the like. 2. Hence, any place or state of ideal perfection. ‘Ideal setting, basically a “perfect world” ‘–my friend
Stealing this from Brian Metzak, because I don’t have access to an encyclopedia right now. Encyclopedic Dictionary of English Usage (Prentice Hall, 2nd edition,1993): (from Greek./ “no place;” title of 1516 book by Thomas More. Perfect society I’m gonna give my definition because I feel my own contribution would be: A sandy hill with wind flowing with a couple of hay balls rolling—a world that does not have any people. I feel utopia cannot exist because people have too many DIFFERENT definitions of a “perfect world” which causes conflict with one’s ideal utopia with another, which is why I think we cannot create a “perfect world” with us altogether.
Anyways, I’d assume the takeaways are: we see things in different views, as it is the reason behind why we see or do things for what they are. Like how someone sees communism as the more efficient system in the world, drugs to someone can be a taboo compared to a regular drug user, or even why Toby is so narcissistic in finding interesting stories for his stream.
Damn, your friend just gave an example, not a definition. But i guess it goes to show that some people don't know the actually definition of something, but rather, give an example. Interesting, huh?

Hey, i used your definition from your encyclopedia, but i want to comment on your friend's definition of an utopia. I agree it can be “An ideal living arrangement, where everyone is happy”, but how long would the happiness last? My one friend is very happy about where he is right now. He's going to school, getting good grades, drinking beer here and there, and eating a lot. He said he's 'happy where [he] is right now. But how long would his happiness last? Who knows? Only time will tell, just like how we had happiness at least one time in our lives.

item.title: Differences Module
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Instructions: Due for the March 4th class. This module is about defining things so that you can come up with thematic approaches to texts. It's pretty straightforward: think about differences and expectations.

Summary: Task: Write a list in the comment area below of the five (5) most significant differences between you and your parents' generation. YOU CANNOT REPEAT SOMETHING SOMEONE IN THE CLASS HAS ALREADY WRITTEN IN THE COMMENT SPACE. YOU MUST COME UP WITH AN ORIGINAL LIST; NO REPEATS.

Outcomes:

  • Think about the question in a variety of ways, not just technological--how do you eat, or cook, differently for instance?
  • Try not to limit things to differences that suggest positives or negatives--think about things that are just different. Where there isn't necessarily a value judgement associated with the difference.
  • Try to think about different contexts -- social differences, cultural differences, economic differences.
  • Frame things around attitudes not just visual cues. Sure, cars look sleeker, but are they uglier as a result? What is the difference between your parent's attitude toward government and your attitude?

Takeaways:

  • Your perspective informs how you notice differences.
  • Your expectations are often governed by how you want to be different than what's come before.
  • We often understand things by interpreting how we are different from those things.
  • We must always interpret the meaning behind what we see as different. Difference isn't an obvious condition.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
One of my best friends actually just joined the military and it was so out of the blue. I didn't think that anyone would to be honest, as it's not something our generation is jumping out of their seats to do.
But we keep in contact every so often and it's amazing to see how much he's grown.
I can't imagine being pressured into joining it, but I don't think it's something our generation needs to be afraid of either. I have now 3 friends who have joined the military in the past 2 years.

1) Dating: My parents have a different perspective when it comes to dating. Because they grew up in a strict background (Asian culture), dating was not allowed until eighteen/when they move out. They focus on finding the true love and getting married right after. On the other hand, my generation focused on dating like getting to know the person, getting involved with relationships and less thoughts about marriage. 2) Money and being cheap: At my parent’s time while growing up, I remember them telling me that they only get paid around four dollars an hour and I think that is why they are more careful about how much they spent. Also, my parents grew up poor (lack of food because Vietnamese War) so they were taught to save as much as they could. Contrary, I was more privilege than them so I did not have to worry about saving because even I did not earn as much, I still make enough to feed myself. 3) Being more greedier: I agree on nicolefrketich because I’ve noticed that me and my siblings are more greedier than my parents. We want new toys, iPads (because everyone has one, so we want it to “fit” in) and more competitive (like at school or getting into a program). Before that, when my parents are young, they are happy with what they got, which is a few toys because that is all they can afford. I guess as we are more privilege than the previous generation, we “want” more stuff. 4) Young people are more impatient: I’ve noticed that when it comes to waiting in line, I am more aggressive than my parents. I think that technology encourage us to be more speedy because technology is fast, you see results instantly and technology is always improving (more quicker now). My parents could wait the load screen on Wi-Fi but I’ve “struggled” a bit while waiting for the screen to load. 5) Parents had to be independent at a young age: My parents had to work ten times harder than we did because they came from a poor country. Not only that, they have to be more independent by moving out from their parents sooner, getting their own car, buying their own house, learning handyman skills or cooking skills. In contrast, I am almost 20 and I still live with my parents (rent is ridiculous), still going to school and having my mom (still) cook for me and borrow their car. I guess that in our generation, we have an extended adolescent life because we go to school longer, marry later and longer lifespan.

Hey Jonathan!
I really enjoyed reading your comments on the differences in generations. My family is Ukrainian and my it's more so my dads side of the family who still carries on some of the traditions. My dad and his siblings always used to do Ukrainian dances in clubs, and go to church and so on, and it never got passed down to our generations (my, my siblings, and cousins).
I agree with you and it goes for any type of culture, back then they were always dressed more conservatively but these days it's all about booty shorts and crop tops.
When you mention the difference between health the aspects of your parents generation and ours is really interesting. I don't know what it is with out generation wanting to be skinny or perfectly sculpted with muscles.. anyways, I find it pretty cool that when you did go to Hong Kong you didn't see any. Im jealous, I feel like we live in a generation where we are so concerned with how we look.
It was refreshing to realize that although we come from different cultures and places, that the differences in generation are similar.

1) Getting married and starting a family aren’t major goals in our twenties now due to an increased focus on our post-secondary education and career paths compared to our parents’ generation. 2) There’s more acceptance of individuals who are not heterosexual and individuals who belong to different ethic races now compared to our parents’ generation. 3) There’s an increased amount of focus on terrorism and terrorist attacks in the media coverage now compared to the media coverage during our parents’ generation. 4) Technology’s presence in everyday society in the forms of cell phones, iPads, GPS in cars etc. is much higher now than it was during our parents’ generation. 5) Online shopping is another occurrence that is more prominent now than it was during my parents’ generation when stores would be the only place to buy clothes, food, gifts etc. whereas now we have Amazon, eBay and a various of other websites for different clothing labels.

Being as my parents grew up in Hungary, there are many cultural differences. First thing I thought of was, food. My mom always makes traditional home cooked meals, all from scratch and never using recipes. Now many of us frequently eat out, make meals that are less time consuming, less traditional. Another, is technology of course. Cell phones, ipads, internet was never a thing. Face to face meetings were important, whereas now we are all glued to our social media outlets, communicating through a screen rather than in person. For my parents generation, women having children at 17-18 years old was a social norm. My generation views 18 as being too young, we are expected to finish college and begin to make a living before caring for children. In Hungary, schooling was much different. They didn't have high schools or universities, schooling for them ended at the grade 8 level. Not only is it different here, but now in Hungary they have more schooling available to pursue careers. And lastly, their taste/style in music is very different. Mainly because they enjoy Hungarian artists, to which I wouldn't be able to put into words what kind of style that is. However, the content of what they listen to is different. While the popular artists and music of my generation is heavily dependent on sex, drugs, violence, their interests were very romanticized and had more of a mellow tone to things. Knowing that there is a vast majority of differences between the generations, it was rather difficult to think of them so hopefully I didn't totally butcher the task.

Amongst Western culture, there are so many differences in our generation and the generation of our parent’s (depends on culture, race, location, etc.):
I’ve noticed, especially with my parent’s views in particular, that our generation can be much more open-minded about appearance. For example, my parents frown upon differences and changes that people make on their bodies. Not that they dislike those with tattoos and piercings, but they definitely judge them and assume about them much more than our generation, even if it’s unconsciously. This, in my opinion, it because it was extremely rare for people to have tattoos and piercing’s when they were growing up, so it’s kind of a surprise today. My brothers and I, as oppose to this, couldn’t care less about the choices that other’s make about their body. Whatever makes you happy is what you should do. I actually envy those who have the courage to completely go “against” the generation that raised us and wear whatever they feel suits them. It’s an act of uniqueness. We have also grown up seeing many people with physical changes on their bodies, so it’s much easier to adapt to the changes and go along with it, unlike our parents.
Another extreme change is today’s socially acceptable ways to act and appear. Back when my parents were kids, they had to dress very formally and speak to their parents in quite serious manners. My mom, for instance, wasn’t allowed to wear pants in her public school. Instead, all young women wore skirts. I think that the attitudes and ways that we’ve been raised have been much more casual and laid back.
I’ve noticed that for our generation, our idea of the “American Dream” is completely different from the ones that our parents had or have. The ideal lifestyle of my parents and their generation has always been the marriage, kids, and 9-5 career. Now, however, our generation seems to be swaying away from that traditional idea and becoming much more casual. Couples in our generation live together and don’t get married or show any interest in having kids. This situation would have been a rarity in my parents’ generation. There had always been the stay at home mom, taking care of the children and the father as the breadwinner. This lifestyle has completely altered, showing that both people in a relationship must work in order to keep up with the economy.
In addition, our generation has shown a great acceptance of different cultures, sexual orientations, and disabilities. My parents were not as exposed to people from different countries around the world, people of different sexual orientations, and those with disabilities. My brothers and I grew up with tons of people who were of different nationalities or homosexual. On the other hand, my parents went to school with all Caucasians and no openly gay students or students with disabilities. I’m not trying to say that they are intolerant of completely judgemental of people with these aspects, but they are definitely not as open and completely comfortable with them as our generation is.
Concern for the environment is also a great difference in generations. The conclusion that Global Warming is occurring has introduced countless “green” organizations and the encouragement to recycle and conserve our resources. This was never an issue for my parents’ generation because they had no idea of it. We, however, have been taught of the problems that the world will face if we don’t take action for the environment. This has completely altered our outlook on the environment in comparison to that of our parents. Instead of the planet being simply something to use, it’s now a resource that we have to respect, protect, and maintain.

When it comes to spending, my parents are way more thrifty than I am. I've noticed that their attitudes towards buying products is that if it's not a necessity, it's not worth buying. I assume that because my parents lived in a place where there weren't a lot of job opportunities, they learned be more thrifty.
Even though my parents are caught up with technological forms of communication, ie: cellphones and facebook to be precise, their communication style still adheres to their generational way of communicating. I don't see my parents sending messages containing "LOL" or "OMG" and any abbreviated words. Also, they tend to be more optimistic and positive with their posts and messages. Often times, they use social media to communicate to friends and family members but not to rant or express anger like my generation does.
With the technological breakthrough in this day and age, the form of entertainment/hobby between my parents and I differ widely. In today's time, the main modes of entertainment comprises of video games, movies, social media, and other electronic gadgets. My parent's main entertainments were climbing trees, hanging out with friends physically (not virtually), playing board games, playing cards, etc.
One thing that really amazes me about my parents is that they married at a young age, and begat children at a relatively young age too. In comparison to my generation, their priority was finding a wife/husband and start a family without delay. I've noticed too that in my parent's generation, more people got married back then whereas now, the becoming trend is simply "living" together under cohabitation law. But this may not be true for everyone, but culturally speaking, a generation ago, having a kid outside the bonds of marriage was frowned upon, but now, it has become more culturally acceptable.
Another thing that has surprised my parents is the way kids interact with older adults in my generation. I remember my mother telling me years ago about her childhood that growing up, joining a conversation with older people was culturally unacceptable. She said that when kids join a conversation between adults was a considered disrespectful. As a punishment, they were spanked or pinched. But now, this once was culturally acceptable behaviour has somehow become acceptable.

1. Motivation: My parents are certainly more motivated than I am. I find them up early on weekends, they work hard at work even if they don’t enjoy it sometimes, and they see most things as challenges rather than burdens. I, on the other hand, can barely roll out of bed after sleeping in for an hour, I slack off at work when I’m not enjoying it, and I see lots of things as another box to check off on my ‘to do’ list.
2. Money: My parents work to save. Whether its for retirement or for next week’s groceries, they are constantly thinking ahead and saving for the future. As of right now, I work to spend my money. We both spend on food, just I like to spend it on lunch at school or dinner with friends.
3. Patience: Compared to me, my parents are extremely patient. They are willing to wait in lines without checking their phones or cooking complicated dishes for the perfect flavours instead of opting for instant noodles. They don't find the need to be distracted when doing chores that I consider boring and time consuming.
4. Values: Growing up and even now, my parents valued being successful. They went to university hoping to become working professionals who own their home in suburbia. These days, I value my individuality and creativity most. I hope the freedom of being unique is prominent in my future too.
5. Appearance: My parents never felt this weird social pressure to look picture perfect all the time. I think they had a happier childhood, in a way, because they didn’t constantly worry about how good they looked or what others thought of them because of how thin they were. I think this wave of commercial marketing and media has a lot to do with setting a social standard of how everyone should look and behave.

My parents are constantly debating and talking about how different their school education was from my brother’s education and mine. In high school and middle school, there were several videos shown in my classes whereas when my parents went to school they did not watch videos in class. The level of information their teachers had shared about them was also different. This is in the way that teachers will tell students about their personal lives whereas when my parents went to school the information they knew about their teachers went as far as their last name.
Wearing pajamas outside or to work was not seen as appropriate when my parents were younger. Today it seems to be acceptable for people to wear their pajamas out to the stores, work, classes, and just going out for a walk. This is also a reflection of the how the perspectives of articles of clothing have changed.
Freedom is a large aspect of how my parents see the difference between my generation and theirs. The freedom to do what they wanted when they were younger is different from how it is today. The freedom to be a child and run out on the street to play hockey is one large difference that can be seen between the two generations. The freedom from technology was more prevalent when they were younger. They were not constantly addicted with the need to check a technological device every minute.
The acceptance of different sexualities such as the gay, lesbian, bisexual, transsexual, asexual, and intersexual community was not accepted when they were growing up. Due to the perspective they were brought up with regarding sexuality, they themselves find it hard to view these communities as appropriate or as having the same terms used to describe their relationship status. My mom in particular does not think that the word marriage should be used for anyone in these communities who wish to legally
The level of access to television entertainment is a large difference that my parents constantly talk about. The repetition of television shows was never around when they were younger. They talk about how the Ed Sullivan show would actually close down or stop city activities

My mother grew up on a farm, and I was raised in a city so there are quite big differences that way. I never had to do the sheer amount of extra chores and work she needed to. She also went to school 7 days a week because her parents brought her to a German language school on Saturdays and she went to Sunday School as well.
In social media, a lot of people I know in my parents generation won't message you to ask how you're doing. They'll post a comment on something random that you shared to ask about you and then try to carry on a public conversation about it.
My parents went to school for a career and stuck with that career for decades, not switching jobs too often and usually not switching types of work. Whereas today it feels a lot more fluid and people can change careers quite easily without too much backlash.
One thing specifically that my parents did differently than I am and a lot of other families is that my dad didn't really work after he left university. My mother worked to support the whole family by herself. My husband and I are both working and trying to find a way for us both to do what we want instead of leaving the other in a place they don't want to be.
My parents generation in my family also tend to get together for "tea" and they will drink tea and talk for hours in someone's kitchen. Pretty much all the time when I want to catch up with someone I know, it's online or we go out to a coffee shop.

One of the main differences between my generation and my mothers is independence. My mom was very close to her parents and relatives. They would help out financially and if she ever needed anything she knew she always had the families support. In comparison to myself, I am very independent when it comes to most things in my life. Financially, I never take my moms money to pay for anything. I earn my money to pay for what I want and need. Even when it comes to food, I usually make dinner myself if my mom is away at work or is unable to cook. Another big difference is the relationships between the different generations. My mom is very open towards me but she was not towards my grandmother. For example, I can openly talk about my personal relationships with my mom but she could not do it openly with my grandmother. My grandmother and grandfather would most likely bring up the word “marriage” if she ever talked about relationships. Personal interests are also a big difference. I don’t have much in common with my mom when it comes to tv shows or music we listen to. I am mostly interested in rap or hip hop while she likes her Indian music. When it comes to tv shows, I like action and violence but she tends to like watching tv shows about love or marriage. Another big difference is the way we spend money.
