My mom does not spend a lot of money on useless things. When it comes to my wallet, I like to spend money on food, liquor or whatever else satisfies me. In my view, I believe money comes and goes. My mom barely spends money outside of things such as groceries or stuff for the house. A very common difference is the way in which we interact with people. My mom would talk in our native language Hindi and I would just talk in English. She is very traditional in how she interacts with people. For example, if I had guests over at my house my mom would make tea and serve food. I would probably open up a beer if a male guest was present. That’s it. Knowing that there is a big difference just shows that the younger generation in my culture is much more modernized than the previous generation.

Differences between generations.
1. Rebellious: I find that it’s quite obvious that our generation compared to my parents is that we are way more rebellious. Some of the things I’ve done and the things my brother and sister have done, my parents often say that they wouldn’t ever think of doing the things we do. I feel like this generation has much more of a chip on their shoulders which makes it difficult to respect others and follow authority. Not saying that it’s always a bad thing but I do think that when rules are broken we tend to not care as much.
2. We are greedier: I find myself that we are way greedier. We want the best type of technology that’s out, or the best shoes, car, clothes, whatever it may be, we are always trying to “one-up” another. Whereas, in my parents generation they would ware the same type of boots (my dad loved his cowboy boots and would wear them until the soles were worn out) or jeans until they had holes in them. They never had to go out once a week to buy something new or have 20 pairs of shoes. The way my parents have talked about the way they grew up makes me kind of jealous. They just lived life, and enjoyed what they had and were given.
3. Trust: These days, again, with technology we can send a quick text and make simple plans and we meet family and friends at a specific time, although most of the time (at least for me most of my friends are never on time). In previous generations when they wanted to make plans whether it was to hangout, or have business meetings they picked a time and they had to trust that they would be there on time.
4. They experienced what real “dating and flirting” was: Because of technology we are just people hiding behind our phones (well a lot of us). It’s so easy to be “catfished” in our generation now. Everything they did in regards to dating and flirting was done in person, never through technology behind a screen and a keyboard. We just expect things to work out or be the same as face-to-face interaction.
5. The way we think: Hearing stories from my parents and grandparents just fascinates me. The way they thought back then was nothing compared to the way we think now. The way life was lived back then was so easy, sure there was stress here and there but my parents just kind of took things day by day, they didn’t think about the world. Our generation now seems to be thinking about money and we need to make this amount to pay for this and that, as if we are just working to live a luxurious lifestyle. Our generation is thinking about the future too much instead of enjoying the simple things and being happy with a simple life. At the same time, I think that those are just our harsh expectations in our generation.

Coming from a traditional Chinese family and living in North America right now, there is a big contrast on how my family views things, and how I view things. One obvious example would be the difference in language, as my parents grew up speaking Chinese their whole lives and I grew up speaking English due to the fact that most of friends only spoke English.
Besides the language difference, there is also the way how we present ourselves to others. I don't know if this applies to all Chinese cultures, but my parents are quiet and withdrawn, only saying "Hi" quietly when they had to. But for me, I like to talk to others and not always be very quiet. As well, my jobs requires me to be outgoing and friendly, not quiet and shy.
Another contrast would be in terms of clothing style choices'. Back when my parents were growing up, I saw old pictures of them always dressed very conservatively and "safe." Their parents dressed the same too. Very conservative and colours that matched their genders, for example: pink for girls and blue for boys. But now, clothing styles are more "crazy and wild," boys gelling their hairs into crazy spikes, and girls dressing like boys, or showing more skin in the summertime.
One really big difference between my parent's generation and mine is the health aspect. Almost on every corner of the street, there is a gym, a gym exclusively for men or women, and almost all my friends, male and female, all have a gym membership. The health craze is very popular right now. But, back when my parents were growing up in Hong Kong, working out is not popular at all, and eating healthy wasn't too big of a trend either. My mom took me to Hong Kong to visit her parents there in 2011, and I can't even recall seeing a gym there too.
The most major difference between my parent's generation and my generation is how we view life should be lived though. When my parents were growing up, it was viewed as school is the most important thing to their lives. School came above all else. Now I know some people may see this as an asian stereotype, but it is true in a sense, just may not be exaggerated as much as some others may have put it. But in my generation, while school is still really important, some people may see other things as a priority over an education, like having a family, religious practices, and pursuing their own dreams which may not reflect on having the best education. I find that living in my generation in North America is much more "free-spirited" in a way.

Lifestyle: I find that in my parents generation the lifestyle was more simple, go to school, find a job, get married young, and then have kids. In our generation I feel that we don't follow what that certain way of life. My generation seems to be more open and free. People aren't always marrying young and people are travelling more and “finding” themselves. Our generation is more open and social media is a big part of that. Our generation uses social media like Facebook and Instagram which allows people to see into each others lives while my parents generation was more private.
Learning: The way my generation learns and how my parent’s generation learns differs in that our generation has more accessible resources. We have technology to lean on as my parents did not. When I need to figure out how to fix something I just google or youtube it but when my parents needed to fix something they had to be patient and be hands on to figure out how to fix things themselves.
Communication: The way my generation communicates is through technology and social media. I find my self on my phone and texting more than actually talking. Also social media like Facebook, snapchat, Instagram, are used more to communicate with people. I also find that when I meet someone I typically ask for their social media instead of their phone number as to my parent’s generation, when they wanted to talk to someone they would pick up the phone and call them, or meet them in person for a coffee or lunch. They would also write letters to their friends if they were from out of town.
Ethics: My generation seems more entitled as my parents worked hard and earned whats theirs. We expect things to be done for us like having dinner prepared, doing laundry and even paying for things. When something new comes out we need to have it right away while my parents were not as materialistic.
Awareness: Compared to my parent’s generation I find that my generation is more environmentally friendly and aware. When I go to the mall I see separate trash cans for different materials. Items that you buy now are mostly “eco friendly” and made with less materials.

I think I’m similar to my parents. I even look like my dad when he was 18…haha.
1. We spend our time differently. My parents spend most of their free time watching T.V. They’re even getting bored of Netflix. How does that happen? My friend’s mom watches a lot of T.V. to kill time. I guess it’s because she’s a housewife and can’t find much to do. I think they’re not creative with their time as they once were my age. I spend my time playing videogames, going to school, and socializing with people. 2. Drinking and… My parents seem to drink alcohol 3-4 times a week. It seems like they do it because it’s a habit and they built a dependence on it, or they are just bored. I see it a lot when my parent’s friends come over to drink a lot. They do it bi-weekly. I do it when a group of friends and I arrange a day to drink. 3. Physical activity I like physical activity, and I have experienced a lot of weight gain/loss in the past year and a half (140lb-200lb-170lb-190lb-180lb). My friend’s and I enjoy doing sports such as: baseball, swimming, and soccer. However, my parents are out of shape, and unmotivated to do any physical activity. My mom takes the car to a grocery store that’s 5 blocks away. It pisses me off when she says “take the car”, when I need something from the store. It’s only a 5-minute walk. I also find that parents do not have the best physical appearance. Maybe it’s because they aren’t forced to do physical activities like how we were in high school. Nonetheless, I find some people are starting to ‘fall off edge’ such as myself in a couple of years? ☺ 4. Doing stupid shit My friend’s and I enjoy doing stuff out of the norm. A couple of us at midnight called each other up to go biking to downtown and back. We live close to each other, so from the bottom of royal st. to downtown was our goal. There and back. Guess what? We did that. The whole trip was 4 hours and 30km. A couple of ourselves almost experienced death twice: One on Granville st. bridge and 1 while being paralyzed with cramps in the middle of the road. My parents on the other hand never do anything ‘stupid’. Maybe because they experienced it when they were our age, and got bored of it? 5. Rituals Damn, I hate these. I have to say grace during a thanksgiving dinner. I have to celebrate Christmas. I have to celebrate birthdays. I just want to do my own thing. My one friend was texting my friends and I during his family dinner, saying he would drive his car at 80km/h to see us. He really wanted to get out. My parents, and other parents care about ritual. I suspect it’s a tradition that would ‘bond’ us together and prevent us from distancing.

My friend broke up with her ex. because her parents referred her ex. as 'an it'. She broke up with him because she didn't want conflict with him and her parents. Her and her parents are Chinese, and her ex. was Filipino. I feel our generation is looking at things in a different way. The way my friend wanted to date a Filipino guy and found it socially acceptable, but vice versa for her parents. We are being more fond of accepting one for who they are, rather than rejection and accepting prejudice.

About the acceptance of different sexualities. My parents said that they we're willing to accept me if I'm gay. It surprised me. I'm of Mongolian and German descent, and they were willing to accept me if I was gay. My other friend said he would be accepted if he was gay, but other friends said they would be rejected if they were gay. I'm just sayin' that not all of their generation were brought up to view non-straight people a taboo.

One difference between my generation and my parents’ generation is fashion. Looking through my parents yearbooks, I didn’t notice too many differences in the clothes they were wearing. Most of them were simple shirts, usually plain, striped or plaid, and I would rarely see any graphic designs. Nowadays, we notice more differences in fashion as there are way more different brands of clothing available with more unique designs. Also, my parents do not understand why some guys sag their pants, because that was never done back when they were in school.
When my parents were younger, marijuana was not as popular as it is today. It was seen as dangerous, and the people who smoked it were seen as “losers” and not part of the “cool” crowd. Nowadays, most people know others, or have friends who partake in smoking marijuana, and it is seen as more of a popular activity, that many now believe to be less harmful than drinking alcohol or smoking cigarettes.
Driving then and driving now are two different processes. At my age, my parents just had to write a test to get their first drivers license, and then after 2 weeks, they could get their full license. Now we have a much stricter program implemented to increase safe driving that involves getting a learner license for a year and then a novice license for 2 years before we can get a full license. Also, with sky trains and buses widely available, we have a wider variety of options to transport ourselves to where we need to go.
When my dad was in school, he witnessed a teacher throw a chair at a classmate who was whispering to his friend during a lecture, If this was ever done in 2015, that teacher would definitely be fired and would likely be sued by the student or student’s family. Teachers also could smack student’s hands with their rulers, which is thankfully unheard of now.
One last difference is that when my parents graduated from high school, it was expected that they take out student loans and move out from home as there was not a wide variety of post secondary institutions nearby to choose from. Currently, there are more post secondary institutions available with more choices of areas of study so that it is easier to live at home and save money while still attending a school that is not too far away.

1) Millitary. My dad served in the millitary, and so did his dad before him, and his grandpa. I think the political climate plays a large role in this, as my dad joined the marines during the cold-war era (where russia was seen as a very real threat to the US, and vice versa).
2) War. My mom lived through the iran-iraq war,whereas now (in Canada) our generation doesn't have to worry about bombs being dropped on us. Her friends all can relate to the hardships of the conflict, whereas I can't, and I know none of my friends can relate to the realities of war. Also, my generation does not have to worry about the economic effects war can have ( mass unemployment, lack of resources, etc).
3) Both my parents were raised in religious families. However, they did not raise me in any way to be religious. It is more common for our generation to openly discuss things such as atheism, agnosticism and spirituality than it was in the past. My parents were raised that the only way to find any sort of faith was through the Church - Organised religion. I have a few friends that go to church - but the majority don't (But that is probably because I don't go to church myself, so I meet less people that go to church).
4) children. my mom and my dad became married really early (at 18) and, and were already parents by the time they were 20. I am 20 right now, and the idea of me having a kid is just nonsense to me. My generation has differing views on marriage/children than my parents. My parents wanted children early on, it was a priority in their life, whereas in my generation no one that I know even talks about wanting kids at my age.
5) being connected. My parents generation had to meet someone up to find out what was new in their life. Nowadays, we can just text each other and not have to wait until the next time we see each other to tell a funny story or just to have a conversation. My parents had telephones in their house, but it was the family telephone and they didn't really have long conversations with friends on it, other than to make plans. Now that we have cell phones with data (internet) access, we can always stay in touch with work/friends/etc. Our generation uses social media and technology to the point where we really aren't totally 'isolated' from our friends when we don't see them, same with other family members. My parents generation never had this luxury, and other than writing letters/telephone calls in the living room, the only other way to catch up with someone or see how they were doing was the pretty much go see them.

Spoiled: Back in my parent’s generation, everyone had to work hard for a living and it was not common to have a lot of money in a family. This resulted in the children having to grow up fast and work hard to help out. Parents don’t want their children to have to go through the same thing so a lot of parents spoil their children. When children are given everything they want, they don’t learn to value what they have or to work hard. This can lead to 30 year olds still living in their parent’s basement. This happens because they were never taught how to grow up so they never did. Back in my parents generation it was not common at all to just stay at home until “you figure out your life.” Instead, you had to grow up, get married, and move out.
Self entitled: Our generation is constantly being told that “you are special” and that there is no normal so you should be whoever you want to be. As good as this might be for self-esteem, it also makes people very selfish. People are seeing themselves as more important than everyone else instead of just the same as everyone else. This results in people being rude to others that aren’t as high of class and having no respect for anyone else. Back in my parent’s generation, most people had the same office job, the same car, and the same size house. This similarity brought people together.
Access to knowledge: In our generation, it seems that we are at a place with technology that allows us to have complete knowledge. This actually causes the opposite of that. Instead, people have less knowledge than ever before because there is no need to store it in our brains. Cellphone have totally changed the game of accessing knowledge because now people always need answers. Years ago before cellphones, kids would hang out and ponder things like “I wonder who sang that song on the radio” and they would just leave it at that. There was no way for them to find the information and they were okay with that. At the same time, if the answer came to them it was a lot more satisfactory. Today, we aren’t okay with not having an answer. There is certain impatience in play.
Attention span: On that note, our generation has a very shorter attention span than that of our parent’s generation. Our parents had to withstand the terrible act of waiting in lines, watching commercials, waiting for buses, and actually accepting awkward social situations instead of resorting to their phones. Now, people can’t handle waiting for commercials because they are so used to skipping through them. A dead cell phone is a tragedy to people because they have to actually entertain themselves while waiting at the bus stop. We always need to be stimulating our brains instead of enjoying silence. It’s an interesting transition how technology had greatly advanced our society but also has harmed it.
Communication: The way that we communicate with each other has drastically changed to become very informal. It doesn’t seem that the respect for elders has gone down but that the approval of more casual conversations has increased. Communication with anyone above us has come to shooting a text out instead of making a formal phone call or calling a meeting. In my parents generation the way people talked to other of authority was very professional and very polite.

There are certainly several differences between my up bringing and my parents up bringing. Two of the main differences that comes to mind is education and relating to that is our growing economy. There are currently countless opportunities in terms of career choices and how students are educated. Research has been conducted over the past decade and it has been found that not everyone learns the same. Therefore, the historical lecture method (the way our parents were taught) is not always the most effective since there are auditory learners, visual learners and people who learn better by completing hands on activities. Technology assists with this by introducing new, innovative programs for people of all ages including iPad apps, Youtube tutorials/lectures, and the new Smart Board which is now used in most classrooms, especially at the primary level.
As our economy continues to expand, there is a high demand for trades people as huge projects such as the Evergreen Line and the Trans Canada Pipeline are constructed. These massive projects guarantee long term employment for those who prefer to work in a hands on environment. Another aspect on education and employment has to do with the amount of education required to attain a well paid career. Back when our parents were young, education after high school was not always a high priority. For example, my dad, who is now a Senior Project Manager for Vancouver Shipyards, does not have a degree. He simply went to BCIT in the eighties to become a welder and has slowly advanced his way up the company. Today this situation would not be as likely especially if he wanted to jump right in and become a project manager before he became a welder.
Our generation has it good compared to our parents generation, almost too good. Many of us rely on our parents too much. When my parents were in grade 10 it was expected that they both get a part time job but nowadays there are several young people I know who do not have a job even though they have been out of high school for almost a year. Parents these days can be known as helicopter parents which does not strengthen a child's independence. I have some friends who ask there parents to come with them when applying for a job. It has become a little excessive and this is also why my generation chooses to live at home after high school.
Another big difference between my generation and my parents is discipline. At school and at home it usually involved some sort of physical aspect. Whether that was throwing chalk or spanking these methods are typically not used in the twenty first century. In fact, if a mother is seen hitting her child in a public place it is very likely the police will be called.

1. Marriage: There is a wide range of differences that have occurred between my parents' generation and my generation among marriage traditions. My parents had arranged marriage that was very common and the norm in my country at that time. In my generation, this kind marriages have declined, and love marriage is most common. Back then, couples married at very young age and maintained healthy marriages throughout their lives. My parents were very young when they married; my mother was 19 years old, and my father was 23 years old and they have been married now for more than 35 years. Comparing to my generation couples are not marrying as young but the divorce rate is higher than ever. Old generation had more commitments toward marriage. They work their problem out and defiantly more responsible. 2. Family stretcher: My parent's generation had a extended family structure; they are more likely be living with another family members such as parents or saplings and family headed by grandfather. After my parents marriage, they lived for three years in my grandfather house (the family house). My father and his older brother had to support their Dad and younger sapling financially and most important socially. In my generation nuclear family stretcher takes place: family may contain grandparents and headed by children’s father.In my generation, there are weak social and emotional links between family members; less social family gathering, less emotional and social support. 3. Follow the laws of society; Old generation is more inclined to follow rules and live the way society has shaped them. My generation has difficulty to respect the authority; hard to follow parents' instructions, hard to accept government guidelines. My parent's generation perceptions are shaped by growing up having to take care of themselves early and watching their politicians lie. My generation grows up sheltered and has protective parents and less ability to survival with limited recourses. 4. Pay Attention and stress tolerate: my parent’s generation has great attention abilities than my generation. Paying attention isn’t a problem because they used to take time to complete their work and get the work done; although, they had harder live circumstances. My generation can’t complete work without Adderal and stimulant drugs. Consuming Alcohol and smoking marijuana to get rid of stress, swallow cocaine and smoking crack in parties for fun!. My parents know and remember history events more than me. For example, my father( 36 years old ) knows and remembers history events like world War 1 and 2 and my country history more than me: I always need to go back to reference. 5. Social Freedom: my generation has more personal and social freedoms than my parents' generation. But are there limits to our freedom expressions ?. We are free to dress whatever we want, but is it part of our freedom to walk naked in streets or to have “no pants sky train ride “ or free nipples events? My parents' generation was worried more about country freedom more than pants freedom as they lived through my country war. Also, they believe that the freedom carry a message for next generation. What if the next generation girls decide to go schools with free nipples? .

1. Conservatism My parent’s generation is far more conservative with their way of life compared to my generation. This is mostly because they grew up in a different environment where dressing or acting a certain way was frowned upon in the society. For example my mother finds things such as getting too many tattoos or piercing inappropriate.
2. Entertainment More specifically my parent’s form of receiving entertainment is far different than it is for my generation. In my parent’s youth they had to go to the theatre to watch a movie compared to our generation where we had the option of DVDs when we were younger for movies and now we have it available online through Netflix. My parent’s generation was not able to watch movies wherever or whenever they pleased, it had to be specifically planned ahead of time.
3. Cartoons This is more specific to my mom’s generation and environment. When she was younger she did not have access to many forms of cartoon or television shows. She told me that they would only come on at a specific time everyday and only for a short amount of time since she only had 2-3 shows to watch on TV. My generation had access to multiple different cartoon shows and they were also longer compared to her shows.
4. Compromise My parents generation was more understanding towards there parents wishes and were willing to compromise things for they’re parents. An example of this may be if a distant relative was visiting my parents had to compromise they’re time to visit that relative. They had to attend all family functions with their parents. However, my generation is given the choice of wanting to attend an event or not. This may be because we are more distant with our relative compared to our parents, or our parents really disliked going to these events themselves and therefore they do not force us.
5. Food My parent’s generation did not have a lot of options for the food they wished to eat. Due to us living in a multicultural country and close to a city my generation has a lot of options for the type of food we wish to eat. My parents had to eat traditional food growing up, so something like noodles was eaten on special occasions.

Health and Fitness: Today health and fitness is largely promoted in school compared to when my parents attended school. In BC you’re required to take P.E up till grade 10 then it becomes optional up to grade 12. The knowledge I retain in health and fitness is different compared to my parents. My mom thought if I continued to work out I would get cancer. Speaking of cancer, my parents believe almost anything will give you cancer.
Family Size: Both of my parents came from a family of 8 plus where as I’m an only child. My cousins are also an only child or have 1 sibling. According to google the average size of the family has decreased. I believe this because times have changed, my grandparents had big families to help work on the farm.
Objective in life: My objective in life is completely different from my parents. My parent’s objective was to move to Canada and start a new life. They wanted to find a job and support their family back in the Philippines. My objective on the other hand is to make something of my life. Instead of just working to make money, I want to love my job.
Connectivity: Anytime of the day we have access to unlimited sources. We can quickly find a fact in a matter of seconds or text someone across the world, where as in my parents didn’t have the sources to do what we can do today. I remember my dad having those block like phones and man were they huge. We get smaller phones that can out match those phones easily. Although there is a gap, my parents are adapting to the technology. They both have laptops and tablets but the knowledge of the device is completely different from mine and theirs. I still help them with small things from here and there.
Video Games: At an early age I was introduced to N64, playstation and other gaming formats. Throughout the years gaming console had advance. I have a wii, ps3 and xbox 360 at home. My parents on the other hand had nothing like this. Our generation is heavy on the video games and is continuing to grow. I played a lot outside as a kid but today a lot of kids are glued to their tablets.

Well I should not have waited this long to do this task but I still have some differences that haven’t been listed yet. Some will sound pretty random but I have been thinking about this for a while so bear with me. The first thing I thought of was the dental system we have now versus what my parents grew up with. I am a huge whiner when it comes to going to the dentist because I always have a cavity here and there and I find the needles/freezing to be unpleasant. My parents always get frustrated with this because they never got any freezing or proper dental care. They always go into gory detail about what it’s like to get a tooth pulled out with no freezing and my grandparents do this as well. They remind me that the dentists in their time would use their body weight as force to extract their teeth and to be grateful that I have access to proper dental care today. Another is neighbourhood friendliness. My grandparents especially and my parents both like to make conversation with their neighbours. They find it really important to know who lives around you and stay connected with them or friendly at least. I can understand where they are coming from however I find this generation tends to stick their headphones in and keep their eyes down. I notice it all the time on my street, kids just find it awkward to say hi or wave anymore so that sense of neighbourhood community is disappearing- at least from what I have noticed. A third is eating meat. I haven’t been able to eat meat since I was a child. I connect with animals and am more educated about how they are slaughtered than my parents are. While they were growing up animals weren’t slaughtered nearly the same way. They still think that animals live on these nice farms and have pleasant times in their “free range” enclosures. They also don’t want to know the truth about what happens today- the transport of farm animals alone in Canada is an embarrassment. I find this a big difference because they chose to be ignorant of what happens to the animals because then it doesn’t bother them and they can continue to eat the way they do. I notice a lot of our generation has chosen to go vegetarian or vegan and not because “omg an animal has to die” but because of HOW they have to die. Skin exposure on television is another difference. When my parents were growing up they did not have women in super tiny outfits or underwear dancing around. This year while I was watching the Victoria secret fashion show for instance, my mom came downstairs and nearly had a heart attack. She finds it distasteful and that’s because while she was growing up it would’ve been considered “pornography” according to her. However we are so exposed to actors being half naked all the time it hardly phases us anymore and we wouldn’t consider a fashion show porn. The last thing I will add here Is that my parent’s generation tends to lean towards the idea that if a girl gets raped she somehow “asks for it”. Whatever the excuse they always put the blame on the girl and what she did to deserve it instead of the guy who thinks it’s okay because the girl was wearing a short skirt or drank too much alcohol. I notice in this generation that social media plays a large role in educating people our age about rape culture and changing the way we view rape. My parent’s generation especially in other cultures like India view women who are raped to have a lesser value and sometimes will not be considered for marriage. Thankfully with this generation and the awareness being raised on the issue there is a shift being made slowly. Some of the things listed here are controversial and I am generalizing when I say my parent’s generation etc. I know that’s not how everyone’s parents feel, but for the module I took the way the majority of them feel.

My grandpa and dad both served in the military as well. I understand how important joining the military was to them and like you said it had a lot to do with the political climate at the time. My dad was disappointed that none of my brothers shared the same value and never joined. I don't know about you but I was also pressured to consider joining and couldn't even imagine doing so.

Sports- Sports have changed tremendously since my parents generation. From rule changes, to instant replay, to better equipment many things have upgraded. There are now even several changes such as TSN and Sportsnet that are solely decimated to sports which never existed back in the day.
Groceries- the amount of new technological you can online has revolutionized so many areas in our day such as online grocery shopping. Back in the day there were only a few stores you could go to do get your groceries. Nowadays there are so many choices and you can actually now order everything you need and have it ordered to your door. Something my parents thought would never be even considered.
Milk Delivered- another thing that has changed is that my parents used to have a milkman come around delivering milk to neighbourhoods. There is still even a little milk door on my house that families long ago used to have their milk delivered. Now that no longer exists and people usually go to the stores themselves to get milk rather from a milkman.
Online Course- the education system has changed significantly since the days of my parents attending school. Now such as this course you can take courses online from your own computer. Having this convenience has revolutionized the education and opened many more opportunities to do schooling from the comfortability of their home.
Features of TV- when my parents watched TV there was a few channel choices but now we have hundreds and hundreds including high definition, places where you can watch movies and TV shows such as Shaw On Demand and Netflix, and you can even rewind and forward to skip those dreadful commercials. All these amazing features that my parents are so in love with because they didn't have this growing up.

Since I am later to post, ill list some very specific ones that I think are relevant.
Cyber bullying: I see this as a major problem today, one that is getting worse. Whereas in my parents generations, if someone was bullying you, you could beat the hell out of them and that was that. Today, people are ruthless and cowardly in the way they bully people online i.e posting pictures, making facebook groups to shame someone etc.. I see this as a major concern for the future.
Marital Temptation: By this I mean, temptation to cheat on your significant other. There is more temptation than ever before. To name one example of the greater temptation there are agencies, such as ashley madison.com, specifically made for married people to cheat on their spouse. Or when an ex girlfriend adds you on Facebook, nothing good can come out of that! I feel this is a huge contributor to why marriages are less likely to work out for the younger generation. Marriages today will almost always involve some degree infidelity on the part of one or both members.
Being handy: Ask someone of our parents generation to help with a project. Notice they are much more likely than a person in their 20's to be able to perform home maintenance tasks, such as basic drywall repair, or plumbing work. I notice it especially at work, where a lot of people my age are not nearly as handy as people of our parent's generations.
Nationalism: Today I believe there is a much weaker sense of national pride. This may have something to do with people who come to Canada to live a better life, but don't really want to give anything back. Also, relate this to people who would volunteer to fight in a major overseas military campaign,and today I think relatively few people would volunteer, compared to the huge percentage of canadians in the 1940's for example.
"Til death do us part":Someone has already mentioned marriage in a way but anyway this quote used to mean something. Today, people will marry but from the start they will keep finances to themselves etc. in the event that it doesnt work out. Many of our parents have been together 20-30 years or more but compare that to people our age who are getting divorced at a rate of 50 percent or more.

Knowledge of Food and Nutrition: This generation focuses heavily on eating right and getting enough exercise compared to the generation 30 years ago when healthy eating wasn't a "thing". Nowadays there are plenty of variety for everyone depending on their lifestyle choices to junk to healthy produce . For example, organic and natural food has blown up in the last 50 years because of new discoveries on GMO and the effects it has. A lot of awareness from where we get our food has been put in the spotlight, schools, media, and work etc. People of this generation fortunately have more knowledge so they can choose what is best suited for them and their lifestyle. Whereas majority of other people's parents mostly ate what were available and given to them.
Animal Rights: No one really cared about the welfare of animals in my parent's generation, there were no organizations to protect animals such as BCSPCA, PETA, and WWF etc. My parent's generation in China overhunted sharks for their fins (to make shark fin soup, a delicacy) and put them back in the water for them to die. The value of animals has been drawn to more people's attention. There are specific organizations and laws restricting the hunt for sharks now. Animals feel too!
Partying and Raves: Since the late 90's the rave scene and parties has been seen as dirty, grungy and full of drugs. "Rave Culture" is a big thing in North America and the rest of the world, with music festivals costing as much as $400. My parents saw raves and parties like it was for junkies, but now with proper event organizers and the attention is gets year around, they don’t see it as a threat to us young adults. Especially if we are educated and know how to stay safe. Work Load: In my parent's day, especially when they were young in their home country, they had no time to rest. It was work, work, work all the time, I would say my work ethic cant be compared to theirs. It was the fact that they had to hustle for my grandparents, money never came easy for them. It's was always nonstop work for them and I have the privilege to go to school and not worry.
Sexual Assault and Domestic Violence: The difference between this generation and my parents generation were the existence of outlets, understanding and platform against violence. Women were were looked down upon and if they told anyone it would put shame on their family. Feminists have coined the term "Rape Culture" to bring awareness because of the lack of awareness about how often it actually occurred. Even though rape is still considered a "taboo" to some, it is more talked about openly than before. The attitudes my parents had about walking out late at night when they were younger were definitely more careless than nowadays. They don't ever want me walking out late at night alone because I am a female and because of their idea of sexual assault and violence from the news. This was to show how perspectives had changed because of the platform and awareness over the years. I had no intention of bringing negative 'differences' but to only bring highlight to society's view of being a female and being able to safely roam the streets alone has changed.

Might I also add, men are victims of domestic violence too and there wasn't much of an understanding of the issue because of the shame it brought to the men. More reports have been made over the past generations as it is more talked about and the men were brave enough to come forward. Past generations haven't even shone light to the abuse from women but more and more social media outlets have shown the truth of abuse and how it can happen to anyone and anywhere.

Hi! You are most definitely right. The idea of religion has changed, back in the days you had to be a certain type of follower of some religion because your parents were raised a certain way. Now we have the freedom to choose our religion and practice what we want. I love how you touched base on that! It's so important to have your own beliefs. My aunt was raised Buddhist but converted to Christianity when she moved to Canada when she was introduced to it when she was at a low point in her life. She is a strong believer of God and practices the religion.

My parents are both Filipinos and lived away from the cities in the Philippines. During childhood, they lived in prairie like towns, accustomed to certain ways of upbringing and expectations. In their generation, leisure activities consisted of enjoying how nature presented itself. They would play out in the rice fields, ride on carabaos or water buffalos, and climb trees, hopping from one tree to the other, or fruit picking like guavas and wild fruits. Also, instead of them staying up late because of Netflix, or some online game, my parents in their youth played late night chess or answer riddles among friends outside their houses, they would have a lot of people watching, placing bets on whoever they think would win. This usually occurs when there is a full moon out. It would almost look like a feast since neighbors would go outside, both children and adults. They would sing songs with a guitar playing alongside them, children would play hide-and-seek in the dark, and other traditional Filipino games that youth right now in the Philippines do not play anymore. Another difference is how almost all relatives either from father and mother’s side lived with the whole family in one big house. My mom would always tell me that her aunties, and uncles, and grandparents lived with them for quite a long time. Often, she would also share bedrooms with cousins aside from sharing with her three siblings. My parents would also recall that every meal of everyday is to be shared with the whole family, most especially dinner time. There was a time set for dinner that all family members must be present in. As an example, my mother said that by 6 o’clock, everyone must be home and ready for dinner, share how their days went, since dinner is mostly the time where everyone would have the chance to share stories, have laughs, and voice up their concerns. Their dinners would last almost two hours over hilarious stories, and endless conversations about friends, school, and happenings they encountered that day. Lastly, according to old sayings, my mother would say that waking up early in the morning is essential to the success for the rest of your day. I asked my dad about this, and both my parents agree that from waking up early, you receive all the blessings from the rising sun, and from up above. Essentially, this helps complete tasks you are about to do for that day. I always loved hearing stories from my parents’ childhood, especially my mom’s, they sound so adventurous and more exciting than how youth live their lives today.

Hi Nicole, I totally agree with you there about TRUST. Texting your friends just to make sure their coming to your said meet up that day sounds like something a friend should not be concerned about. Agreeing on the time of your meet up is a more than enough confirmation that you will in fact be there with or without a text message to confirm it.

Thanks for taking the time to read my post, Nicole!
I guess it's just our parents and the way there were brought up. They've lived like that their whole lives and it would be really difficult to just change in an instant. And, I suppose all cultures do have some similarities too.
I read yours as well, and I definitely agree with how our generation thinks too much about the future (I find myself doing that sometimes too), instead of just living life and enjoying every single day. It'd be cool to go back to our parent's generation and living a couple days to see how that would be.

Tattoo's: The public acceptance and obsession with tattoos has increased from my parents generation to ours. Neither of my parents had any tattoo's before this past summer whereas all of my siblings and I had already had at least 2 each. People in our generation can get tattoo's by walk in appointment without a second thought. Not to say this applies to everyone and it certainly doesn't apply to my mother now whom within the past year has acquired 12 tattoos.... But just in general the accessibility and acceptability of them in the workplace and culture.
Reading: My parents generation were very well read - the level of novels that were published weren't the trashy teen-bopper vampire love stories that are engulfing my generation now. The language that was used was more challenging and the novels had deeper meanings
Hand written work: With the use of computers the era of knowing proper spelling and punctuation will soon come to an end. The calligraphy and ability to hand write letters and the art of beautiful writing will become digitized. My mother has an obsession with calligraphy and yet I'm not sure how to properly write a capital J in handwriting.
Physical memories – photographs versus digital copies. The feeling of holding a picture in your hand and passing it around is so much more satisfying that flipping through a desktop folder. The increased amount of storage within a computer for pictures has made us snap - happy and willing to save everything. My parents (thankfully) still print off photo's from the year every Christmas for presents, but they're memories aren't within the amount of pictures but the memories the pictures are from.
Health conscientiousness: Or perhaps it's paranoia, but our generation is more aware of possible health concerns about everything. Carcinogens, mercury et cetera. My parents generation did not have nearly as many warning labels or possible cancer causers as we have now. My dad (who was a redneck) used to have frozen deer poop fights ( I don't need to explain that one). I'm not sure I know of anyone in this generation that would thing to pick up a frozen deer turd and chuck it at his buddy. Also our generation has an obsession with hand sanitizer and antibiotics.
Basically the tangible side of life - books, hand written work, picture memories - has been a main difference in the generation of my parents and mine, whereas we like the world to be virtual and kept online.
As well (just had a brain blast) vehicle expression. Now vehicles are bigger and louder, or sleek and aerodynamic. They are all shiney and round edged. I find the vehicles from my parents generation have box-ier lines and less "bedazzle" to them.

1. No electronics Consumerism in my parents’ generation compared to my generation is completely different. For example, in the way that we communicate. Our generation today is heavily reliant on technology and hand held devices for communication, whereas my parents’ generation never had a cell phone to communicate with other people while they were out. Generally, the most common way of communication for my generation is through text, however for my parents, they communicated through the land line phone whenever they were home. My generation is consumed with technology whereas my parents’ generation could live without it. 2. Fashion Fashion in the older generation has changed completely. My mother always used to talk about the way that she dressed and explained to me that fashion is like a cycle. One thing for her goes out of style and soon enough comes back into style. She finds that a lot of the clothes for my generation is a more provocative style of what she used to where. In her generation, there would almost never be any skin to show because it was improper for women to expose themselves. In my generation, crop tops and short shorts have become the social norms.
3. Intensity in sports The intensity in sports have greatly increased from my parents’ generation to my generation. When my dad used to play volleyball in high school, he never had to go to weight training or practice 5 times a week. He was his own coach of his high school team and captain on the court. In my generation of sports, the programs are becoming more intense. Instead of sports being a way to keep active with no stress, the sports have become very competitive. In my high school volleyball career, I had to practice 5 times a week and weight train twice a week. On top of all this training, we competed in tournaments on the weekends. Students are training at a younger age than my parents as they began in high school for competitive sports to continue to college, but now in order to make a college team you must compete at such a high level that training usually begins in grades 5-6.
4. Education what we took in high school is there college level Education in high school for my generation was equivalent to my parents’ generation of college education. The education system, just like sports, have become more intense. The requirements to get into universities have become more than just a high school diploma. In some universities, the requirements include volunteer work and work experience depending on the programs. The increase in intensity of education could be due to the fact that our generation is more knowledgeable about the world than my parents’ generation.
5. Economically cost of living The cost of living for my parents’ generation was much lower than our generation. The cost of gas has been a roller coaster for our generation but for my parents’ generation, the gas never reached over a dollar. The cost of food expenses are rising, as well as housing prices. Just paying for the necessities now are more expensive than my parents’ generation.

War: Both of my parents were born and raised in Lebanon, and a majority of their lives were lived through war (that eventually stopped after they arrived in Canada). Based on what my mother has described to me over the years, living in a war-ridden environment was normal to her. More often than not, disputes between governments or different nations would be settled by fighting, rather than more civilized means seen today (although not necessarily always the case). The attitude displayed by a lot of the newer generations is how war is “bad” and that “fighting for peace” is counterproductive. Whereas back then, and still seen in certain parts of the world, war is simply means of settling conflict.
Arranged Marriage: My parents only knew each other for a week before they got married, a marriage to which only lasted ten years. Arranged marriages are becoming decreasingly common in Lebanon, but the idea behind them is arguably not that bad. The ideal of saving yourself for marriage and for it to be an intimate occasion between two families, as well as individuals is great. Although I have the freedom to choose who I want to date and (one day) marry, having family approve of who I have chosen is really important.
Religion: Both of my parents grew up Islamic. And in Islam, the belief is that if a man and a woman get married, their children will always follow the religion of the father (even if the woman is of any other religion). This was the practice that they were taught by their parents, the religion they were to practice was the one their parents told them to. However growing up with just my mom, she never particularly enforced religion as something that I must believe in or practice. She had her beliefs, and understood that I may have differing ones, or a lack there of. The common theme of choice is prevalent again, as I now have the choice to believe in what I decide.
Choice: Since choice seemed to be a common theme with all of the examples given so far, I have chosen (ha-ha) to make it its own example. Over a not long period of time, there has been a shift of being reliant on parents or elders for guidance in decision making, to a more independent approach utilized today.
Lastly, I’m not sure what I should title it but maybe “Chores” is good? I must not be the only one, howver I do not think I noticed it as I read over the other comments. I continually hear my mom say “back when I was your age I did so much work around the house and cooked all the meals”. Meanwhile, it seems like I do only a fraction of that (a good day would involve me cleaning my room).

1) Education was not important for my Dad growing up; he dropped out of school in grade 9 and has still always had a very good job. Presently I would have a harder time finding as good of a job, if I only went to school up until grade 9. 2) Smoking cigarettes was extremely popular in the 80’s. My Dad said everyone use to have a cigarette hanging out of their mouths. Now I think that people realize that smoking cigarettes is very unhealthy and less people smoke them. 3) Moving away from home at an earlier age was far more normal then it is now. My Dad moved out of the house shortly after he dropped out of school and lots of his friends did too. I think that my generation is more dependent on their parents because of the amount of education people have to pay or because they’re too lazy. 4) Internet access was never available for my Dad growing up. My generation is so dependent on google and social media networks that it would be hard to picture life without it. 5) The city of Surrey has changed a lot in the past 10 years as well. My Dad told me that when he first moved here, Surrey used to be all bush with small houses on big properties. Presently, Surrey is quite populated, houses are much bigger and bunched up in units and almost all the trees have been chopped down to build more houses.

item.title: Photo Theme Module - Part I
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Instructions: Due for March 5th!! This module builds on the two modules that proceeded it about Moxyland, definitions, differences, and recognizing themes for literary interpretation. This module has two parts. These instructions and actions cover Part I of the module. Instructions and actions for Part II will be posted to this webspace on March 6th, so be sure to check back. All you need to do for now is send me two pictures--no commentary needed; we'll get to that in Part II. Task: Take two photos (cellphone camera is fine) of something (an object, a place, a person; be creative!) related to what you see as representative of the themes in Moxyland. After taking the two pictures, Email (wrightd at douglascollege dot ca) them to me no later than March 5th at Midnight. If I don't receive your pictures by then, you will not get credit for this module. When thinking about and taking your two photos, you should be asking yourself how you conceptualize the themes in Moxyland. Ask yourself what you think the novel is about and what it is trying say. What statement is the novel trying to make and why? What is the underlying metaphor of the novel? Is it about Apartheid? Is about the fear being disconnected? Is it about friendship? Is it about betrayal? Is it about technology? Which part of technology is it about? How is the novel about technology? How might you represent themes through the objects you are photographing? In other words, don't just wander around and randomly take two photos--although that's one way of going about this assignment. Instead, be conscious of how your photo represents a theme in Moxyland as YOU SEE IT (so don't worry whether you understand the theme, or if it's the "right" theme). NOTE: When taking pictures of people, please be respectful of their privacy. If you are taking a picture of people (or a person) in a public space, ask their permission to take a photo of them or take the picture in a way that prohibits the recognition of faces (i.e.: from behind or the side). Outcomes: Hopefully, Part I of the module is fun. At the same time, thinking about the relevance of your photograph to the themes as you see them in Moxyland will prime you for Part II of the module.

item.title: Photo Theme Module -- Part II
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Instructions: Due before March 11th class For those of you who submitted pictures, thanks. You'll see a bunch of contact sheets below that contain all the pictures submitted for this module. Your job now is to comment on a theme you see emerging from those contact sheets, using three of the photos to prove your point (sure, you can use your own pictures, but that's really lame and self-centred; this module not all about you dude). (If you didn't submit two pictures, you can do this part of the module (and you should!), but you lost your credit already. So, no grade for you on this module! But, we welcome your participation.) Task: Tell us what theme you think THREE pictures represent. You should come up with the theme--it can be anything you think is reinforced by the three pictures. Make sure you describe the pictures and tell us what about the pictures (context, content, approach) is important for understanding how the pictures apply to your theme. We should be able to identify what picture you are talking about by how you describe what's relevant about it. The Pictures (You can click on the sheet to make the pictures bigger) A few notes to help you complete this module:
  • When writing about the theme you see emerging out of the pictures above, and when you are picking your three examples to reinforce that claim, try to think about the coherence of your evidence. How do the pictures signal the same theme exactly? What about the objects in the pictures reflect the theme?
  • Avoid thinking about Moxyland for now. Think about what the pictures here show and what themes they reflect, then pick one of those themes and three examples.
  • For those of you who want to push things a bit, think outside the objects inside the pictures. What else is similar in the evidence (the angle the picture is taken from, the colours, the resolution). In others words, don't restrict your thinking about what the pictures reflect thematically to the content alone; what about other stuff?
Outcomes:
  • We will build on your commentary in class next week, but this part of the module is trying to get you to think about coherence--how evidence goes together to reinforce your "decoding" of a theme.
  • Notice how the pictures already reflect similar broad themes -- technology for instance (how many of you took pictures of cell phones!?). But notice too how everyone's approach to taking a picture of technology is quite different. What this is trying to show you is how we need to refine and define how we are approaching broad themes by locating our thinking within specifics. When we say "technology," we mean a lot of different things. So, it's important to think about specific examples when we write essays about technology in texts.
  • Hopefully, what this module will also show is how you can put things together that are similar and arrive at different readings. The same three pictures can mean many different things depending on the context we put them in--being aware of this will make you a better reader and textual critic.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: The picture of people on a transit system who are looking at their cellphones, I feel, gives a sense of dependence on technology—chained to their phones and eliminating social interactions amongst people. https://www.facebook.com/JOHNNYLIUPHOTOGRAPHY/photos/a.603692629654621.1073741834.461118003912085/666449843378899/?type=3&theater Is a good photo that says we’re too ‘tangled up in tech’, just how people in the text are. The picture of resting homeless people can reference people who are disconnected. We often ignore homeless people on the streets, even when they’re begging for our scraps of change. I think we ignore them because they don’t look like they fit in with society. They don’t contribute to society, they look dirty and dirty. And we ignore them because of that. The theme, I think, is social status is important to people. It determines what benefits you get and lose depending on who you are. The guy lying down on the field on a nice sunny day looks free. I think the theme is freedom. Something that most people never do is find their ‘inner self’ by stopping, and looking at the world for what it is and their position in the world. I personally like to look at trains and airplanes pass by with my friend because it’s nice to stop hitting the books and relax and think. It makes me think what my position, and others in the world are. Of course, that’s the result of freedom, and I do enjoy lying down back-to-back with my friend, and I do have to cherish it because other people have it worse than me. I think the book is about what we could lose, and cherish what we have now, because all hell can go loose at any time, causing use to things that we don’t value, making us ‘disconnected’.

The picture of the surveillance camera on the last row of photos, the police car on the fourteenth row of photos and the transformer box with the spray painted black and white eye on the twelfth row of photos represent the theme of public surveillance by a higher authority in my opinion. For most individuals, the presence of the police and placement of surveillance cameras in public areas deliver a means of safety while some believe it is an invasion of privacy.
Surveillance cameras, police cars and transformer boxes share a similarity as they are common objects that are present on the streets and can be easily recognized by individuals when they are out and about in public.
The spray painted eye on the transformer box is a visual metaphor of the theme as it represents the ‘all-seeing eye’ authority has on the public at all times by constantly monitoring actions and events taking place in society. Similarly, the surveillance cameras perform the actual deed of ‘seeing’ society by monitoring city streets, parking lots of shopping malls, the doors of banks and a multitude of other types of public locations. The photo of the police car represents the obvious, which is the presence of a form of higher authority in society. The photo of the police car is shown to be taken during the latter part of the day as it is dark out. In addition, the police car is parked on the side of a building with the absence of flashing emergency lights which could represent the random placement of police personnel as an attempt to monitor the public.
All in all, the photos of the police car, surveillance camera and the spray painted eye on the transformer all contribute evidence to support the theme of public surveillance by a high authority in my opinion.

The fourth set of pictures contain a photo of a Monster Energy drink can, an Apple laptop, and a shot of a TV that is displaying a movie or show. Each of these photos have symbols that the average Western individual would instantly recognize. They represent forms of materialism and consumerism. The Monster Energy drink and the laptop show how quickly we are to recognize a brand. We know exactly what an image contains simply by seeing a bitten silver apple with a silver background. Right away, it’s easy to tell that the picture shows an Apple product, which Steve Jobs originally introduced. Without conducting any research, I’m aware of most of Apple’s products (iPhone, iPad, mac, iwatch, and iTunes). The average student will also recall the price ranges of most of their products and the setup of their store, the qualities that they have to offer, how their iOS system works, and have a basic understanding of how to use their electronics. This is a lot of information that one has knowledge of simply by noticing a brand. Personally, when spotting the Monster symbol on the black can, I didn’t need to read the words below the big green ‘M’ to know that it’s a Monster Energy Drink, similarly to most people of my age and culture. I’d also instantly remember the taste and price by seeing the drink. The photo of the TV is playing a show on Global TV, a channel on cable. Anyone who owns a TV and cable in North America will be aware of this channel and the shows that it plays. Most TV shows on this station are also American, which is evident by the big American flag stand in the photo. These are all photos of huge companies in North America. Apple and Monster are both American, which shows the influence that the United States has on Canadian consumerism. Instant knowledge of these popular brands also show the unconscious materialistic perspective that we have on the world and it’s industries.

The picture of the two washroom signs in the first set of pictures represents a theme of equality. There was a story on the news just last week actually that was talking about transgender individuals using the men’s/women’s washroom (man now women still feels comfortable using the men’s washroom but other men don’t feel comfortable with it, vice versa). But to me it shouldn’t really matter, if you feel comfortable using either washroom then do so. We live in a world where equality is something we are striving for. We need to learn to accept people for who they are. Although there are some risk factors to having transgender men and women using the “appropriate” washrooms, as the news said there have been cases of assault, we still should accept people, we don’t live in a “black and white/right or wrong” world anymore, a lot of things are grey.
The second picture that caught my eye was again, in the first set. It’s the picture of the people on the sky-train but everyone is literally glued to their phones or some type of device. It’s amazing that we have to be so connected to twitter, instagram, texting, apps, email, and Facebook no matter where we go. Just like in the books we’ve read, technology now is such a huge part of our lives, who knows what it’s going to be like 10 years from now (it’s kind of scary to think about). The problem with staying connected all the time is we lose something in exchange for technology, we aren’t as social, we don’t like to talk face-to-face if we don’t have to, the list goes on and on. It’s sad to see that technology is affecting and keeping people “connected” of all ages.
The picture taken of the newspaper article, along with the surveillance cameras, police car, the intersection, all represent authority (hierarchy for the newspaper article about Ferguson). I’ll start with the news article, this was such a big deal as it exemplified that yes, there still is racism everywhere but it also has to do with taking advantage of your job, responsibilities, and people. Not saying that the article is about racism but we’ve heard it all around the world, individuals in authority whether its driving a city bus, police officer, etc. take advantage of their responsibilities and I honestly think that some (not all!) people think they are better than others and use their position to their advantage. As for authority with the video cameras, intersections, they are all things that give us orders. Intersections tell people when to stop, go, turn left turn right. Cameras enforce obedience, we all act a certain way or different when we know we are being filmed.
That particular photo was taken looking up at the cameras, which is a prime example of how we act when we see it, we walk in somewhere, see a surveillance camera, and immediately adjust our behavior.

I think that a common theme through all the pictures posted has to do with technology. The amount of pictures of phones, computers and people on their phones portrays what our society as consumers. The theme that stood out to me most was our society being consumers.
The first picture that really stood out to me almost in shock was the picture of the family on the sky train. The whole family was on their phones and not paying attention to anyone around them. Our society is becoming more reliant and obsessed with technology. In this case the family was consumed by their cell phones. The connection was strong between the individual and their cell phone but a weak connection between each family member. Technology is becoming the most valued possession in people’s lives.
The second photo that stood out to me is the picture of the five dollar bill. Much like technology, money is highly valued in our society. We rely on money just as we rely on technology to live and just get us through life. As consumers, we use money to buy whatever is new and popular to keep up with the constantly changing fashion, vehicles or technology.
The last photo that I thought would also fit under a consumers society theme is the Iron Mountain truck. The advertisement on the back of the truck is formed to fit into our consumer’s society. Even vehicles are moving advertisements for businesses and products.
I find that we cannot go through life without being a consumer in our society. Being a consumer is unavoidable. All three of these pictures are just different examples of how we are caught in the constant cycle of consuming the new products that are released so that we can keep up with our fast moving generation.

The majority of the pictures displayed seem to have something to do with technology. In my opinion, the picture with people on their mobile phones on the skytrain, the picture with the many hand held devices grouped together, and the interface of a smart phone all represent the theme of reliance on technology. In the novel Moxyland, technology plays a major role. Cell phones are important when it comes to the characters personal information and survival. When I look at these three photos, I see that technology is important to us but not as critically important as it is to the novels story. I am not surprised at all when I see the photo of people on the skytrain using their mobile devices. From my own personal experiences in some of my classes, I have seen plenty of students using their mobile devices when we go on our breaks. It looks quite humorous but it just points out to the fact that humans are so reliant on cell phones. When I compare it to the four individuals using their cell phones on the skytrain, you can see a similar picture emerging but in a different setting. The second picture shows the many forms of hand held devices that people use for either entertainment or communication. The IPod and gaming devices represent ways in how we can entertain ourselves. For example, the Xbox controller is used as a hand held device to play video games on the Xbox. 20 years ago gaming would have never been considered as advanced as it is today. The many ways we can entertain ourselves has increased drastically due to the growth of technology. Gaming is such a big part of our entertainment industry that the younger generation relies on it for entertainment. The smart phone user interface is probably one of the most important when it comes to the reliance on technology. In this photo, it shows that a person can email another person, look at maps, and use the calculator and internet. Furthermore, this device has many more user functions. The interface shows that a person can communicate, do research, and perform other tasks all from this device at the palm of your hand. Personally, I rely on my smart phone to accomplish some of these tasks in a quick and easy way. From looking at some of these pictures, it is pretty clear that technology plays an important role in our day-to-day lives. Past generations were not as reliant on technology as we are today. Future generations will be even more dependent on technology as years go by. I still have a dazed look on my face when I see my 8 year old nephew play on an Apple tablet.

A majority of the photos seen in this module represents the theme of a dystopian society that is mainly controlled by technology such as we see in Moxyland. Even in our world today we see how much of an impact technology has on our lives. In Moxyland we see the extreme of this as the government uses technology to control everything to a point where the citizens have no privacy or proper rights.
The first photo that stood out to me was the surveillance camera. This is a technology that is used to monitor areas and ensure security. In Moxyland's dystopian society we can see that they use technology with cell phones to monitor everything that is happening and make sure it happens exactly how the governments wants it to happen. The second photo I chose is the photo of the police car. The police car also fits with the dystopian society theme as the police use technology with the cell phones and the biotechnology with the police dogs to ensure the society is controlled the way they want through technology. The third photo I chose is the picture of the people on the train all on there cellphones. We can see how our society today is so technologically based and how gadgets such as cell phones are such a big part of our lives. In Moxyland we see that the cell phone is a necessity to be connected and how Moxyland truly is a dystopian society.

To continue on my point above that we can see through all three photos they represent a connected theme of dystopia. Without referring these photos theme to Moxyland we can still see the significant impact technology has on our lives. Technology is controlling how we go through our daily routines and how we will evolve and progress as life goes on. Its scary to actually think how dependent humans are on technology and that futuristic societies may be completely controlled by technology.

Dependency on technology is a dominant theme within most of these pictures, so is a higher authority surveillance/lack of privacy, which all point toward dystopia being a prominent theme throughout the photographs as well. Specifically the picture with the puzzle in the sixth row which exhibits a dystopian theme, the puzzle can represent a dystopian society by having the pieces all over the place instead of a picture of a well put together puzzle (utopian, well put together society). The middle picture in the last row, of the art/graffiti displays a more frightening outlook on things. This can also represent a dystopia, it's more graphic monstrous look would not fit in with a happy, utopia. The appeal of it is more all over the place, chaotic and fits perfectly with the dystopian theme. The last picture in the eighth row, middle with all of the electrical cords tangled helps aid the dystopian theme. Again with being chaotic, unwelcoming, dysfunctional, disorganized, and an overall unappealing place or state to be a part of seem to be a reoccurring theme you get from most of the photos posted, but focusing on the three I pointed out, I feel they demonstrate a dystopia quite well.

Most of the pictures taken all have technology as the main theme. They can be seen as little bits of technology adding to the dystopia that created Moxyland. I want to try and analyze the pictures in a different light though. The theme I want to try and use is technology creating an almost utopia, instead of a dystopia.
The first picture I will use is the sunrise. This can be seen as a new beginning for technology, and the great new advancements that technology can bring to the human society.
The next picture I will use is the Douglas College "3600 Entrance" picture. I will be focusing more on the grey brick walls though. The thick brick walls represents the sturdiness of how much human society has evolved. From lighting fires for light to creating a mini-computer in the palm of our hands. The grey color of the think walls represents how new the technology is that the human society has their hands on. The foundation for new technology is here, but is still so new that society has to adjust to it. Almost like a new wall has been built, but still needs a color to be painted on to signify what the wall is for, what the person who owns that wall likes, etc.
The third picture I will use is the American Flag with the man in it. This picture represents a new form of government coming to society. Like technology and human society, the government needs to evolve, as well. This new form of government will cater to the public more and be more welcoming to different ethnicities. An example of this would be Obama, a black man, becoming the President of the United States. The government will also listen to what the public needs more instead of catering to itself more. Thus, the world is becoming more of a utopia, catering to the general public. But, the flag is down because it is indoors. But, this could also signify that although the government becoming to cater more to the public, it can never cater to everyone's needs, thus becoming more and more of a utopia, but the world may never be a utopia to everyone's specific needs and wants.

The three pictures I chose to use for finding a theme are the people on their phones in the Skytrain, the screenshot of the different apps, and the different gaming consoles and phones on the ground. They are representing the theme of technology but more specifically they represent the theme of how we use technology and how much it impacts our daily lives. The variety of gaming consoles and phones all have the same purpose for us today and that is to keep us entertained and connected. All the gaming consoles are used for the same purpose of playing a game most of the time but they are all made slightly different so people would buy more of them. The ipod in the image is for listening to music, which can also be done on the iphone in the image, but the iphone does not have enough memory to story all of the music most people have so they use the ipod as well. So although they all have the similar purpose, we have multiple different ways of performing those tasks. In the top corner of the home screen screen shot I can identify two different apps for the purpose of listening to music.
