I similarly have multiple apps for music but that is because they all differ slightly so they can meet to my specific demands that I want in the moment. This can represent a theme of technology consumption due to the demand for more apps to perform tasks better than the last one the supply for different apps keep increasing. The amount of technology we consume is also a theme present in all of the pictures. It is shown best in the image of the people on the Skytrain on their phones. Instead of just sitting on the ride doing nothing or talking to person beside them they are all on their devices. This also shows the theme of communication, how we do less and less of face-to-face communication and more of digital communication. All of those people were most likely using their phones to communicate with people either through social media or text messages, even though there was a person beside them that they could have just interacted with.

Tell us what theme you think THREE pictures represent. You should come up with the theme–it can be anything you think is reinforced by the three pictures. Make sure you describe the pictures and tell us what about the pictures (context, content, approach) is important for understanding how the pictures apply to your theme. We should be able to identify what picture you are talking about by how you describe what’s relevant about it.

OOps please ignore the top part there. The three pictures I will discuss are 1) the top section photo in the second row that has a “quiet zone” sign, 2) the picture of a keyboard with the focus on the control key in the second section, top row and 3) the Fruitopia with the pills in the second section as well, bottom row. These photos share a common theme within the novel of control. Within the book the government controls everything the people do and enforce strict laws to ensure that the people don’t rebel and if they do the consequences are quite severe. As described in the earlier modules, Moxyland is controlled by a totalitarian government. Control is one of the most blatantly obvious themes because of the way the government controls the people, but the pictures kind of show a few examples of how obedience is achieved. There are drinks and pills for the characters to take in Moxyland that is shown in the photo above. Ghost is the popular soft drink because the people like Kendra who are injected with nano bots need the drink to refuel and stay sharp. Without it they start to fade and lose concentration and energy. As for the pills, in today’s society medication is a huge way that control is enforced. For example, in some elementary schools there are kids who have to take pills to control their ADHD/ ADD so there by giving the teachers control of their behaviour. The “quiet zone” sign could reflect the idea that in Moxyland you have to be careful about what is said in conversation. If the government doesn’t agree with the people’s opinions they will punish you because they can’t risk having any rebellious people. For example when Tendeka and ash are in the rally and are joined by hundreds of others, the government doesn’t bow down, they take extreme measures by spraying everyone with a deadly virus. The sign emphasizes how important it is to keep your opinions to yourself in Moxyland because if you don’t follow the rules it can cost your life.

The first picture that caught my eye was the women being arrested by police officers in the first set of sheets. The caption below states, “A demonstrator is arrested at an August protest.” Not knowing what the real situation is, the appearance of police in public especially at big events show that safety comes first. This gives the message to citizens that police will not tolerate any misconduct or behaviour that will jeopardize the balance of peace.
The second picture I choose is the stop lights on the fifth set of sheets symbolizing how we deal with life. The green light represents to go ahead with life and see the different possibilities life can take us. When the light turns yellow, this can be a time where life is mediocre where things are only going average, nothing too special. In order to get ahead in life and do better, this is the time where we re-evaluate the decisions we’ve made and be extra mindful how the decisions we make will benefit or misguide us. In every success, there must be a downfall. At certain points in life, we feel vulnerable and feel as if nothing is going right. The red light indicates we have to stop, take a breathe and rethink how we are handling life because what we are doing isn’t working the way we want to. To get ahead, we must have a change in direction with a new perspective.
The surveillance camera in the last of pictures represents that there is no sense of privacy in the public eye. All eyes are directed towards each and one of us where we are constantly scrutinized and judged for our actions or behaviour. Being constantly watched, we have the tendency to please others for their own happiness and their approval. We sometimes forget to be true to ourselves and lose a part of our identity.
In life, we are judged for our actions and behaviour. The choices we make will can lead us to success, though there are times where we will stumble and fall. We must choose to get back up and move forward. Between all the photos, the demonstrator being arrested, the stop light, and the surveillance cameras supports the theme of personal growth and as unique individuals, how we can positively contribute back to the community.

The first picture that stood out to me was the picture of the police car (row 14 in the middle). This immediately made me think of an authority theme linked with technology. When I think of jobs that have a high level of authority, I immediately think of police officers. Being a police officer is a very noble job that takes courage to pursue due to its higher level of danger but I really respect them for putting their lives on the line to try to keep our society safe and in order. one thing this picture doesn't show, is the excessive amount of technology that is set up in these cars, such as GPS, computers, and intercom but it is common sense that these types of technology would be inside the car to facilitate their job. The picture was also taken at night, reinforcing the fact that it is a 24 hour job.
On the contrary to the first picture, the picture in the middle of the first row really caught my eye. I think it represents authority, and their (sometimes) unfair way of imposing that authority over citizens. It shows two police officers appearing to use brutal force on an African-American woman who was simply just protesting for what she believed in. You can also see a group of African-Americans standing there and watching (most likely in disgust, although you cannot see their faces), which goes to show that sometimes authority will take advantage of their power to try to change your beliefs to match theirs.
Another interesting picture was the family on the skytrain who seemed so engrossed in their phones (third row on the left). The theme demonstrated here is technology, and more specifically, their apparent obsession with it. Instead of being social, and interacting together as a family, four out of six of them are staring blankly into their phones, the other two are young children who appear to be ignored by their parents/family. This shifts the dependance from family, to technology.

The three pictures I have chosen are the picture of clouds and sunshine, the picture of a green grassy field with trees and the picture of a man with a bunch of items laid out on a street in a city. The three photos cover a wide colour spectrum. One photo focuses on more of a dark grey scale while one of the other photos is visibly brighter with green and blue colours. The last photo is a combination of dark grey and a bright orange colour. The picture of the clouds with sunshine and the picture of the grassy field with the sun shining both were perceived as bright and gives off a more positive reaction. While the picture with the man (perhaps he is homeless) on a street with items laid out in the dark gave me a more of a gloomy and sad reaction. From these three pictures I can see a theme of nature with positive and negative perspectives and it could be how we perceive the world we live in The first two pictures were taken when the sun was out and brightening up the pictures, which could be a representation that the world we live in is a bright and positive place. In the picture with a possible homeless man with items laid out on a sidewalk could represent another side of our world. The picture was taken when it was dark outside which contributes to a gloomy and depressing feeling when looking at the picture. The picture shows a more dark side and that there is more then just sunshine and pretty grassy fields in the world we live in.

Hey Jessica, I totally agree that money and technology rules everything around us, it's rather depressing. I like how you analyzed the pictures such as the dollar bill, being a consumer truly is unavoidable especially when we live in a society where being materialistic is the norm. The cellphone analogy got to me! Families these days are so wrapped up in their own lives that they forget to enjoy it with those who truly matter. People spend too much time trying to catch up with unimportant relations.
My mom is completely obsessed with her phone, she shattered her screen the other day and got a brand new iphone6 the next day like it was no big deal.

The three pictures I chose are the can or Fruitopia and pills, the Mac laptop and the apps on a Samsung device. The pictures illustrates how modern technology and research has been successful in aiding to people here in Canada and the rest of the world. They fit in the society we live in, although the products in the picture are not necessary to some, they benefit the average person. The pictures projects the constant change and research made by top researchers and engineers so it can be made available for millions of consumers. This was a focus on the achievements the products have made and how it made life a little more bearable. Pills are more accessible now and are integrated into everyday life that helps heal the society in many ways such as multipurpose pills for muscle tension, period pains, fever, and headaches etc. Pills are available virtually anywhere such as in your local supermarket, your pharmacy, convenience stores, your mom's car... Medicine is apart of advanced technology, although some medicine are natural, technology and research has improved medicine's quality, taste, look and accessibility. The Mac laptop is a succession from it's inventor, Steve Jobs. It has impacted the world in a dynamic way and Apple is also everywhere you look , with the continuation of development, it has grown in popularity and sales in the past decade. The Mac laptop is also a multipurpose tool that helps you in your studies or field. The Apple store dominates every major mall because of the company's ability to always improve. Apps (application software) on the Samsung device shows how computer programs in mobiles are important for convenience and accessibility. Apps are distributed through platforms that reach millions such as the games on GameHub on the screen, it has influenced how Canadians kill time and help them find their way at the same time (Google maps) . It seems like apps are also very dominate in an average person's life as it is used for many things.

The three pictures I chose are the can or Fruitopia and pills, the Mac laptop and the apps on a Samsung device. The pictures illustrates how modern technology and research has been successful in aiding to people here in Canada and the rest of the world. They fit in the society we live in, although the products in the picture are not necessary to some, they benefit the average person. The pictures projects the constant change and research made by top researchers and engineers so it can be made available for millions of consumers. This was a focus on the achievements the products have made and how it made life a little more bearable.
Pills are more accessible now and are integrated into everyday life that helps heal the society in many ways such as multipurpose pills for muscle tension, period pains, fever, and headaches etc. Pills are available virtually anywhere such as in your local supermarket, your pharmacy, convenience stores, your mom's car... Medicine is apart of advanced technology, although some medicine are natural, technology and research has improved medicine's quality, taste, look and accessibility. The Mac laptop is a succession from it's inventor, Steve Jobs. It has impacted the world in a dynamic way and Apple is also everywhere you look , with the continuation of development, it has grown in popularity and sales in the past decade. The Mac laptop is also a multipurpose tool that helps you in your studies or field. The Apple store dominates every major mall because of the company's ability to always improve. Apps (application software) on the Samsung device shows how computer programs in mobiles are important for convenience and accessibility. Apps are distributed through platforms that reach millions such as the games on GameHub on the screen, it has influenced how Canadians kill time and help them find their way at the same time (google maps) . It seems like apps are also very dominate in an average person's life as it is used for many things.
Sorry, I didn't like my previous format

The recurring theme I see in three pictures is the CONTROL through ART. Artists’ personalities exude from how they can naturally create pieces that control the emotions of artists themselves and as well as their audience. There are reactions that come from their audiences that have experienced their works and moved them in some kind of way. Artistry is expressing what you feel and see or what you have seen through different forms and ways of creativity. It can be expressed through words: songs and poems, paintings, acting: movies and television shows, video games, and even graffiti. There are numerous photos in this module that correspond to this particular theme: the actor on the Global Channel show, two pictures with graffiti, and the photo of an avatar. All photos show that art can be a way to let people know what they are ought to know and be able to manipulate them in a less violent way. And although it involves no violence, it is still quite effective with deceiving the audience. As an example, the picture with the spray painted eye was so prominent in the photo. It shows one’s sadness, perhaps problems in a person’s life or someone searching for answers among chaos that others can relate to. One would also notice the shadow of the fence that corrupts the eye of the same picture. It is comparable as to how novels like “Moxyland” and “1984” show how blind the citizens are from the manipulations of the government. They place this big barrier in front of characters’ eyes that stop them from seeing the truth and the corrupt ways of the government. Consequently, they just have to open their eyes and learn to climb that fence and overcome the government’s control and power over them. Similarly, the other graffiti photo has so much creativity in it, and also, a story that is all too familiar at the same time. It is amazing and quite insightful how ironic the picture presents itself. It is full of many bright colours, and movement (comparable/illusion of a dystopian society). The picture has that bright side to it, but the art itself can be compared to a government that just feeds its citizens with information. They don't care whether it is all false or pure truths as long as it it coming from them. Furthermore, the photo of the avatar is an expression of a computer generated character appearing to look like a person. One can appear to be someone else, and take on a new persona just like how "gamers" play in video games. Actors and actresses are asked take on a new attitude and experience something they have never felt when they are acting. Similarly, this is why famous artists make music and have passions in acting because they can show something that they normally won’t show in normal circumstances. They have total control of their own emotions, and take control of how they want their audience to feel. They can be manipulative with how they act and their interpretations in every scene. Artists know what they want, and how they want their art to be seen, making it truly effective in controlling their audience. This noticeable total control of emotions, actions, and thoughts through art is essential in the life of every artist.

Based on the pictures above, and the overwhelming amount of pictures taken of technology, it is safe to say that is the big umbrella theme represented. However technology is represented in a few different ways. One thing I noticed about a majority of the photos is that they were taken from either a bird’s eye view, or from a level distance, not so much from an ‘ants eye view’ (a view looking bottom up). This led to think that one of the themes could be pertaining to the perceived control humans have over technology. Technology and innovations are man-made, leading us to think that we have control over them, and not the other way around – however is that actually the case? Are our inventions truly making the world a ‘better’ place? The first picture that stood out to me regarding this theme was the one of the can of Fruitopia and the open bottle of antibiotics. I picked this because innovation has allowed companies first of all, to sell a can covered in fruit with contents of juice containing on average 32g or more to consumers that will see the ‘fresh looking fruit’ on it and perceive is as something beneficial to their health. This is of course not the case and anyone that drinks Fruitopia instead of eating fresh fruit will ultimately get sick. Which is where the bottle of antibiotics come in. Technology has also given us medication to make us feel better, when the cause of illness could be attributed to technology, too.
The second picture I chose was of the family sitting down on the seats, all starring down at their phones. I laughed at the picture, even though it looks familiar to every bus or sky train ride. Technology is definitely in control in this picture because it is forcing humans to be consumed in the product during times of waiting instead of having the human’s converse with one another.
The last picture I chose was the one of the various different cellphones, iPods, game console controllers, handheld game consoles all laid out on the ground. It showed the dominance that technology has over humans in a way that we can see the progression of technology over the years, that is, the progression of technology that we possess as younger children, to adults. The times and technology change rapidly as time goes on, which compels consumers to do the same with the devices they own. Why? Why isn’t a Blackberry Curve not a sufficient smartphone to have anymore? Why is it that people feel the need to wait 8 hours in line at Metrotown for the newest iPhone? Technology has driven us to do unimaginable things.

Wireless modem on top of an apple gadget, translink compass card tap machine, and the video game is, in my opinion, reflective of our society: free of any attachment/commitment. We are heading towards wire-free. Numerous technological companies are in a race in inventing cool gadgets and accessories free of any reliance to wires. Likewise, with the increased popularity of wire-less world, our society has slowly freed itself from any attachment to the real world. There is an increased usage of social media, virtual worlds, and many other offline medium to connect with one another. We are disconnected physically but at the same time connected by form or wireless connection.

I found that keyboard picture with the focus on control stand out as well. I think this picture beautifully demonstrates technology and suppression as themes. To build off this theme of supression, I will point to a minor theme of surveillance in the photo with the two surveillance cameras. Technology not only allows us to have access to much more information than previous generations, but it also can be used to gather information on us, whether it be by government or corporate or whoever. This can be used a tool for control (Kinda like not wanting to do something because you saw a camera there pointed at you).
The police cruiser also adds to the theme of suppression (specifically state/government suppression through technology). The police now can also use a suspect's phone to incriminate, and some cruisers have lap-tops on the console. They can run your name in that laptop and have access to all your important information (Name, address, etc). So the benefits of technology can go both ways.
In any-other context, I would just see all the pictures of wifi-routers and gaming consoles as useless mumbo-jumbo if I was given the same context, but having read Moxyland, the technological aspect definitely was the first thing that popped into my head. I really do believe that my reading of Moxyland affected this, as I probably would of decided to focus on the just the police and/or drugs/money as a theme if I was told to do this assignment in any other context.

The theme of a police state, whereby the police are recording many aspects of peoples lives, is dominant in several of the photos. The theme is very reminiscent of George Orwell's 1984 and how "big brother is watching you". Specifically, the photo of two different cameras, angled slightly differently. This is an interesting photo because whoever took that picture probably took it this way so that the cameras couldn't record it. This may have been done subconsciously but it reflects the concerns and mistrust we have about being recorded, and how we might not want those who are monitoring the cameras to know we took a picture of it. Then, whoever took another photo of a skytrain platform seemingly didn't have such concerns about taking a picture of a camera that the camera would have or could have seen. Also, at least one of the people in the photo appear to have noticed they were getting their photo taken. This is a similar picture to the first photo I mentioned but was taken from a frontal angle, with no concern for who was aware of the picture taken. Finally, the picture of the eye is symbolic in that it represents that we are being watched and recorded all the time, whether it be by cameras, satellite images, google earth, etc.. The fact that someone spray painted close to it could very well represent our dislike for being recorded, watched, etc.
This is a significant theme because it is relevant to us today, in Canada. For example, about a week ago, a customs agent wanted to look through a Quebec man's cell phone who was returning from vacation and he refused. Now, it will probably become a precedent setting case. Also, Harper wanting to pass bill c-51 which would intrude even more so on our privacy. Anyway, that is a little off topic a little but makes for an interesting comparison.

The photos of the demonstrator pinned down by the officers, the jumbled jigsaw pieces, and the colourful mural all represent civil unrest.
The photo of the arrested demonstrator implies protesting against what is probably a social and/or political problem. The civilians in the background are probably a part of the group of protesters demonstrating their displeasure and/or anguish to the public or the government. Such opposition consequently brings chaos and in this case, the demonstrator’s arrest.
The photo of the puzzle pieces is similar in that the disorganized heap of pieces have ‘acted together’ to bring disorder to the completer of the puzzle. Though the pieces are inanimate, they possess the ability to cause conflict and dismay by causing the person to meticulously sort through and correctly assemble the puzzle.
The vibrant mural is an incredible clash of colours all encapsulated in one image. The disorder of hues in the illustration grabs the attention of onlookers in an unpleasant way, evoking feelings of confusion and conflict. The image voices the ideas of the artist, that seemingly oppose the common views of its audience, with its display of dramatically contrasting colours.
While there is chaos in each photo, there is the possibility of harmony too. Negotiations or compromise are likely to resolve the demonstrator’s woes, while the jigsaw reflects harmony when the pieces are united, and the mural is a piece of art when looked at from a distance. To every problem, there is a solution. It is the way the solution is reached that can cause significant disorder.

The three pictures I chose were: 1. The photo of the cell phone and the baton on the table. 2. The photo with the painted eye on the shaded transformer box. (I took that picture buts it’s a pretty great picture, if I do say so myself) 3. The photo with the two monsters graphited on the wall.
These pictures all represent the theme of rebellion against a controlling authority figure. In the first photo, the controlling authority figure is the cell phone that was created and introduced by a consumeristic government. People are constantly checking their phones even when no alerts go off. Cell phones control the lives of any first world citizens because people are so overly dependent on their phones. A cell phone can also be a listening device by the speakerphone or the camera. By placing the baton right next to the phone, it shows a sense of fight or resentment against the phone that the government may or may not be hacking into and that so many people cannot go without. The second picture is the picture of the “angry watching eye” painting on the transformer box. This photo screams rebellion against a controlling authority that closely watches and observes the citizens within its district. Someone had to of painted that symbol on the box and by grafting a transformer box that shows a sense of defiance against a nosey and controlling government. I also think that the person who painted this picture wants others so see and recognize the theme of the closely watching government and to show awareness of what people do when they think no one is watching. The last photo is the two monsters graphited on the wall. The two monsters remind me of a “bate and trap” scenario. Where the bigger monster has his tentacle hanging out as the” bate” for the smaller monster to come bite it. When the smaller monster bites the bigger monster, he falls into his “trap” and the bigger monster then eats him. This could be a representation or a metaphor of a controlling government handing out “bate” to their smaller minded citizens and the citizens taking that bate; thus, falling into their trap. By this picture being graphited on the wall, it does show a symbol of rebellion and a fight against the monstrous government.

One of the main themes that I can see by looking at all of the photos is the need of connectivity through all of our society. In the twenty-first century, one of the most prominent ways that people continue to stay connected with one another is through technology. We get caught up in our cellphones, computers, and tablets even when we are face to face with friends and family. We feel the need to be up to the minute on events and breaking news around the world and in the lives of others so we are constantly checking our newsfeed, storyboards and refreshing our updates. We often forget that we could just reach out to important people in our lives face to face where there is a deeper connection.
The first picture that I chose which relates to this is theme is the man sitting at the table who is engaged in his phone and appears to be texting or playing a game. Probably everyone has experienced a similar situation with a friend or family. Second, the family on the skytrain who are not engaged with one another but are seemingly "glued" to their phones. When multiple human beings are forced to be in a confined public space, they often feel uncomfortable and turn to what is comfortable to them: texting and checking their social media updates. This is an alternative to facing what is actually surrounding them and not having to deal with the possibility of an awkward social interaction or brief eye contact.
Finally, the last picture that relates to my theme of a detached society is the picture of the unconnected puzzle pieces on the floor. This relates to our relationships with one another with not exactly knowing what is going on in each others lives. Those who spend a lot of their time online believing they are engaged in intimate relationships, typically misunderstand the level of connectivity. Sometimes we find ourselves very separated from our real world surroundings and this can lead to loneliness and even depression.

The picture of the monster energy drink represents addiction. When I first saw the picture, it quickly reminded me of Kendra’s addiction to the soft drink called “Ghost”. Kendra is described as a “walking advertisement” and it can lure people into getting the drug that Kendra was injected with. It can be compared to a TV commercial for example. The intent of the commercial is to lure audiences into buying it/consuming the product and potentially make the audience to buy more of this product. Addiction could be a theme in Moxyland as we read that Kendra consume a lot of Ghost after she was injected with the nanobots.
The picture of the large green garbage disposal with graffiti on it (which looks like an eye) can represent dystopia. Graffiti in my mind always tells me that this place is where crimes take place or vandalism. I looked up the word dystopia on Wikipedia and it tells me that it is an “imaginary community that is frightening”. This can connect to Moxyland because the tone of the story sounds unpleasant. For example, Tendeka was beaten because he rebels to the cooperation that produces nanobots and injecting them to people. He think that this cooperation corrupts Cape Town because the cooperation controls people and overpowering them with advertisements. From that, I could see why people like Tendeka view Cape Town as a dytopia.
The last picture is the person who using his phone. The picture seems to represent being connected to society. In Moxyland, being connected is important to be able to live in Cape Town because people use it for money, jobs and to be part of society. If a person disconnected, they would be abandoned by society and this means that person will “lose” their life because they no relationship with anybody (we are all relationships/interactions with other people so that we can function through life).

There is a theme of chance in these photographs. Although the subjects in the majority of the photographs are classified as high tech, there is the theme of chance because there is always the thought that the device or technology will not work. Three photos that clearly show the thought of chance is the puzzle pieces, the coin, and the red lights. These all represent the theme of chance because there is a possibility of it not working out the way that it is supposed to which can be due to the perspective that a particular individual has on it.
The three photographs that clearly show chance are the ones that are unrelated to high tech. The puzzle pieces show chance because it takes a fair amount of time for someone to be able to find the right pieces to fit together, the probability of picking up a piece to fit another right away is really low. The coin shows chance because of the idea behind flipping a coin to decide an outcome. The red lights also present the idea of chance because the chance of coming across a red light on your journey is fairly high, especially if it is in the city.
With all the technology as a whole and all the photographs together the theme of chance is still present because there is a chance with technology that it will not work or something will go wrong with it. There is the chance of a mistake occurring with the software, mistake of pulling the wrong cord, mistake of accidental food poisoning, chance of misunderstanding and so on.

The surveillance camera and the stop lights show surveillance by people with more power and higher authority than yourself. It also shows that people have to comply to rules in a way and makes people feel safer. There are also many photos of technology here. Not all technology in the photos are of high tech or old technology but show the diversity in technology and throughout the novel there were many instances when all sorts of technology played a role in moving the narrative forward. The stop lights and the surveillance camera both display the theme of technology at different levels. Then there is also a photo of a screen shot of a phone showing apps and what technology that younger generations use. In many of the photos you can see that our generation and society today focuses a lot on technology. It surrounds our everyday lives. There are even a few photos of other people that are all on their phones while they are with other people not communicating with each other but rather with people who aren't with us. On the other hand the photos of the people being consumed by technology could show how they are trying to stay connected with everything that is going on in the lives of others when they aren't with them. Just like in Moxyland staying connected is important in order for you to stay part of Moxyland and not becoming an outcast.

The three pictures that caught my eye were 1. The African American protester (in the first set of pictures), 2. The homeless person (in the second set of pictures) and the five dollars picture. The common theme through the three pictures is discrimination. Discrimination may be based on an individual’s race, sex, age, religion or beliefs. In general, the African American picture is representing the theme of discrimination that is going around the ward every day, and how authorities deal with it. The picture shows several protesters one of them women is laying on the ground refuses to move and two police officers use excessive force toward her. The police officers represent the government, and the force used represents the way used to control people. The picture reflects the racial discrimination toward African American and how the government tries to suppress protesters. The homeless person photo represents discrimination based on social economic status of an individual. The picture shows man setting on street looks like homeless. Most people don’t like to deal with homeless people .Because they understand that homelessness is related to mental health and addictions issues or individual problem. Most people do not choose homelessness. Instead, homelessness results from a social system which fails to catch and support people who are at risk of homelessness. The third picture of five dollars could represent economic discrimination. Different rates of compensation for the same ability based on worker’s age, race, religion or sex.

item.title: Ready, Set, Play - Module Week 11
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Instructions: Due for the March 18th class. Reading Ready Player One is a trip through a mind-boggling assortment of cultural references--mostly to 1980s video games and pop culture. You probably understand better now why we watched War Games earlier in the semester. This module asks you to play a 1980s video game and think about a theme suggested by that game. Task: Seek out an online emulator and play a 1980s video game. There are a few sites and examples below, but try to seek out your own. You can use the video game references in Ready Player One as a guide or, simply forge out on your own and type "1980s video games" into google--add "emulator" if the return is all knowledge-based stuff (a lot of people nerd out on 1980s video games). Once you have played the game a few times (at least 5 times, but no need to master it; unless you need to master it), write about the themes that the game puts into play or suggests through the gameplay. Another way to think about it: how would you "read" or interpret this video game? How would you make the game mean something? Please make sure to include a link to the game you played. Here's a list of some games (DON'T PAY FOR ANY GAMES - THERE ARE PLENTY OF FREE ONES): Ready Player One Ready Player Two Ready Player Three Ready Player Four Ready Player Five Summary What we should be getting at here is threefold: 1) the games often reflect a 1980s-based diaspora (look it up!), suggesting imminent death by aliens, atomic warfare, or otherwise--this reflects the themes of the 1980s and the concerns many had about the future; 2) the themes of the day are varied, but they all focus on loss (Mario loses his girl to Donkey Kong (and it's not even a Donkey; it's a Gorilla, how does that make any sense?), Space Invaders shows us alone in our fight to project ourselves from invasion (hello USSR metaphor!), and quests (you gotta get something or find something to survive); 3) How do the above two elements (folds?) combine in Ready Player One? That's to say: what is Ready Player One about? Some suggested themes: Atari, Movies, 1980s cultural references, dystopia, hacker, gunter, race, religion, education, games, gameplay, literary games, biotechnology, dystopia, utopia, nanotechnology, digital technology, hierarchy, hegemony, privilege, cyberpunk, indulgence, totalitarianism, government, gender, corporation, consent, ecology, signal, control, autonomy. Outcomes
  • Try to think about how you could write about the numerous cultural references in the book in a meaningful way. What do they mean?
  • How is "gaming" a theme? One that is rich with definitional possibilities--do we mean "gaming" as in "gaming the system" or cheating; or, do we mean "gaming" as a verb--to play the game? How might they be related?
  • How does the book seem to reflect a current cultural moment while also reflecting upon another one at the same time? Who's virtual world is this we're in?
  • Bring the terms we have discussed in the course to bear on your reading: is there a "resistant" way to read this novel? What are the characteristics of its dominant reader? What kind of cultural capital does one need to understand the book? If one doesn't have the capital, where does one find it?
Note: Remember, we're starting to wind down the course. Work on using the terms of the first half of the course (setting, character, POV, etc.) within the thematic analysis (what part and/or action of a character suggests that the 1980s were a very shallow decade?). Final Note: There's a lot of reasons to become passionately involved in Ready Player One and its numerous cultural references. Here's a few items for those of you who want to go further down the rabbit hole.
  • The Nerdist Book Club is doing a good read-along of Ready Player One, timing couldn't be better.
  • This a great story about Atari that has been in the news recently.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
http://my.ign.com/atari/missile-command
Missile Command represents a dystopian society, laden with turmoil and uncertainty. The main theme in this game is 1980's cultural reference to the Cold War, which suggests the possibility of American-Russian missile/nuclear warfare . This is bourne of the of context that a nation is trying to defend cities while an aircraft flying overhead is dropping bombs which aims at obliterating the defender's missile defense systems.
In connection to Ready Player One, IOI represents totalitarian government which aims at gaining control over the OASIS— representative of our society. The Easter Egg is representative of resources (oil, gold, land, fortune, etc). After reading articles about the existing crisis that was prevalent in the 1980's, I got a sense of the cultural reference within the video game I played.
Ready Player One makes an interesting connection between the past and the current events. Wade plays this super futuristic, very technological video game which revolves around 1980's era. When I think of the world virtual world, I think of "care-free, having no sense of accountability, nonexistent" environment in which you can do virtually anything. So to go along with the question, "whose virtual world is this we're in?" I say the government. We are the government's OASIS. In virtual games, the player can manipulate and bend rules, just like the government.

Super Mushroom Mario (http://www.1980-games.com/us/action-games/flash-games/mario.php ) is a video game with a simple goal – collect a certain number of mushrooms in order to enter the castle at the end of the level. Visually, the game is designed with simplicity in mind as the setting only includes different arrangements of blocks which are used as steps, the castle at the end of the level and the mushrooms themselves, all against a blue sky background. The theme of the video game represents the obstacles one faces while achieving a certain goal. Although Super Mushroom Mario is a simple game with a simple goal, there is still a lot of room for error which could mess with Mario’s progress. Unlike other video games, there are no villains, monsters or representations of ‘evil’ trying to interfere with Mario’s attempt at collecting mushrooms. The lack of ‘evil’, in my opinion, makes Mario’s mistakes more his fault than anyone else’s which demonstrates the personal struggles one can face while achieving a goal. In relation to Ready Play One, Mario represents Parzival on his quest to obtain all three of the keys in order to locate and unlock the Easter Egg, or in Mario’s case, the mushrooms needed to enter the castles at the end of each level. Similar to the way Mario’s personal mistakes affect his progress, Wade’s personal circumstances (lack of money, unable to travel to other planets, relationship with Art3mis etc.) often caused problems for his avatar Parzival and his quest to find the keys. In terms of cultural capital, Ready Player One has far too many unfamiliar references to the 1980s era which in turn makes them difficult to comprehend. However, with the case of the Super Mushroom Mario video game, I have enough cultural capital associated with Mario-related games to know that the mushrooms that needed to be collected usually represent benefits like speed, good health or extra strength, a tidbit of information someone unfamiliar with Mario would not understand.

I played Super Mario Bros. 3 which can be found at www.tripletsandus.com/80s/80s_games/html5_supermariobrothers3.htm
The goal of this game is to avoid many obstacles such as turtles, mushrooms and flowers that shoot at you. If you can for the most part avoid the obstacles for ten levels without running out of lives you can advance to the castle to unlock the princess but if you use all of your lives you must begin again at level one. This theme caries through many of the Mario games where Mario is typically trying to save the damsel in distress. Not only is it a theme in this 1980's video game but also in many other stories, TV shows and movies today. It is never the man that needs to be saved, it is always the woman which clearly makes a statement on our society. One could read this in a way that men are strong and noble and women are weak and require a man to save them from the troubles that life brings. The game also states that men will continue to 'jump through hoops' to save their woman.
Thinking about cultural capital regarding Super Mario Bros. 3, I can easily understand that there are certain objectives in the game and boosts such as coins and power ups that can help along the way because I played video games as a child and Mario was quite popular. Whereas in Ready Player 1, it is more complex since I didn't grow up in the eighties so some of the references do not make sense to me especially the ones relating to eighties pop culture. To find the cultural capital from the novel, one could look up unknown references in the book on the internet or talk to someone who grew up in the 1980s or someone who is knowledgeable about the era.
To read the novel as a dominant reader, you must have a little background on the eighties era. For instance, if my grandparents read this novel they would probably read it resistantly since they grew up in the forties and are against technology and don't take an interest in new innovations such as video games and the internet.

http://www.1980-games.com/us/remake/bubble-bobble/070.php
The theme present in this game is time or the struggle of keeping up with time; the purpose of this game is to beat the monsters before the time runs out. When the time runs out a ghost appears that will make you lose lives. You must destroy the monsters before the ghost arrives because after that the ghost will be chasing you until it kills your character. It represents the struggle of everyone trying to catch up to time and complete tasks before time runs out or else they fail in their goal.
In Ready Player One, all the players of the game are also fighting against time to keep up with it so that they do not fail. They need to find the Easter egg before IOI does or else they lose everything they value. So similarly to the game I played we need to complete the task before time runs out or else it will get harder to defeat the monsters (IOI). Time was especially important at the last round of the Easter egg hunt as it was the first person that could find it in the room that would ultimately win the game even if it does take three people to pass the last gate.
To read this book one needs cultural capital of the 1980’s as most of the new technology present in the novel is explained in it. However, if one does not know much about the 1980’s they will be left out of a lot of the jokes or references being made in the novel. To gain this cultural capital one simply can Google most of the references but it will take time understanding it to a level similar to someone who grew up in that era.

The game I chose is called space invaders. It essentially is shooting down a bunch of aliens who float around and who also shoot at you (your player is a tank). The further into the level you get the closer the aliens come towards your tank and their shooting rate increases. They also pick up the music in the background and sound alarms when the giant UFOS come out because they are worth the most points. This game obviously presents the theme of Aliens invading earth. They project that the aliens come in their UFO’s and their only goal is to destroy us. This leads to me think the theme of this could also be fear because in the 1980’s UFOS and aliens caused a lot of hysteria. There wasn’t exactly a happy feeling to this game, it was set up with a dark background with creepy music and alarms that would signal when the UFO would be flying over-head for you to shoot down. The themes of alien invasion and fear are what I get from this game because the whole objective is to shoot as many aliens as possible. They are not wanted because they are not understood. I mean who knows if they even exist right so another theme could be controversy over that- over the believers and non-believers. That’s essentially how I made this game mean something. I thought about how aliens were viewed at the time and the threat they pose even though aliens are hypothetical constructs created by people who are afraid of what other life could potentially exist. The game was made to be appealing and sort of subconsciously reinforces the idea that aliens are bad and dangerous and they should all be shot. Mostly because they threaten the future of humans and were only depicted as wanting to kill us. The fact that this game portrays a one sided argument- that the general belief was the aliens sole purpose was to invade and destroy earth- shows they were not thinking of other possible outcomes or that aliens may not even exist at all or want to do any of the things listed above. Maybe they wanted to coexist or just check the place out, who knows. Anyway, this point of view only shows they were acting out of fear and uncertainty of what else could live among them and their gut reaction as a culture was to shoot it down (so to speak).

The game I played was Sonic the Hedgehog found at: http://www.1980-games.com/us/action-games/flash-games/sonic.php The objective of the game is for Sonic the super speedy hedgehog to make his way through the levels collecting coins and killing bad guys (monkeys, penguins, Doctor Eggman etc). Themes emerging from this video game are time and greed.
Time relates to the theme in the sense that Sonic is a ‘fast’ animal (although hedgehogs in real life have big bodies and small little legs which doesn’t make them ideal for running) that has to get through the different stages as quick as possible, but still collecting the coins and killing bad guys. This could be representative of people’s thoughts that the quicker something was done, the better. Greed is a second theme I noticed in the game, because of how Sonic collected gold coins. When you moved Sonic into a bad guy, you lost a lot of coins. This is representative of how people often don’t like to share with others, especially money or rewards, and often fear of losing it when others get involved.
Moreover, in Ready Player One, the members of OASIS also relate to these themes. Ironically, the hunt for the Easter Egg took years from when it first was released, and theoretically could have taken many more. But since Parzival, Aech, Art3mis, and Daito and Shoto were so determined to solve this quest in hopes of doing so before the IOI did, it was done so much sooner. Also, it was the IOI’s greed that fueled them to initiate all the Sixers in on the hunt to help increase their chances of solving the hunt sooner.
The resistant way to read Ready Player One would be by generations prior to the 1980’s, that haven’t had a lot of exposure to computer games and virtual worlds. The dominant reading of the book would be someone that ideally grew up in the 1980’s since they would possess the cultural capital required to understand the references made. However, as someone who isn’t too familiar with the 80’s, the points the narrator was trying to get across did work due to the context they were put in (eg, Wade setting his alarm to play Wham’s “Wake Me Up Before You Go-Go” in the morning).

I played the game Tetris, which is a puzzle solving game than involves rotating blocks of different shapes and sizes to form a horizontal line with no gaps. It requires you to make rapid decisions about how to best make the blocks fit tightly together. As the game proceeds, you have less time to think about how to best place the blocks. Also, as you advance further, random assortments of blocks appear prior to starting a new level, which makes it more difficult as well.Unlike many other games, it may actually be good for your brain to play the game of tetris. That is not my opinion but rather the opinion of people who have done research on the topic. Search "Is tetris good for you brain" or some combination thereof, and you can see various studies that seem to indicate that it may stimulate certain areas of the brain. Admittedly, some of these studies are certainly biased. Here is one study that explains why it might be good for the brain: http://thebeautifulbrain.com/2011/06/the-neuroscience-of-tetris/
The game of tetris, in my opinion, is somewhat reminiscent of a rubix cube. They both involve solving puzzles, but of course are different in the way you go about it. They are different in a lot of ways as well. However, they are similar in that they are both a race against the clock and make you think about how things fit together, and how to rotate them accordingly to do so.
Tetris tests how quickly you can mentally rotate objects in your head, prior to physically doing so. Some blocks appear similar but as they are sliding down the screen they are in a horizontal position. When you go to rotate them, you can waste time if you don't immediately recognize if the "L" shaped block,or the backwards facing "L", when rotated 180 degrees, will fit appropriately in the spaces available. So in that sense it does cause you to think on your feet. As you advance you have little time to think, and it is all about reacting quickly. I think that is why this game was and/or is so popular, because it actually involves making rapid decisions and reacting accordingly. In this way, as opposed to some other games, many different people can play it since it is non-violent, involves solving puzzles, may actually stimulate your brain etc..
There are a lot of similar games and editions of tetris but here is the one I played. http://www.1980-games.com/us/remake/tetris/004.php

I played duck hunt. It’s a game about shooting ducks, usually with a plastic gun (it was like a 1980’s wii), by aiming at the screen with your gun. You lose by not shooting a certain amount of ducks from each round and when you lose, a dog taunts you with his annoying laugh. The game cannot be beaten, even with using cheats to ‘alter your skills’ (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LvYvNDFnEM8). Though, I feel the game’s theme is skill. To prepare yourself for killing ducks, practicing rather. I find it interesting that there is no winner, even though the goal of the game is to win, or at least mine was. No matter how good someone could be, they would always lose. I find Duck Hunt to be similar to Tetris, where you can’t win. I also find resetting back to level 1 on both games when you lose interesting. Frankly because I can act more of a retard in the lower stages of the game, but find that I have more to lose in the later stages. It’s similar to ready player one, because Wade has to take precautions of the Sixers. Otherwise, he would lose all his stuff and start out as a level 1. Overall, I think this assignment is putting us in Ernest Cline’s shoes. I feel like he portrays Haliday because of the references he enjoys (I’m assuming!) inside the book. And we, the readers, are the gunters. Cline’s way of giving showing us references of what he enjoys, just as Haliday did. That, and his contest for solving the puzzle in his book—the prize being a car from back from the future. I’d imagine it would be like finding the limerick in ch. 2—find the odd letters and put them together, thus finding a clue to the puzzle. Anyways, that’s my interpretation of this assignment so far.
Link to Duckhunt http://www.free80sarcade.com/duckhunt.php

I played a bunch of different ones but Mario games have always been my favorite so first I played the Mario mushroom where the goal of the game is successfully collect a certain number of mushrooms to enter the castle, then I played Mario remix (http://www.1980-games.com/us/remake/mario/017.php) and the goal of this one is to get through the obstacles, like turtles, and other creatures in your way. Honestly, I played about 39 times and I couldn't get through the first round so I just got frustrated and closed the game, so I am not 100% sure of how the levels go. Since I am somewhat familiar with the Mario type games I am able to figure out what the goal is quickly, what controls to use and the sorts of level ups there are in the game. Although I am awful at the game itself I have some cultural capital since I have played it, and many other versions of the game throughout my childhood. The theme relates to defiance and perseverance in these games, from obstacles to your own self. You want to make the character jump or go a certain way but if you're too slow or don't know how to use the controls it is likely it won't go the way you planned. The obstacles like all the creatures will continue to stand in your way to make you fail. After failing, you start up at the beginning and continue the quest, a lot of patience is required. These show up in Ready Player One, going on the quest for the Halliday's egg, the patience it took to do all the thorough research on Halliday, constantly pushing through and avoiding obstacles like the sixers. In the novel, I had little cultural capital seeing as I wasn't familiar with the games and movies that were being played or talked about (besides War Games) and so while reading the novel I think a little of all three types of reading came into play. The lack of cultural capital and understanding of the 1980's games resulted in some oppositional reading. Whereas for some parts, being able to picture the technology being used or knowing the movie War Games helped the dominant reading.

http://www.1980-games.com/us/old-games/nintendo/s/Super_Mario_Bros_3/game.php
One of the first games I ever bought on my Nintendo 64 was Super Mario 64. I decided to play Super Mario Brothers 3 as it reminded me of my first childhood game. The character you play as, Mario, is one of the most iconic video game characters ever created. Although the game play overshadows the story, Super Mario Brothers 3 still has a plot. It is presented in tidbits while the game play is exposed in a bigger fashion. Just as in other Mario games, Princess Peach needs to be rescued by Mario. Maybe the theme in Super Mario Brothers 3 could be rescuing the damsel in distress. This is the theme I feel is most represented because the plot does not show any other storyline. Furthermore, Bowser is the character holding the Princess captive and he plays an antagonistic role in the game. In Ready Player One, Wade’s main objective is to find the easter egg in the OASIS while being pursued by Sorrento. When compared together, both plots revolve around a bad character trying to cause a problem. The goal of Super Mario Brothers 3 is to go from the first level to the last by beating enemies along the way. In the game, there are a few maps and the objective is to beat all the levels in each map. This will advance the player further into the game. It seems the game tries to present itself as a point A to B type of game. Beating enemies is pretty simple because all the player needs to do is hop on top of the enemy. They pose a threat to Mario’s health and this eliminates them. One thing I clearly noticed is how much this character, and video game series has evolved. Graphics and the power of the current generation hardware are evidence of that in the modern age. As I played the game, I noticed basic controls and the characters not having much of a back-story. Games are very complex and robust in these categories nowadays. However, their have been games where the developer completely botches the title.

http://www.1980-games.com/us/action-games/flash-games/missile-strike.php
The game that I played is called Missile Strike and to play, you have to shoot rockets to save your base from being destroyed from asteroids. This game reflects the popular theme in the 80’s of nuclear warfare. The Cold War caused a huge scare of nuclear bombs so the games of that time reflect this situation. This game would be popular for kids because it is an exciting relevant issue. Children always want to act like adults so being able to become some sort of leader of an attack will appeal to them. Ready Player One reflects upon two different points in time that are relevant to our culture today. The setting of the novel in in a dystopia where the earth is dying and society is collapsing. This is a realistic future comparing it to the direction that society is heading towards with global warming and terrorist attacks. Despite the glim future, the book keeps a positive attitude going with OASIS. The program is gives hope to the players that they can still enjoy life despite their real troubles. The 80’s were a time of excitement as technology grew faster and people were always looking up. As time went by, the hope of society diminished so keeping the excitement of the 80’s alive is a coping mechanism for the people.

I also noticed that it was really easy to get frustrated at these games. Our cultural capital makes it difficult to enjoy these games because loosing is not something we are used to. The games of our day have winners (for the most part) so the lack of accomplishment was annoying.

The game Street Fighter 2(http://streetfighteronline.info/) is a fighting game where the characters from different nationalities battle each other in a timed 2 round fight. The main objective of the game is to win fights. A theme in the game is time because if your health is lower than your opponents after the time is up then you lose.This time limit creates a sense of urgency to complete a task which in this case is to beat/knockout the opponent.This relates to Reader Player One because Parzival has a time limit to find the egg and if he doesn't complete this task quickly then other Gunters might complete it before he does. Another theme in this game is patriotism/war because each character is from a different nationality it seems as if the characters are fighting for their countries. Like Ready Player One there are many different characters in the OASIS and the Characters are fighting for something. Parzival is fighting against the Sixers of the IOI because the Sixers are after him while Art3mis is trying to find the egg so she can do a good deed and help end world hunger. There were few references that I understood in Ready Player One because I didn’t grow up in the 80’s and don't the cultural capital. But after completing this module I could see some games that were referenced in the book and I even tried a couple of them. To my cultural culture I can say the Oasis in Ready Player One is similar to the internet. You can be or do anything in the Oasis, like Parzival going to school and learning. The way we use our internet is similar as we use the internet to google everything. Also in our internet we “technically” can be a character and live in a virtual world.

http://www.tripletsandus.com/80s/80s_games/html5_galaga.htm
The (fantastically frustrating) game, Galaga, suggests that people should be prepared to face death. Players are given 3 lives for a reason- so they can play twice more when they die! Death is imminent. Galaga certainly proposes that death can happen at any time and we can’t always predict when it will occur to us. The invading enemy aliens shoot at you and sometimes swarm you, killing you from behind. Because of the enemy’s clear death threat, you always have to be on guard, prepared to defend your spaceship by shooting the enemies down. There is a lot of emphasis on being ‘quick on your feet’ to protect yourself and kill the enemy. Galaga is probably responsible for training David Lightman, from WarGames, to be quick witted in every situation. In a way, Galaga has prepared David to take down Joshua/WOPR.
Like players of Galaga, Parzival is constantly in danger of being killed thus he must always be ready to protect himself, especially from sixers. Just like Galaga ‘trained’ David Lightman, all the 80s culture research prepares Wade to find the Easter egg and his own sharp wits allow him to go further on the hunt. Galaga and all Wade’s 80s research overall suggests that people should prepared to defend themselves, whether its with weapons or knowledge, or be prepared to die…

I played the game pacman. The goal of the game is to eat all the pellets on the screen before getting tagged by a ghost. The ghost is able to capture or stop pacman by touching or tagging him. It is like a game of tag between pacman and the ghosts. If the pacman is able to eat a fruit, then the rolls of the ghosts and the pacman are temporarily reversed and the pacman is now trying to eat the ghosts.
The pacman game relates to Ready Player One in the way that the ghosts in pacman are trying to prevent pacman from moving on to the next level just as the IOI employees are trying to prevent Wade and the other players to moving on to the next level. The IOI employees are trying to get possession of all the keys so that the players cannot win, however they do not know how to unlock the next level or gate. The ghosts in pacman are trying to prevent pacman from eating all the pellets which has no use to the ghosts because they do not know how to, or serve the purpose to unlock the next level.
Some of the references in the Ready Player One novel were confusing to me because I did not grow up in the same time frame as the setting in the book. The book takes place more into the 1980’s. The references to their popular culture was different compared to the very different culture that we have today.
The theme I picked out of the pacman game was more like the survival of the fittest rather than obstacles to be overcome. The goal of the game is basically to stay alive. As soon as you get “tagged” in the pacman game, you lose all of the progress that you made with eating the pellets and have to begin back at the beginning.

I played contra, found at http://www.1980-games.com/us/action-games/remake/contra.php
I played contra before, when I was much younger and I had a rough idea of what it was about gameplay wise.What struck me as odd was that some of the graphics looked as if they were added with a modern flash animator (the ship in the intro, plus the sparkles in the starting menu). The emulator also added a CPU monitor, infinite lives, and a cheat-menu for weapons. Contra, although the core of it is the same on this emulator, has lost the level of challenge that I remember it having (although I slightly expected it to be altered after seeing the sparkles at the start menu).
However, I was able to notice something about the theme that the poorly made plot was presenting. Two Marines (A branch of the US Navy) are fighting the Red falcon (Red, being the USSR reference). I decided to wikipedia the story-line of contra, reading that the Red Falcon alien invaders are stationed in the Galuga archipelago, New zealand. Again, the USSR had their work-camps nicknamed the Gulag-Archipelago (Referring to the gulags spread throughout Siberia) and this struck me as a second reference to the USSR. The alien invaders crash into earth, remain dormant for 2 years, and then abruptly unleash Armageddon on humanity (referencing the USSRs capability to unleash a nuclear war). The metaphor to the USSR is complete with the soldiers themselves: the enemies are literally a red army. The red falcon represents the lost security in the cold war-era, where the threat of nuclear war hung over everybody's head.
In Ready Player One, Wade speaks out about the injustices in the real world that is plagued with poverty, unemployment and war. In Wade's world, the threat that hangs over their head is the loss of security as-well due to the semi-disastrous conditions the world was in. In the prologue, the narrator talks about Major Cities being nuked. Wade's thought also present a theme of isolation in the early chapters (He spends his free time in OASIS, interacting with people online rather than in person, was raised on OASIS, he lost his parents, his mother was an E-escort). The theme of catastrophe that is present in the 80s video games, is also present in Wade's world. Video games are used in both instances as a sort of 'snap shot' of the era. In the 80s, the theme of loss was common in gaming, fighting off a relentless enemy bent on bringing about world domination. Similarly, Wade's world is filled with the same threat of the world coming undone but the threat I extracted was that Wade saw humanity as the sole cause of it. The video game Wade plays shows a utopia, a haven from the grim real world (Just like how a real oasis is a haven from the brutal conditions of a desert).

I played a 1980’s video game called Frogger. The theme of Frogger is to get the 5 frogs from one side of the street to the other one at a time. But to do so, the frog must successfully leap through a 5 lane highway without getting hit by any cars, then it must successfully leap through a river by timing its jumps to land on the moving lilypads and logs which will sink if you take too long. The next step is to time your jump so that you land in one of the 5 sockets at the end. Sound easy? Well it’s not because you only have 3 lives and a time limit. I used to play this game occasionally in grade 4 at my elementary school but I was never able to beat it. Even after trying it ten times or so recently, I still could not beat it. Although I am making this game out to seem difficult, I grew up without video games, so for someone who grew up playing video games it might potentially be easier. This game represents to me the theme of a quest. The frog is in a race to survive, if the frog is too slow he will die, so he must be quick to survive and timing is key. This is similar to Ready Player One, Wade must be quick and well timed to succeed in his quest to decipher Halliday’s riddles in order to outperform any competitors. However, Wade has a clear meaning for embarking on his quest, whereas the frog does not. Therefore, to make the game Frogger actually mean something on a higher level than just an eighties arcade game, I would add a backstory, perhaps a short animated video at the beginning that explains to the player how the frog came to be in that situation, and a more specific motivation for strategically crossing the street. Currently the reason appears to be “so that it doesn’t die”, which is too vague.
http://www.free80sarcade.com/frogger.php

http://www.1980-games.com/us/action-games/flash-games/frogger.php
The game I chose was Frogger. This is a classic video game from the 1980’s that also appears in one of my favourite Seinfeld episodes. The game is very challenging but addicting and it takes dedication to master and get a score like George Constanza got. The objective of the game is to make the frog cross the road and lake to the grass while dodging the obstacles such as cars, bikes, and trucks.
Frogger like Ready Player One both involve people blocking the main character (Frogger or Wade) from getting to the “finish”. The Frog must dodge all the hazards and obstacles while Wade is faced with Sorrento and his Innovative Online Industries members preventing him from finding the “egg”.
Themes I see with Frogger is dystopia in the frog’s society as there are many things going on that are undesirable and frightening as one wrong movement could lead to the frog being splattered. With Wade and his quest to find the egg we can also see the dystopian society in Ready Player with both the game OASIS and also with the sixers of the IOI and how they created many frightening situations in Wade’s real life.

http://www.1980-games.com/us/action-games/flash-games/sonic.php
I played the game Sonic for a ridiculous amount of time. The point of Sonic was to collect as many rings as you possibly could before running to the end of the course. Of course you were being timed but it was just a timer that went up instead of down, it never “timed out” opposite of what most games are like. In this game you got to choose from about 4 different characters, each always had 3 lives.
The theme was difficult to pick out. It’s clear that you need something to survive, not just in Sonic but also in any of the games (I played multiple). You need something in order to live and move on to the next level. However, if you don’t succeed you will not move on. In Sonic if you hit a bee, crab, money, or spikes you lost all the rings you collected, so there’s always a chance that you need to reset just as in Ready Player One and the War Games movie we watched.
A theme the game exemplifies not only just in the video game but playing it (relates to reality too) I noticed I was very greedy. Every time I died I would just play again trying to beat the level and collect as much gold rings as I could, and whenever I hit something and lost everything I had I was so frustrated. But it also took a lot of patience, a theme that shows up in Ready Player One, when they try to hunt for Halliday’s egg.

I gave Neuromancer a few tries. I haven't played many oldschool rpg type games so even getting the controls was pretty frustrating (for example- forgetting that they didn't use mouse controls very much, it's very keyboard focused), but the point of the game seems to be to not get arrested and/or killed, upgrade your "deck" and yourself with skill chips and hopefully find some people who have gone missing. I haven't gotten too far yet because I keep getting arrested and fined. This game gives me a really big Blade Runner vibe. Neuromancer definitely has a dystopian hacker focused society, with some biotech, and religion based around the game Pong. It is similar to Ready Player One in this way... The "religion" rather than Pong, is the hunt for the easter egg in RPO and almost everyone is involved in the OASIS on some level, but there are the few gunters/hackers who try to find the hidden gems of information and game the system to their advantage. I'd say that "gaming" in the sense of "gaming the system" and as the act of playing a game pretty much go hand in hand. The limits of the rules in a game are always being tested by the players. Some players are content to remain within the rules, but others are more concerned with winning a game no matter what the rules, as long as they aren't caught or there are acceptable risks involved. As long as there have been games, I'm sure there have always been the honest and dishonest players. I'm not sure whether you are speaking literally (outside the context of the book) or within the limits of Ready Player One when you ask "Who's virtual world is this we're in?"... in the book it could be the world of Parzival/Wade, which is within the virtual world of OASIS which is in turn the virtual world of Halliday/Anorak and Og. A lot of layers of reality. If we're also including the world that contains the book, it gets kind of fuzzy and probably totally irrelevant, I'm sorry.
I bet there is a "resistant" way to read this book, but I can't think of how that would be because I'm pretty firmly in what is probably the dominant reading of Ready Player One. I think the easiest way to access the dominant reading is to have lived through the 80s or at least the 90s and have had a connection to the nerdy side of our culture even if you weren't directly involved in it. If someone didn't have the cultural capital to read this book, a great place would be youtube or wikipedia... there are tons of channels on youtube that have 80's era game reviews and a lot of original content inspired by the 80's.
I think the 80's seem to be a shallow decade because the movies and media I've seen is pretty taken up with youth and innocence, contrasting with the state of politics and the cold war. They were trying to emulate a simpler time to escape from what was really happening around them.
I always get really lost when it comes to thematic analysis, so I hope I at least hit something within the ballpark
Neuromancer link - https://archive.org/details/msdos_Neuromancer_1988

http://www.tripletsandus.com/80s/80s_games/html5_DonkeyKong.htm#play
The game I played was Donkey Kong. Basically all you have to do is make your way to the top of a ramp by climbing up ladders and jumping over barrels that are being thrown at you by Donkey Kong. If you succeed at making it to the top you rescue Princess Peach and move on to the next level.
I believe that the theme of this game was heroism. Mario is working his way through trying to dodge the barrels being thrown at him to save the captured Princess. If Mario gets hit by a barrel or rolled over by one he dies. As the levels increase in difficulty you need to then jump from one platform from another increasing the chances of dying. It takes a hero to face all these challenges just to save the Princess.
In relation to Ready Player One you could say that the theme of hierarchy is also seen through out the game. You have the Princess who has been captured, which is the top of the chain, then there is Mario who is one step below, who is trying to save the princess, sort of like the soldiers or knights in a castle and then there is Donkey Kong who is at the bottom of the chain and is the evil villain. When it comes to cultural references from the book Ready Player One, it references many things from the 1980's era that may not be as easily picked up on unless you are familiar with games or terms from that era.

I know exactly what you mean by getting frustrated. I probably spent more time than needed trying to beat one level on the game I was playing just because you feel like you are so close and get so focused on trying to beat it that it gets frustrating. I ended up having to give up since I had to much homework to do and couldn't waste anymore time on it.

The game I played was Galaga it’s a space shooting game found at: http://www.1980-games.com/us/remake/space-invaders/039.php The main goal of the game is to destroy the aliens coming on screen. I played the game many times but couldn’t go more than level one. The player have to be fast, by moving the spaceship left and wright to brevets alien’s hits. To collects points player have to keep shooting to destroy the enemies (aliens). I saw a video about this game, it’s showing that this game has many levels and in higher level player can double the firepower. I believe higher levels will be harder to reach. The game ends when the last player’s spaceship destroys. The theme of this game is defensive to protect self and ground and maybe control. In relation to Ready Player One the theme of self defense is there as Wade Watts tries to define himself from IOI. Also, Art3mis think to save the earth if she wins the ester egg by helping poor people and try to end starvation. The spaceship reminds me of aliens (in old movies) who try to control the earth recourses. The same as IOI they try to control the OASIS. If the reader aware about the 80s capital culture, it will be much easier and more fun to read this novel. The story took place on 2044 but it’s evolve around 80s pop culture. While I’m reading the novel, I Google some names or games which mentioned to help to me understand better.

http://www.1980-games.com/us/old-games/nintendo/t/Tetris/game.php
The video game I played is Tetris. The task is to rotate blocks of various shapes (but same size because they all have four cubes) and form a horizontal line without gaps. It gets harder when the blocks fall down quicker, forcing the player to think rapidly on forming the horizontal lines. The theme of Tetris represents how one is able to successfully solve the puzzle (horizontal line) in a given time. Also the game requires players to use their thinking to solve the puzzle in a short amount of time. Since time management is a theme in Tetris, the game relates to Ready Player One because the main character Parzival is trying to unlock the third gate and finding the secret egg before the Sixers. Moreover in relation to problem solving in Tetris, this reminded me when Parzival/ Wade escape from the IOI after he was captured and hacked into their database to find all the information about him, Art3mis, Aech and Shoto before IOI captures all of them. This situation pressures Wade just like the game of Tetris pressures gamers as the game gets harder.

The game called Galaga from 1981 found at http://www.free80sarcade.com/galaga.php is a space game where there are enemy ships trying to attack your player. The game reflects the style of the 1980’s and possesses the colours and the pixilation of the software of the time.
