The game is based on a high technology based galaxy and reflects the theme of invasion by alien forces. This game focuses on the loss of a battle to survive against forces that are unknown to us and only known to be a threat.
This combines into Ready Player one in the way that there is the ability to reset to the original status and there is the ability to try again in a variance of ways. This theme of gaming ties the novel to the games in the way that it is a learning adventure in the way that once you have tried one way of doing something and it doesn’t work there is another way to try it. Therefore there is a way to accomplish a set goal by a task of trial and error, where in the end it can be reset.

https://archive.org/stream/atari_2600_m.a.s.h_1983_20th_century_fox_video_games_frank_cohen_douglas_dallas_n/atari_2600_m.a.s.h_1983_20th_century_fox_video_games_frank_cohen_douglas_dallas_n.bin?module=a2600&scale=2 The game of choice was M*A*S*H, a field hospital for the war with 5 separate choices of game styles, 3 of which are retrieval of men from the field and returning them to base while avoiding being shot by an enemy tank as well as beating the opponent (computer). The other two are identical to operation only its computer based and pixelated. The theme is surrounding war, but not the gory heroic war of a single Rambo taking down an entire enemy squad with only a paper clip, but more towards the fight behind the scenes. The race against the opponent relates to the race against time, and at some points in the game you miss men that you just can’t pick up. This would have been a reality in war that some soldiers got left behind. Without knowing that M*A*S*H was related to war hospitals from watching M*A*S*H 4077 on TV I probably wouldn’t have chosen this game because out of context M*A*S*H could mean anything. The previous knowledge I have due to my cultural background allowed me to play the game and understand what was going on (after a few mishaps discovering how to use an online emulator) without having to read instructions or google an answer. Majority of the games chosen by other classmates probably have something to do with their cultural history as well, which I find quite intriguing after reading which games chosen. Majority of them I have heard of and have a faint Idea of what the general gist of the game is but others I haven’t the faintest idea about.

The game that I played was Pac-Man which can be found at: http://www.tripletsandus.com/80s/80s_games/arcade.htm
The goal of the game is to control Pac-Man through a maze and eat pac-dots. Pac-man has four enemies (Blinky, Pinky, Inky, and Clyde) that try to catch him while trying to obtain the pac-dots. Once all the pac-dots have been eaten, you begin a new level which is more difficult and challenging then the previous level. If one of the ghost touches Pac-Man, a life is lost and Pac-Man dies. There are a total of three lives throughout the game, if all life chances have been used, the game ends.
In every corner of the maze, there are four larger dots that temporarily give pac-man the ability to eat his enemies. When Pac-Man eats one of the larger dots, his enemies turn into a deep blue colour and reverse the direction they are going, moving in a slower pace. When an enemy is eaten, they return to their normal color and reappear to to the centre box and begin to hunt down pac-Man.
The theme that relates to the novel Player One was in a virtual game, you have life chances that allow you a second chance to restart from the beginning to succeed moving onto the next level. In Pac-Man and in the novel Player One, you have up to three lives and then the game ends. In life, we don’t have a reset button where we can undo the mistakes we’ve made or forget where we have failed, instead we have to choose to get back up where we fell and continue on of our journey. From playing pac-man and reading Player One, I was reminded of how we are in a journey to find our own prize and succeed. People are constantly in a race to out win the other players, and if you fall behind it feels as if reaching the end of the tunnel feels impossible.

The game I chose to play was "Venture" , the goal is to guide your character named Winky to defeat monsters and collect as many rewards as you can. There are many levels (3) where it gets harder with increasing speed of the monsters. I only made it to level 2 because I am a rookie, even with multiple tries. The theme is about perseverance and exploration of your surroundings in order to advance. There are many obstacles in the way where you have to keep trying to keep your focus and keep your eyes on the treasure. I made it into the "Two headed room", if you picked up a treasure, a monster with two heads will appear in hopes of ruining your chances of victory.The IOI employees in "Ready Player One" were like "the monsters", with their intentions of making you lose. The objective reminded me of Wade and his colleagues drive with locating the Easter Egg.
Just like Winky, Wade has to be better and quicker than his opponent to complete his quest with drive to win the egg. Exploration of your surrounding will always benefit you, and never fail because it's best to know your field and what you're playing for (egg, treasure). When I was playing the game I noticed the pattern of the monsters moving and took advantage of Winky's surrounding in order to guide myself through the doors. http://www.vizzed.com/play/venture-a2600-online-atari-2600-4504-game

Hey, I love how you compared Tetris to the rubix cube. It does involved fast thinking, but I think there are better games that can improve how fast you can think on your feet that are actually designed for your brain (check out the app store on the iphone!). Tetris in my opinion is just a simple version that doesn't stimulate the brain enough.

item.title: Your Essay Profile Module
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Instructions: (Due for the March 25th class.) We're heading into the final essay of the semester, finishing off Ready Player One, and moving into JPod. So, its appropriate that we now move into some creative critical practice: designing an essay profile. This module asks you to create a profile for your essay the same way you would create a profile on The Facebook, The Twitters, The Instgram, or The Ello, or some other The Social Network. Task: After choosing one of the essay questions, create a profile for your essay and post that profile in the comment space below. You should concentrate on three main attributes:
  • Name (the title of your paper):
  • No more than 150 words describing the essay--the "bio" part of most social media profile sections. Tell us a little about the paper
  • Describe two main subjects your paper might cover
Summary You're not beholden to anything you write down here. The module is just trying to get you thinking about or conceptualizing what you will write about. The idea here is not to come up with something definitive. The idea is to come up with a profile for your paper; something you can look at and try to imagine fully formed. Doing so will tell you what kind of paper you have and whether or not the paper is really about something of interest to you--and me! Outcomes
  • Thinking about essay writing as if you were creating a social media profile should reveal more about how you are structuring your argument/approach to the subject at hand. Like social media profiles, essay profiles can reveal certain idiosyncrasies that can be great or they can be disastrous. The trick is being able to "read into" your profile and extract the good stuff, mould your essay's personality.
  • Profiles often force us to be succinct where we are often discursive (look it up!). Coming up with an effective essay profile means doing some refining and defining, something every good complete essay needs.
  • Understanding the "likes" that you have for your essay subject at an early stage can help you avoid writing about something you have no interest in and which, as a result of your disinterest, isn't sustainable as an essay subject.
  • Writing a profile is a good way of thinking about your essay's "logos," "pathos," and "ethos." It also reveals the category of analysis you will be relying on. All of which makes your essay easier to write when the time comes to add some depth to your profile.
Note: Remember, we're starting to wind down the course. Work on using the terms of the first half of the course (setting, character, POV, etc.) in the articulation of your profile.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Mutated Weapons A little about the paper: The totalitarian government uses extreme force and new kinds of weapons that threaten the lives of anyone who steps out of line in Moxyland. New hybrid police dogs, Aitos, that attack on command more viciously than ever roam the streets instilling fear into the homeless and anyone who breaks the law. Bombs that contain not gun powder but a strain of a virus that without treatment are fatal are dropped on the masses who rebel against the government without hesitation. As awful as these sound, perhaps the most disturbing of all the weapons are what the people cherish most; their cellphones. People cannot function without them. They are connected to everything that is essential in daily life like money supply, access to their homes and identity. How is this a weapon you might ask? Not only does it deliver an electric shock as a punishment if the police think it’s necessary, but authorities can “disconnect” a person from their cell phone at any time. Cutting them off from society, from everything important and necessary to survive. This is the most disturbing because it is said to be a worse punishment than jail to the people living in this society. These people are so reliant on their cellphones that they would rather be dead than disconnected from them. The way that weapons have been modified is significant because it projects the possibility of a future that our own generation could be heading towards. Two main subjects this paper may cover include: a) How the weapons have been modified to suit the society that they control and the reason they have more power than any machine gun or traditional use of force ever could. b) Why it’s disturbing and what it implies for the future of our generation and its cell phone addiction

Thematic Element: Friendship (in Ready Player One)
The name of people would be about Friendship and the title of my paper would (something) be: How Friendship Should Be Online (may have to change it when I’m done my essay).
In Ready Player One, the citizens use OASIS as a way to conceal their true identity and showcase their false identity to other people. People want their peers to see them what they want them to see, regardless who they truly are. OASIS gives the opportunity for people to create their “perfect” version of themselves by using avatars. In the OASIS world, Parzival has shown trust in relationships with other gunters while searching for the Easter egg. At the end, trust is essential to unlock the third gate because it needed three crystal keys. The text has relevance for Friendship because Parzival, has shown trust with Aech, Art3mis and Shoto, even though when they never met in real life and trusting their avatars as who they really are in real life. I think true friendship is the key in searching for the easter egg and surprisingly Parzival achieved those relationships, especially when everyone refuse to reveal their true identity.
For my two main subjects I want to cover more on Parzival’s character development and how his relationships with other gunters help him winning the OASIS game because of his trust and willing to take risk to believe other people (regardless of other gunter’s avatar). Second subject would be the setting of the story and how it abuses living condition of citizens and lead to options that would ruin relationships with other people. By “ruining relationships”, I mean that citizens are living in a virtual utopian world (OASIS game) so they could hide their problems and be in relationships where it isn’t necessary to reveal their true selves. They can deceive other people by showcasing their ideal self. Some people who are using OASIS are abusing technology to make them “forget” the dystopian world they live in.

If You Give Up You Won’t Win About the paper… In Ready Player One Wade dedicates 5 years of his life to find just the first key in search for the Easter egg. After that along with help from his online friends he was able to discover the other 3 hidden keys. Many odds were against them to not continue but they just kept pushing through trying to find the keys. IOI offered Wade the opportunity to work for them but when he declines they threaten to hurt his friends and family. They end up killing everyone in the “stacks” even though everyone there was innocent. Wade doesn’t let that affect him and perseveres to try and find the keys and not allow IOI to take over the game. Main Topics… The amount of time Wade and his friends dedicate to finding the key when most people had already given up. With all odds against them they still perseveres to finish the hunt for The Easter egg.

An Abundance of Technology: This quality piece of writing will include the overwhelming dependency the characters in Ready Player One have on technology. Whether OASIS is used for recreational, educational, business purposes the characters all rely on a fantasy world to get through the day. Each day spent in a fictional utopia, is another day they lose sight of reality. Two possible topics: How technology has impacted, and influenced characters lives and how it will continue to affect these lives if technology proceeds to gain control where there is no longer a distinction between fictional and reality.

The control of Digital Culture
In JPod, digital culture and computer competency is widely sought after as one of the setting takes place in a video game company. Technology connects us, something as small a "Y2K" computer glitch brought people together in an office whose name starts with a "J". The setting is a cave-like haven even though it is referred to as a "basement office", far from contact with others as everyone in the novel is so wrapped up in technology. The main character is Ethan Jarlewski whose mother kills another character named Tim in an act to defend herself in the first chapter while he was talking on the phone. The accidental murder suggests foreshadow that technology will eventually kill us in a metaphorical sense as it can rob people their of attention span, daily social interactions, and culture.The game created by the Jpod staff represents a world of digital culture as one of the main idea is to have a consequence free environment where players can do anything without any real punishment. The new marketing director, Steven Lefkowitz, suggests a turtle to be put into "Board X". To justify this suggestion, Steven tries to persuade the Jpod staff that children will find comfort and share laughs and sorrows with a fictional character. Implying that children nowadays spend more time with games than actual friends.
Possible Topics: Digital Culture is a mere Utopian created by humans > suggesting that people find comfort and safety in technology.
Why we are so dependent on digital culture > possibly talk about humans natural dependency and how we are oblivious.

Title: Human Survival Based on Technology
Thematic Element: Technology
In Moxyland, there is a huge reliance on having a cell phone and a SIM card. These are essential in human survival as it contains the personal information for the citizens. Accessing cell phones allows people to have access to their money, jobs, and homes. It is used to survive in society. However, the government also uses it as a form of punishment. For example, if a person committed a crime they would be “disconnected.” This means that they would not have access to communication, transportation or from food and water. This reliance on cell phones helps the government maintain control over the population.
Two main subjects:
Human dependency on cell phones in real life compared to the actual survival based on cell phones in the book
How the government is using this form of technology to control the population

Friendship from Within In the novel Ready Player One, Wade’s relationships with the people closest to him often come in the form of friendship. Whether it’s with Art3mis, Aech, Shoto or Daito, Wade exhibits care towards these individuals and considers them as friends as well as allies. Especially when given the example of Aech, Wade had no idea who his best friend was considering Aech was a ‘she’ and not a ‘he’. Similarly, Art3mis had a physical feature she was not confident with but Wade did not consider it a big deal. Regardless, these examples prove how Wade formed friendships based on the inner personalities of these individuals and not their physical appearance. One topic my paper might cover is the importance of teamwork in friendship and how it ultimately lead Wade/Parzival to the discovery of the Easter Egg. Another topic that my paper might cover is the lack of prejudice in the friendships Wade had with his friends, especially Aech and Atr3mis, and how they formed bonds based on personality and not physical appearance.

The Player Vs The Corporation
In Ready Player One the novel portrays a theme of large corporations (e.g. IOI) versus the people (e.g. Parzival, Aech, art3mis, Shoto/Daito). Innovative Online Industries is a huge multinational corporation that aims to take over the OASIS with the intent of making profit. Nolan Sorrento, the head of IOI leads the company in their pursuit of the Easter egg with strategies that include violent acts, both in the OASIS and in the real world. With IOI being a huge internet service provider corporation, they have the means and the resources that can be advantageous in reaching their end goal. Wade and his fellow gunters are aware of the corporation’s intention and battle the IOI even though they don’t have luxury of resources and means of the IOI. Not wanting the OASIS to fall in the hands of the IOI. Parzival and fellow gunters continue their quest to find the Easter egg by their own means and eventually Parzival succeeds.
Two main subjects the paper may cover include: 1) Comparing and contrasting the intention of the corporation versus the people in the hunt for the Easter Egg 2) Comparing and contrasting the strategies and resources used by the corporation versus the people

Title: Relationships on the Road to Success
Thematic Element: Relationships
Book: Ready Player One
Plot In Ready Player One, Wade has the same goal as all of the other main characters, to be the first to find Halliday’s Egg and therefore receive Halliday’s full inheritance, which includes a fortune, and control of the game Oasis.
Setting However, this can only be done in the virtual world of Oasis where your identity is anonymous and Wade is known as Parzival. Wade spends more of his time in Oasis then he spends out of it, as he dreads his reality, as a lonely orphan.
Relationships On the contrary, he has friends in the Oasis and quickly rises to fame as he becomes the first gunter to find the first key which put him up at the top of the scoreboard for the quest to find the egg. Nevertheless, the quest gets far more difficult and that is where the significance of relationships arise.
Main Subjects:
1. Parzival could not have successfully completed the quest to find Halliday’s Egg without the contributed capital from his friends, Art3mis, Aech, and Shoto. 2. Parzival was eventually able to enhance his reality outside of Oasis by bringing the best part of his virtual life, Art3mis, into his real life as Wade.

Thematic Element: Gender In Ready Player One, gender is theme that is present throughout the entire novel. It is represented first through Art3mis as she is the only female character present throughout most of the novel. She is the only character that the reader can get a perspective on how a female character is in the OASIS. Most of the players portrayed in the novel are males, which may show a different how gender is viewed in the OASIS. This is not clearly understood until it is revealed that Aech is a girl in real life. Then it is shown the conflict of what a women may face in the OASIS, this gives the novel two different perspectives about how women are portrayed in the game. Furthermore, even after discovering that Aech is a girl, Parzival does not treat her/him any differently since he is demonstrating how Aech’s sexuality is not based on his gender. Overall, the book had only Art3mis to show how female gender is present in the novel, until Aech is revealed to be a female, which changes most of those views. So gender is present in the novel by comparing and contrasting Art3mis and Aech’s characters.

You have great ideas about the theme of technology in Ready Player 1! I think it is almost as if they are living in a bit of a fantasy when they are communicating through the OASIS since in real life, you have to face your problems in real time.

Title: Virtuality Brought to Life
Book: Ready Player 1
Thematic Element: Communication
Bio: My essay will discuss the virtual friendships Wade has with Art3mis, Aech and Shoto, how they change when they meet face to face and how they communicate overall. The benefit of being logged into the OASIS is that one does not have to show their true self. They have the ability to create a beautiful avatar who may look nothing like their actual self. One can also easily cover up any insecurities and forget about reality. In Wade's case, he is a lonely orphan who is having troubles finding a place to fit in. Do these kind of friendships have the ability to share a deep connection? Or was it only when the friends all came together in the end that they really bonded?
Topics: The dynamic between Wade and Aech when Wade finds out Aech is a girl. Wade surprisingly continues to treat Aech the same and accepts the fact that Aech has lied to him all of this time. Wade's openness with his friends even though they have never met in person. He takes a risk by trusting them with some of his dark secrets and relies on them for advice. Wade's relationship with Haliday.

Sure, but where and when will you talk about the book?
You want to be careful that you are referencing how the book works to represent or comment upon these things.
Also, watch those big words like "society" and "generation" and "addiction" and "future."
I'm not sure what this essay profile is telling me. Right now, it looks a bit like ranty crazy person yelling about weapons and cellphones.

Guess what? I have no idea what you mean by "friendship." That's a massive term; like "furniture." There's lots of different kinds of friendship (NO CAPS!!), which kind are you referring to here and WHY does Ready Player One represent that kind of friendship; or HOW does it represent that friendship? There's some nuggets here, but again, this profile reads a bit like someone telling me they're going to "change." OK, how? why? for what reason? What are you changing? You have a bunch of massive concepts in here such as "citizens," "relationships." "ideal self." You better pare things down or you're going to be all over the place. What kind of friendship? How does RPO define friendship for us? So what?

OK, you are reviewing the plot of the novel. No need, I've read it.
You might be looking for this word: perseverance.
Right now, this profile looks like someone is logging in their daily routine like this: "I get out of bed everyday, it's hard; but I do it. Yeah. I do it. Again. Get out of bed. It's hard though. Real hard. Then I get out of it though. Always. Again. Everyday. Hard. I get out of bed!

Ummm... who has the abundance exactly? And which technology are we talking about here? A pencil, a cup, a wheel is technology. And, if you are planning on explaining how EVERY CHARACTER in RPO depends on technology, you are in for a world of pain. Narrow the focus, name the technology, NAME ONE CHARACTER, how does the SPECIFIC PIECE OF TECH INFLUENCE HIS/HER SPECIFIC LIFE AND WHAT DOES THAT TELL US EXACTLY? See, now it might be a "quality piece of writing," but what you have above is like that Facebook profile where the guy writes: "I'm super good looking" and posts a picture of himself flexing his burly muscles while winking, all of it captioned with "looking for love...?"

Title: Everyday Life in Digital Culture
In Ready Player One there are generations who grown up in dystopian digital culture. They are using technology as way to communicate, socialize, educate, entertain and escape from word problems. Main characters Wade and others are spending their time in the OASIS consider it as a virtual reality home. The internet has been incorporate in to everyday life practice and become essential in today’s developed society. Possible topic: How the internet transformed culture and how digital culture impacts our self identity, education practices, communication and social life.

Title: Utopia in a Dystopian Society
Bio: The paper I am planning to write is answering essay question one using Ready Player One and how Wade’s escapes his real life is in a dystopian society to one where he is in a online virtual utopian society. The OASIS is a utopian society that Wade goes to to escape from the problems of real life. Like many others in the world of 2045 people escape the world of poverty and danger to enter the highly desirable almost perfect world in OASIS. Ready Player One text portrays and comments on the thematic elements of Dystopia and Utopia. The book shows how significant Dystopia is presented through the text. We can see how even the idyll world of OASIS still conflicts with the real worlds dystopia as the IOI attempting to murder Wade in real life.
Two main subjects 1. How the two different societies (Earth, OASIS) impact Wade’s life and relationships with others. 2. The connection and contrasts between Earth’s Dystopian society and the OASIS’s utopian society.

Generation X
Topic: Cultural reference
There is a natural tendency for humans to look forward rather than look back and appreciate the wonders we have created. Often times, yesterday is regarded as bad and today is better when in reality, today is just as bad as yesterday, the only difference is the type of crisis each time has. In Ready Player One, Wade has immersed himself essentially in the world of his hero, James Halliday. Based on the way and tone he narrates the story, Wade seems to praise and show interest in the 1980's. Wade's interest in 1980's games, movies, and television shows grew as he persevered in solving the puzzle in the OASIS. In addition, even though a lot of the context in the book refer to the cultural reference of the 1980's crisis of the possibility of nuclear war, there is not any hint of fear, but only a joyful era. Wade's interest in the 1980's is possibly a result of the restricted freedom he enjoys due to the economic meltdown of his generation, as compared to the 1980's when people were lively and the economy was good, at least according to Wade.

Title: Knowledge is Power
Bio: In Ready Player One, knowledge of 80’s culture is proven to be invaluable in the search for Halliday’s Easter egg. My essay will explore how Ready Player One portrays the study of 80’s culture as a means of education. Like every gunter, Wade is a student of all things 1980s and he uses his education to pass ‘the test’ of finding the Easter egg.
Subjects covered: How knowledge can be a catalyst for opportunity. By furthering his learning, Parzival is able to discover new things, move forward in the hunt and gain the ultimate reward, which opens a floodgate of opportunities to better his life as Wade, in the real world. The importance of the audience understanding references to 80’s movies, video games and consoles, books, and music. How intertextuality allows readers to connect to the excitement of moving forward both in the hunt and the book. Readers can also recognize how their personal knowledge of 80’s culture is just one example of how education connects them to the world and people around them.

The part where it says "quality piece of writing" was intended to be mocking the whole Facebook profile type of guy you mentioned, that exaggerates the truth. I haven't quite figured out what I want to write about yet hence the very generalized essay profile but your comments are helping me narrow down a topic that may interest me, thank you!!

No worries, I read you loud and clear on the "quality" bit; it's actually important to visualize it as being "quality." That said, you also don't want it to be ironic... see, we're all about the learning here.
Move to specifics is alls ima sayin'... SPECIFICS!

Abundance is actually a pretty interesting topic. Think about what you mean by that term, or how the text might be used to support a unique definition of abundance. That might be interesting... whatevs.

Title: Dis(connected) escapism
About: Wade never really fit in the "real world" - in highschool he wasn't popular and he jumped at the opportunity to escape real-world school for virtual school. Oasis is wade's metaphorical oasis in the baren, harsh, reality that he lives in. In the context of a society falling apart, the Oasis represents a universal appeal to everyone: purpose and identity (or lack thereof).
Topics covered: The easter egg - it was what justified the seemingly odd obsession Wade had with 80s culture and virtual reality. Being a 'gunter' was part of who Wade identified as, he wasn't Wade in Oasis, he was Parzival, the famous easter-egg hunter. The hunt for the easter egg wasn't just for the money - it really seemed to be part of Wade's identity. When Art3mis and Sorrento threatened to beat him to the easter egg, it shook Wade to his core - to the point where he 'snapped out' of the funk he was in. The Easter egg in Ready Player One represents a sort of 'salvation', a purpose behind the anti-social character that is Wade. Ready Player One paints escapism with a purpose - a stark contrast from reality.

Title: What is Life Without Technology?
In my paper I’m going to discuss the relevance of technology in Ready Player One (or Moxyland, still undecided). I want to emphasize on how Ready Player One/Moxyland represents technology. Yes, I know “technology” is a huge word, so I’m going to look at the subsets that help define the theme of technology (one of many) in R.P.O/Moxyland and look at what they signal. When looking at the subsets in the book, I want to look at one specific device, whether it’s a cellphone, the Internet, or a video game, or how it affects one person. Two possible topics: How Ready Player One/Moxyland represents ______________ (ex. Cell phones > communication, information source, security, connectivity) and inhibits our communication.

It’s A Man’s World
Ready player one portrays women as being unknowledgeable and negative influences toward success. The female roles in this novel were very minimal and the included female characters were not shown as being strong individual characters.
Art3mis seemed to be an independent character but as the story progressed, her independence depleted. She became just the love interest in the story that just provided drama that helped the narrative move forward. Instead of just being a competitive friend, she had to be a crush of Wade.
Aech did have a strong character that had her own intelligence that didn’t rely on others but there was a catch. It wasn’t okay for her to be heterosexual, she had to be homosexual as if people with male traits will succeed against challenges.

Corporatocracy in Moxyland
I intend to write about how Moxyland presents a society whose reins have been commandeered by various corporations. Even going as far as developing technologies to turn people into walking advertisements and assisting in the segregation of different classes of people.

Cartoons for Digital Social Connection
The use of cartoon characters for online profiles to connect the employees of in the jPod office, removes an emotional connections to coworkers however through the use of this online social interaction the people working at jPod have a greater in depth knowledge of who each other is because their true characters are able to come out through the online interactions they have with each other. The qualities brought to the jPodsters by the use of this programming for social interaction allows for the ability of their characters to develop as well as to be explained right away via the online character profiles.
The main topics are the use of profiles in the jPod work environment and how this affects the social interactions that occur between the characters at jPod. The significance of this is how the characters in jPod develop with one another or how the characters stay the same throughout the novel.

Title: Wired Worthless Phone Users
Book: Moxyland by Lauren Beukes
Objective: To discuss a social practice in “Moxyland”, that is significant to how the reader would approach the text. Talk about how it influences how we read it and be able to make a suggestion about the significance to interpret the novel.
Social Practice: Self-absorbed human beings who rely so much on cell phones, specifically needing the best device that makes their life easier.
Bio: Moxyland is a very complex and confusing novel. It is difficult to follow at the beginning because of the different type of language the characters talk in. It is challenging because of the multiple shifts of point of views, jumping from one character to another. Despite this difficulty of understanding the text, it addresses an alarming social practice the current population lives about. Truly, it is humans’ reliance on cellular phones that shape them to be completely useless and self-absorbed beings. The recurring social practice of relying too much on technology, spark readers’ interest in our four narrators, particularly Toby who constantly seeks the use of a cell phone. The readers start to become frustrated reading because of how self centered and boastful the characters are in the novel, Toby, in particular. He only ever thinks about getting laid, getting money from Lerato, and get a hold on a phone to contact for help and entertainment. Truly, he becomes so annoying that readers begin to question who they are in this story. Evidently, a person reading this novel is intently criticized, judged by the narrator through mirroring the current practices human beings indulge in today. Indeed, it is Toby’s infuriating character that influences the readers to pause and reflect on what kind of life they are living in right now. Readers are ought to see what life would be like in the future with our reliance and wired minds on cellular devices.

1) Title: The Realities of Modern-Virtual Day Life
2) The Realities of Modern-Virtual Day Life essay will cover many different aspects of digital culture in the 2010 era such as modern day technologies like cellphones, social media applications, and being in-tune with virtual life. It will also cover how it has affected human society so much in a way that is almost beginning to have a negative affect on society. For example, society is starting to become dependent on these technologies, and for some, have trouble going through daily life when their cellphone runs out of batteries. This is very present in Moxyland as Kendra has allowed herself to become a walking billboard for a soft drink called Ghost in exchange for enhanced strength and mental health. And now she will have an addiction to Ghost for as long as she is alive.
Two Topics:
1) How relevant the technology used in Moxyland is compared to our current generations as technology is slowly becoming more of an integrated part of our lives.
2) How technology is being pushed on us as consumers compared to how the government in Moxyland pushes everyone to live futuristically with technology.

1) Title: The Realities of Modern-Virtual Day Life
2) The Realities of Modern-Virtual Day Life essay will cover many different aspects of digital culture in the 2010 era such as modern day technologies like cellphones, social media applications, and being in-tune with virtual life. It will also cover how it has affected human society so much in a way that is almost beginning to have a negative affect on society. For example, society is starting to become dependent on these technologies, and for some, have trouble going through daily life when their cellphone runs out of batteries. This is very present in Moxyland as Kendra has allowed herself to become a walking billboard for a soft drink called Ghost in exchange for enhanced strength and mental health. And now she will have an addiction to Ghost for as long as she is alive.
Two Topics:
1) How relevant the technology used in Moxyland is compared to our current generations as technology is slowly becoming more of an integrated part of our lives.
2) How technology is being pushed on us as consumers compared to how the government in Moxyland pushes everyone to live futuristically with technology.

Control Freaks To live in Moxyland you have to give up control. Everything depends on being connected. No independence or choice on the matter, everything works via the SIM card of your phone. Disobeying the law leads to electric shock administered from said phone, leaving really no opportunity for rebellion without disconnection first. Lerato also displays the need for control in her life over her partners, her work and her life in general. When Lerato makes her move up in the company and manipulates it so she won’t have to work with her previous partner she is controlling the outcome of her future in a cold calculating way. Her detachment from emotions makes this control easier to maintain.
This paper will dive into the topic of control within Moxyland ~ How Lerato needs control over her entire life, how living within Moxyland demands you give control to those operating your phones. How this affects the law and enforcement as well as the increased appeal of rebellion.

Title: The Not-So-Betrayed Friendship of Parzival and Aech
Bio
Wade lives in life, his real life, in the OASIS. Everything he sees, does, feels, and is all real to this protagonist. Arguably, Wade’s alternate ego Parzival has a life of his own there too. A major component in Parzival’s life, which assisted him in finding the Easter egg, was his online friendship with fellow Gunter Aech. , Aech is a manly man (or is he?), and has been friends with Parzival for several years prior to their commencement of the quest for The Egg. For a great lapse of time, he remained one of the top Gunters in The OASIS, which was until the IOI took over. Parzival and Aech shared a lot of fond memories together such as the numerous quests they helped each other to solve, as well as the intimate secrets that were told in secrecy. HOWEVER, this friendship comes to a temporary roadblock when he finds out Aech’s true identity...
Two Main Subjects 1) How does the gender of Aech affect her friendship with Wade (how or how not)? 2) How does Aech relate so much with Parzival through the OASIS?

I'm also thinking of discussing about the specifics of control in Moxyland, but I am always at a loss on what certain "thing" that is that controls the characters in the novel. Discussing Lerato's control over what she wants to live by is a great choice of topic. I'm interested in hearing more about how you would make it significant and how it influences readers.

Title: A changing priority; how the quest for the golden egg became a battle of good versus evil
Thematic element :teamwork
Main Points: How the quest morphed from an individualistic pursuit of wealth and/or fame to a unified fight against the evil corporation of IOS. Initially, the character's have little interest and desire to share hints about the quest and help each other out. However, with the IOS having a powerful group of people supporting them behind the scenes, it becomes clear that teamwork is the only way to compete against them. IOS is clearly representative of evil, in what would become a battle of good versus evil. This is exemplified in their willingness to kill innocent people and do whatever is necessary to win. Reacting to this, the leading competitors, who previously do little to help each other, unite to fight their common enemy. These characters are representative of the "good" side because their intentions are noble and honest, in that they intend to use the money to help others.
Another thing to talk about is how characters are portrayed and how some characters fulfill pre-existing beliefs we have them. For example, the Japanese character, Shoto, sacrifices the life of his avatar to help his friends get closer to completing the quest. The way he did is reminiscent of a kamikaze pilot choosing a target and sacrificing their life to help the cause. The character of Shoto is representative of a more collectivist culture, whereby the group is more important than the individual-(which is more what western culture values). The fact that he was willing to give his avatar's life demonstrate this belief, but also demonstrates the power of teamwork in this fight of good versus evil.

Hey, I feel your subjects are a bit too big. I feel human dependency can be a topic for QUESTION#2. Why? It's a cultural practice I think. Is it not? I mean a lot of people struggle not to get disconnected. And even if they do get disconnected, they often don't run the risk of making their punishment of being disconnected permanent. Just a thought!

Hey, how are relationships significant? I felt like you summarized again for your topic. I feel relationships(investing time into other people in order to get sometime back) is too big of a topic. Maybe you can talk about the importance of trust the characters have with one another because of a big foe. When there's a bigger foe that no one cna take, are alliances formed. Think of alien invasions when the world makes peace with itself in order to defeat the aliens. Also, hold it cowboy. How do you really know Wade's reality is enhanced by meeting Art3mis? Sure they kiss, but it ends there. You're assuming it's enhanced. Maybe talk about the importance of people over wealth? I mean he did want to risk a lot of money for her. Again, these are just some thoughts!

Hey, I like this. But only when you compare and contrast of two girls who deceive people through their appearance. Discuss outcomes, and the importance of: appearances aren't everything. UNLESS, you want to talk about gender. Then discuss the importance of the girls overcoming obstacles. E.g. Art3mis discovers the temple for the copper key before Wade. Otherwise, these are just thoughts!

Digital culture is a gateway to another life. The characters of Ready Player One take advantage of their new life by altering their appearance to fulfill their flaws, and express their true personalities without the feeling of criticism from other players. The text supports it by giving an orphan the power to mute, make friends with people who are not what they seem in real life and a chance to escape the harsh reality the orphan is in. The two elements that might cover the paper are: Identity and… nah. Just identity. Examples from Wade’s life will be used as evidence to the online world being a gateway to another life.

I like where this going, but you'll need to refine this to one character--perhaps just deal with Art3mis. You can explore the contradictions inherent in the story as you suggest, but try to get at what this means for our understanding of the novel. What does the female character's representation say about the nature of intelligence for women? Why is it represented that way? What does the book give us in the way of examples or stereotypes that might be imbedded in the reading or reception of the female character?
I would watch talking about the homosexuality only insofar as it's a separate essay. You'll need another essay on that one and one that lays out a little more clearly what you see as the stereotypes--a good example of an essay that requires strict definitions. There's a lot going on in that last sentence, particularly the assumptions it makes about the nature of homosexuality. You'll need to clear that up before you can really get at how the book represents homosexuality and why that representation might be important.

This is quite scattered -- a lot of ideas flying off in all directions. Try to narrow the focus and locate yourself within the book. What examples does the book present to help you explain or define digital culture. As it is, the commentary above isn't really about anything; it's a bunch of scattered thoughts that don't have any connection in things. Look at the last question as an example (there's no question mark, but it's a question): what does "human's natural dependency" even mean? And what exactly are we "oblivious" too? And then finally, how are these two incoherent terms related to each other?
#agreed Everything Brandon writes is true.

I noted this in class, but this is far too big conceptually. You're trying to cover too much ground without enough focus on what it is you are trying to show the reader. Narrow things down to one or two things... not personality and physical appearance, but one or the other.
I would think about doing only 1) or 2); not both.

Again, 1. or 2.; not both. And make sure you define your terms. What do you mean by "relationship"? How would you characterize that? What do you mean by "society"? If you can narrow down the focus a bit, you might be able to work it through with some more specifics.

Watch the formal sentence level work in here--there are a lot of errors in diction and phrasing, particularly around prepositional phrases. Make sure your ideas connect naturally, not through the use of prepositional connectors such as "indeed" and "truly," which deceive.
You might also think about what you mean by "social practice." If you just mean how people use cell phones, then just state that, getting rid of the social practice thing. Remember what we have been discussing in class: work from small THINGS into big concepts, not the other way around. So start with cell phones and show how they work in the novel and then show the reader how that is a unique kind of social practice.
Finally, make sure there is a coherence to your ideas. The essay should "flow" because it has a unified approach or reading of the subject under discussion. If you have too many disparate subjects, like dealing with too many different aspects of one character (Toby) that are not connected clearly enough to the social practice under discussion. IN other words, how does "Toby's infuriating character" "influence" readers "to pause and reflect on the life they are living right now"? Where are you getting support for that claim? It seems to suggest that you can read the reader's minds--that you can assume the reactions of other people; that's a tall order.
Get yourself into specific instances in the text where Toby does something that will illustrate your claims. If you cannot find such examples, then you probably don't have something there.

item.title: JPod Casting Module
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Instructions: (Due for the April 1st class–no joke!) You made it, the last module! Yay you!

This module asks you to cast a TV version of JPod and give your reasons for casting it with the actors you’ve chosen. You should watch an episode or two of the CBC series to get a feel for what you might be casting. No need to follow their representational choices, but it’ll give you a guideline. You can choose any reasonably famous movie or TV star to fill out the cast, and you must cast and justify no fewer than three characters in the novel.

Task: After first naming the character in JPod, suggest a movie or TV or stage actor you would cast in the role. Make sure you justify your decision for each casting choice by

  1. justifying the qualities the actor might be able to portray and how these mesh with the representative qualities for the character (i.e.: he’s tall, does good geek, and is good looking)
  2. suggesting how the actor will cohere with the other actors you have cast (i.e.: she and XXX look like the kind of couple I imagine XXX and XXX to be in the book)
  3. ordering the three (or more) casting decisions in terms of billing and justifying their placement. So, if you cast Tom Cruise, you better be prepared to give him top billing, which might take Benedict Cumberbatch off the list because he would also deserve top billing; how will you justify hiring them both? (writing that you have an unlimited budget is not allowed!)

Outcomes

  • Thinking about how you would cast characters should get you thinking in more narrow terms about how characters interplay and interweave in a text. How there are certain qualities and characteristics that are replicated and not.
  • Be daring with your casting–is there a case where you could cast against sex for example–casting a male actor in a female role. What concepts or characteristics might this reveal in the character that you think are present in the book? Imagine Barbara in The Bug as played by Kanye, for instance. How would this allow us to better reveal Barbara’s predominant dispositions?
  • Narrow your focus and think seriously about what qualities you want to emphasize in your casting–doing so often reveals areas of thematic interest in the text.
  • Are you casting based qualities (similar / dissimilar) or theme (this is a novel about technology, all the actors need to be young!)? Think about the ramifications of these decisions and the way you are contextualizing things.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
After watching one of the episodes of J pod from the CBC series, I thought they did a decent job of casting characters. The choices in actors/actresses were pretty well done but I felt like Kaitlin and John Doe could've been casted differently. Anyway, here are my choices:
John Doe: Paul Rudd He is perfect for this part because Paul Rudd is really good at doing nerdy roles and being an odd character. Id imagine John Doe is pretty weird due to his unusual upbringing and the fact that he chose his name to be something so generic kind of implies he is boring. Paul Rudd would go well with the others chosen because he is good at playing a laid back part and he shows how bizarre he can be in his role in “Our Idiot Brother”. He would receive top billing because he is the most popular actor, even though he isn’t the main character he would be good for playing John Doe. Ethan: Chris Pratt Chris Pratt has an excellent sense of humor, is known to play sarcastic roles in TV series such as Parks and Rec and was in Guardians of the Galaxy which shows he is into sci-fi/ fantasy genres that reflect videogames. He and Aubrey Plaza are a couple in Parks and Rec and they are both hilarious and a good on screen pair so that is why I chose her to be Kaitlin. He is pretty famous as well but wouldn’t receive top pay. Kaitlin: Aubrey Plaza Perfect for playing Kaitlin who is kind of bossy, sarcastic and also intelligent. Like I mentioned above her and Chris Pratt are an excellent couple and they both would suit the relationship that exists between Kaitlin and Ethan in the novel. Aubrey Plaza is good at portraying a strong female lead in the workplace like Kaitlin does in J pod. She would go well with the other actors because of her sense of humor and quick wit. She is known well enough to get paid the same as Chris Pratt and not just for her popularity but for her talent as an actress. Bree: Brenda Song She is good at playing both silly and serious characters. She is also really pretty but smart so she reflects Bree's character in the novel well. I think she would make a good nerd. As far as compensation goes, since her “Suite life of Zack and Cody” days she fell off the map so really she should be grateful she is being considered and take what is offered.

JPod was an interesting novel to say the least due to the unique characters and strange plot twists. Nonetheless, the number of random, outrageous details ultimately made the novel quite funny in my opinion. Having said that, if I were to cast actors to play the characters in JPod, I would choose the following: 1. Ethan’s mom, Carol Jarlewski, Jamie Lee Curtis She could portray the character of a pot-growing, psychotic, murderous mom in my opinion because of her appearance and fun smile, in addition to her ability to play comedic roles. 2. Ethan’s boss, Steve Lefkowitz, Ed Helms He could portray the character of a slightly ‘odd’ middle-aged heroin addict going through a mid-life crisis really well in my opinion because he’s got an average looking appearance and would seem like a good fit for a man obsessing over a much older lady. 3. Kam Fong, Chinese mobster, Ken Jeong He could portray the perfect combination of a person who is dangerous yet extremely weird (a gangster who ballroom dances??), much like his character in the Hangover series. In general, I believe all these characters will get along quite well due to their outgoing personalities and comedic abilities. Out of the three actors I chose to cast, I would say their given order is pretty accurate in terms of billing. Although all three are well-heard of, I think since Jamie Lee Curtis has more experience in the acting industry, she would get a slightly higher amount of pay. Other than that, I don’t think these actors are among the big-shot Hollywood celebrities that need a hefty compensation, that too for supporting roles.

Characters Ethan’s Dad: Steve Carrel I can imagine Ethan’s dad being Steve Carrel because Steve Carrel has just the right amount of weirdness and randomness to play Ethan’s Dad. Steve Carrel is the only actor that I can imagine that would be funny and also so passionate about something like ballroom dancing. Also his age range would be good for a role of a father. Kaitlin: Emma Stone Emma Stone generally plays comedic characters in most movies she is in, which is why I can see her being Kaitlin. Because her type of comedy would be perfect for doing that scene where Kaitlin trolls with everyone with her subway post and her stalker neighbour. And in the CBC series she was a blonde character and we have seen Emma Stone Blond as well from Spiderman when she portrayed Gwen. Furthermore, Emma stone is also in her twenties so she could fit Kaitlin’s description pretty well. Ethan’s Boss (Steve): Chris Pine Chris Pine played the boss’s son in Horrible Bosses 2, which is why I can see him playing the Ethan’s Boss. In the movie he played a character that would do anything for money even rob his own dad, similarly Steve was willing to whatever he could just to interact with his own children, even if it meant that it was bad for his own company or business and that all his employees were against the idea. All the characters I have chosen tend to do similar comedies in movies, so I don’t think they will have a lot of conflict with each other. Also they would most likely not have any scenes with each other since they mostly interact with Ethan so even if there was conflict between them, it would not matter. Furthermore two of them are playing supporting roles so it should not cost them much for their roles especially for Steve as he is missing for most of the middle of the book. This way they can spend a bit more money to cast Emma Stone as Kaitlin.

Actors I would cast for jPod:
Kate Winslet as Kaitlin When I watch Kaitlin interacting with other jPodders, she can be very bossy, hard-working and ambitious (unlike the others who slacks and fool around at work). I see Kate Winslet playing this character because I always seen her in serious roles. For example, in her role in Mildred Pierce, she plays a hard working mother and has goals as her priority. So this role reminded me of Kaitlin wanting to leave jPod and move where she could work with more ambitious people (episode 1). Also I chose Kate Winslet as Kaitlin because they have the blonde hair and similar age (I checked the actress who played Kaitlin). I think Kate deserve top billing because she is famous for laying many successful movies.
Ian Somerhalder as Cancer Cowboy I chose Ian (the guy who played Damon Salvatore in the Vampire Diaries, which is a TV show) because his character is laid-back, more in the first season. The first episode of jPod, Cowboy described that he started smoking because it was cool, even his parents warned him not to smoke. So this tells me that Cowboy is doing whatever pleases him. He is not really productive during work (recording with camera, chilling with other jpodders). This unmotivated character reminds me of Damon because he loves to chill and also murderous. The fact that Cowboy has an obsession with death, Ian who played a killer would be a plus.
Michael Cera as John Doe When I think of Michael Cera, I always picture him playing the same type of character: awkward, shy and nerdy. Take for example, superbad, arrested development and Scott Pilgrim. Since John Doe is different because he grew up in a lesbian commune, never tried soda, no television and at the same time, tries to act “normal”, I think Cera could play John Doe. As for appearance, Cera does have a nerdy look to him and so does the actor who played John Doe. I placed Cera last because his character is not the most important character and also Cera is not as famous as the two above.

Jpod was an enjoyable novel to read but it was interesting to see how the characters were portrayed on tv. The show on CBC was quite humorous and light-hearted to watch. The characters in the television series were acted out very well but there are a few other actors who would perfectly play the role of Ethan, Carol and Cancer Cowboy.
Ethan Jarlewski: Jonah Hill
I think Jonah would play the part of Ethan very well. I can just see the character of Carol calling Jonah to bail her out of a problem which leads to a humorous outcome. In my opinion, he also looks like he would be good at portraying a computer programmer or someone working for a video game company. In most of Jonah’s movies, he depicts an outgoing personality who gets along with everyone. This is similar to Ethan’s character in JPod. These indications suggest he would fit the perfect profile as Ethan Jarlewski.
Carol Jarlewski: Katey Sagal
Katey would be a great fit to play Carol. Katey also plays the mother of the protagonist on Sons of Anarchy and her character strongly resembles Carol Jarlewski. In the show, she is at times involved in illegal activities for the motorcycle club. Carol runs a marijuana grow-op in JPod. They both have accidently killed someone and both are portrayed as a loving mother towards their children. Katey is also a very attractive female and she could play the character Steve falls in love with.
Cancer Cowboy: Bobby Cannavale
I can see Bobby portray the character of Cancer Cowboy. He has been in many tv shows and movies portraying a comedic personality. In JPod, Cancer Cowboy is a humorous character who is also addicted to sex. Bobby’s character in Boardwalk Empire depicts a hot headed gangster who enjoys auto-erotic asphyxiation in the form applied by a belt to his neck. He enjoys this form of pleasure rather than having sex with women. In Boardwalk Empire, it is quite humorous seeing a women try to strangle him in this fashion. His character was very enjoyable to watch and he would be a great fit to portray Cancer Cowboy.

Ethan: John Krasinski I think John Krasinski would be a great choice for the role of Ethan. Ethan’s is a character who is both smart and uses sarcasm for most of his humour. He reminds me of John Krasinski when he played Jim in The Office as a young sales rep who was very sarcastic and funny in pranking his fellow coworker Dwight Schrute. He also has a caring soft side to him just like Ethan as we see he helps others such as his mom. John would be the lowest of the three on the billing list of the actors behind Jennifer Lawrence.
Kaitlin: Jennifer Lawrnce Jennifer Lawrence would be a great fit for the role of Kaitlin. As we see with Hunger Games Jennifer can play the hard working role, stubborn character and I think she would be a great fit with John as they would match well together and eventually show interest each other and date as seen later in Jpod. The only part she would have to change her usual acting is with Kaitlin’s perkiness personality at times but I’m sure Jennifer would be able to adjust to this role. Jennifer would be the second highest on the billing list behind Sandra Bullock.
Carol: Sandra Bullock I think would be an excellent fit for the role of Ethan’s mother Carol. She can play the sexy, sneaky badass mom kind of role. Her role in The Blind Side is the type of character I see her playing in this show in how she can be uptight and bossy. She fits well with John playing Ethan I believe and I could see them working well together in the close caring mother and son relationship. Sandra would be the highest on the billing list and realistically be very tough to get her on this type of show.

Andrew Garfield as Ethan Jarlewski
I think Andrew could portray Ethan quite well in the sense that Ethan is intelligent and creative. Andrew Garfield has played various roles, the most popular being Spider-Man in the latest film. He has a witty personality and often brings out his sarcastic, goofy side which I think fits perfectly for the character of Ethan.
Meryl Streep as Ethan's mother
Ethan's mother has a very distinct personality, and vibe to her that is given off in the book. From the grow op in her basement, to experimenting with women she is kind of unpredictable. She is badass yet very infatuating and Meryl can and has played so many different roles that she could easily adapt into the very different phases Ethan's mother goes through naturally.
Amanda Seyfried as Ellen Kovacs (Ethan's dad's young girlfriend)
I feel she would play the role of the young, ditzy girlfriend quite well. The blonde, blue eyed beauty working on a set fits perfectly. Having a strange, inappropriate? relationship with Ethan's much older father is something I can picture Amanda doing. There's no knowing the true intentions behind the relationship itself but one can have all types of assumptions. The part in the novel where she got high from "The Dude" plays into the role of her being a young, irresponsible woman.
As for the billing, Meryl Streep would get top billing as she is the most established of the bunch as an actress. Then Andrew Garfield, being the main character and all. And lastly, Amanda Seyfried as she has a smaller role and isn't as popular or well known as the other two.

After watching the first two episodes of JPOD, I must say it was very annoying to watch and the acting seemed very fake to me. Enough of my negativity, if I were to cast actors and actresses to play characters in JPOD I would choose the following;
1. Ethan’s Dad: Jim Carrey Ethan’s father is portrayed as this immature, young at heart grandpa age man. He does not take responsibility for his actions and allows his son, Ethan to take the blame for his mistakes. Ethan’s father that does not act as a father figure to Ethan, instead a buddy who has no self control. The actor that I can guarantee 100% would nail this role would be Jim Carrey. Jim is known for his flexible facial expressions and the spunky attitude that brings life to the roles he plays. Jim, would be able to carry the role of Ethan’s father with his various animated voices and extravert personality that allows him to act immature and 16 year old stuck in a 60 year old body.
2. Ethan’s Boss, Steve Lefkowitz: Vince Voughan Steve Lefkowitz is a middle age man who is going through a life crisis where he just got out of an ugly divorce and has zero custody of his son from his failed marriage. Steve is willing to sacrifice his own company in order to have some form of interaction with his son. His character is self centred, exciting, positive and a pushy boss. Vince Voughan would be perfect for the role where he is seen as intimidating with his towering height and on top of that having a sardonic sense of humor. Vince has the personality of being optimistic, enthusiastic, creative being a visionary. His character traits fit the role as Steve pushing the team to “think outside of the box.”
3. Kaitlin: Anna Kendrick Kaitlin is the newest member of JPOD, who is very goal driven, bossy, and is intelligent. Kaitlin is a suck up to the Steve and wants to succeed. Anna Kendrick would do a phenomenal job portraying Kaitlin. She would do well because of her outgoing, strong personality, and sarcastic sense of humor. She would do well sucking up to her boss Steve aka Vince Voughan who would take little notice of her.

After watching a few episodes of the JPod series on CBC I thought they did a pretty good job of casting the characters. However, I personally would’ve changed the roles of, John Doe, Carol Ethan’s mom, Bree Jyang, and Cancer Cowboy.
Ian Somerhalder as Cancer Cowboy Lets just start off by stating the facts; Ian Somerhalder is one sexy looking guy. Ian plays the role of Damon Salvatore in Vampire Diaries. His character is just a ruthless, “I don’t give a damn about anything or anyone” type of guy. Ian would be able to bring the smart alec, witty, rebellious, traits for the role but also make it clear that he’s very justified in what he’s doing.
Adam Brody as John Doe After watching the first episode of the JPod series I thought Adam Brody would be the perfect fit. In Brody’s previous projects (starred in the hit series “The O.C”) he played Seth Cohen. He plays the unpopular, nerdy, non-athletic type of guy, who’s afraid to be around girls let alone talk to them. I’ve seen a few movies/series that Brody has done, he can play that nerdy, shy, smart, character and portray John Doe perfectly.
Leighton Meester as Bree Jyang Leighton Meester used to play “Blair” in the series Gossip Girl. She was the popular girl, known as “queen B”. Just as Bree, she has severe control issues, defiantly a perfectionist. She was raised in a family that had extremely high standards for her. Bree is emotions capture expert meaning, she takes “perfect moments and imprisons them on her hard drive for ever and ever”. Meester plays roles that are confident and sexy, in pervious roles she intimidates men, I think she would be able to portray the role in a very confident, snarky, witty way. She would find her inner Blair to play the role of Bree.
Laura Dern as Ethan’s Mom Carol I chose Laura Dern to play the role of Ethan’s mom because to me she has that hippie, happy-go-lucky type of personality. Plus she reminded me of the actress who played Ethan’s mom in the TV series. I’ve researched some of the work Dern has done and she’s able to play the funny, silly, but serious and heart-aching roles so I think for the type of story line she can both be serious and humorous.
As far as billing I would probably list them as, Ian Somerhalder, Adam Brody, Leighton Meester, then Laura Dern as last just because I think there are a lot of “TV moms” you can chose from that could easily play the role.

Ethan: Andy Samberg Andy would be a great cast for Ethan because he has experience being a sarcastic geek. Andy’s role in Brooklyn 99, he was a really good cop that was also a rebel against authority. The reflex Ethan’s personality at work because he is always trying to do anything but work. Andy’s appearance also reflects what I imagined Ethan to looks like. He isn’t some super model and he has some uniqueness to his appearance.
Kaitlin: Hayden Panettiere Hayden would play Kaitlin very well because she can play a stuck of female that keeps to herself. Hayden can play a very self-supporting character just like Kaitlin and I think she can also be sarcastic. Andy and Hayden would also look good together as a couple and Hayden seems like the character that needs to be chased to get. Hayden has the personality and appearance that I expected Kaitlin to have because she holds herself like she is better than others.
Ethan’s Mom: Patricia Clarkson Patricia would be an excellent cast for Ethan’s mom because she is very quirky. Patricia’s role in Easy A is very similar to what I think Ethan’s mom is like because she is very free minded and loving. Patricia’s appearance is not what I expected from Ethan’s mom but her personality makes up for that.
These actors will work together very well because they all have very sarcastic personalities. I honestly have no idea how to pay these guys cause I have no interest in the movie business. I don’t know who would get paid what because I don’t know who is a better actor.

Jim Jarlewski: For the character of Ethan’s father Jim Jarlewski I would cast Will Ferrell. Will Ferrell is hilarious and odd which portrays the Jim Jarlewski character. I believe Will Ferrell could be that father who is immature but who could also show a little bit of emotion in a humorous way.
Cancer Cowboy: For the character of Cancer Cowboy I would cast Rob Corddry. Rob Corddry played “Lou” in the movie Hot tub time machine where he played a suicidal party animal who was laid back and a big fan of women. Just like Cowboy who's character who's a confident, womanizing, laid back guy who eventually becomes obsessed with death. I also think Rob Corddry would be awesome because of his physical appearance isn't what you would expect for Cowboy’s character.
Kaitlin Joyce: For Kaitlins character I would cast Cameron Diaz. Cameron Diaz is usually playing a perky and charming blonde in her movie roles and would great for the character of Kaitlin. Kaitlin plays a smart blonde girl who is a bit of a keener and tries to further her career. I think Cameron Diaz could play that role perfectly but also had some flavour to the character, if that makes sense.

Steven (The Boss) played by Will Ferrell Steven comes across as a goofy and sarcastic person who is always making weird faces and sometime even weird hand gestures. Will Ferrell would be perfect for this part because he plays a goofy character in all of his movies and could easily pass for a weird boss. Both Steven and Will Ferrell often act like they are a bit full of themselves.
Ethan played by Darin Brooks Ethan reminds me of Darin Brooks from the tv show, Blue Mountain State. He is a laid back guys who seems to go with the flow. I also noticed a lot of similar facial expressions between Ethan and Darin Brooks, such as their smug grin, or the face they make when they are embarrassed.
Cancer Cowboy played by Sean William Scott Sean William Scott, more commonly known as Stifler from the American Pie movies, would be the best fit to play the part of Cancer Cowboy. Cancer Cowboy acts overconfident and cocky with a sense of humour and perhaps a sex addiction. In American Pie, Sean William Scott had all of those qualities, and the two find themselves similarly up to no good.
Bree played by Julie Bowen Julie Bowen plays Claire Dunphy on the tv show Modern Family. She resembles Bree because they are both high maintenance people who strive for perfectionism, however they both have a wild side which one may not expect after a first impression.
I believe these actors would have excellent chemistry together because they would all greatly reenact the elements of humour in this show, which there is a lot of. Even though these four actors have their own levels of fame, they are all extremely talented and would be right for their respective roles in Jpod. They would combine for a manageable budget that would likely receive critical acclaim from viewers.

Ethan’s Dad, Jim Jarlewski played by Dustin Hoffman To me, Dustin Hoffman gives off a very youthful spirit in many characters, especially as Bernie Focker in Meet the Fockers, which is why I would cast him as Jim. Both Jim and Dustin are feisty gentlemen, who seem less technologically inclined and more interested in having an affair with a much younger woman and watching Law & Order, if there is enough time in the day. Dusty can really turn on the flare and fun in characters, while portraying a serious tone too.
I think Dustin would fit perfectly with Jane Fonda as Jim and Carol. The two are equally respected in film for their energy, versatility and raw talent. Dustin and Jane are also the same age so they seem like a fitting couple to be married and play parents of adult children.
Ethan’s Mom, Carol Jarlewski played by Jane Fonda Jane Fonda is such a lively woman with a lot of attitude and strong values. Jane could easily switch between the multiple facets of the loving mother, wife, ‘gardener’, and accidental murderer. I think she could bring out the dimension of Carol that is determined to do her own ‘thing’, especially when Carol runs off to the lesbian commune.
Aside from her perfect dynamic with Dusty, I think Jane would bring a hilariously sarcastic dimension to her opening scene with Ethan when the two are driving around to find a grave for Tim the biker.
John Doe played by Nicholas Hoult Nicholas Hoult’s tall, lankier figure strikes me as geeky which seems like it might suit the character of John Doe. Nicholas is a young man in film who has a story behind the spotlight, just like John. He seems like the introverted and knowledgable type who takes a genuine interest in technology and creating.

Ethan's mom Carol Jarlewski - Lena Headey.
Lena Headey's performances in Dredd and Game of Thrones show that she is well rounded in being able to play as a loving mother - as-well as a killer. Lena Headey's character Cersei Lannister in Game of Thrones was more cynical than Carol, but her ability to combine those elements is why I chose her.
- In terms of Billing, Lena would probably cost the most.
John Doe - Micheal Cera Micheal Cera played the perfect 'typical freshman' in Superbad. Despite his ability to play the 'typical' he has a quirky, and odd nature to his acting aswell. In both Superbad and Youth in revolt, he played as a socially awkward teenager. John Doe had a crazy upbringing from a mother who bragged about not shaving her arm-pits, and micheal cera captures that "I'm trying to be normal but in reality..." aura that John Doe had while I was reading the book.
-Micheal cera is 2nd in terms of billing. I'm not sure on his popularity compared to Lena Headey, but I think Lena is the better actor anyways. Lena is more diverse in her acting ability, Micheal Cera is not.
-I think the akwardness of Micheal Cera - and the 60s-70s lighthearted innuendos of Mike Myers would be entertaining to watch, because these two actors are so vastly different in the characters they can accurately portray.
Cancer Cowboy - Mike Myers (As Austin Powers) The Cancer Cowboy in the CBC version looks like a normal guy besides him walking around shirtless/opened button shirt. Mike Myer's character Austin Powers constantly made sexual innuendos throughout the film - similar to Cancer Cowboy. However I think Cancer Cowboy's actor has too serious of a mood when it comes to his personality, Mike Myers would be able to actually play his character while being funny at the same time.
- However for billing, Mike Myers would be at the bottom.

JPOD cast
Ethan Jarlewski :Jesse Eisenberg
He would be a good fit for a number of reasons. First of all, he has played in other roles where his parents were dysfunctional and his family life is a burden on him. Also, he has played roles where he is socially akyward and in a geek type role. Lastly, he would be much younger that those playing his parents, which helps to illustrate why his parents are so out of touch with him and his life.
Carol Jarlewski : Cathy Bates
Cathy Bates would be have top billing. Her past performance in the movie 'Misery', whereby she played a sadistic, tough as nails woman make her an obvious choice for the role of Carol. Also, her versatility in the many roles she has done make her an smart choice as well.
Jim Jarlewski: Bryan Cranston Bryan Cranston is a good enough actor that he could actually play someone who has no acting ability, as was the case for Jim's character in the book. He would have second billing. Also, his role in Breaking Bad in a way parallels the role of Jim in the book, whereby both roles involved trying to be something other than themselves (i.e the chemistry teacher turned drug lord and the wannabe actor constantly acting out different scenarios-with little success of course).Also, Bryan Cranston's ability to act out being intoxicated (while representing the character of Walter White) would do well to represent Jim's heavy drinking in the latter half of the book.
How would they interact? I believe they would have a mutual respect for each other's acting ability, and also respect the billing decisions expressed-since it goes by seniority essentially, giving most credit and pay to the age/experience of each actor/actress.

Anne Hathaway as Kaitlin Kaitlin has a very controlling personality. She is a great leader and motivates the JPod crew meet their goals. Anne Hathaway appears in many movies in this type of role including Get Smart, Love & Other Drugs, and Interstellar. I feel that Anne deserves to be paid well because she is so well known but not as well known as Adam Stadler.
Chris Pine as Ethan One of the main reasons I chose Chris to play the part of Ethan in JPod is because him and Anne Hathaway work so well together. They are the kind of couple that I envisioned in JPod. He also has a relaxed personality and would be able to withstand a crazy family and a difficult work life. He would be able to overcome burying the biker as well as both his parents having an affair. Recently, Chris has had leads in several action packed movies including Star Trek which is also filled with many technological advances and innovations. He would certainly have the knowledge to work out the flaws of a gaming system.
Adam Sandler as Ethan's dad Adam would play the role of Ethan's dad perfectly since he has a lot of experience and has been a fatherly figure in several movies. He is very funny and most of the movies he is in are comedies. Ethan's dad is a very quirky character and very spontaneous so Adam definitely fits the part. Although he is very well know, he will not be the top paid actor in this film because he is not the main character. Since he is constantly in the spot light in films every year, he would be the second top paid actor.
Tina Fey as Bree Tina would be a great actor to play the part of Bree. Her character in Baby Mamma had uptight and bossy attitude. She also had a determined attitude in with Bree also shows. As well as their rule following personalities, both Fey and Bree can also come across as very adventurous and mischievous. Fey shows off this side in movies such as date night.
Although these four actors are all well known, not all of them have an equal amount of screen time or lines. Chris does not have as much experience and wisdom in the acting world as Adam does and thus, Adam will be paid the most out of the four. Anne Hathaway will be paid the third top and Tina will be the least paid out of the four since her character does not change throughout the movie and she has less of an entertaining role.
